
JOURNAL
TO
STELLA
 
LETTER
1
.
 
<EOS>
CHESTER
,
Sept.
2
,
1710
.
  
<EOS>
Joe
will
give
you
an
account
of
me
till
I
got
into
the
boat
;
after
which
the
rogues
made
a
new
bargain
,
and
forced
me
to
give
them
two
crowns
,
and
talked
as
if
we
should
not
be
able
to
overtake
any
ship
:
 
but
in
half
an
hour
we
got
to
the
yacht
;
for
the
ships
lay
by
[
to
]
wait
for
my
Lord
Lieutenant
's
steward
.
 
<EOS>
We
made
our
voyage
in
fifteen
hours
just
.
 
<EOS>
Last
night
I
came
to
this
town
,
and
shall
leave
it
,
I
believe
,
on
Monday
.
 
<EOS>
The
first
man
I
met
in
Chester
was
Dr.
Raymond
.
 
<EOS>
He
and
Mrs.
Raymond
were
here
about
levying
a
fine
,
in
order
to
have
power
to
sell
their
estate
.
 
<EOS>
They
have
found
everything
answer
very
well
.
 
<EOS>
They
both
desire
to
present
their
humble
services
to
you
:
they
do
not
think
of
Ireland
till
next
year
.
 
<EOS>
I
got
a
fall
off
my
horse
,
riding
here
from
Parkgate
,
but
no
hurt
;
the
horse
understanding
falls
very
well
,
and
lying
quietly
till
I
get
up
.
 
<EOS>
My
duty
to
the
Bishop
of
Clogher
.
<EOS>
I
saw
him
returning
from
Dunleary
;
but
he
saw
not
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
take
it
ill
<EOS>
he
was
not
at
Convocation
,
and
that
I
have
not
his
name
to
my
powers
.
 
<EOS>
I
beg
you
will
hold
your
resolution
of
going
to
Trim
,
and
riding
there
as
much
as
you
can
.
 
<EOS>
Let
the
Bishop
of
Clogher
remind
the
Bishop
of
Killala
to
send
me
a
letter
,
with
one
enclosed
to
the
Bishop
of
Lichfield
.
 
<EOS>
Let
all
who
write
to
me
,
enclose
to
Richard
Steele
,
Esq
.
,
at
his
office
at
the
Cockpit
,
near
Whitehall
.
 
<EOS>
But
not
MD
;
I
will
pay
for
their
letters
at
St.
James
's
Coffee-
house
,
that
I
may
have
them
the
sooner
.
 
<EOS>
My
Lord
Mountjoy
is
now
in
the
humour
that
we
should
begin
our
journey
this
afternoon
;
so
that
I
have
stole
here
again
to
finish
this
letter
,
which
must
be
short
or
long
accordingly
.
 
<EOS>
I
write
this
post
to
Mrs.
Wesley
,
and
will
tell
her
,
that
I
have
taken
care
<EOS>
she
may
have
her
bill
of
one
hundred
and
fifteen
pounds
whenever
she
pleases
to
send
for
it
;
and
in
that
case
I
desire
you
will
send
it
<EOS>
her
enclosed
and
sealed
,
and
have
it
ready
<EOS>
so
,
in
case
she
should
send
for
it
:
 
<EOS>
otherwise
keep
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
say
no
more
till
I
hear
whether
I
go
to
-
day
or
no
:
 
<EOS>
if
I
do
,
the
letter
is
almost
at
an
end
.
 
<EOS>
My
cozen
Abigail
is
grown
prodigiously
old
.
 
<EOS>
God
Almighty
bless
poo
dee
richar
MD
;
and
,
for
God
's
sake
,
be
merry
,
and
get
oo
health
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
perfectly
resolved
to
return
as
soon
as
I
have
done
my
commission
,
whether
it
succeeds
or
no
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
went
to
England
with
so
little
desire
in
my
life
.
 
<EOS>
If
Mrs.
Curry
makes
any
difficulty
about
the
lodgings
,
I
will
quit
them
and
pay
her
from
July
9
last
,
and
Mrs.
Brent
must
write
to
Parvisol
with
orders
accordingly
.
 
<EOS>
The
post
is
come
from
London
,
and
just
going
out
;
so
I
have
only
time
to
pray
God
to
bless
poor
richr
MD
FW
FW
MD
MD
ME
ME
ME
.
   
<EOS>
LETTER
2
.
 
<EOS>
LONDON
,
Sept.
9
,
1710
.
  
<EOS>
Got
here
last
Thursday
,
after
five
days
'
travelling
,
weary
the
first
,
almost
dead
the
second
,
tolerable
the
third
,
and
well
enough
the
rest
;
and
am
now
glad
of
the
fatigue
,
which
has
served
for
exercise
;
and
I
am
at
present
well
enough
.
 
<EOS>
The
Whigs
were
ravished
to
see
me
,
and
would
lay
hold
on
me
as
a
twig
while
they
are
drowning
,
and
the
great
men
making
me
their
clumsy
apologies
,
etc
.
 
<EOS>
But
my
Lord
Treasurer
received
me
with
a
great
deal
of
coldness
,
which
has
enraged
me
so
,
I
am
almost
vowing
revenge
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
yet
gone
half
my
circle
;
but
I
find
all
my
acquaintance
just
as
I
left
them
.
 
<EOS>
I
hear
my
Lady
Giffard
is
much
at
Court
,
and
Lady
Wharton
was
ridiculing
it
t'other
day
;
so
I
have
lost
a
friend
there
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
yet
seen
her
,
nor
intend
it
;
but
I
will
contrive
to
see
Stella
's
mother
some
other
way
.
 
<EOS>
I
writ
to
the
Bishop
of
Clogher
from
Chester
;
and
I
now
write
to
the
Archbishop
of
Dublin
.
 
<EOS>
Everything
is
turning
upside
down
;
every
Whig
in
great
office
will
,
to
a
man
,
be
infallibly
put
out
;
and
we
shall
have
such
a
winter
as
hath
not
been
seen
in
England
.
 
<EOS>
Everybody
asks
me
,
how
I
came
to
be
so
long
in
Ireland
,
as
naturally
as
if
here
were
my
being
;
but
no
soul
offers
to
make
it
so
:
 
and
I
protest
I
shall
return
to
Dublin
,
and
the
Canal
at
Laracor
,
with
more
satisfaction
than
ever
I
did
in
my
life
.
 
<EOS>
The
Tatler
expects
every
day
to
be
turned
out
of
his
employment
;
and
the
Duke
of
Ormond
,
they
say
,
will
be
Lieutenant
of
Ireland
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
you
are
now
peaceably
in
Presto
's
lodgings
;
but
I
resolve
to
turn
you
out
by
Christmas
;
in
which
time
I
shall
either
do
my
business
,
or
find
it
not
to
be
done
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
be
at
Trim
by
the
time
this
letter
comes
to
you
;
and
ride
little
Johnson
,
who
must
needs
be
now
in
good
case
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
begun
this
letter
unusually
,
on
the
post
-
night
,
and
have
already
written
to
the
Archbishop
;
and
can
not
lengthen
this
.
 
<EOS>
Henceforth
I
will
write
something
every
day
to
MD
,
and
make
it
a
sort
of
journal
;
and
when
it
is
full
,
I
will
send
it
,
whether
MD
writes
or
no
;
and
so
that
will
be
pretty
:
 
and
I
shall
always
be
in
conversation
with
MD
,
and
MD
with
Presto
.
<EOS>
Pray
make
Parvisol
pay
you
the
ten
pounds
immediately
;
so
I
ordered
him
.
 
<EOS>
They
tell
me
I
am
grown
fatter
,
and
look
better
;
and
,
on
Monday
,
Jervas
is
to
retouch
my
picture
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
I
saw
Jack
Temple
and
his
wife
pass
by
me
to
-
day
in
their
coach
;
but
I
took
no
notice
of
them
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
glad
I
have
wholly
shaken
off
that
family
.
 
<EOS>
Tell
the
Provost
,
I
have
obeyed
his
commands
to
the
Duke
of
Ormond
;
or
let
it
alone
,
if
you
please
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
Jemmy
Leigh
just
now
at
the
Coffee
-
house
,
who
asked
after
you
with
great
kindness
:
 
<EOS>
he
talks
of
going
in
a
fortnight
to
Ireland
.
 
<EOS>
My
service
to
the
Dean
,
and
Mrs.
Walls
,
and
her
Archdeacon
.
 
<EOS>
Will
Frankland
's
wife
is
near
bringing
to
-
bed
,
and
I
have
promised
to
christen
the
child
.
 
<EOS>
I
fancy
<EOS>
you
had
my
Chester
letter
the
Tuesday
after
I
writ
.
 
<EOS>
I
presented
Dr.
Raymond
to
Lord
Wharton
at
Chester
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
let
me
know
when
Joe
gets
his
money
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
near
ten
,
and
I
hate
to
send
by
the
bellman
.
 
<EOS>
MD
shall
have
a
longer
letter
in
a
week
,
but
I
send
this
only
to
tell
I
am
safe
in
London
;
and
so
farewell
,
etc
.
   
<EOS>
LETTER
3
.
 
<EOS>
LONDON
,
Sept.
9
,
1710
.
  
<EOS>
After
seeing
the
Duke
of
Ormond
,
dining
with
Dr.
Cockburn
,
passing
some
part
of
the
afternoon
with
Sir
Matthew
Dudley
and
Will
Frankland
,
the
rest
at
St.
 
James
's
Coffee
-
house
,
I
came
home
,
and
writ
to
the
Archbishop
of
Dublin
and
MD
,
and
am
going
to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
I
forgot
to
tell
you
,
that
I
begged
Will
Frankland
to
stand
Manley
's
friend
with
his
father
in
this
shaking
season
for
places
.
 
<EOS>
He
told
me
,
his
father
was
in
danger
to
be
out
;
that
several
were
now
soliciting
for
Manley
's
place
;
that
he
was
accused
of
opening
letters
;
that
Sir
Thomas
Frankland
would
sacrifice
everything
to
save
himself
;
and
in
that
,
I
fear
,
Manley
is
undone
,
etc
.
  
<EOS>
l0
.
 
<EOS>
To
-
day
I
dined
with
Lord
Mountjoy
at
Kensington
;
saw
my
mistress
,
Ophy
Butler
's
wife
,
who
is
grown
a
little
charmless
.
 
<EOS>
I
sat
till
ten
in
the
evening
with
Addison
and
Steele
:
 
<EOS>
Steele
will
certainly
lose
his
Gazetteer
's
place
,
all
the
world
detesting
his
engaging
in
parties
.
 
<EOS>
At
ten
I
went
to
the
Coffee
-
house
,
hoping
to
find
Lord
Radnor
,
whom
I
had
not
seen
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
there
;
and
for
an
hour
and
a
half
we
talked
treason
heartily
against
the
Whigs
,
their
baseness
and
ingratitude
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
am
come
home
,
rolling
resentments
in
my
mind
,
and
framing
schemes
of
revenge
:
 
full
of
which
<EOS>
(
having
written
down
some
hints
)
I
go
to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
MD
dined
at
home
,
because
it
is
Sunday
;
and
there
was
the
little
half
-
pint
of
wine
:
 
for
God
's
sake
,
be
good
girls
,
and
all
will
be
well
.
 
<EOS>
Ben
Tooke
was
with
me
this
morning
.
  
<EOS>
11
.
 
<EOS>
Seven
,
morning
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
rising
to
go
to
Jervas
to
finish
my
picture
,
and
'
tis
shaving
-
day
,
so
good
-
morrow
MD
;
but
do
n't
keep
me
now
,
for
I
ca
n't
stay
;
and
pray
dine
with
the
Dean
,
but
do
n't
lose
your
money
.
 
<EOS>
I
long
to
hear
from
you
,
etc
.
 
<EOS>
Ten
at
night
.
 
<EOS>
I
sat
four
hours
this
morning
to
Jervas
,
who
has
given
my
picture
quite
another
turn
,
and
now
approves
it
entirely
;
but
we
must
have
the
approbation
of
the
town
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
were
rich
enough
,
I
would
get
a
copy
of
it
,
and
bring
it
over
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Addison
and
I
dined
together
at
his
lodgings
,
and
I
sat
with
him
part
of
this
evening
;
and
I
am
now
come
home
to
write
an
hour
.
 
<EOS>
Patrick
observes
,
that
the
rabble
here
are
much
more
inquisitive
in
politics
than
in
Ireland
.
 
<EOS>
Every
day
we
expect
changes
,
and
the
Parliament
to
be
dissolved
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Wharton
expects
every
day
to
be
out
:
 
he
is
working
like
a
horse
for
elections
;
and
,
in
short
,
I
never
saw
so
great
<EOS>
a
ferment
among
all
sorts
of
people
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
a
miserable
letter
from
Joe
last
Saturday
,
telling
me
Mr.
Pratt
refuses
payment
of
his
money
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
told
it
Mr.
Addison
,
and
will
to
Lord
Wharton
;
but
I
fear
with
no
success
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
I
will
do
all
I
can
.
  
<EOS>
12
.
 
<EOS>
To
-
day
I
presented
Mr.
Ford
to
the
Duke
of
Ormond
;
and
paid
my
first
visit
to
Lord
President
,
with
whom
I
had
much
discourse
;
but
put
him
always
off
when
he
began
to
talk
of
Lord
Wharton
in
relation
to
me
,
till
he
urged
it
:
 
<EOS>
then
I
said
,
he
knew
I
never
expected
anything
from
Lord
Wharton
,
and
that
Lord
Wharton
knew
that
I
understood
it
so
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
that
he
had
written
twice
to
Lord
Wharton
about
me
,
who
both
times
said
nothing
at
all
to
that
part
of
his
letter
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
advised
not
to
meddle
in
the
affair
of
the
First
-
Fruits
,
till
this
hurry
is
a
little
over
,
which
still
depends
,
and
we
are
all
in
the
dark
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
President
told
me
he
expects
every
day
to
be
out
,
and
has
done
so
these
two
months
.
 
<EOS>
I
protest
,
upon
my
life
,
I
am
heartily
weary
of
this
town
,
and
wish
I
had
never
stirred
.
  
<EOS>
13
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
this
morning
to
the
city
,
to
see
Mr.
Stratford
the
Hamburg
merchant
,
my
old
schoolfellow
;
but
calling
at
Bull
's
on
Ludgate
Hill
,
he
forced
me
to
his
house
at
Hampstead
to
dinner
among
a
great
deal
of
ill
company
;
among
the
rest
<EOS>
Mr.
Hoadley
,
the
Whig
clergyman
,
so
famous
for
acting
the
contrary
part
to
Sacheverell
:
  
<EOS>
but
tomorrow
I
design
again
to
see
Stratford
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
glad
,
however
,
to
be
at
Hampstead
,
where
I
saw
Lady
Lucy
and
Moll
Stanhope
.
 
<EOS>
I
hear
very
unfortunate
news
of
Mrs.
Long
;
she
and
her
comrade
have
broke
up
house
,
and
she
is
broke
for
good
and
all
,
and
is
gone
to
the
country
:
 
<EOS>
I
should
be
extremely
sorry
if
this
be
true
.
  
<EOS>
14
.
 
<EOS>
To
-
day
,
I
saw
Patty
Rolt
,
who
heard
I
was
in
town
;
and
I
dined
with
Stratford
at
a
merchant
's
in
the
city
,
where
I
drank
the
first
Tokay
wine
I
ever
saw
;
and
it
is
admirable
,
yet
not
to
the
degree
I
expected
.
 
<EOS>
Stratford
is
worth
a
plum
,
and
is
now
lending
the
Government
forty
thousand
pounds
;
yet
we
were
educated
together
at
the
same
school
and
university
.
 
<EOS>
We
hear
the
Chancellor
is
to
be
suddenly
out
,
and
Sir
Simon
Harcourt
to
succeed
him
:
 
<EOS>
I
am
come
early
home
,
not
caring
for
the
Coffee
-
house
.
  
<EOS>
15
.
 
<EOS>
To
-
day
Mr.
Addison
,
Colonel
Freind
,
and
I
,
went
to
see
the
million
lottery
drawn
at
Guildhall
.
 
<EOS>
The
jackanapes
of
bluecoat
boys
gave
themselves
such
airs
in
pulling
out
the
tickets
,
and
showed
white
hands
open
to
the
company
,
to
let
us
see
there
was
no
cheat
.
 
<EOS>
We
dined
at
a
country
-
house
near
Chelsea
,
where
Mr.
Addison
often
retires
;
and
to
-
night
,
at
the
Coffee
-
house
,
we
hear
Sir
Simon
Harcourt
is
made
Lord
Keeper
;
so
that
now
we
expect
every
moment
the
Parliament
will
be
dissolved
;
but
I
forgot
that
this
letter
will
not
go
in
three
or
four
days
,
and
that
my
news
will
be
stale
,
which
I
should
therefore
put
in
the
last
paragraph
.
 
<EOS>
Shall
I
send
this
letter
before
I
hear
from
MD
,
or
shall
I
keep
it
to
lengthen
?
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
yet
seen
Stella
's
mother
,
because
I
will
not
see
Lady
Giffard
;
but
I
will
contrive
to
go
there
when
Lady
Giffard
is
abroad
.
 
<EOS>
I
forgot
to
mark
my
two
former
letters
;
but
I
remember
this
is
Number
3
,
and
I
have
not
yet
had
Number
1
from
MD
;
but
I
shall
by
Monday
,
which
I
reckon
will
be
just
a
fortnight
after
you
had
my
first
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
resolved
to
bring
over
a
great
deal
of
china
.
 
<EOS>
I
loved
it
mightily
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
What
shall
I
bring
?
  
<EOS>
16
.
 
<EOS>
Morning
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
John
Holland
,
Comptroller
of
the
Household
,
has
sent
to
desire
my
acquaintance
:
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
mind
to
refuse
him
,
because
he
is
a
Whig
,
and
will
,
I
suppose
,
be
out
among
the
rest
;
but
he
is
a
man
of
worth
and
learning
.
 
<EOS>
Tell
me
,
do
you
like
this
journal
way
of
writing
?
 
<EOS>
Is
it
not
tedious
and
dull
?
  
<EOS>
Night
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
with
a
cousin
,
a
printer
,
where
Patty
Rolt
lodges
,
and
then
came
home
,
after
a
visit
or
two
;
and
it
has
been
a
very
insipid
day
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Long
's
misfortune
is
confirmed
to
me
;
bailiffs
were
in
her
house
;
she
retired
to
private
lodgings
;
thence
to
the
country
,
nobody
knows
where
:
 
her
friends
leave
letters
at
some
inn
,
and
they
are
carried
to
her
;
and
she
writes
answers
without
dating
them
from
any
place
.
 
<EOS>
I
swear
,
it
grieves
me
to
the
soul
.
  
<EOS>
17
.
 
<EOS>
To
-
day
I
dined
six
miles
out
of
town
,
with
Will
Pate
,
the
learned
woollen
-
draper
;
Mr.
Stratford
went
with
me
;
six
miles
here
is
nothing
:
 
<EOS>
we
left
Pate
after
sunset
,
and
were
here
before
it
was
dark
.
 
<EOS>
This
letter
shall
go
on
Tuesday
,
whether
I
hear
from
MD
or
no
.
 
<EOS>
My
health
continues
pretty
well
;
pray
God
Stella
may
give
me
a
good
account
of
hers
!
<EOS>
and
I
hope
you
are
now
at
Trim
,
or
soon
designing
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
disappointed
to
-
night
:
 
<EOS>
the
fellow
gave
me
a
letter
,
and
I
hoped
to
see
little
MD
's
hand
;
and
it
was
only
to
invite
me
to
a
venison
pasty
to
-
day
:
 
<EOS>
so
I
lost
my
pasty
into
the
bargain
.
 
<EOS>
Pox
on
these
declining
courtiers
!
 
<EOS>
Here
is
Mr.
Brydges
,
the
Paymaster
-
General
,
desiring
my
acquaintance
;
but
I
hear
the
Queen
sent
Lord
Shrewsbury
to
assure
him
he
may
keep
his
place
;
and
he
promises
me
great

in
the
affair
of
the
First
-
Fruits
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
I
must
turn
over
this
leaf
to
-
night
,
though
the
side
would
hold
another
line
;
but
pray
consider
this
is
a
whole
sheet
;
it
holds
a
plaguy
deal
,
and
you
must
be
content
to
be
weary
;
but
I
'll
do
so
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Simon
Harcourt
is
made
Attorney
-
General
,
and
not
Lord
Keeper
.
  
<EOS>
18
.
 
<EOS>
To
-
day
I
dined
with
Mr.
Stratford
at
Mr.
Addison
's
retirement
near
Chelsea
;
then
came
to

;
got

,
and

,
about
the

of
style
and
writing
,
etc
.
,
and
,
having
not
heard
from
you
,
am
resolved
this
letter
shall
go
to
-
night
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Wharton
was
sent
for
to
town
in
mighty

,
by
the
Duke
of
Devonshire
:
 
<EOS>
they
have
some
project
in
hand
;
but
it
will
not
do
,
for
every
hour
we
expect
a
thorough

,
and
that
the
Parliament
will
be
dissolved
.
 
<EOS>
When
you
see
Joe
,
tell
him
Lord
Wharton
is
too

to
mind
any
of
his
affairs
;
but
I
will
get
what

I

from
Mr.
Addison
,
and
will

to

day
to
Mr.
Pratt
;
and
bid
Joe
not
to

,
for
I
am
confident
he
will
get
the
money
under

;
but
he
must
have

.
  
<EOS>
19
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
scribbling
this

,
and
I
believe
shall
hardly
fill
this
side
to
-
day
,
but
send
it
as
it
is
;
and
it
is
good
enough
for
naughty
girls
that
wo
n't
write
to
a

,
and
to

like

.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
to
have
sent
this
to

,
but
was

by

,
and
could
not
;
and
,
to

,
I
had
a
little

to
expect

post
more
for
a
letter
from
MD
.
<EOS>
Yesterday
at
noon
died
the
Earl
of
Anglesea
,
the
great
support
of
the
Tories
;
so
that
employment
of
Vice
-
Treasurer
of
Ireland
is
again
vacant
.
 
<EOS>
We
were
to
have
been
great
friends
,
and
I
could
hardly
have
a
loss
that
could
grieve
me
more
.
 
<EOS>
The
Bishop
of
Durham
died
the
same
day
.
 
<EOS>
The
Duke
of
Ormond
's
daughter
was
to
visit
me
to
-
day
at
a
third
place
by
way
of
advance
,
and
I
am
to
return
it
to
-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
had
a
letter
from
Lady
Berkeley
,
begging
me
for
charity
to
come
to
Berkeley
Castle
,
for
company
to
my
lord
,
who
has
been
ill
of
a
dropsy
;
but
I
can
not
go
,
and
must
send
my
excuse
to
-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
told
that
in
a
few
hours
there
will
be
more

.
  
<EOS>
20
.
 
<EOS>
To
-
day
I
returned
my
visits
to
the
Duke
's
daughters
;
the
insolent
drabs
came
up
to
my
very
mouth
to
salute
me
.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
heard
the
report
confirmed
of
removals
;
my
Lord
President
Somers
;
the
Duke
of
Devonshire
,
Lord
Steward
;
and
Mr.
Boyle
,
Secretary
of
State
,
are
all
turned
out
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
remember
such
bold
steps
taken
by
a
Court
:
 
<EOS>
I
am
almost
shocked
at
it
,
though
I
did
not
care
if
they
were
all
hanged
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
astonished
why
the
Parliament
is
not
yet
dissolved
,
and
why
they
keep
a
matter
of
that
importance
to
the
last
.
 
<EOS>
We
shall
have
a
strange
winter
here
,
between
the
struggles
of
a
cunning
provoked
discarded
party
,
and
the
triumphs
of
one
in
power
;
of
both
which
I
shall
be
an
indifferent
spectator
,
and
return
very
peaceably
to
Ireland
,
when
I
have
done
my
part
in
the
affair
I
am
entrusted
with
,
whether
it
succeeds
or
no
.
 
<EOS>
To
-
morrow
<EOS>
I
change
my
lodgings
in
Pall
Mall
for
one
in
Bury
Street
,
where
I
suppose
I
shall
continue
while
I
stay
in
London
.
 
<EOS>
If
anything
happens
tomorrow
,
I
will
add
it
.
 
<EOS>
Robin
's
Coffee
-
house
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
great
news
just
now
from
Spain
;
Madrid
taken
,
and
Pampeluna
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
here
ever

.
  
<EOS>
21
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
just

your

,
which
I
will
not

;
God

all

.
 
<EOS>
I
find

have
not

second
:
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
This

:
 
great

from

;
<EOS>
King

and

,

.
 
<EOS>
Farewell
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
from
St.
James
's

-

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
Pray

.
 
<EOS>
I
do

Trim
.
 
<EOS>
Parvisol
tells

.
 
<EOS>
Sell

,

pox
?
 
<EOS>
Pray

.
 
<EOS>
What
?
<EOS>
sell

Stella

,

?
<EOS>
It
is
hers
,

:
 
<EOS>
pray

know

by

.
 
<EOS>
Let

grey
,

.
   
<EOS>
LETTER
4
.
 
<EOS>
LONDON
,
Sept.
21
,
1710
.
  
<EOS>
Here
must
I
begin
another
letter
,
on
a
whole

,
for
fear
saucy
little
MD
should
be
angry
,
and
think
MUCH
that
the
paper
is
too
LITTLE
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
your
letter
this
night
,
as
told
you
just
and
no
more
in
my
last
;
for
this
must
be
taken
up
in
answering
yours
,
saucebox
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
I
told

where
I
dined
to
-
day
;
and
to
-
morrow
I
go
out
of
town
for
two
days
to

with
the
same
company
on
Sunday
;
Molesworth
the
Florence
Envoy
,
Stratford
,
and
some
others
.
 
<EOS>
I
heard
to
-
day
that
a
gentlewoman
from
Lady
Giffard
's
house
had
been
at
the
Coffee
-
house
to
inquire

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
Stella
's
mother
,
I
suppose
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
send
her
a
penny
-

letter
to
-

,
and
contrive
to
see
her
without
hazarding
seeing
Lady
Giffard
,
which
I
will
not
do
until
she

.
  
<EOS>
22
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
at
Hampstead
with
Lady
Lucy
,
etc
.
,
and
when
I
got
home
found
a

from
Joe
,
with

to
Lord
Wharton
,
which
I
will
send
to
his
Excellency
,
and
second
it
as
well
as
I
can
;
but
to
talk
of
getting
the
Queen
's
order
is
a
jest
.
 
<EOS>
Things
are
in
such
a
combustion
here
,
that
I
am
advised
not
to
meddle
yet
in
the
affair
I
am
upon
,
which
concerns
the
clergy
of
a
whole
kingdom
;
and
does
he
think
anybody
will
trouble
the
Queen
about
Joe
?
 
<EOS>
We
shall
<EOS>
,
I
hope
,
get
a
recommendation
from
the
Lord
Lieutenant
to
the
trustees
for
the
linen
business
,
and
I
hope
that
will
do
;
and
<EOS>
so
I
will
write
to
him
in
a
few
days
,
and
he
must
have

.
 
<EOS>
This
is
an
answer
to
part

your
letter
as
well
as

.
 
<EOS>
I
lied
;
it
is
to
-
morrow
<EOS>
I
go
to
the
country
,
and
I
wo
n't
answer
a
bit
more
of
your
letter
yet
.
  
<EOS>
23
.
 
<EOS>
Here
is
such
a
stir
and
bustle
with
this
little
MD
of
ours
;
I
must
be
writing
every
night
;
I
ca
n't
go
to
bed
without
a
word
to
them
;
I
ca
n't
put
out
my
candle
till
I
have
bid
them
good
-
night
:
 
<EOS>
O
Lord
,
O
Lord
!
 
<EOS>
Well
,
I
dined
the
first
time
to
-
day
,
with
Will
Frankland
and
his
fortune
:
 
<EOS>
she
is
not
very
handsome
.
 
<EOS>
Did
I
not
say
I
would
go
out
of
town
to
-
day
?
 
<EOS>
I
hate
lying
abroad
and
clutter
;
I
go
tomorrow
in
Frankland
's
chariot
,
and
come
back
at
night
.
<EOS>
Lady
Berkeley
has
invited
me
to
Berkeley
Castle
,
and
Lady
Betty
Germaine
to
Drayton
in
Northamptonshire
;
and
I
'll
go
to
neither
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
alone
,
I
must
finish
my
pamphlet
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
sent
a
long
letter
to
Bickerstaff
:
let
the
Bishop
of
Clogher
smoke
it
if
he
can
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
I
'll
write
to
the
Bishop
of
Killala
;
but
you
might
have
told
him
how
sudden
and
unexpected
my
journey
was
though
.
 
<EOS>
Deuce
take
Lady
S
#
#
#
#
;
and
if
I
know
D####y
,
he
is
a
rawboned
-
faced
fellow
,
not
handsome
,
nor
visibly
so
young
as
you
say
:
 
<EOS>
she
sacrifices
two
thousand
pounds
a
year
,
and
keeps
only
six
hundred
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
you
have
had
all
my
land
journey
in
my
second
letter
,
and
so
much
for
that
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
you
have
got
into
Presto
's
lodgings
;
very
fine
,
truly
!
 
<EOS>
We
have
had
a
fortnight
of
the
most
glorious
weather
on
earth
,
and
still
continues
:
 
<EOS>
I
hope
you
have
made
the
best
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
Ballygall

<EOS>
LONDON
,
Sept.
30
,
1710
.
  
<EOS>
Han't
<EOS>
I
brought
myself
into
a
fine
praemunire
,
to
begin
writing
letters
in
whole
sheets
?
<EOS>
and
now
I
dare
not
leave
it
off
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
tell
whether
you
like
these
journal
letters
:
 
<EOS>
I
believe
they
would
be
dull
to
me
to
read
them
over
;
but
,
perhaps
,
little
MD
is
pleased
to
know
how
Presto
passes
his
time
in
her
absence
.
 
<EOS>
I
always
begin
my
last
the
same
day
I
ended
my
former
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
you
where
I
dined
to
-
day
at
a
tavern
with
Stratford
:
 
Lewis
,
who
is
a
great
favourite
of
Harley
's
,
was
to
have
been
with
us
;
but
he
was
hurried
to
Hampton
Court
,
and
sent
his
excuse
;
and
that
next
Wednesday
he
would
introduce
me
to
Harley
.
 
<EOS>
'
Tis
good
to
see
what
a
lamentable
confession
<EOS>
the
Whigs
all
make
me
of
my
ill
usage
:
 
<EOS>
but
I
mind
them
not
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
already
represented
to
Harley
as
a
discontented
person
,
that
was
used
ill
for
not
being
Whig
enough
;
and
I
hope
for
good
usage
from
him
.
 
<EOS>
The
Tories
drily
tell
me
,
I
may
make
my
fortune
,
if
I
please
;
but
I
do
not
understand
them
 
or
rather
,
I
do
understand
them
.
  
<EOS>
Oct.
1
.
 
<EOS>
To
-
day
I
dined
at
Molesworth
's
,
the
Florence
Envoy
;
and
sat
this
evening
with
my
friend
Darteneuf
,
whom
you
have
heard
me
talk
of
;
the
greatest
punner
of
this
town
next
myself
.
 
<EOS>
Have
you
smoked
the
Tatler
that
I
writ
?
 
<EOS>
It
is
much
liked
here
,
and
I
think
it
a
pure
one
.
 
<EOS>
To
-
morrow
<EOS>
I
go
with
Delaval
,
the
Portugal
Envoy
,
to
dine
with
Lord
Halifax
near
Hampton
Court
.
 
<EOS>
Your
Manley
's
brother
,
a
Parliament
-
man
here
,
has
gotten
an
employment
;
and
I
am
informed
uses
much
interest
to
preserve
his
brother
:
and
,
to
-
day
,
I
spoke
to
the
elder
Frankland
to
engage
his
father
(
Postmaster
here
)
;
and
I
hope
he
will
be
safe
,
although
he
is
cruelly
hated
by
all
the
Tories
of
Ireland
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
almost
finished
my
lampoon
,
and
will
print
it
for
revenge
on
a
certain
great
person
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
cost
me
but
three
shillings
in
meat
and
drink
since
I
came
here
,
as
thin
as
the
town
is
.
 
<EOS>
I
laugh
to
see
myself
so
disengaged
in
these
revolutions
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
I
must
leave
off
,
and
go
write
to
Sir
John
Stanley
,
to
desire
him
to
engage
Lady
Hyde
as
my
mistress
to
engage
Lord
Hyde
in
favour
of
Mr.
Pratt
.
  
<EOS>
2
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Halifax
was
at
Hampton
Court
at
his
lodgings
,
and
I
dined
with
him
there
with
Methuen
,
and
Delaval
,
and
the
late
Attorney
-
General
.
<EOS>
I
went
to
the
Drawing
-
room
before
dinner
(
for
the
Queen
was
at
Hampton
Court
)
,
and
expected
to
see
nobody
;
but
I
met
acquaintance
enough
.
 
<EOS>
I
walked
in
the
gardens
,
saw
the
cartoons
of
Raphael
,
and
other
things
;
and
with
great
difficulty
got
from
Lord
Halifax
,
who
would
have
kept
me
to
-
morrow
to
show
me
his
house
and
park
,
and
improvements
.
 
<EOS>
We
left
Hampton
Court
at
sunset
,
and
got
here
in
a
chariot
and
two
horses
time
enough
by
starlight
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
something
<EOS>
charms
me
mightily
about
London
<EOS>
;
that
you
go
dine
a
dozen
miles
off
in
October
,
stay
all
day
,
and
return
so
quickly
:
 
<EOS>
you
can
not
do
anything
like
this
in
Dublin
.
<EOS>
I
writ
a
second
penny
post
letter
to
your
mother
,
and
hear
nothing
of
her
.
 
<EOS>
Did
I
tell
you
that
Earl
Berkeley
died
last
Sunday
was
se'nnight
,
at
Berkeley
Castle
,
of
a
dropsy
?
 
<EOS>
Lord
Halifax
began
a
health
to
me
to
-
day
;
it
was
the
Resurrection
of
the
Whigs
,
which
I
refused
unless
he
would
add
their
Reformation
too
and
<EOS>
I
told
him
he
was
the
only
Whig
in
England
I
loved
,
or
had
any
good
opinion
of
.
  
<EOS>
3
.
 
<EOS>
This
morning
Stella
's
sister
came
to
me
with
a
letter
from
her
mother
,
who
is
at
Sheen
;
but
will
soon
be
in
town
,
and
will
call
to
see
me
:
 
<EOS>
she
gave
me
a
bottle
of
palsy
water
,
a
small
one
,
and
desired
I
would
send
it
you
by
the
first

,
as
I
will
;
and
she
promises
a
quart
bottle
of
the
same
:
 
<EOS>
your
sister
looked
very
well
,
and
seems
a
good
modest
sort
of
girl
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
then
to
Mr.
Lewis
,
first
secretary
to
Lord
Dartmouth
,
and
favourite
to
Mr.
Harley
,
who
is
to
introduce
me
to
-
morrow
morning
.
 
<EOS>
Lewis
had
with
him
one
Mr.
Dyot
,
a
Justice
of
Peace
,
worth
twenty
thousand
pounds
,
a
Commissioner
of
the
Stamp
Office
,
and
married
to
a
sister
of
Sir
Philip
Meadows
,

.
 
<EOS>
I
tell
you
this
,
because
it
is
odds
but
this
Mr.
Dyot
will
be
hanged
;
for
he
is
discovered
to
have
counterfeited
stamped
paper
,
in
which
he
was
a
Commissioner
;
and
,
with
his
accomplices
,
has
cheated
the
Queen
of
a
hundred
thousand
pounds
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
hear
of
it
before
this
come
to
you
,
but
may
be
not
so
particularly
;
and
it
is
a
very
odd
accident
in
such
a
man
.
 
<EOS>
Smoke
Presto
writing
news
to
MD
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
with
Lord
Mountjoy
at
Kensington
,
and
walked
from
thence
this
evening
to
town
like
an
emperor
.
 
<EOS>
Remember
that
yesterday
,
October
2
,
was
a
cruel
hard
frost
,
with
ice
;
and
six
days
ago
I
was
dying
with
heat
.
 
<EOS>
As
thin
as
the
town
is
,
I
have
more
dinners
than
ever
;
and
am
asked
this
month
by
some
people
,
without
being
able
to
come
for
pre
-
engagements
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
but
I
should
write
plainer
,
when
I
consider
Stella
can
not
read
,
and
Dingley
is
not
so
skilful
at
my
ugly
hand
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
tonight
<EOS>
a
letter
from
Mr.
Pratt
,
who
tells
me
Joe
will
have
his
money
when
there
are

the
Lord

for

;
and

,
I

whoever

Lord

,
and
am
in

.
 
<EOS>
So
pray
tell
or
write
him
word
,
and
bid

not

cast
down
;
for
Ned
Southwell
and
Mr.
Addison
both
think
Pratt
in

.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
lose

money
at
Manley
's
to
-

,

.
  
<EOS>
4
.
 
<EOS>
After

last

,

;
but
I
sent

word
,
I
had

of

,

.
 
<EOS>
And
to

day
I
was

Mr.
Harley
,
who
received

with
the
greatest

:
 
<EOS>
he
has

an

Saturday

four
,

,
when
I
will
open
my
business
to
him
;
which
expression
I
would
not
use
if

were

woman
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
you
smoked
it
;
but
<EOS>
I
did
not
till
I
writ

.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-

at
Mr.
Delaval
's
,
the

,

Nic
Rowe

,

other

;
and

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
more

in
my
heart
;
and
I
think
it
shall
go
round
with
them
all
,
as
this
hits
,
and
I
can
find

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
certain
<EOS>
I
answered

2d
letter
,
<EOS>
and
yet
I
do
not

.
 
<EOS>
I

in

4th
:
 
and
why
N.
2d
,
3d
;
is

to

,

,

,

?
<EOS>
etc
.
 
<EOS>
I

:
 
<EOS>
I
'll
be
far
enough
<EOS>
but

,

;

?
<EOS>
they

:
 
<EOS>
I
think

have

.
 
<EOS>
I
fear

.
 
<EOS>
Pray
,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

that

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
God

!
  
<EOS>
5
.
 
<EOS>
This
morning
Delaval
came
to
see

,
and
we
went
together
to
Kneller
's
,
who
was
not

.
 
<EOS>
In

met
the
electors
for
Parliament
-
men
:
 
and
the
rabble
came
about
our

,
crying
,
"
A
Colt
,
a
Stanhope
,
"
etc
.
 
<EOS>
We
were
afraid
of
a
dead
cat
,
or
our
glasses
broken
,
and
so
were
always
of
their
side
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
again
at
Delaval
's
;
and
in
the
evening
,
at
the
Coffee
-
house
,
heard
Sir
Andrew
Fountaine
was
come
to
town
.
 
<EOS>
This
has
been
but
an
insipid
sort
of
day
,
and
I
have
nothing
to
remark
upon
it
worth
threepence
:
 
<EOS>
I
hope
MD
had
a
better
,
with
the
Dean
,
the
Bishop
,
or
Mrs.
Walls
.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
the
reason
you
lost
four
and
eightpence
last
night
but
one
at
Manley
's
was
,
because
you
played
bad
games
:
 
<EOS>
I
took
notice
of
six
that
you
had
ten
to
one
against
you
:
 
Would
any
but
a
mad
lady
go
out
twice
upon
Manilio
;
Basto
,
and
two
small

?
<EOS>
Then
in
that
game
of
spades
,
you
blundered
when
you
had
ten
-
ace
;
I
never
saw
the
like

:
 
<EOS>
and
now
you
are
in

I
tell

this
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
here
's
two
and
eightpence
halfpenny
towards
your
loss
.
  
<EOS>
6
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Andrew
Fountaine
came
this
morning
,
and
caught
me
writing
in
bed
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
into
the
city
with
him
;
and
we
dined
at
the
Chop
-
house
with
Will
Pate
,
the
learned
woollen
-
draper
:
 
<EOS>
then
we
sauntered
at
China
-
shops
and
booksellers
;
went
to
the
tavern
,
drank
two
pints
of
white
wine
,
and
never
parted
till
ten
:
 
and
now
I
am
come
home
,
and
must
copy
out
some
papers
I
intend
for
Mr.
Harley
,
whom
I
am
to
see
,
as
I
told
you
,
to
-
morrow
afternoon
;
so
that
this
night
I
shall
say
little
to
MD
,
but
that
I
heartily
wish
myself
with
them
,
and
will
come
as
soon
as
I
either
fail
,
or
compass
my
business
.
 
<EOS>
We
now
hear
daily
of
elections
;
and
,
in
a
list
I
saw
yesterday
of
about
twenty
,
there
are
seven
or
eight
more
Tories
than
in
the
last
Parliament
;
so
that
I
believe
they
need
not
fear
a
majority
,
with
the
help
of
those
who
will
vote
as
the
Court
pleases
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
have
been
told
that
Mr.
Harley
himself
would
not
let
the
Tories
be
too
numerous
,
for
fear
they
should
be
insolent
,
and
kick
against
him
;
and
for
that
reason
they
have
kept
several
Whigs
in
employments
,
who
expected
to
be
turned
out
every
day
;
as
Sir
John
Holland
the
Comptroller
,
and
many
others
.
 
<EOS>
And
so
get
you
gone
to
your
cards
,
and
your
claret
and
orange
,
at
the
Dean
's
;
and
I
'll
go
write
.
  
<EOS>
7
.
 
<EOS>
I
wonder
when
this
letter
will
be
finished
:
 
it
must
go
by
Tuesday
<EOS>
,
that
's
certain
;
and

from
MD

,

<EOS>
,

.
 
<EOS>
'
Tis
now

,
<EOS>
and

not

for

Harley
last

;
for
you
must
understand
Presto
was

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
Very
pretty
that
I
must

in

,
faith
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
good

;
<EOS>
and
so

,
and

,
sirrahs
.
 
<EOS>
At
night
.
 
<EOS>
Jack
<EOS>
How
told
Harley
that
if
there
were
a
lower
place
in
hell
than
another
,
it
was
reserved
for
his
porter
,
who
tells
lies
so
gravely
,
and
with
so
civil
a
manner
.
 
<EOS>
This
porter
I
have
had
to
deal
with
,
going
this
evening
at
four
to
visit
Mr.
Harley
,
by
his
own
appointment
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
fellow
told
me
no
lie
,
though
I
suspected
every
word
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
He
told
me
his
master
was
just
gone
to
dinner
,
with
much
company
,
and
desired
I
would
come
an
hour
hence
:
 
which
I
did
,
expecting
to
hear
Mr.
Harley
was
gone
out
;
but
they
had
just
done
dinner
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Harley
came
out
to
me
,
brought
me
in
,
and
presented
to
me
his
son
-
in
-
law
Lord
Doblane
(
or
some
such
name
)
and
his
own
son
,
and
,
among
others
,
Will
Penn
the
Quaker
:
 
we
sat
two
hours
drinking
as
good
wine
as
you
do
;
and
two
hours
more
<EOS>
he
and
I
alone
<EOS>
;
where
he
heard
me
tell
my
business
;
entered
into
it
with
all
kindness
;
asked
for
my
powers
,
and
read
them
;
and
read
likewise
a
memorial
I
had
drawn
up
,
and
put
it
in
his
pocket
to
show
the
Queen
;
told
me
the
measures
he
would
take
;
and
,
in
short
,
said
everything
I
could
wish
:
 
told
me
,
he
must
bring
Mr.
St.
John
(
Secretary
of
State
)
and
me
acquainted
;
and
spoke
so
many
things
of
personal
kindness
and
esteem
for
me
,
that
I
am
inclined
half
to
believe
what
some
friends
have
told
me
,
that
he
would
do
everything
to
bring
me
over
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
desired
to
dine
with
me
<EOS>
(
what
a
comical
mistake
was
that
!
)
.
 
<EOS>
I
mean
he
has
desired
me
to
dine
with
him
on
Tuesday
;
and
after
four
hours
being
with
him
,
set
me
down
at
St.
James
's
Coffee
-
house
in
a
hackney
-
coach
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
is
odd
and
comical
,
if
you
consider
him
and
me
.
 
<EOS>
He
knew
my
Christian
name
very
well
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
forbear
saying
thus
much
upon
this
matter
,
although
you
will
think
it
tedious
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
'll
tell
you
;
you
must
know
,
'
tis
fatal
to
me
to
be
a
scoundrel
and
a
prince
the
same
day
:
 
for
,
being
to
see
him
at
four
,
I
could
not
engage
myself
to
dine
at
any
friend
's
;
so
I
went
to
Tooke
,
to
give
him
a
ballad
,
and
dine
with
him
;
but
he
was
not
at
home
:
 
<EOS>
so
I
was
forced
to
go
to
a
blind
chop
-
house
,
and
dine
for
tenpence
upon
gill
-
ale
,
bad
broth

.

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
An
odd

:
 
one
Captain

,

,
found

"
Commons
,

,

,
it
is
to

:
 
and

.
 
<EOS>
Lavallin

this

,

;
but

,
about

:
 
<EOS>
the

,

;
but

:
 
upon

what

.

;

.
 
<EOS>

:
 
<EOS>
this

;
but

,

,

!
 
<EOS>
There

fellow
here

town
<EOS>

,

,
<EOS>

,
good
sense
,
and
good
nature
;
has
written
some
mighty

;
that
in
your
6th

,
about
the
Sprig
of
an
Orange
,
is
his
:
 
<EOS>
he
has
nothing
to
live
on
but
being
governor
to
one
of
the
Duke
of
Queensberry
's
sons
for

.
 
<EOS>
The
fine
fellows
are
always

him
to
the

,
and
make

.
<EOS>
Henley
is
a
great

of
his
:
 
<EOS>
they
are
often
at
the

at
six

seven
shillings
reckoning
,
and
he
always
makes
the

.
 
<EOS>
A

a
lord
were
at
him
and
me
the

-
night
:
 
<EOS>
I
absolutely

,
and
made
Harrison
lag

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
I
tell

this
,
because
I
find
all
rich
fellows
have
that

of
using

without
any

of
their
fortunes
;
but
I
will
see

rot

.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Halifax
is
always

to

his
country
house
,
which
will

a

to

,

coach

;
and

.
 
<EOS>
Is

a

?
 
<EOS>
But

am

,

:
 
<EOS>
he

,

;

.
 
<EOS>

,

:
 
came

:
 
<EOS>
then

Addison
and
supped

Mountjoy
,

.
 
<EOS>
I
forgot

I

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

17
.
 
<EOS>
This

,

;

.
 
<EOS>

Sterne
,

,

;
but
,
<EOS>

,

came
in
the

of

,
Colonel
Edgworth
;
so

.
 
<EOS>
This
day

out

Tatler
,

of

"
Shower
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
They
say
it
is
the
best
thing
I
ever
writ
,
and
I
think
so
too
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
the
Bishop
of
Clogher
will
show
it
you
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
tell
me
how
you
like
it
.
 
<EOS>
Tooke
is
going
on
with
my
Miscellany
.
<EOS>
I
'd
give
a
penny
the
letter
to
the
Bishop
of
Killaloe
<EOS>
was
in

:
  
'
<EOS>
twould

.
 
<EOS>
Could

contrive

say
,
you
hear
they
are

together
;
and
that
you
with
the

had
that
letter
among

:
but
do

as

.
 
<EOS>
I
forget

was
good
or
no
;
but
only

much
commended
,
perhaps

may

.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
I
have
to
-
morrow
to
finish
this
letter
in
,
and
then
I
will

next

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
so

that
you
should

to

,
when
you
had
but
<EOS>
my

,
and
<EOS>

,

:
 
<EOS>

,

,
<EOS>
little
,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
18
.
 
<EOS>
To

,

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
And

Patrick
is

,
and

,
and
I
can
not
I

night
-

.
 
<EOS>
I
have

to
turn
that

away
:
 
<EOS>
he
has
been

ten

in

.
 
<EOS>
But

han't
time
to

;
so
good

,

.
  
<EOS>
19
.
 
<EOS>
I
am

,

;
and
just

,

<EOS>
,

was
this

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

;
but
hope

done

First
-

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,
to

;
but

.
 
<EOS>
I
have

to

,
to

by

:
 
<EOS>
I

Curry
,

;
<EOS>
so

when

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

will

's

,

.
 
<EOS>
And

,

<EOS>
but

MD
's
:
 
<EOS>
now

am

,

;
and

MD
,

.
   
<EOS>
LETTER
7
.
 
<EOS>
LONDON
,
Oct.
19
,
1710
.
  
<EOS>
Faith
,
I
am
undone
!
<EOS>
this
paper
is
larger
than
the
other
,
and
yet
I
am
condemned
to
a
sheet
;
but
,
since
it
is
MD
,
I
did
not
value
though
I
were
condemned
to
a
pair
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
you
in
my
letter
to
-
day
where
I
had
been
,
and
how
the
day
passed
;
and
<EOS>
so
,
etc
.
  
<EOS>
20
.
 
<EOS>
To
-
day
I
went
to
Mr.
Lewis
,
at
the
Secretary
's
office
,
to
know
when
I
might
see
Mr.
Harley
;
and
by
and
by
comes
up
Mr.
Harley
himself
,
and
appoints
me
to
dine
with
him
to
-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Mrs.
Vanhomrigh
,
and
went
to
wait
on
the
two
Lady
Butlers
;
but
the
porter
answered
they
were
not
at
home
:
 
the
meaning
was
,
the
youngest
,
Lady
Mary
,
is
to
be
married
to
-
morrow
to
Lord
Ashburnham
,
the
best
match
now
in
England
,
twelve
thousand
pounds
a
year
,
and
abundance
of
money
.
 
<EOS>
Tell
me
how
my
"
Shower
"
is
liked
in
Ireland
:
 
<EOS>
I
never
knew
anything
pass
better
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
spent
the
evening
with
Wortley
Montagu
and
Mr.
Addison
,
over
a
bottle
of
Irish
wine
.
 
<EOS>
Do
they
know
anything
in
Ireland
of
my
greatness
among
the
Tories
?
 
<EOS>
Everybody
reproaches
me
of
it
here
;
but
I
value
them
not
.
 
<EOS>
Have
you
heard
of
the
verses
about
the
"
Rod
of
Sid
Hamet
"
?
 
<EOS>
Say
nothing
of
them
for
your
life
.
 
<EOS>
Hardly
anybody
suspects
me
for
them
;
only
they
think
nobody
but
Prior
or
I
could
write
them
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
doubt
they
have
not
reached
you
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
likewise
a
ballad
full
of
puns
on
the
Westminster
Election
,
that
cost
me
half
an
hour
:
 
<EOS>
it
runs
,
though
it
be
good
for
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
But
this
is
likewise
a
secret
to
all
but
MD
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
have
them
not
,
I
will
bring
them
over
.
  
<EOS>
21
.
 
<EOS>
I
got
MD
's
fourth
to
-
day
at
the
Coffee
-
house
.
 
<EOS>
God
Almighty
bless
poor
,
dear
Stella
,
and
her
eyes
and
head
!
 
<EOS>
What
shall
we
do
to
cure
them
?
<EOS>
poor
,
dear
life
!
 
<EOS>
Your
disorders
are
a
pull
-
back
for
your
good
qualities
.
 
<EOS>
Would
to
Heaven
<EOS>
I
were
this
minute
shaving
your
poor
,
dear
head
,
<EOS>
either
here
or
there
!
<EOS>
Pray
do
not
write
,
nor
read
this
letter
,
nor
anything
else
;
and
I
will
write
plainer
for
Dingley
to
read
from
henceforward
,
though
my
pen
is
apt
to
ramble
when
I
think
whom
I
am
writing
to
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
not
answer
your
letter
until
I
tell
you
that
I
dined
this
day
with
Mr.
Harley
,
who
presented
me
to
the
Earl
of
Stirling
,
a
Scotch
lord
;
and
in
the
evening
came
in
Lord
Peterborow
.
 
<EOS>
I
stayed
till
nine
before
Mr.
Harley
would
let
me
go
,
or
tell
me
anything
of
my
affair
.
 
<EOS>
He
says
the
Queen
has
now
granted
the
First
-
Fruits
and
Twentieth
Parts
;
but
he
will
not
give
me
leave
to
write
to
the
Archbishop
,
because
the
Queen
designs
to
signify
it
to
the
Bishops
in
Ireland
in
form
;
and
to
take
notice
,
that
it
was
done
upon
a
memorial
from
me
;
which
,
Mr.
Harley
tells
me
he
does
to
make
it
look
more
respectful
to
me
,
etc
.
;
and
I
am
to
see
him
on
Tuesday
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
not
whether
I
told
you
that
,
in
my
memorial
which
was
given
to
the
Queen
,
I
begged
for
two
thousand
pounds
a
year
more
,
though
it
was
not
in
my

;
but
that
,
Mr.
Harley
says
,
can
not
yet

done
,
and
that
he
and
I
must
talk

:
 
however
,
I
have
started
it
,
and
it
may
follow
in
time
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
say
nothing
of
the
First
-
Fruits
being
granted
,
unless
I
give
leave
at
the
bottom
of
this
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
never
anything
was
compassed
so
soon
,
and
purely
done
by
my
personal
credit
with
Mr.
Harley
,
who
is
so
excessively
obliging
,
that
I
know
not
what
to
make
of
it
,
unless
to
show
the
rascals
of
the
other
party
that
they
used
a
man
unworthily
who
had
deserved
better
.
 
<EOS>
The
memorial
given
to
the
Queen
from
me
speaks
with
great
plainness
of
Lord
Wharton
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
this
business
is
as
important
to
you
as
the
Convocation
disputes
from
Tisdall
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
in
a
month
or
two
all
the
forms
of
settling
this
matter
will
be
over
;
and
then
I
shall
have
nothing
to
do
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
only
add
one
foolish
thing
more
,
because
it
is
just
come
into
my
head
.
 
<EOS>
When
this
thing
is
made
known
,
tell
me
impartially
whether
they
give
any
of
the
merit
to
me
,
or
no
<EOS>
;
for
I
am
sure
I
have
so
much
,
that
I
will
never
take
it
upon
me
.
 
<EOS>
Insolent
sluts
!
<EOS>
because
I
say
Dublin
,
Ireland
,
therefore
you
must
say
London
,
England
:
 
<EOS>
that
is
Stella
's
malice
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
for
that
I
will
not
answer
your
letter
till
to
-
morrow

day
,
and
<EOS>
so
and
so
:
 
I
will
go
write
something
else
,
and
it
will
not
be
much
;
for
'
tis
late
.
  
<EOS>
22
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this
morning
with
Mr.
Lewis
,
the
under
-
secretary
to
Lord
Dartmouth
,
two
hours
,
talking
politics
,
and
contriving
to
keep
Steele
in
his
office
of
stamped
paper
:
 
<EOS>
he
has
lost
his
place
of
Gazetteer
,
three
hundred
pounds
a
year
,
for
writing
a
Tatler
,
some
months
ago
,
against
Mr.
Harley
,
who
gave

at

,
and
raised

from

to
three
hundred
pounds
.
<EOS>
This
was
devilish
ungrateful
;
and
Lewis
was
telling
me
the
particulars
:
 
<EOS>
but
I
had
a
hint
given
me
,
that
I
might
save
him
in
the
other
employment
:
 
and
leave
<EOS>
was
given
me
to
clear
matters
with
Steele
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
I
dined
with
Sir
Matthew
Dudley
,
and
in
the
evening
went
to
sit
with
Mr.
Addison
,
and
offer
the
matter
at
distance
to
him
,
as
the
discreeter
person
;
but
found
party
had
so
possessed
him
,
that
he
talked
as
if
he
suspected
me
,
and
would
not
fall
in
with
anything
I
said
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
stopped
short
in
my
overture
,
and
we
parted
very
drily
;
and
I
shall
say
nothing
to
Steele
,
and
let
them
do
as
they
will
;
but
,
if
things
stand
as
they
are
,
he
will
certainly
lose
it
,
unless
I
save
him
;
and
therefore
I
will
not
speak
to
him
,
that
I
may
not
report
to
his
disadvantage
.
 
<EOS>
Is
not
this
vexatious
?
<EOS>
and
is
there
so
much
in
the
proverb
of
proffered
service
?
<EOS>
When
shall
I
grow
wise
?
 
<EOS>
I
endeavour
to
act
in
the
most
exact
points
of
honour
and
conscience
;
and
my
nearest
friends
will
not
understand
it
so
.
 
<EOS>
What
must
a
man
expect
from
his
enemies
?
 
<EOS>
This
would
vex
me
,
but
it
shall
not
;
and
so
I
bid
you
good
-
night
,
etc
.
  
<EOS>
23
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
'
tis
neither
wit
nor
diversion
to
tell
you
every
day
where
I
dine
;
neither
do
I
write
it
to
fill

letter
;
but
<EOS>
I
fancy
I
shall
,
<EOS>
some

or
other
,
have
the
curiosity
of
seeing
some

how
I
passed
my
life
when
I

from
MD
this

;
and
so
I
tell

now
that
I
dined
to
-
day
at
Molesworth
's
,
the
Florence
Envoy
,
then
went
to
the
Coffee
-
house
,
where
I
behaved

coldly
enough
to
Mr.
Addison
,
and
so

home
to
scribble
.
 
<EOS>
We
dine
together
to
-
morrow
and
next
day
by
invitation
;
but
I
shall
alter
my
behaviour
to
him
,
till
he
begs
my
pardon
,
or
else
we
shall
grow
bare
acquaintance
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
weary
of
friends
;
and
friendships
are
all
monsters
,
but
MD
's
.
  
<EOS>
24
.
 
<EOS>
I
forgot
to
tell
you
,
that
last
night
I
went
to
Mr.
Harley
's
,
hoping
 
faith
,
I
am
blundering
,
<EOS>
for
it
was
this
very
night
at
six
;
and
I
hoped
he
would
have
told
me
all
things
were
done
and

:
 
<EOS>
but
he
was
abroad
,
and
came
home
ill
,
and
was
gone
to

,
much
out

order
,
unless
the
porter
lied
.
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
at
Sir
Matthew
Dudley
's
,

Mr.
Addison
,
etc
.
  
<EOS>
25
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
to
-
day
to
see
the
Duke
of
Ormond
;
and
,
coming
out
,
met
Lord
Berkeley
of
Stratton
,
who
told
me
that
Mrs.
Temple
,
the
widow
,
died
last
Saturday
,
which
,
I
suppose
,
is
much
to
the
outward
grief
and
inward
joy
of
the
family
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
with
Addison
and
Steele
,
and
a
sister
of
Mr.
Addison
,
who
is
married
to
one
Mons
.
 
<EOS>
Sartre
,
a
Frenchman
,
prebendary
of
Westminster
,
who
has
a
delicious
house
and
garden
;
yet
<EOS>
I
thought
it
was
a
sort
of
monastic
life
in
those
cloisters
,
and
I
liked
Laracor
better
.
 
<EOS>
Addison
's
sister
is
a
sort
of
a
wit
,
very
like
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
fond
of
her
,
etc
.
  
<EOS>
26
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
to
-
day
to
see
Mr.
Congreve
,
who
is
almost
blind
with
cataracts
growing
on
his
eyes
;
and
his
case
is
,
that
he
must
wait
two
or
three
years
,
until
the
cataracts
are
riper
,
and
till
he
is
quite
blind
,
and
then
he
must
have
them
couched
;
and
,
besides
,
he
is
never
rid
of
the
gout
,
yet
he
looks
young
and
fresh
,
and
is
as
cheerful
as
ever
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
younger
by
three
years
or
more
than
I
;
and
I
am
twenty
years
younger
than
he
.
 
<EOS>
He
gave
me
a
pain
in
the
great
toe
,
by
mentioning
the
gout
.
 
<EOS>
I
find
such
suspicions
frequently
,
but
they
go
off
again
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
a
second
letter
from
Mr.
Morgan
,
for
which
I
thank
you
:
 
<EOS>
I
wish
you
were
whipped
,
for
forgetting
to
send
him
that
answer
<EOS>
I
desired
you
in
one
of
my
former
,
that
I
could
do
nothing
for
him
of
what
he
desired
,
having
no
credit
at
all
,
etc
.
 
<EOS>
Go
,
be
far
enough
,
you
negligent
baggages
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
had
also
a
letter
from
Parvisol
,
with
an
account
how
my
livings
are
set
;
and
that
they
are
fallen
,
since
last
year
,
sixty
pounds
.
 
<EOS>
A
comfortable
piece
of
news
!
 
<EOS>
He
tells
me
plainly
that
he
finds
you
have
no
mind
to
part
with
the
horse
,
because
you
sent
for
him
at
the
same
time
you
sent
him
my
letter
;
so
that
I
know
not
what
must
be
done
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
sad
thing
that
Stella
must
have
her
own
horse
,
whether
Parvisol
will
or
no
.
 
<EOS>
So
now
to
answer
your
letter
that
I
had
three
or
four
days
ago
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
now
in
bed
,
but
am
come
home
by
eight
;
and
,
it
being
warm
,
I
write
up
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
writ
to
the
Bishop
of
Killala
,
<EOS>
which
,
I
suppose
,
was
the
reason
he
had
not
my

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
time
,
there
is
the
short
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
As
fond
as
the
Dean
is
of
my
letter
,
he
has
not
written
to

.
 
<EOS>
I
would
only
know
whether
Dean
Bolton
paid
him
the
twenty

;
and
for
the
rest
,
he
may
kiss
 
And
that
you
may
ask
him
,
because
I
am
in
pain
about
it
,
that
Dean
Bolton
is
such
a

.
'
<EOS>
Tis
the
most

the
world
in
Dean
Sterne
to

.
<EOS>
I
believe
he
knows
it
will
please
me
,
and
makes
up
,
that

,
his
other
usage
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
we
have
had
none
of
your
snow
,
but
a

one
morning
;
yet
I
think
it
was
great
snow
for
an
hour
or

,
but
no

.
 
<EOS>
I
had
heard
of
Will
Crowe
's
death
before
,
but
not
the
foolish

that

.
 
<EOS>
No
,
I
have
taken
care
that
Captain
Pratt
shall
not
suffer
by
Lord

's
death
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
try
some

to

of
my
picture
from
Jervas
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
make
Sir
Andrew
Fountaine
buy
one
as
for
himself
,
and
I
will
pay

again
,
and
take
it
,
that

,

.
 
<EOS>
Poor
John
!
<EOS>
is
he
gone
?
<EOS>
and
Madam
Parvisol
has
been
in

!
<EOS>
Humm
.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
Tighe
and
I
,
when
he
comes
,
shall
not
take
any
notice
of
each

;
I
would
not
do

much
in
this

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
was
to
-

at
Mr.
Sterne
's

:
 
<EOS>
he
was
not
within
;
and
Mr.
Leigh
is
not
come

;
but
I
will
do
Dingley
's

when
I
see

.
 
<EOS>
What

know
whether
china
be
dear
or

?
 
<EOS>
I
once
took
a
fancy
of
resolving
to
grow
mad
for
it
,
but
now
it
is
off
;
I
suppose

told

in
some
former

.
 
<EOS>
And
so

only
want
some

-

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
,
you
shall
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
you
have
named
as
much
as
will
cost
five

.
 
<EOS>
Now
to
Stella
's
little
postscript
;
and
I

you
vex

for

.
 
<EOS>
Can

Dingley
,

?
 
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Pray

;

,

,

,

,
"

?
"
 
<EOS>
That

.
 
<EOS>
Faith
,

and

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
Here

!
<EOS>
Well

,

in

<EOS>
Method

.
 
<EOS>
Order

.
 
<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>
A

<EOS>
Is

?
 
<EOS>
I

with
Patty

at

,

:
 
<EOS>
he

<EOS>

<EOS>

;

<EOS>

of

,

<EOS>

,
"

"
I

,

wo

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
It

,
and
has

in

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
and

.
<EOS>
and

:
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
  
<EOS>
27
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.

<EOS>
I

Prior

:

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

.
 
<EOS>
But
now
my
head
continues
pretty

;
I
have

,

mixed

,

,

;

,

.

28
.
 
<EOS>
Garth

Addison
<EOS>

;

,

,

:
 
<EOS>
so

.
 
<EOS>
Then

,

;
and

;

.
 
<EOS>
Then

Butler
,

son

of

denied

:
 
<EOS>
so
I
sent

,
for

always
to

.
 
<EOS>
I
was
weary
of

,

;
which
I

,

,

twelve
,
and
now
am
got
into

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
the
new
Ministry
is
at

about

:
 
<EOS>
the
Whigs
talk
<EOS>
so
,

the

;
and
I

Harley

.
 
<EOS>
They

he

.
 
<EOS>
God

.
 
<EOS>
I

round

:
 
<EOS>
it
will
ruin
the
Church
and

;

.
 
<EOS>
I

29
.
 
<EOS>

;

.

30
.
 
<EOS>

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
31
.
 
<EOS>
The

ends

;
and

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Aire
,

,

,

:
 
'

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

's

.
 
<EOS>
They

,

;

,

;
and

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Pray

.
 
<EOS>
I
seldom

;
but
I
can

MD
no

.
 
<EOS>
Pray

Brent
.
  
<EOS>
I
am

pretty

;
and
you

,

.
<EOS>
I

;

.
  
<EOS>

,

D

.
 
<EOS>
Do

?
 
<EOS>
O

,

,
faith
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
Pox

;

,

.
   
<EOS>
LETTER
8
.
 
<EOS>
LONDON
,
Oct.
31
,
1710
.
  
<EOS>
So
,
now
I
have
sent
my
seventh
to
your
fourth
,
young
women
;
and
now
I
will
tell
you
what
I
would
not
in
my
last
,
that
this
morning
,
sitting
in
my
bed
,
I
had
a
fit
of
giddiness
:
 
<EOS>
the
room
turned
round
for
about
a
minute
,
and
then
it
went
off
,
leaving
me
sickish
,
but
not
very
:
 
<EOS>
and
so
I
passed
the
day
as
I
told
you
;
but
I
would
not
end
a
letter
with
telling
you
this
,
because
it
might
vex
you
:
 
and
I
hope
in
God
I
shall
have
no
more
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
Dr.
Cockburn
to
-
day
,
and
he
promises
to
send
me
the
pills
that
did
me
good
last
year
;
and
likewise
has
promised
me
an
oil
for
my
ear
,
that
he
has
been
making
for
that
ailment
for
somebody
else
.
  
<EOS>
Nov.
1
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
MD
a
merry
new
year
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
this
is
the
first
day
of
it
with
us
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
no
giddiness
to
-
day
;
but
I
drank
brandy
,
and
have
bought
a
pint
for
two
shillings
.
 
<EOS>
I
sat
up
the
night
before
my
giddiness
pretty
late
,
and
writ
very
much
;
so
I
will
impute
it
to
that
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
never
eat
fruit
,
nor
drink
ale
;
but
drink
better
wine
than
you
do
,
as
I
did
to
-
day
with
Mr.
Addison
at
Lord
Mountjoy
's
:
 
then
went
at
five
to
see
Mr.
Harley
,
who
could
not
see
me
for
much
company
;
but
sent
me
his
excuse
,
and
desired
I
would
dine
with
him
on
Friday
;
and
then
I
expect
some
answer
to
this
business
,
which
must
either
be
soon
done
,
or
begun
again
;
and
then
the
Duke
of
Ormond
and
his
people
will
interfere
for
their
honour
,
and
do
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
I
came
home
at
six
,
and
spent
my
time
in
my
chamber
,
without
going
to
the
Coffee
-
house
,
which
I
grow
weary
of
;
and
I
studied
at
leisure
,
writ
not
above
forty
lines
,
some
inventions
of
my
own
,
and
some
hints
,
and
read
not
at
all
,
and
this
because
I
would
take
care
of
Presto
,
for
fear
little
MD
should
be
angry
.
  
<EOS>
2
.
 
<EOS>
I
took
my
four
pills
last
night
,
and
they
lay
an
hour
in
my
throat
,
and
so
they
will
do
to
-
night
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
I
could
swallow
four
affronts
as
easily
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Dr.
Cockburn
to
-
day
,
and
came
home
at
seven
;
but
Mr.
Ford
has
been
with
me
till
just
now
,
and
it
is
near
eleven
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
had
no
giddiness
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
Mr.
 
Dopping
I
have
seen
;
and
he
tells
me
coldly
,
my
"
Shower
"
is
liked
well
enough
;
there
's
your
Irish
judgment
!
 
<EOS>
I
writ
this
post
to
the
Bishop
of
Clogher
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
now
just
a
fortnight
since
I
heard
from
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
have
you
write
once
a
fortnight
,
and
then
I
will
allow
for
wind
and
weather
.
 
<EOS>
How
goes
ombre
?
 
<EOS>
Does
Mrs.
Walls
win
constantly
,
as
she
used
to
do
?
 
<EOS>
And
Mrs.
Stoyte
;
I
have
not
thought
of
her
this
long
time
:
 
<EOS>
how
does
she
?
 
<EOS>
I
find
we
have
a
cargo
of
Irish
coming
for
London
:
 
<EOS>
I
am
sorry
for
it
;
but
I
never
go
near
them
.
 
<EOS>
And
Tighe
is
landed
;
but
Mrs.
Wesley
,
they
say
,
is
going
home
to
her
husband
,
like
a
fool
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
little
monkeys
mine
,
I
must
go
write
;
and
so
goodnight
.
  
<EOS>
3
.
 
<EOS>
I
ought
to
read
these
letters
I
write
,
after
I
have
done
;
for
,
looking
over
thus
much
,
I
found
two
or
three
literal
mistakes
,
which
should
not
be
when
the
hand
is
so
bad
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
hope
it
does
not
puzzle
little
Dingley
to
read
,
for
I
think
I
mend
:
 
but
methinks
,
when
I
write
plain
,
I
do
not
know
how
,
but
we
are
not
alone
,
all
the
world
can
see
us
.
 
<EOS>
A
bad
scrawl
is
so
snug
,
it
looks
like
a
PMD
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
scurvy
Tatlers
of
late
:
 
<EOS>
so
pray
do
not
suspect
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
one
or
two
hints
I
design
to
send
him
,
and
never
any
more
:
he
does
not
deserve
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
governed
by
his
wife
most
abominably
,
as
bad
as
#
#
#
#
.
  
<EOS>
I
never
saw
her
since
I
came
;
nor
has
he
ever
made
me
an
invitation
:
either
he
dares
not
,
or
is
such
a
thoughtless
Tisdall
fellow
,
that
he
never
minds
it
.
 
<EOS>
So
what
care
I
for
his
wit
?
<EOS>
for
he
is
the
worst
company
in
the
world
,
till
he
has
a
bottle
of
wine
in
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
write
straighter
in
bed
,
so
you
must
be
content
.
 
<EOS>
At
night
in
bed
.
 
<EOS>
Stay
,
let

where
's
this

to
MD
among

?
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
here
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
I
will
go
on

;
but
I
am
very

(
smoke

new

.
)
 
<EOS>
I
dined

Harley
to
-

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

;

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
;

Dublin

<EOS>
(
I

)
.
 
<EOS>
I

;

<EOS>
If

;

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

;

<EOS>

;

<EOS>
'

<EOS>

;

<EOS>
No

faith

,

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
4
.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
I
writ

,
for
I

till
nine
,
and
am

;
for
Colonel
Proud
was
very
ill
company
,
and
I

of

with

again
;
and
I
drank
punch
,
and
that
and
ill
company
has
made

.
  
<EOS>
5
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
with
Mr.
Harley
from

to
seven
this
night
,
and
went
to
the
Coffee

,
where
Dr.
Davenant
would
fain

at

hard
by
,
with
Dr.
Chamberlen
,
but
the

used
so
many

,
that
I

;
and

at
eight
,
I

,
that
Chamberlen
was
going
to
a
patient
,
and
therefore

another

:
 
<EOS>
so
he
,

,

,

Matthew
Dudley
to

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Davenant
has
been
teasing

to

that

;
but

rogue

,

;
and

,

Tom
Double
;
to

,

.
  
<EOS>
6
.
 
<EOS>
I

to

Rolt
,

,

;

,

,

,

:
 
for
dinners
<EOS>
are

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
wo

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

:
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
7
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined

's
,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Vanbrugh
,

,

;
but

.
 
<EOS>
Lady
Marlborough

with

,

,

be

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

I

,

Queen

;
not

Whig
:

<EOS>
;

.

MD
?
"

.
  
<EOS>
8
.
 
<EOS>
Here
's

!
 
<EOS>
I

's

;

<EOS>
I

,

,
and

,

,

had

fire
,
O
ho
!
<EOS>
and
now
am
in
bed
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
no

in

bed

;
but
'
tis

warm
weather
when
one
's
in
bed
.
<EOS>
Your
fine
cap
,
Madam
Dingley
,

too

,

:
 
<EOS>
I
will

that

;
I
wish

;
and
my
old

is

.
 
<EOS>
Is

velvet
under

fur
?
 
<EOS>
I
was
feeling
,
but
can
not

:
 
if

be
,
'
twill
do
without
it
else
<EOS>
I

;
but

must

:
 
but
may
be
I
may

.
 
<EOS>
What
shall

do
?
 
<EOS>
Well
,
now
to
rogue
MD
's
letter
.
 
<EOS>
God
be
thanked
for
Stella
's
eyes
mending
;
and

holds
;
but
faith
you
writ
too
much
at
a

:
 
better
write
less
,
or

ten
times
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
faith
,
a
long
letter
in
a
morning
from
a
dear
friend
is
a
dear
thing
.
 
<EOS>
I
smoke
a
compliment
,
little
mischievous
girls
,
I
do
so
.
 
<EOS>
But
who
are
those
WIGGS
that
think
I
am
turned
Tory
?
 
<EOS>
Do

Whigs
?
 
<EOS>
Which
WIGGS
and
WAT

do
you
mean
?
 
<EOS>
I
know
nothing
of
Raymond
,
and
only

one

from
him
a
little
after
I
came
here.[Pray
<EOS>
remember
Morgan
.
)
 
<EOS>
Raymond
is
indeed
like
to
have
much
influence
over
me
in
London
,
and
to
share
much
of
my
conversation
.
<EOS>
I
shall
,
no
doubt
,
introduce
him
to
Harley
,
and
Lord
Keeper
,
and
the
Secretary
of
State
.
 
<EOS>
The
Tatler
upon
Ithuriel
's
spear
is
not
mine
,
madam
.
 
<EOS>
What
a
puzzle
there
is
betwixt
you
and
your
judgment
!
 
<EOS>
In
general
you
may
be
sometimes
sure
of
things
,
as
that
about
STYLE
,
because
it
is
what
I
have
frequently
spoken
of
;
but
guessing
is
mine
a
#
#
#
#
,
and
I
defy
mankind
,
if
I
please
.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
I
writ
a
pamphlet
when
I
was
last
in
London
,
that
you
and
a
thousand
have
seen
,
and
never

to

.
 
<EOS>

"

?
 
<EOS>
How

went
?
<EOS>
but

in

.
 
<EOS>
Nor

;
(

)
<EOS>
and

.
 
<EOS>
'

.
"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
'

:
 
not

,

<EOS>
Your

<EOS>
I

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Would

,

.
 
<EOS>

;

here
<EOS>
,

<EOS>
'

,

:
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mrs.

,

<EOS>
Mr.

,

<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Rot

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
LETTER
9
.
 
<EOS>
LONDON
,
Nov.
11
,
1710
.
  
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
,
by
invitation
,
with
the
Secretary
of
State
,
Mr.
St.
John
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Harley
came
in
to
us
before
dinner
,
and
made
me
his
excuses
for
not
dining
with
us
,
because
he
was
to
receive
people
who
came
to
propose
advancing
money
to
the
Government
:
 
there
dined
with
us
only
Mr.
Lewis
,
and
Dr.
Freind
(
that
writ
"
Lord
Peterborow
's
Actions
in
Spain
"
)
.
 
<EOS>
I
stayed
with
them
till
just
now
between
ten
and
eleven
,
and
was
forced
again
to
give
my
eighth
to
the
bellman
,
which
I
did
with
my
own
hands
,
rather
than
keep
it
till
next
post
.
<EOS>
The
Secretary
used
me
with
all
the
kindness
in
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
Prior
came
in
after
dinner
;
and
,
upon
an
occasion
,
he
(
the
Secretary
)
said
,
"
The
best
thing
I
ever
read
is
not
yours
,
but
Dr.
Swift
's
on
Vanbrugh
"
;
which
I
do
not
reckon
so
very
good
neither
.
 
<EOS>
But
Prior
was
damped
,
until
I
stuffed
him
with
two
or
three
compliments
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
thinking
what
a
veneration
we
used
to
have
for
Sir
William
Temple
,
because
he
might
have
been
Secretary
of
State
at
fifty
;
and
here
is
a
young
fellow
,
hardly
thirty
,
in
that
employment
.
 
<EOS>
His
father
is
a
man
of
pleasure
,
that
walks
the
Mall
,
and
frequents
St.
James
's
Coffee
-
house
,
and
the
chocolate
-
houses
;
and
the
young
son
is
principal
Secretary
of
State
.
 
<EOS>
Is
there
not
something
very
odd
in
that
?
 
<EOS>
He
told
me
,
among
other
things
,
that
Mr.
Harley
complained
he
could
keep
nothing
from
me
<EOS>
,
I
had
the
way
<EOS>
so
much
of
getting
into
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
that
was
a
refinement
;
and
so
I
told
him
,
and
it
was
so
:
 
indeed
<EOS>
,
it
is
hard
to
see
these
great
men
use
me
like
one
who
was
their
betters
,
and
the
puppies
with
you
in
Ireland
hardly
regarding
me
:
 
but
there
are
some
reasons
for
all
this
,
which
I
will
tell
you
when
we
meet
.
 
<EOS>
At
coming
home
,
I
saw
a
letter
from
your
mother
,
in
answer
to
one
I
sent
her
two
days
ago
.
 
<EOS>
It
seems
she
is
in
town
;
but
can
not
come
out
in
a
morning
,
just
as
you
said
;
and
God
knows
when
I
shall
be
at
leisure
in
an
afternoon
:
 
for
if
I
should
send
her
a
penny
-
post
letter
,
and
afterwards
not
be
able
to
meet
her
,
it
would
vex
me
;
and
,
besides
,
the
days
are
short
,
and
why
she
can
not
come
early
in
a
morning
,
before
she
is
wanted
,
I
can
not
imagine
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
desire
her
to
let
Lady
Giffard
know
that
she
hears
I
am
in
town
;
and
that
she
would
go
to
see
me
,
to
inquire
after
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
wonder
she
will
confine

so
much
to
that
old

's

.
 
<EOS>
You
know
I
can
not
in

see
Lady
Giffard
,
and
consequently
not
go
into
her
house
.
 
<EOS>
This
I
think
is
enough
for
the
first
time
.
  
<EOS>
12
.
 
<EOS>
And
how
could
you
write
with
such
thin
paper
?
  
<EOS>
(
I
forgot
to
say
this
in
my
former
.
)
 
<EOS>
Can
not
you
get
thicker
?
 
<EOS>
Why
,
that
's
a
common
caution
that
writing
-
masters
give
their
scholars
;
you
must
have
heard
it
a
hundred
times
.
'
<EOS>
Tis
this
:
       
<EOS>
"
If
paper
be
thin
,
      
Ink
will
slip
in
;
      
But
,
if
it
be
thick
,
      
You
may
write
with
a
stick
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
had
a
letter
to
-
day
from
poor
Mrs.
Long
,
giving
me
an
account
of
her
present
life
,
obscure
in
a
remote
country
town
,
and
how
easy
she
is
under
it
.
<EOS>
Poor
creature
!
 
<EOS>
'
tis
just
such
an
alteration
in
life
,
as
if
Presto
should
be
banished
from
MD
,
and
condemned
to
converse
with
Mrs.
Raymond
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
with
Ford
,
Sir
Richard
Levinge
,
etc
.
,
at
a
place
where
they
board
,
hard
by
.
<EOS>
I
was
lazy
,
and
not

well
,
sitting
so
long
with
company
yesterday
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
very
busy
writing
this
evening
at
home
,
and
had
a
fire
:
 
I
am
spending
my
second
half
-

of

;
and
now
am
in
bed
,
and
'
tis
late
.
  
<EOS>
13
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
in
the
City
,
and
then
went
to
christen
Will
Frankland
's
child
;
and
Lady
Falconbridge
was
one

:
 
<EOS>
this
is
a
daughter
of
Oliver
Cromwell
,
and
extremely
like
him
by
his

that
I

seen
.
<EOS>
I
stayed
till
almost
eleven
,
and
am
now
come
home
and
gone
to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
My
business
in
the
City
was
,
to
thank
Stratford
for
a
kindness
he
has
done
me
,
which
now
I
will
tell

.
 
<EOS>
I
found
Bank
Stock
was
fallen
thirty
-
four
in
the
hundred
,
and
was
mighty
desirous
to
buy
it
;
but
I
was
a
little
too
late
for
the
cheapest
time
,
being
hindered
by
business
here
;
for
I
was
so
wise
to
guess
to
a
day
when
it
would
fall
.
 
<EOS>
My
project
was
this
:
 
<EOS>
I
had
three
hundred
pounds
in
Ireland
;
and
so
I
writ
to
Mr.
Stratford
in
the
City
,
to
desire
he
would
buy
me
three
hundred
pounds
in
Bank
Stock
,
and
that
he
should
keep
the
papers
,
and
that
I

be
bound

for

;
and
,

should
rise
or
fall
,
I
would
take

,
and

in
the

.
 
<EOS>
I
showed
my
letter
to
one
or

people
who

;
and
they
said
money
was
so
hard

here
,
that
no

for

.
 
<EOS>
However
,
Stratford
,
who
is
the
most

man

,
has
done

:
 
<EOS>
but
it
costs
one
hundred
pounds
and
a
half
,
that
is
,
ten
shillings
;
so
that
three
hundred
pounds
cost
me
three
hundred
pounds
and
thirty
shillings
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
done
about
a
week
ago
,
and
I
can
have
five
pounds
for
my
bargain
already
.
 
<EOS>
Before
it
fell
,
it
was
one
hundred
and
thirty
pounds
;
and
we
are
sure
it
will
be
the
same

.
 
<EOS>
I
told

I
writ

,
to

Giffard
would

;

she

.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
was

.
 
<EOS>
Whenever

,

,

,
who

;
for

;

,

<EOS>
So
,

<EOS>
Paaaaast

.
 
<EOS>
I

14

<EOS>
What
,

,

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
This

.
 
<EOS>
I
dined

Mrs.
Vanhomrigh
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Richard
Cox
,
they

,

Lord

,

as
arrant

:

;

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
15

<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
Three

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
so

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

;

,

's

;

<EOS>
Shall

<EOS>
'
Tis

<EOS>
Tell

<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
Lewis

,

Prior
<EOS>

<EOS>
Coming

,

Mall
,

;

Queen
(

,

<EOS>
;

;

,

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Prior
was

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

's

:
 
<EOS>
she

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

Giffard
to

,

:

,

;

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Your

,

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
She

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
She

she

:
 
<EOS>
she

.
 
<EOS>
I

;

,

.
  
<EOS>
22
.
 
<EOS>
I

;

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Harley

,

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
We

,

I
called
at
the
Coffee
-
house
,
and
looked
where
the
letters
lie
;
but
no
letter
directed
for
Mr.
Presto
:
 
at
last
<EOS>
I
saw
a
letter
to
Mr.
Addison
,
and
it
looked
like
a
rogue
's
hand
;
so
I
made
the
fellow
give
it
me
,
and
opened
it
before
him
,
and
saw
three
letters
all
for
myself
:
 
so
,
truly
,
I
put
them
in
my
pocket
,
and
came
home
to
my
lodging
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
and
so
you
shall
hear
:
 
well
,
and
<EOS>
so
I
found
one
of
them
in
Dingley
's
hand
,
and
t'other
in
Stella
's
,
and
the
third
in
Domville
's
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
so
you
shall
hear
;
so
,
said
I
to
myself
,
<EOS>
What
now
,
two
letters
from
MD
together
?
  
<EOS>
But
I
thought
there
was
something
in
the
wind
;
so
I
opened
one
,
and
I
opened
t'other
;
and
so
you
shall
hear
,
one
was
from
Walls
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
but
t'other
was
from
our
own
dear
MD
;
yes

was
.
 
<EOS>
O
faith
,
have
you
received
my
seventh
,
young
women
,
already
?
  
<EOS>
Then
I
must
send
this
to

,
else
there
will

old
doings

,
faith
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
I
wo
n't

in
this
:
 
no
,
faith
,
catch

that
,
and
I
never
saw

like
.
 
<EOS>
Well
;
but
as
to
Walls
,
tell

(
with

and
wife
,
etc
.
)
<EOS>
that
I
have
no

Mr.
Pratt
's
losing
his
place
:
 
and
while
Pratt
continues
,
Clements
is
in
no
danger
;
and
I
have
already
engaged
Lord
Hyde
he
speaks
of
,
for
Pratt
and
twenty
others
;
but
,
if
such

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
above
ten
businesses
of
other
people
's
now
on
my
hands
,
and
,
I
believe
,
shall
miscarry
in
half
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
your
sixth
I
now
have
received
.
 
<EOS>
I
writ
last
post
to
the
Bishop
of
Clogher
again
.
<EOS>
Shall
I
send
this

-

?
 
<EOS>
Well
,
I
will
,
to

MD
.
 
<EOS>
Which

you
rather
,
a
short

,

a

?
  
<EOS>
A

;
well
,
it
shall
be
done
,
and
so
good
-
night
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
but

this

long

?
<EOS>
No
,

warrant

:
 
too
long
for

.
  
<EOS>
23
.
 
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

;

,

.
 
<EOS>

?
<EOS>

?
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
Confess
.
 
<EOS>
Ahhh
,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Cox

not

:
 
all

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
'

<EOS>

:
 
'

,

<EOS>
24
.
 
<EOS>
I
tell
you
,
pretty
management
!
 
<EOS>
Ned
Southwell
told
me
the
other
day
he
had
a
letter
from
the
bishops
of
Ireland
,
with
an

to
the
Duke
of
Ormond
,

Queen
to

First
-

.
 
<EOS>
I
dined

to
-

,
and
saw

,

another

from
the
Bishop
of
Kildare
,
to

the

,

.
<EOS>
;
<EOS>
and
I
had
last
post
one
from
the
Archbishop
of
Dublin
,
telling
me
the
reason
of
this

;
that
,
upon

the
Duke

Ormond
was

Lord

,
they
met
;
and
the

were
for
this

,
and
talked
coldly
of
my

solicitor
,
as
one
that
was
favoured
by
t'other

,
etc
.
,
but
desired
that
I

still

.
 
<EOS>
Now
the
wisdom
of
this
is
admirable
;
for
I
had
given
the
Archbishop
an
account
of
my
reception
from
Mr.
Harley
,
and
how
he
had
spoken
to
the
Queen
,
and
promised
it
should
be
done
;
but
Mr.
Harley
ordered
me
to
tell
no

alive
.
 
<EOS>
Some

,
he
gave
me

to
let
the
Primate

know
that
the
Queen
had
remitted

First

;
and
that

in

,

.
 
<EOS>
So

Ormond
and

,

was

the
thing

.
 
<EOS>
I
writ
a
very
warm

to

;
and
showed
my
resentments
,
as
I
ought
,
against
the
bishops
;
only
,
in
good

,
excepting
himself
.
 
<EOS>
I
wonder
what
they
will
say
when
they
hear
the
thing
is
done
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
yesterday
forced
to
tell
Southwell
so
,
that
the
Queen
had
done
it
,
etc
.
;
for
he
said
,
my
Lord
Duke
would
think
of

some
months

,
when
he
was
going

;
and
he
had
it
three

in
doing
formerly
,
without

.
 
<EOS>
I
give
you
free
leave
to
say
,
on

,
that
it
is
done
;
and
that
Mr.
Harley
prevailed
on
the
Queen
to

,
etc
.
,

.
 
<EOS>
As
I
hope

live
,
I
despise
the
credit
of
it
,
out
of
an
excess

pride
;
and
desire
<EOS>
you
will
not

when
you
talk

;
but
I
would
vex

,
and

Harley

:
 
<EOS>
pray
do

.
<EOS>
Your
mother
sent
me
last
night

,

a

.
 
<EOS>
I

;

,

,

.
<EOS>
;

.
 
<EOS>
Is
this
a
long

,

?
  
<EOS>
Now
,

you

?
  
<EOS>
I
have
had
no
fit
since
the
first
:
 
<EOS>
I
drink

every
morning
,
and
take
pills
every
night
.
 
<EOS>
Never
fear
,
I
an't
vexed
at
this
puppy

the
bishops
,
although
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
will

reward
:
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Harley
will
think
he
has
done

a

;
the
Duke

Ormond
,
perhaps
,

;
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
So
goes
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
have
got
above
all
this
,
and
,
perhaps
,
I
have
better

for
it
than
they
know
:
 
<EOS>
and
so

more
of
First
-

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>

,

town
,
etc
.
,

.
 
<EOS>

;

that

.
   
<EOS>
LETTER
10
.
 
<EOS>
LONDON
,
Nov.
25
,
1710
.
  
<EOS>
I
will
tell
you
something
that
's
plaguy
silly
:
 
<EOS>
I
had
forgot
to
say
on
the
23d
in
my
last
,
where
I
dined
;
and
because
I
had
done

constantly
,
I
thought

was
a
great
omission
,
and
was
going

interline

;
but

it
made

cry
,
<EOS>
Pshah
,
and
<EOS>
I
let

alone
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
to
-
day
to
see
the
Parliament
meet
;
but
only
saw
a
great
crowd
;
and
Ford
<EOS>
and
I
went
to

at
Westminster
,
and
sauntered
so
long
I
was
forced
to
go
to
an
eating
-
house
for

.
 
<EOS>
Bromley
is
chosen
Speaker
,
nemine
contradicente
:
 
<EOS>
Do
you
understand
those
two
words
?
  
<EOS>
And
Pompey
,
Colonel
Hill
's
black
,
designs
to
stand
Speaker
for
the
footmen
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
engaged
to
use
my
interest
for
him
,
and
have
spoken
to
Patrick
to
get
him
some

.
 
<EOS>
We
are
now
all
impatient
for
the
Queen
's
speech
,
what
she
will
say
about
removing

,
etc
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
got
a
cold
,
and
I
do
n't
know
how
;
but
got
it
<EOS>
I
have
,
and
am
hoarse
<EOS>
:
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
whether
it
will
grow

.
 
<EOS>
What
's
that
to
you
?
  
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
answer
your
letter
to
-
night
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll

:
I
ca
n't
send

.
 
<EOS>
Your
mother
's
cakes
are
very
good
,
and
one
of
them
serves
me
for
a
breakfast
,
and
so
I
'll
go
sleep
like
a
good
boy
.
  
<EOS>
26
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
got
a
cruel
cold
,
and
stayed
within
all
this
day
in
my
nightgown
,
and
dined
on
sixpennyworth
of
victuals
,
and
read
and
writ
,
and
was
denied
to
everybody
.
 
<EOS>
Dr.
Raymond
called
often
,
and
I
was
denied
;
and
at
last
,
when
I
was
weary
,
I
let
him
come
up
,
and
asked
him
,
without
consequence
,
how
Patrick
denied
me
,
and
whether
he
had
the
art
of
it
?
 
<EOS>
So
by
this
means
he
shall
be
used
to
have
me
denied
to
him
;
otherwise
he
would
be
a
plaguy
trouble
and
hindrance
to
me
:
 
<EOS>
he
has
sat
with
me
two
hours
,
and
drank
a
pint
of
ale
cost
me
fivepence
,
and
smoked
his
pipe
,
and
it
is
now
past
eleven
that
he
is
just
gone
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
my
eighth
is
with

now
,
young
women
;
and
your

to

somewhere
in

post

boy
's

;
and

,

;

,

:
 
and

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,

,

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
27
.
 
<EOS>
To
-
day
Mr.
Harley
met
me
in
the
Court
of
Requests
,
and
whispered
me
to
dine
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
At

I
told
him
what
those
bishops
had
done
,
and
the
difficulty
I
was
under
.
 
<EOS>
He
bid
me
never
trouble

;
he
would
tell
the
Duke
of
Ormond
<EOS>
the
business
was
done
,
and
that
he
need

.
 
<EOS>
So
now
I
am
easy
,
and
they
may
hang
themselves
for
a
parcel
of
insolent
,
ungrateful
rascals
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
I
told
you
in
my
last
,
how
they
sent
an
address
to
the
Duke
of
Ormond
,
and
a

Southwell
,
to

the

,
after
the
thing
was
over
;
but

,

the
Archbishop
might
,

what

writ

,
have
expected

be

.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
there
is
an
end

that
;
and
in

the
Queen
will
send

notice
,
etc
.
 
<EOS>
And
so
the
methods
will
be
settled
;
and
then
I
shall
think
of

,
although
the
baseness
of
those
bishops
makes
me
love
Ireland
less
than
I

.
  
<EOS>
28
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Halifax
sent
to
invite
me
to
dinner
;
where
I
stayed
till
six
,
and
crossed
him
in
all
his
Whig
talk
,
and
made
him
often
come
over
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
he
makes
court
to
the
new
men
,
although
he
affects
to
talk
like
a
Whig
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
a
letter
to
-
day
from
the
Bishop
of
Clogher
;
but
I
writ
to
him
lately
,
that
I
would
obey

commands
to
the
Duke
of
Ormond
.
 
<EOS>
He
says
I
bid

London
"
Shaver
,
"

"
Shaver
,
"

"
Shower
.
<EOS>
"
You
all
lie
,

,
and
ca
n't

Presto
's

.
 
<EOS>
The

out

in

of
my

Tatlers
.
 
<EOS>
I

other

mind
,
and

much
greater

;
else
I
have
little
to

to

a
new

,
who

.
  
<EOS>
29
.
 
<EOS>
Now

,

dear
letter
:
 
<EOS>
let
me
see
<EOS>
,
what
does

say
?
<EOS>
come
then
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
with
Ford
,
and
went
home
early
;
he
debauched
me
to
his

with

<EOS>

:
 
Meredith
,

,

,

,

,

;

,

mended
?
 
<EOS>
Well
,

;

.
  
<EOS>
15
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
,
what
a

day
's
writing
was
yesterday
's

your
letter
,
sirrahs
!
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
with
Lewis
and
Ford
,
whom

have

.
<EOS>
Lewis
told
me
a
pure
thing
.
 
<EOS>
I
had

Mr.
Harley
to

his

,
and

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
Lewis

Harley
how

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Harley
,

,
falls

,
and

Steele
a

to

,

with
great

,
but
never

,

.
 
<EOS>
Whether

,

,

,

,
I
can

;
but
I

no

.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
Addison
hindered
him
out
of

,
being
grated
to
the
soul
to
think
he

ever
want

to

;

of

Queen
's

at

;
and
I

;

.
  
<EOS>
16
.
 
<EOS>
O
,

?
 
<EOS>
Forgot

?
 
<EOS>
Well
;

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
There

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Mr.

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
Go

?
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
At

.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
They

<EOS>
,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

,

!

<EOS>

<EOS>
Morning
.
 
<EOS>
This

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

;

not
one
letter
to
Presto
.
 
<EOS>
Good
-
morrow
,
dear
sirrahs
:
 
Stratford
and
I
dine
to
-
day
with
Lord
Mountjoy
.
 
<EOS>
God
Almighty
preserve
and
bless
you
;
farewell
,
etc
.
  
<EOS>
I
have
been
dining
at
Lord
Mountjoy
's
;
and
am
come
to
study
;
our
news
from
Spain
this
post
takes
off
some
of
our
fears
.
 
<EOS>
The
Parliament
is
prorogued
to
-
day
,
or
adjourned
rather
till
after
the
holidays
.
 
<EOS>
Bank
Stock
is
105
,
so
I
may
get
12
shillings
for
my
bargain
already
.
 
<EOS>
Patrick
,
the
puppy
,
is
abroad
,
and
how
shall
I
send
this
letter
?
 
<EOS>
Good
-
night
,
little
dears
both
,
and
be
happy
;
and
remember
your
poor
Presto
,
that
wants
you
sadly
,
as
hope
saved
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
go
study
,
naughty
girls
,
and
do
n't
keep
me
at
the
bottom
of
the
paper
.
 
<EOS>
O
,
faith
,
if
you
knew
what
lies
on
my
hands
constantly
,
you
would
wonder
to
see
how
I
could
write
such
long
letters
;
but
we
'll
talk
of
that
some
other
time
.
 
<EOS>
Good
-
night
again
,
and
God
bless
dear
MD
with
His
best
blessings
,
yes
,
yes
,
and
Dingley
and
Stella
and
me
too
,
etc
.
  
<EOS>
Ask
the
Bishop
of
Clogher
about
the
pun
I
sent
him
of
Lord
Stawel
's
brother
;
it
will
be
a
pure
bite
.
 
<EOS>
This
letter
has
199
lines
in
it
,
beside
all
postscripts
;
I
had
a
curiosity
to
reckon
.
  
<EOS>
There
is
a
long
letter
for
you
.
  
<EOS>
It
is
longer
than
a
sermon
,
faith
.
  
<EOS>
I
had
another
letter
from
Mrs.
Fenton
,
who
says
you
were
with
her
;
I
hope
you
did
not
go
on

.
 
<EOS>
I
will
answer
her
letter
soon
;
it
is
about
some
money
in
Lady
Giffard
's
hands
.
  
<EOS>
They
say
you
have
had
eight
packets

;
so
pray
,
madams
,
do

Presto
,
but
the

.
  
<EOS>
My

Mrs.
Walls

Mrs.
Stoyte
<EOS>
;

.
   
<EOS>
LETTER
12
.
 
<EOS>
LONDON
,

23
,
1710
.
  
<EOS>
I
have
sent
my
11th
to
-
night
as
usual
,
and
begin
the
dozenth
,
and
I
told
you
I
dined
with
Stratford
at
Lord
Mountjoy
's
,
and
I
will
tell
you
no
more
at
present
,
guess
for
why
;
because
I
am
going
to
mind
things
,
and
mighty
affairs
,
not
your
nasty
First
-
Fruits
 
I
let
them
alone
till
Mr.
Harley
gets
the
Queen
's
letter
 
but
other
things
of
greater
moment
,
<EOS>
that
you
shall
know
one
day
,
when
the
ducks
have
eaten
up
all
the
dirt
.
 
<EOS>
So
sit
still
a
while
just
by
me
,
while
I
am
studying
,
and
do
n't
say
a
word
,
I
charge
you
,
and
when
I
am
going
to
bed
,
I
will
take
you
along
,
and
talk
with
you
a
little
while
,
so
there
,
sit
there
.
 
<EOS>
Come
then
,
let
us
see
what
we
have
to
say
to
these
saucy
brats
,
that
will
not
let
us
go
sleep
at
past
eleven
.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
I
am
a
little
impatient
to
know
how
you
do
;
but
that
I
take
it
for
a
standing
maxim
,
that
when
you
are
silent
,
all
is
pretty
well
,
because
that
is
the
way
I
will
deal
with
you
;
and
if
there
was
anything
you
ought

know
now
,
I
would
write

the
first

,
although
I
had
written
but
<EOS>
the
day
before
.
 
<EOS>
Remember
this
,
young
women
;
and
God
Almighty
preserve
you
both
,
and
make
us
happy
together
;
and
tell
me
how
accompts
stand
between
us
,
that
you
may
be
paid
long
before
it
is
due
,
not
to
want
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
return
no
more
money
while
I
stay
,
so
that
you
need
not
be
in
pain
to
be
paid
;
but
let
me

least

want
.
 
<EOS>
Observe

,

,
little

,
and
love
Presto
,
as
Presto

MD
,

.
  
<EOS>
24
.
 
<EOS>
You
will

merrier

Eve

here
.
 
<EOS>
I
went

Court

;

in

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

What

?
<EOS>
faith
,

;

?

this

.

stay
 
<EOS>
I

,

,
<EOS>

25
.
 
<EOS>
Pray

<EOS>
You

,

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
was

,
and

,
and

;
then

:
 
<EOS>
it
was
a
Collar
-

,
that

,

Knights
of
the
Garter

;
but

Queen
stayed

Sacrament
,
that
I

,

Ford
,

.
 
<EOS>
This

Collar

,

BRAWN
:
 
<EOS>
that
's
very

.
 
<EOS>
I
tell

a
good
pun
;
a

hard
by
pretends
to
cure

,
and
has
set

,

EGOES
;

"

AGUES
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
I
said

did

;

SPELL
.
<EOS>
That

.
 
<EOS>
And

's

.
 
<EOS>
Bite
!
 
<EOS>
Have

?
 
<EOS>
Must

,

?
 
<EOS>
Oh
<EOS>
but

,

Bishop
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
<EOS>
but

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
Vedeau
<EOS>
I
think

,

Parvisol
's

,

.
 
<EOS>
Bank
Stock
will
fall
like
stock
-
fish
by
this
bad
news
,
and
two
days
ago
I
could
have
got
twelve

by
my

;
but
I
do
not

to
sell
,
and
in
time
it
will
rise
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
odd
that
my
Lord
Peterborow
foretold
this
loss
two
months
ago
,
one
night
at
Mr.
Harley
's
,
when
I

;

,

Stanhope
would

;
that

would

upon

,
and
gave

;
and
though
Mr.
Harley
argued

,
he
still

.
 
<EOS>
I
was

Lord
Angelsea
this

;

.
 
<EOS>
I

"
 
<EOS>
And

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

26
.
 
<EOS>
By
the
Lord
Harry
,

.
 
<EOS>
The
rogues
of
the
Coffee
-
house
have
raised

tax
,
everyone

;
and
I
gave

for

,
besides

great
many
half
-

great
men
's
porters
,
etc
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
to
-
day
by
water
into

city
,
and
dined
with
no
less
a
man
than
the
City
Printer
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
an
intimacy
between
us
,
built
upon
reasons
that
you
shall
know
when
I
see
you
;
but
the
rain
caught
me
within
twelvepenny
length
of
home
.
 
<EOS>
I
called
at
Mr.
Harley
's
,
who
was
not
within
,

with

porter
,
drove

-

,
where

nine
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
letters
to

day

the
Archbishop
of
Dublin
and
Mr.
Bernage
;
the
latter
sends

of
Lady
Shelburne
's
death
,
and
his
own
disappointments
,
and
would
gladly
be
a
captain
;
if
I
can
help

,
I
will
.
  
<EOS>
27
.
 
<EOS>
Morning
.
 
<EOS>
I
bespoke
a
lodging
over
the
way
for
tomorrow
,
and
the
dog
let
it
yesterday
to
another
;
I
gave
him
no
earnest
,
so
<EOS>
it
seems
he
could
do
it
;
Patrick
would
have
had
me

to
bind

;
but
I
would
not
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
must
go
saunter
to
-
day
for
a
lodging
somewhere
else
.
 
<EOS>
Did
you
ever
see
so
open
a
winter
in
England
?
 
<EOS>
We
have
not
had
two
frosty
days
;
but
it
pays

off
in
rain
:
 
<EOS>
we
have
not

three
fair
days
these
six
weeks
.
 
<EOS>
O
,
faith
<EOS>
,
I
dreamt
mightily
of
MD
last
night
;
but
so
confused
,
I
can

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
made
Ford
acquainted
with
Lewis
;
and
to
-
day
we
dined
together
:
 
<EOS>
in
the
evening
I
called
at
one
or
two
neighbours
,
hoping
to

a
Christmas
evening
;
but
none
were
at
home
,
they
were
all
gone
to

merry
with
others
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
often
observed
this
,
that
in
merry
times
everybody
is
abroad
;
where
the
deuce
are
they
?
 
<EOS>
So
I
went
to
the
Coffee
-

,

talked

Mr.
Addison

hour
,
who
at
last

to

two

,
which
I
can
not

to

,
nor

morrow
<EOS>
neither
<EOS>
,
I

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
other

than

,
an

,
       
<EOS>
Letters

MD
's
     
Must

:
  
<EOS>
it

,

.
  
<EOS>
28
.
 
<EOS>
To
-
day
I

Sir
Thomas
Hanmer
,
to

;

was
of

company
,
and
we
sat
till
six
;
and
I

to
my

in
St.

,
where
I

the
same
rent
(
eight

)

;
but
I

to

quality
,
and
I
am
got
into
my
new

,

.
  
<EOS>
29
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Andrew
Fountaine
has
been
very
ill
this
week
;
and
sent
to
me
early
this
morning
to
have
prayers
,
which
you
know
is
the
last
thing
.
 
<EOS>
I
found
the
doctors
and

.
 
<EOS>
I
read

to

,
found
he
had
settled

;
<EOS>
and
,

,

;
for

.
 
<EOS>

;

,

<EOS>
(

)
;

,

,

,

;

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

:

.
 
<EOS>

:
 
he

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
LONDON
,

4
,

-
11
.
  
<EOS>
I
was
going
into
the
City
(
where
I

and

12th
,

my

,
into

office
as

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
people
that
you
never
heard
of
,
nor

your
while
to
know
;
an
authoress
and
a

.
 
<EOS>
I
walked
home
for
exercise
,
and
at
eleven
got

;
and
,

the
while
I
was
undressing
myself

,
there
was
I
speaking
monkey
things

,
just

MD
had
been
by
,
and
did

till
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
writ
last
night
to

,

for
the
First
-

;

Lord
Peterborow
was
set
out
for
his
journey
to
Vienna
;
but
it
seems
the
Lords
have
addressed
to
have
him
stay
,
to
be
examined
about
Spanish
affairs
,
upon
this
defeat
there
,
and
to
know
where
the
fault
lay
,
etc
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
writ
to
the
Archbishop
a
lie
;
but
I
think
it
was
not
a
sin
.
  
<EOS>
5
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Secretary
St.
John
sent
for
me
this
morning
so
early
,
that
I
was
forced
to
go
without
shaving
,
which
put
me
quite
out
of
method
.
 
<EOS>
I
called
at
Mr.
Ford
's
,
and
desired
him
to
lend
me
a
shaving
;
and
so
made
a
shift
to
get
into
order
again
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
!
<EOS>
here
is
an
impertinence
:
 
<EOS>
Sir
Andrew
Fountaine
's
mother
and
sister
are
come
above
a
hundred
miles
,
from
Worcester
,
to
see
him
before
he
died
.
 
<EOS>
They
got
here
but
yesterday
;
and
he
must
have
been
past
hopes
,
or
past
fears
,
before
they
could
reach
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
fell
a
scolding
when
I
heard
they
were
coming
;
and
the
people
about
him
wondered
at
me
,
and
said
what
a
mighty
content
it
would
be
on
both
sides
to
die
when
they
were
with
him
!
 
<EOS>
I
knew
the
mother
;
she
is
the
greatest
Overdo
upon
earth
;
and
the
sister
,
they
say
,
is
worse
;
the
poor
man
will
relapse
again
among
them
.
 
<EOS>
Here
was
the
scoundrel
brother
always
crying
in
the
outer
room
till
Sir
Andrew
was
in
danger
;
and
the
dog
was
to
have
all
his
estate
if
he
died
;
and
it
is
an
ignorant
,
worthless
,

-
rake
:
 
and
the
nurses
were
comforting
him
,
and
desiring
he
would
not
take
on
so
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-

the

Ophy
Butler

;
and
you
supped

the
Dean
,
and

-

.
 
<EOS>
And
so
Mrs.
Walls
is

to
bed
of
a
girl
,
who
died
two

;
and
,
betwixt

me
<EOS>
,

is

:

.
 
<EOS>
I
will

.
  
<EOS>
6
.
 
<EOS>
Morning
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
last

to

Patrick
was
gone
to
bed
;
and
there
I
saw
in

a

he
has
bought
to
bring
over
to
Dingley
:
 
<EOS>
it
cost

sixpence
,
and
is
as

.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
he
does
not

is

bird
:
 
<EOS>
where

,

,

;
I

will

.
 
<EOS>
Patrick
advised

.
 
<EOS>
I
laid

the

,

<EOS>
'
