<EOS>

<EOS>
Mr.

;

<EOS>
I

,

;

's
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
talk
politics
.
 
<EOS>
I
protest
I
am
afraid
we
shall
all
be

with

.
 
<EOS>
The
Whigs
,
now
they
are
fallen
,
are
the
most
malicious
toads
in
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
had
now
a
second
misfortune
,
the
loss
of
several
Virginia
ships
.
 
<EOS>
I
fear
people
will
begin
to
think
that
nothing
thrives
under
this
Ministry
:
 
and
if
the
Ministry
can
once
be
rendered
odious
to
the
people
,
the
Parliament
may
be
chosen
Whig

Tory

.
<EOS>
Then
I
think

friends
press
a

on

Duke

Marlborough
.
<EOS>
The
country
members
are
violent

into
,

have

;
but
I
do
not

.
 
<EOS>
In

Peace
;
and
I
am

;
and
then

Whigs
will
bawl
what

.
 
<EOS>
I

;

,

,

,

,

not

;

.
 
<EOS>
The

hear

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
Meantime
,

,

,

.

?

<EOS>
Our
frost
holds
like
a
dragon
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
to
Mr.
Addison
's
,
and
dined
with
him
at
his
lodgings
;
I
had
not
seen
him
these
three
weeks
,
we
are
grown
common
acquaintance
;
yet
what
have
not
I
done
for
his
friend
Steele
?
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Harley
reproached
me
the
last
time
I
saw
him
,
that
to
please
me
he
would
be
reconciled
to
Steele
,
and
had
promised
and
appointed
to
see
him
,
and
that
Steele
never
came
.
 
<EOS>
Harrison
,
whom
Mr.
Addison
recommended
to
me
,
I
have
introduced
to
the
Secretary
of
State
,
who
has
promised
me
to
take
care
of
him
;
and
I
have
represented
Addison
himself
so
to
the
Ministry
,
that
they
think
and
talk
in
his
favour
,
though
they
hated
him
before
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
he
is
now
in
my
debt
,
and
there
's
an
end
;
and
I
never
had
the
least
obligation
to
him
,
and
there
's
another
end
.
 
<EOS>
This
evening
I
had
a
message
from
Mr.
Harley
,
desiring
to
know
whether
I
was
alive
,
and
that
I
would
dine
with
him
to
-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
They
dine
so
late
,
that
since
my
head
has
been
wrong
I
have
avoided
being
with
them
.
  
<EOS>
Patrick
has
been
out
of
favour
these
ten
days
;
I
talk
dry
and
cross
to
him
,
and
have
called
him
"
friend
"
three
or
four
times
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
sirrahs
,

.

5
.

Morning
.
 
<EOS>

;

ca

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Mr.

,

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

;

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
6
.
 
<EOS>
Here

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
All

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

,

<EOS>
Mr.
Ford

.
 
<EOS>
Did

Patrick

,

?
 
<EOS>
It
was
very

,
and
'

.
 
<EOS>
He
keeps

,

;
but

:
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
When

MD
's

?
 
<EOS>
One

.
 
<EOS>
This

,

,

<EOS>
Mr.
Harley

;

:
 
<EOS>
and

.
  
<EOS>
7
.
 
<EOS>
I

Lewis

,

have

,

let

know
I
expect

.
 
<EOS>
If

let

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
promises

,

;
but
I
wo
n't
,
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
'll

,

.
 
<EOS>
In
that
he
did
something
,
which
he
intended

a

;
and
I
have
taken

quite

,
disliking

the

the

,
and
it
has
heartily

,

all

,

;
and
I
absolutely

to
submit

his
intended

,
and
expect

.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Ford
and
I
dined
with
Mr.
Lewis
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
a
monstrous
deal

snow
,
and
it
has

me
two

to
-
day
in
chair

,
and
walked
till

was
dirty

.
 
<EOS>
I
know
not
what

is

.
 
<EOS>
The

do
up

to
our
MD
,
and

,
and
put

,

so

.
 
<EOS>
But

,

.

8
.
 
<EOS>
Morning
.
 
<EOS>
I
HAVE
DESIRED

<EOS>
Pray
,

?
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
But
party
carries

nowadays
,

about

that

,

!
 
<EOS>
Pray

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
Why
 
ay
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
At

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
Do

<EOS>
We

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
It

.

9
.
 
<EOS>
Morning
.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.

Is

?

,

<EOS>
O

"

,

,

<EOS>
O
,
faith
<EOS>
,

<EOS>
I

MD
,

.
  
<EOS>
But

:
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
As

Goodman

,

.
 
<EOS>
Fie
,

,

:
 
and

,

<EOS>
Sir

;

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
And

MD

?
 
<EOS>
I
'm

it

.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,

done

:
 
<EOS>
it

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
You

.
 
<EOS>
Twelve

box
<EOS>
;

.
 
<EOS>
No

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

:
 
<EOS>
nobody

,

.
  
<EOS>
The

<EOS>

<EOS>
Nobody

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Poor

's

!
 
<EOS>
God

,

.
 
<EOS>
Pray

,

<EOS>
How

,

?
 
<EOS>
Pretty

,

<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
Stay

I

:
 
<EOS>
he

:
 
<EOS>
so

.
 
<EOS>
Well
,

.
  
<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>
The

does
not

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Harley

:
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
You

<EOS>
Morning
.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
Do

<EOS>
A
t

.
<EOS>
It

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
I

,

,

;

,

:
 
<EOS>
then
I

Congreve
,

;

.
 
<EOS>
He

Tatler
he

written

,
as
blind

is
,
for
little
Harrison
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
about
a
scoundrel
that
was
grown
rich
,
and
went
and
bought

arms
at

Herald
's
,

at
Fleet

;
'

,

,
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
It
is
now
between
ten
and

,
and
I
am
going
to
bed
.
  
<EOS>
14
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
Mrs.
Vanhomrigh
's
daughter
's
birthday
,
and
Mr.
Ford
and
I
were
invited
to
dinner
to
keep
it
,
and
we
spent
the
evening
there
,
drinking
punch
.
 
<EOS>
That
was
our
way
of
beginning
Lent
;
and
in
the
morning
Lord
Shelburne
,
Lady
Kerry
,
Mrs.
Pratt
,
and
I
,
went
to
Hyde
Park
,
instead
of
going
to
church
;
for
,
till
my
head
is
a
little
settled
,
I
think
it
better
not
to
go
;
it
would
be
so
silly
and
troublesome
to
go
out
sick
.
 
<EOS>
Dr.
Duke
died
suddenly
two
or
three
nights
ago
;
he
was
one
of
the
wits
when
we
were
children
,
but
turned
parson
,
and
left
it
,
and
never
writ
farther
than
a
prologue
or
recommendatory
copy
of
verses
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
fine
living
given
him
by
the
Bishop
of
Winchester
about
three
months
ago
;
he
got
his
living
suddenly
,
and
he
got
his
dying
so
too
.
  
<EOS>
15
.
 
<EOS>
I
walked
purely
to
-
day
about
the
Park
<EOS>
,
the
rain
being
just
over
,
of
which
we
have
had
a
great
deal
,
mixed
with
little
short
frosts
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
to
the
Court
of
Requests
,
thinking
,
if
Mr.
Harley
dined
early
,
to
go
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
meeting
Leigh
and
Sterne
,
they
invited
me
to

,
and
away

.
 
<EOS>
When

his
room
,
one
H
#
#
#
#
,
a

fellow
,

there
,

;
so
I
stepped

,
and

,
that
I
would
not
dine
with
that
fellow
:
 
they
made

,
and

me
to

;
but
away

Mr.
Harley
's
,
and
he

;
and

at
Sir
John
Germaine
's
,
and
found
Lady
Betty
but

of

.
 
<EOS>
I
am

for
Lord
Berkeley
's

;
you

young
rake
his

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
She

in

,
and

'll

in

.
 
<EOS>
You
ladies
are
brave
,
bold
,

;
and
the
chit
is
but

,
and
is
ill

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
16
.
 
<EOS>
Faith
,
this
letter
goes
on

;
'
tis
a

old
,
and
the
first

not

.
 
<EOS>
I
went
to
-

into
the
City
for
a
walk
,
but

;

,

called

Congreve

,

Estcourt
,

<EOS>
;

Harley

,

;

,

,

has

,
which

(

)
that

<EOS>
Atterbury

.
 
<EOS>
Congreve
's

.
  
<EOS>
17
.
 
<EOS>
I
took

,

.
<EOS>
Lord

<EOS>

<EOS>

;

<EOS>

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
18
.
 
<EOS>
My

,

;

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Secretary

John
would
needs

;

,

:
 
<EOS>
so

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Peterborow
is
now

,
and

to

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
No
,

,

;

<EOS>
a

?
 
<EOS>
We

here

,
that

,

above

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

:
 
the

,

<EOS>
The

,

.
 
<EOS>
Lord

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

;

<EOS>

<EOS>
O

,

!
<EOS>
faith
,

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
Good

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
At
night
.
 
<EOS>
Lady
Kerry

to

lords

she

in

here
:
 
<EOS>
I
called

,
but

had

engaged
every

I

,
and
that

was

;
and
it
rained
like

;
so

took

,
for

,
and
dined

a

-
dog
in
the
City
,
and
walked
back
in

.
 
<EOS>
The
days
are
now
long
enough
to
walk
in
the
Park
after

;
and
so
I
do
whenever

is

.
 
<EOS>
This

is
a
strange
remedy
:
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Prior
walks
,
to
make
himself
fat
,
and
I
to
bring
myself
down
;
he
has
generally
a
cough
,
which
he
only
calls
a
cold
;
we
often
walk
round
the
Park
together
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
'll
go
sleep
.
  
<EOS>
22
.
 
<EOS>
It
snowed
all
this
morning
prodigiously
,
and
was
some
inches
thick
in

four

.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Mr.
Lewis
of
the
Secretary
's

:
 
<EOS>
the
chairmen
that
carried

against

,
who
wisely
turned

back
,
and
broke
one
of
the
side
-

in

.
 
<EOS>
I
fell

,
pretended
<EOS>
I
was
like

,
and

chair
in
the
Park
,
while

;
and
,

,

;
so

,

;
but

,
"

,
wo

<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
How

?
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

.

23
.
 
<EOS>
The

is
gone
every

,
except

.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Sterne
was
with

this

.
 
<EOS>
That
drab
Mrs.
Edgworth
is

,

infallibly
next

:
 
and

,

!
 
<EOS>
So

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
24
.
 
<EOS>
Morning
.
 
<EOS>
This

this

,

,

,

;

,

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

a

-

;

.
<EOS>
And

,

;

;
'
tis
as
good
as
our
Park
,
but
not
so
large
.
<EOS>
Faith
,
this
summer
we
'll
take
a
coach
for
sixpence
to
the
Green
Well
,
the
two
walks
,
and
thence
all
the
way
to
Stoyte
's
.
 
<EOS>
My
hearty
service
to
Goody
Stoyte
and
Catherine
;
and
<EOS>
I
hope
Mrs.
Walls
had
a
good
time
.
 
<EOS>
How
inconstant
I
am
!
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
imagine
I
was
ever
in
love
with
her
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
I
'm
going
;
what
have
you
to
say
?
 
<EOS>
I
DO
NOT
CARE
<EOS>
HOW
<EOS>
I
WRITE
NOW
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
design
to
write
on
this
side
;
these
few
lines
are
but
so
much
more
than
your
due
;
so
I
will
write
LARGE
or
small
as
I
please
.
 
<EOS>
O
,
faith
,
my
hands
are
starving
in
bed
;
I
believe
it
is
a
hard
frost
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
rise
,
and
bid
you
good
-
bye
,
for
I
'll
seal
this
letter
immediately
,
and
carry
it
in
my
pocket
,
and
put
it
into
the
post

office
with
my
own
fair
hands
.
 
<EOS>
Farewell
.
  
<EOS>
This
letter
is
just
a
fortnight
's
journal
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
and
so
it
is
,
I
'm
sure
,

,
with
your
two
eggs
a

.
  
<EOS>
Lele
,
lele
,
lele
.
  
<EOS>
O

,
I

lele
,
lele
,

:
 
and
,

talk

keys
,
that
dog
Patrick

the
key

general
of
the

of
drawers

locks
,

have

to

,

!
   
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
LONDON
,

.
  
<EOS>
Now
,
young
women
,
I
gave
in
my

this

.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Ford
<EOS>
(
it
was
his
Opera
-

)
<EOS>
as
usual
;
it
is

do
so
,
for
coming
home
early
after
a

in
the
Park
,
which
now
the
days
will
allow
.
 
<EOS>
I
called

,

Bernage
to

Argyle
;

,

,

,

,

,
as

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
So

.
 
<EOS>

,

and

<EOS>

late
.
  
<EOS>
25
.
 
<EOS>
The

out

,
and

will

MD
,
and
hope

that
Stella

:
 
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Can

<EOS>
Yes

We

<EOS>

26
.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Sir

<EOS>
Darteneuf

rare

I

<EOS>

,

;

;

.
  
<EOS>
2
.
 
<EOS>
This

undoes

.
 
<EOS>
I
was

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Sterne

;

;

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
But
,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

Lord
Abercorn
,

son
Peasley

.
  
<EOS>
3
.
 
<EOS>
I

's

:
<EOS>
he

,

.
 
<EOS>
My

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
Every

,
Lord

,

,

,

;

<EOS>
Patrick

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

MD

;

<EOS>
Oh

wo

<EOS>
An't
<EOS>
I
silly
?
<EOS>
faith
,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
He

well
,

.
 
<EOS>
So
I
came

,
like

,

.
  
<EOS>
4
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined

with
Mr.
Secretary
St.
John
;
and
after

Harley
,
that

was
much

.
 
<EOS>
Pray
God
preserve
his
health
!
<EOS>
everything
depends
upon
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
Parliament
at
present
can
not
go
a
step
without
him
,
nor
the
Queen
neither
.
 
<EOS>
I
long
to
be
in
Ireland
;
but
the
Ministry
beg
me
to
stay
:
 
however
,
when
this
Parliament
lurry
is
over
,
I
will
endeavour
to
steal
away
;
by
which
time
I
hope
the
First
-
Fruit
business
will
be
done
.
 
<EOS>
This
kingdom
is
certainly
ruined
as
much
as
was
ever
any
bankrupt
merchant
.
 
<EOS>
We
must
have
peace
,
let
it
be
a
bad
or
a
good
one
,
though
nobody
dares
talk
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
nearer
I
look
upon
things
,
the
worse
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
the
confederacy
will
soon
break
to
pieces
,
and
our
factions
at
home
increase
.
 
<EOS>
The
Ministry
is
upon
a
very
narrow
bottom
,
and
stand
like
an
isthmus
,
between
the
Whigs
on
one
side
,
and
violent
Tories
on
the
other
.
<EOS>
They
are
able
seamen
;
but
the
tempest
is
too
great
,
the
ship
too
rotten
,
and
the
crew
all
against

.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Somers
has
been
twice
in
the
Queen
's
closet
,
once
very

;
and
your
Duchess
of
Somerset
,
who
now

,
is
a
most

woman
;
and
I

will

same

that
has

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
told

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
They

so
much
against

,

she

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
Mr.
 
Walls

.
 
<EOS>
First
,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

Clements
:
 
I

,

;

,

,

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
I
wish
you
could
hinder
it
;
but
if
it
ca
n't
be
helped
,
pay
what
you
think
proper
,
and
get
the
Provost
to
stand
for
me
,
and
let
his
Christian
name
be
Harley
,
in
honour
of
my
friend
,
now
lying
stabbed
and
doubtful
of
his
life
.
 
<EOS>
As
for
Bernage
,
he
writes
me
word
that
his
colonel
has
offered
to
make
him
captain
-
lieutenant
for
a
hundred
pounds
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
such
a
fool
to
offer
him
money
without
writing
to
me
till
it
was
done
,
though
I
have
had
a
dozen
letters
from
him
;
and
then
he
desires
I
would
say
nothing
of
this
,
for
fear
his
colonel
should
be
angry
.
 
<EOS>
People
are
mad
.
 
<EOS>
What
can
I
do
?
 
<EOS>
I
engaged
Colonel
Disney
,
who
was
one
of
his
solicitors
to
the
Secretary
,
and
then
told
him
the
story
.
 
<EOS>
He
assured
me
that
Fielding
(
Bernage
's
colonel
)
said
he
might
have
got
that
sum
;
but
,
on
account
of
those
great
recommendations
he
had
,
would
give
it
him
for
nothing
:
 
and
I
would
have
Bernage
write
him
a
letter
of
thanks
,
as
of
a
thing
given
him
for
nothing
,
upon
recommendations
,
etc
.
 
<EOS>
Disney
tells
me
he
will
again
speak
to
Fielding
,
and
clear
up
this
matter
;
then
I
will
write
to
Bernage
.
 
<EOS>
A
pox
on
him
for
promising
money
till
I
had
it
promised
to
me
;
and
then
making
it
such
a
ticklish
point
,
that
one
can
not
expostulate
with
the
colonel
upon
it
:
 
but
let
him
do
as
I
say
,
and
there
is
an
end
.
 
<EOS>
I
engaged
the
Secretary
of
State
in
it
;
and
am
sure
it
was
meant
a
kindness
to
me
,
and
that
no
money
should
be
given
,
and
a
hundred
pounds
is
too
much
in
a
Smithfield
bargain
,
as
a
major
-
general
told
me
,
whose
opinion
I
asked
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
now
hurried
,
and
can
say
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
Farewell
,
etc
.
<EOS>
etc
.
  
<EOS>
How
shall
I
superscribe
to
your
new
lodgings
,
pray
,
madams
?
 
<EOS>
Tell
me
but
that
,
impudence
and
saucy
-
face
.
  
<EOS>
Are
not
you
sauceboxes
to
write
"
lele
"
like
Presto
?
 
<EOS>
O
poor
Presto
!
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Harley
is
better
to
-
night
,
that
makes
me
so
pert
,
you
saucy
Gog
and
Magog
.
   
<EOS>
LETTER
18
.
 
<EOS>
LONDON
,
March
10
,
1710
-
11
.
  
<EOS>
Pretty
little
MD
must
expect
little
from
me
till
Mr.
Harley
is
out
of
danger
.
<EOS>
We
hope
he
is
so
now
;
but
I
am
subject
to
fear
for
my
friends
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
a
head
full
of
the
whole
business
of
the
nation
,
was
out
of
order
when
the
villain
stabbed
him
,
and
had
a
cruel
contusion
by
the
second
blow
.
 
<EOS>
But
all
goes
on
well
yet
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Ford
and
I
dined
with
Mr.
Lewis
,
and
we
hope
the
best
.
  
<EOS>
11
.
 
<EOS>
This
morning
Mr.
Secretary
and
I
met
at
Court
,
where
he
went
to
the
Queen
,
who
is
out
of
order
,
and
aguish
:
 
<EOS>
I
doubt
the
worse
for
this
accident
to
Mr.
Harley
.
 
<EOS>
We
went
together
to
his
house
,
and
his
wound
looks
well
,
and
he
is
not
feverish
at
all
,
and
I
think
it
is
foolish
in
me
to
be
so
much
in
pain
as
I
am
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
the
penknife
in
my
hand
,
which
is
broken
within
a
quarter
of
an
inch
of
the
handle
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
mind
to
write
and
publish
an
account
of
all
the
particularities
of
this
fact
:
 
<EOS>
it
will
be
very
curious
,
and
I
would
do
it
when
Mr.
Harley
is
past
danger
.
  
<EOS>
12
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
been
in
terrible
pain
to
-
day
about
Mr.
Harley
,
who
never
slept
last
night
,
and
has
been
very
feverish
.
 
<EOS>
But
this
evening
I
called
there
;
and
young
Mr.
Harley
(
his
only
son
)
tells
me
he
is
now
much
better
,
and
was
then
asleep
.
 
<EOS>
They
let
nobody
see
him
,
and
that
is
perfectly
right
.
 
<EOS>
The
Parliament
can
not
go
on
till
he
is
well
,
and
are
forced
to
adjourn
their
money
businesses
,
which
none
<EOS>
but
he
can
help
them
in
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
God
preserve
him
.
  
<EOS>
13
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Harley
is
better
to
-
day
,
slept
well
all
night
,
and
we
are
a
little
out
of
our
fears
.
 
<EOS>
I
send
and
call
three
or
four
times
every
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
into
the
City
for
a
walk
,
and
dined
there
with
a
private
man
;
and
coming
home
this
evening
,
broke
my
shin
in
the
Strand
over
a
tub
of
sand
left
just
in
the
way
.
<EOS>
I
got
home
dirty
enough
,
and
went
straight
to
bed
,
where
I
have
been
cooking
it
with
gold
-
beater
's
skin
,
and
have
been
peevish
enough
with
Patrick
,
who
was
near
an
hour
bringing
a
rag
from
next
door
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
my
right
shin
,
where
never
any
humour
fell
when
t'other
used
to
swell
;
so
I
apprehend
it
less
:
 
<EOS>
however
,
I
shall
not
stir
till
'
tis
well
,
which
I
reckon
will
be
in
a
week
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
very
careful
in
these
sort
of
things
;
but
I
wish
I
had
Mrs.
J
<EOS>
#
#
#
#
's
water
:
she
is
out
of
town
,
and
I
must
make
a
shift
with
alum
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
dine
with
Mrs.
Vanhomrigh
till
I
am
well
,
who
lives
but
five
doors
off
;
and
that
I
may
venture
.
  
<EOS>
14
.
 
<EOS>
My
journals
are
like
to
be
very
diverting
,
now
I
can
not
stir
abroad
,
between
accounts
of
Mr.
Harley
's
mending
,
and
of
my
broken
shin
.
 
<EOS>
I
just
walked
to
my
neighbour
Vanhomrigh
at
two
,
and
came
away
at
six
,
when
little
Harrison
the
Tatler
came
to
me
,
and
begged
me
to
dictate
a
paper
to
him
,
which
I
was
forced
in
charity
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Harley
still
mends
;
and
I
hope
in
a
day
or
two
to
trouble
you
no
more
with
him
,
nor
with
my
shin
.
 
<EOS>
Go
to
bed
and
sleep
,
sirrahs
,
that
you
may
rise
to
-
morrow
and
walk
to
Donnybrook
,
and
lose
your
money
with
Stoyte
and
the
Dean
;
do
so
,
dear
little
rogues
,
and
drink
Presto
's
health
.
 
<EOS>
O
pray
,
do
n't
you
drink
Presto
's
health
sometimes
with
your
deans
,
and
your
Stoytes
,
and
your
Walls
,
and
your
Manleys
,
and
your
everybodies
,
pray
now
?
 
<EOS>
I
drink
MD
's
to
myself
a
hundred
thousand
times
.
  
<EOS>
15
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this
morning
at
Mr.
Secretary
St.
John
's
for
all
my
shin
;
and
he
has
given
me
for
young
Harrison
the
Tatler
the
prettiest
employment
in
Europe
;
secretary
to
my
Lord
Raby
,
who
is
to
be
Ambassador
Extraordinary
at
the
Hague
,
where
all
the
great
affairs
will
be
concerted
;
so
we
shall
lose
the
Tatlers
in
a
fortnight
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
send
Harrison
to
-
morrow
morning
to
thank
the
Secretary
.
 
<EOS>
Poor
Biddy
Floyd
has
got
the
smallpox
.
 
<EOS>
I
called
this
morning
to
see
Lady
Betty
Germaine
,
and
when
she
told
me
so
,
I
fairly
took
my
leave
.
<EOS>
I
have
the
luck
of
it
;
for
about
ten
days
ago
I
was
to
see
Lord
Carteret
;
and
my
lady
was
entertaining
me
with
telling
of
a
young
lady
,
a
cousin
,
who
was
then
ill
in
the
house
of
the
smallpox
,
and
is
since
dead
:
 
<EOS>
it
was
near
Lady
Betty
's
,
and
I
fancy
Biddy
took
the
fright
by
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Mr.
Secretary
;
and
a
physician
came
in
just
from
Guiscard
,
who
tells
us
he
is
dying
of
his
wounds
,
and
can
hardly
live
till
to
-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
A
poor
wench
that
Guiscard
kept
,
sent
him
a
bottle
of
sack
;
but
the
keeper
would
not
let
him
touch
it
,
for
fear
it
was
poison
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
two
quarts
of
old
clotted
blood
come
out
of
his
side
to
-
day
,
and
is
delirious
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sorry
he
is
dying
;
for
they
had
found
out
a
way
to
hang
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
certainly
had
an
intention
to
murder
the
Queen
.
  
<EOS>
16
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
made
but
<EOS>
little
progress
in
this
letter
for
so
many
days
,
thanks
to
Guiscard
and
Mr.
Harley
;
and
it
would
be
endless
to
tell
you
all
the
particulars
of
that
odious
fact
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
not
yet
hear
that
Guiscard
is
dead
,
but
they
say
'
tis
impossible
he
should
recover
.
 
<EOS>
I
walked
too
much
yesterday
for
a
man
with
a
broken
shin
;
to
-
day
I
rested
,
and
went
no
farther
than
Mrs.
Vanhomrigh
's
,
where
I
dined
;
and
Lady
Betty
Butler
coming
in
about
six
<EOS>
,
I
was
forced
in
good
manners
to
sit
with
her
till
nine
;
then
I
came
home
,
and
Mr.
Ford
came
in
to
visit
my
shin
,
and
sat
with
me
till
eleven
:
 
<EOS>
so
I
have
been
very
idle
and
naughty
.
 
<EOS>
It
vexes
me
to
the
pluck
that
I
should
lose
walking
this
delicious
day
.
 
<EOS>
Have
you
seen
the
Spectator
yet
,
a
paper
that
comes
out
every
day
?
 
<EOS>
'
Tis
written
by
Mr.
Steele
,
who
seems
to
have
gathered
new
life
,
and
have
a
new
fund
of
wit
;
it
is
in
the
same
nature
as
his
Tatlers
,
and
they
have
all
of
them
had
something
pretty
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
Addison
and
he
club
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
see
them
;
and
I
plainly
told
Mr.
Harley
and
Mr.
St.
John
,
ten
days
ago
,
before
my
Lord
Keeper
and
Lord

,
that
I
had
been
foolish

to
spend
my

with
them
in

of
Addison
and
Steele
;
but
that
I
would
engage
and
promise
never
to
say
one
word
in
their

,
having
been
used
so
ill
for
what
I
had
already

.
 
<EOS>
So
,
now
I
am
got
into
the
way
of
prating
again
,
there
will
be
no
quiet
for
me
.
       
<EOS>
When
Presto
begins
to
prate
,
     
Give
him
a
rap
upon
the
pate
.
  
<EOS>
O
Lord
,
how
I
blot
!
<EOS>
it
is
time
to
leave
off
,
etc
.
  
<EOS>
17
.
 
<EOS>
Guiscard
died
this
morning
at
two
;
and
the
coroner
's
inquest
have
found
that
he
was
killed
by
bruises
received
from
a
messenger
,
so
to
clear
the
Cabinet
Councillors
from
whom
he
received
his
wounds
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
a
letter
from
Raymond
,
who
can
not
hear
of
your
box
;
but
I
hope
you
have
it
before
this
comes
to

hands
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
with
Mr.
Lewis
of
the
Secretary
's
office
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Harley
has
abundance
of
extravasated
blood
comes
from
his
breast
out
of
his
wound
,
and
will
not
be
well
so
soon
as
we
expected
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
something
to
say
,
but
can
not
call
it
to

.
 
<EOS>
(
What
was
it
?
)
  
<EOS>
18
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
to
-
day
at
Court
to
look
for
the
Duke
of
Argyle
,
and
gave
him
the
memorial
about
Bernage
.
 
<EOS>
The
Duke
goes
with
the
first
fair
wind
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
find
him
,
but
I
have
given
the
memorial
to
another
to
give
him
;
and
,
however
,
it
shall
be
sent
after
him
.
 
<EOS>
Bernage
has
made
a
blunder
in
offering
money
to
his
colonel
without
my
advice
;
however
,
he
is
made
captain
-
lieutenant
,
only
he
must
recruit
the
company
,
which
will
cost
him
forty
pounds
,
and
that
is
cheaper
than
an
hundred
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
with
Mr.
Secretary
St.
John
,
and
stayed
till
seven
,
but
would
not
drink
his
champagne
and
burgundy
,
for
fear
of
the
gout
.
 
<EOS>
My
shin
mends
,
but
is
not
well
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
it
will
by
the
time
I
send
this
letter
,
next
Saturday
.
  
<EOS>
19
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
to
-
day
into
the
City
,
but
in
a
coach
,
and
sossed
up
my
leg
on
the
seat
;
and
as
I
came
home
,
I
went
to
see
poor
Charles
Barnard
's
books
,
which
are
to
be
sold
by
auction
,
and
I
itch
to
lay
out
nine
or
ten
pounds
for
some
fine
editions
of
fine
authors
.
 
<EOS>
But
'
tis
too
far
,
and
I
shall
let
it
slip
,
as
I
usually
do
all
such
opportunities
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
in
a
coffee
-
house
with
Stratford
upon
chops
and
some
of
his
wine
.
 
<EOS>
Where
did
MD
dine
?
 
<EOS>
Why
,
poor
MD
dined
at
home
to
-
day
,
because
of
the
Archbishop
,
and
they
could
not
go
abroad
,
and
had
a
breast
of
mutton
and
a
pint
of
wine
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
Mrs.
Walls
mends
;
and
pray
give
me
an
account
what
sort
of
godfather
I
made
,
and
whether
I
behaved
myself
handsomely
.
 
<EOS>
The
Duke
of
Argyle
is
gone
;
and
whether
he
has
my
memorial
,
I
know
not
,
till
I
see
Dr.
Arbuthnot
,
to
whom
I
gave
it
.
 
<EOS>
That
hard
name
belongs
to
a
Scotch
doctor
,
an
acquaintance
of
the
Duke
's
and
me
;
Stella
ca
n't
pronounce
it
.
 
<EOS>
Oh

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
This

,

.
<EOS>
He

;
and

ca

,

a

,

<EOS>

(

)
;

ever
together
,

,

.

,

<EOS>
No

;

<EOS>

<EOS>
LONDON
,

1711
.
  
<EOS>
I

in

post

just

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
This
rain

in

-

;
I
walked
away
sixpennyworth
,
and
came
within
a

length
,
and
then
took
a
coach
,
and
got
a
lift
back
for
nothing
;
and
am
now

.
  
<EOS>
6
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Secretary
desired
I

;

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Ford

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
forced

;

,

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,
by

,
<EOS>

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
chid

so

that

take

well
:
 
<EOS>
then

went

John
,

growing

;

,
for

much

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
8
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
with
Mr.
Secretary
St.
John
;
he
gave
me
a
letter
to

,
which
was
from
the
publisher
of
the
newspaper
called
the
Postboy
;
in
it

of

,

Whigs

upon
Mr.
Harley
's

,
and
how

Mr.

John
;
and

half

,

of
the
Archbishop
of
Dublin
,
and
abusing

horribly
;
this

on
Tuesday
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
the
Secretary
I
would
not
suffer
that
about
the
Archbishop
to
be
printed
,
and
so
I
crossed
it
out
;
and
afterwards
,
to
prevent
all
danger
,
I
made
him
give
me
the
letter
,
and
,
upon
further
thought
,
would
let
none
of
it
be
published
:
 
<EOS>
and
I
sent
for
the
printer
,
and
told
him
so
,
and
ordered
him
,
in
the
Secretary
's
name
,
to
print
nothing
reflecting
on
anybody
in
Ireland
till
he
had
showed
it
me
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
I
have
prevented
a
terrible
scandal
to
the
Archbishop
,
by
a
piece
of
perfect
good
fortune
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
let
him
know
it
by
next
post
;
and
pray
,
if
you
pick
it
out
,
let
me
know
,
and
whether
he
is
thankful
for
it
;
but
say
nothing
.
  
<EOS>
9
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
to
-
day
at
the
House
of
Commons
again
about
their
yarn
,
at
Lord
Anglesea
's
desire
;
but

is
again

Monday
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Sir
John
Stanley
,
by
an
assignation
I
had
made
with
Mr.
St.
John
,
and
George
Granville
,
the
Secretary
at
War
;
<EOS>
but
they
let
in
other
company
,
some
ladies
,
and
<EOS>
so
we
were
not
so
easy
as
I
intended
.
 
<EOS>
My
head
is
pretty
tolerable
,
but
every
day
I
feel
some
little
disorders
;
I
have
left
off
snuff
since
Sunday
,
finding
myself
much
worse
after
taking
a
good
deal
at
the
Secretary
's
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
not
let
him
drink
one
drop
of
champagne
or
burgundy
without
water
,
and
in
compliment
I
did
so
myself
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
much
better
;
but
when
he
is
well
,
he
is
like
Stella
,
and
will
not
be
governed
.
 
<EOS>
So
go
to
your
Stoyte
's
,
and
I
'll
go
sleep
.
  
<EOS>
10
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
visiting
Lady
Worsley
and
Mrs.
Barton
today
,
and
dined
soberly
with
my
friend
Lewis
.
 
<EOS>
The
Dauphin
is
dead
of
an
apoplexy
;
I
wish
he
had
lived
till
the
finishing
of
this
letter
,
that
it
might
be
news
to
you
.
<EOS>
Duncombe
,
the
rich
alderman
,
died
to
-
day
,
and
I
hear
has
left
the
Duke
of
Argyle
,
who
married
his
niece
,
two
hundred
thousand
pounds
;
I
hope
it
is
true
,
for
I
love
that
Duke
mightily
.
 
<EOS>
I
writ
this
evening
to
the
Archbishop
of
Dublin
,
about
what
I
told
you
;
and
then
went
to
take
leave
of
poor
Mrs.
St.
John
,
who
gave
me
strict
charge
to
take
care
of
the
Secretary
in
her
absence
;
said
she
had
none
to
trust
but
me
;
and
the
poor
creature
's
tears
came
fresh
in
her
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
Before
we
took
leave
,
I
was
drawn
in
by
the
other
ladies
and
Sir
John
Stanley
to
raffle
for
a
fan
,
with
a
pox
;
it
was
four
guineas
,
and
we
put
in
seven
shillings
apiece
,
several
raffling
for
absent
people
;
but
I
lost
,
and
so
missed
an
opportunity
of
showing
my
gallantry
to
Mrs.
St.
John
,
whom
I
designed
to
have
presented
it
to
if
I
had
won
.
 
<EOS>
Is
Dilly
gone
to
the
Bath
?
<EOS>
His
face
will
whizz
in
the
water
;
I
suppose
he
will
write
to
us
from
thence
,
and
will
take
London
in
his
way
back
.
 
<EOS>
The
rabble
will
say
,
"
There
goes
a
drunken
parson
"
;
and
,
which
is
worse
,
they
will
say
true
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
but
you
must
know
I
carried
Ford
to
dine
with
Mr.
St.
John
last
Sunday
,
that
he
may
brag
,
when
he
goes
back
,
of
dining
with
a
Secretary
of
State
.
 
<EOS>
The
Secretary
<EOS>
and
I
went
away
early
,
and
left
him
drinking
with
the
rest
,
and
he
told
me
that
two
or
three
of
them
were
drunk
.
 
<EOS>
They
talk
of
great
promotions
to
be
made
;
that
Mr.
Harley
is
to
be
Lord
Treasurer
,
and
Lord
Poulett
Master
of
the
Horse
,
etc
.
,
but
they
are
only
conjecture
.
 
<EOS>
The
Speaker
is
to
make
Mr.
Harley
a
compliment
the
first
time
he
comes
into
the
House
,
which
I
hope
will
be
in
a
week
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
had
an
ill
surgeon
,
by
the
caprice
of
that
puppy
Dr.
Radcliffe
,
which
has
kept
him
back
so
long
;
and
yesterday
he
got
a
cold
,
but
is
better
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
What
!
<EOS>
I
think
I
am
stark
mad
,
to
write
so
much
in
one
day
to
little
saucy
MD
;
here
is
a
deal
of
stuff
,
indeed
!
<EOS>
ca
n't
you
bid
those
little
dear
rogues
good
-
night
,
and
let
them
go
sleep
,
Mr.
Presto
?
 
<EOS>
When
your
tongue
runs
there
's
no
ho
with
you
,
pray
.
  
<EOS>
11
.
 
<EOS>
Again
at
the
lobby
(
like
a
lobcock
)
of
the
House
of
Commons
,
about
your
Irish
yarn
,
and
again
put
off
till
Friday
;
and
I
and
Patrick
went
into
the
City
by
water
,
where
I
dined
,
and
then
I
went
to
the
auction
of
Charles
Barnard
's
books
;
but
the
good
ones
were
so
monstrous
<EOS>
dear
<EOS>
,
I
could
not
reach
them
,
so
I
laid
out
one
pound
seven
shillings
but
very
indifferently
,
and
came
away
,
and
will
go
there
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
Henley
would
fain
engage
me
to
go
with
Steele
and
Rowe
,
etc
.
,
to
an
invitation
at
Sir
William
Read
's
.
 
<EOS>
Surely
you
have
heard
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
been
a
mountebank
,
and
is
the
Queen
's
oculist
;
he
makes
admirable
punch
,
and
treats
you
in
gold
vessels
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
am
engaged
,
and
will
not
go
,
neither
indeed
am
I
fond
of
the
jaunt
.
 
<EOS>
So
good
-
night
,
and
go
sleep
.
  
<EOS>
12
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
about
noon
to
the
Secretary
,
who
is
very
ill
with
a
cold
,
and
sometimes
of
the
gravel
,
with
his
champagne
,
etc
.
 
<EOS>
I
scolded
him
like
a
dog
,
and
he
promises
faithfully
more
care
for
the
future
.
 
<EOS>
To
-
day
<EOS>
my
Lord
Anglesea
,
and
Sir
Thomas
Hammer
,
and
Prior
,
and
I
dined
,
by
appointment
,
with
Lieutenant
-
General
Webb
.
 
<EOS>
My
lord
and
I
stayed
till
ten
o'clock
;
but
we
drank
soberly
,
and
I
always
with
water
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
with
us
one
Mr.
Campain
,
one
of
the
October
Club
,
if
you
know
what
that
is
;
a
Club
of
country
members
,
who
think
the
Ministers
are
too
backward
in
punishing
and
turning
out
the
Whigs
.
 
<EOS>
I
found
my
lord
and
the
rest
thought
I
had
more
credit
with
the
Ministry
than
I
pretend
to
have
,
and
would
have
engaged
me
to
put
them
upon
something
that
would
satisfy
their
desires
,
and
indeed
I
think
they
have
some
reason
to
complain
;
however
,
I
will
not
burn
my
fingers
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
remember
Stella
's
chiding
,
"
What
had
you
to
do
with
what
did
not
belong
to
you
?
"
<EOS>
etc
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
you
will
give
me
leave
to
tell
the
Ministry
my
thoughts
when
they
ask
them
,
and
other
people
's
thoughts
sometimes
when
they
do
not
ask
;
so
thinks
Dingley
.
  
<EOS>
13
.
 
<EOS>
I
called
this
morning
at
Mrs.
Vedeau
's
again
,
who
has
employed
a
friend
to
get
the
money
;
it
will
be
done
in
a
fortnight
,
and
then
she
will
deliver
me
up
the
parchment
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
then
to
see
Mr.
Harley
,
who
I
hope
will
be
out
in
a
few
days
;
he
was
in
excellent
good
humour
,
only
complained
to
me
of
the
neglect
of
Guiscard
's
cure
,
<EOS>
how
glad
he
would
have
been
to
have
had
him
live
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Secretary
came
in
to
us
,
and
we
were
very
merry
till
Lord
Chamberlain
(
Duke
of
Shrewsbury
)
came
up
;
then
Colonel
Masham
and
I
went
off
,
after
I
had
been
presented
to
the
Duke
,
and
that
we
made
two
or
three
silly
compliments
suitable
to
the
occasion
.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
attended
at
the
House
of
Commons
about
your
yarn
,
and
it
is
again
put
off
.
 
<EOS>
Then
Ford
drew
me
to
dine
at
a
tavern
;
it
happened
to
be
the
day
and
the
house
where
the
October
Club
dine
.
<EOS>
After
we
had
dined
,
coming
down
<EOS>
we
called
to
inquire
whether
our
yarn
business
had
been
over
that
day
,
and
I
sent
into
the
room
for
Sir
George
Beaumont
.
<EOS>
But
I
had
like
to
be
drawn
into
a
difficulty
;
for
in
two
minutes
out
comes
Mr.
Finch
,
Lord
Guernsey
's
son
,
to
let
me
know
that
my
Lord
Compton
,
the
steward
of
this
feast
,
desired
,
in
the
name
of
the
Club
,
that
I
would
do
them
the
honour
to
dine
with
them
.
 
<EOS>
I
sent
my
excuses
,
adorned
with
about
thirty
compliments
,
and
got
off
as
fast
as
I
could
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
a
most
improper
thing
for
me
to
dine
there
,
considering
my
friendship
with
the
Ministry
.
 
<EOS>
The
Club
is
about
a
hundred
and
fifty
,
and
near
eighty
of
them
were
then
going
to
dinner
at
two
long
tables
in
a
great
ground
-
room
.
 
<EOS>
At
evening
I
went
to
the
auction
of
Barnard
's
books
,
and
laid
out
three
pounds
three
shillings
,
but
I
'll
go
there
no
more
;
and
<EOS>
so
I
said
once
before
,
<EOS>
but
now
I
'll
keep
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
forgot
to
tell
that
when
I
dined
at
Webb
's
with
Lord
Anglesea
,
I
spoke
to
him
of
Clements
,
as
one
recommended
for
a
very
honest
gentleman
and
good
officer
,
and
hoped
he
would
keep
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
he
had
not
thought
otherwise
,
and
that
he
should
certainly
hold
his
place
while
he
continued
to
deserve
it
;
and
I
could
not
find
there
had
been
any
intentions
from
his
lordship
against
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
tell
you
,
hunny
,
the
impropriety
of
this
.
 
<EOS>
A
great
man
will
do
a
favour
for
me
,
or
for
my
friend
;
but
why
should
he
do
it
for
my
friend
's
friend
?
 
<EOS>
Recommendations
should
stop
before
they
come
to
that
.
<EOS>
Let
any
friend
of
mine
recommend
one
of
his
to
me
for
a
thing
in
my
power
,
I
will
do
it
for
his
sake
;
but
to
speak
to
another
for
my
friend
's
friend
is
against
all
reason
;
and
I
desire
you
will
understand
this
,
and
discourage
any
such
troubles
given
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
this
may
do
some
good
to
Clements
<EOS>
,
it
can
do
him
no
hurt
;
and
I
find
by
Mrs.
Pratt
,
that
her
husband
is
his
friend
;
and
the
Bishop
of
Clogher
says
Clements
's
danger
is
not
from
Pratt
,
but
from
some
other
enemies
,
that
think
him
a
Whig
.
  
<EOS>
14
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
so
busy
this
morning
that
I
did
not
go
out
till
late
.
 
<EOS>
I
writ
to
-
day
to
the
Duke
of
Argyle
,
but
said
nothing
of
Bernage
,
who
,
I
believe
,
will
not
see
him
till
Spain
is
conquered
,
and
that
is
,
not
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
to
-
day
at
Lord
Shelburne
's
,
and
spoke
to
Mrs.
Pratt
again
about
Clements
;
her
husband
himself
wants
some
good
offices
,
and
I
have
done
him
very
good
ones
lately
,
and
told
Mrs.
Pratt
I
expected
her
husband
should
stand
by
Clements
in
return
.
<EOS>
Sir
Andrew
Fountaine
and
I
dined
with
neighbour
Vanhomrigh
;
he
is
mighty
ill
of
an
asthma
,
and
apprehends
himself
in
much
danger
;
'
tis
his
own
fault
,
that
will
rake
and
drink
,
when
he
is
but
just
crawled
out
of
his
grave
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
send
this
letter
just
now
,
because
I
think
my
half
-
year
is
out
for
my
lodging
;
and
,
if
you
please
,
I
would
be
glad
it
were
paid
off
,
and
some
deal
boxes
made
for
my
books
,
and
kept
in
some
safe
place
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
give
something
for
their
keeping
:
 
<EOS>
but
I
doubt
that
lodging
will
not
serve
me
when
I
come
back
;
I
would
have
a
larger
place
for
books
,
and
a
stable
,
if
possible
.
 
<EOS>
So
pray
be
so
kind
to
pay
the
lodging
,
and
all
accounts
about
it
;
and
get
Mrs.
Brent
to
put
up
my
things
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
have
no
books
put
in
that
trunk
where
my
papers
are
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
do
not
think
of
going
to
the
Bath
,
I
here
send
you
a
bill
on
Parvisol
for
twenty
pounds
Irish
,
out
of
which
you
will
pay
for
the
lodging
,
and
score
the
rest
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
Do
as
you
please
,
and
love
poor
Presto
,
that
loves
MD
better
than
his
life
a
thousand
millions
of
times
.
 
<EOS>
Farewell
,
MD
,
etc
.
<EOS>
etc
.
   
<EOS>
LETTER
21
.
 
<EOS>
LONDON
,
April
14
,
1711
.
  
<EOS>
Remember
,
sirrahs
,
that
there
are
but
nine
days
between
the
dates
of
my
two
former
letters
.
 
<EOS>
I
sent
away
my
twentieth
this
moment
,
and
now
am
writing
on
like
a
fish
,
as
if
nothing
was
done
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
was
a
cause
for
my
hasting
away
the
last
,
<EOS>
for
fear
it
should
not
come
time
enough
before
a
new
quarter
began
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
you
where
I
dined
to
-
day
;
but
forgot
to
tell
you
what
I
believe
,
that
Mr.
Harley
will
be
Lord
Treasurer
in
a
short
time
,
and
other
great
removes
and
promotions
made
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
my
thought
,
etc
.
  
<EOS>
15
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this
morning
with
Mr.
Secretary
,
and
he
is
grown
pretty
well
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
him
to
-
day
,
and
drank
some
of
that
wine
which
the
Duke
of
Tuscany
used
to
send
to
Sir
William
Temple
:
 
he
always
sends
some
to
the
chief
Ministers
.
 
<EOS>
I
liked
it
mightily
,
but
he
does
not
;
and
he
ordered
his
butler
to
send
me
a
chest
of
it
to
-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
Would
to
God
MD
had
it
!
 
<EOS>
The
Queen
is
well
again
,
and
was
at
chapel
to
-
day
,
etc
.
  
<EOS>
16
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
with
Ford
into
the
City
to
-
day
,
and
dined
with
Stratford
,
and
drank
Tokay
,
and
then
we
went
to
the
auction
;
but
I
did
not
lay
out
above
twelve
shillings
.
 
<EOS>
My
head
is
a
little
out
of
order
<EOS>
to
-
night
,
though
no
formal
fit
.
 
<EOS>
My
Lord
Keeper
has
sent
to
invite
me
to
dinner
to
-
morrow
,
and
you
'll
dine
better
with
the
Dean
;
and
God
bless
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
forgot
to
tell
you
that
yesterday
was
sent
me
a
Narrative
printed
,
with
all
the
circumstances
of
Mr.
Harley
's
stabbing
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
not
time
to
do
it
myself
;
so
I
sent
my
hints
to
the
author
of
the
Atalantis
,
and
she
has
cooked
it
into
a
sixpenny
pamphlet
,
in
her
own
style
,
only
the
first
page
is
left
as
I
was
beginning
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
was
afraid
of
disobliging
Mr.
Harley
or
Mr.
St.
John
in
one
critical
point
about
it
,
and
so
would
not
do
it
myself
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
worth
your
reading
,
for
the
circumstances
are
all
true
.
 
<EOS>
My
chest
of
Florence
was
sent
me
this
morning
,
and
cost
me
seven
and
sixpence
to
two
servants
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
give
two
guineas
you
had
it
,
etc
.
  
<EOS>
17
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
so
out
of
order
with
my
head
this
morning
,
that
I
was
going
to
send
my
excuses
to
my
Lord
Keeper
;
but
however
I
got
up
at
eleven
,
and
walked
there
after
two
,
and
stayed
till
eight
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
Sir
Thomas
Mansel
,
Prior
,
George
Granville
,
and
Mr.
Caesar
,
and
we
were
very
merry
.
 
<EOS>
My
head
is
still
wrong
,
but
I
have
had
no
formal
fit
,
only
I
totter
a
little
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
left
off
snuff
altogether
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
noble
roll
of
tobacco
for
grating
,
very
good
.
 
<EOS>
Shall
I
send
it
to
MD
,
if
she
likes
that
sort
?
 
<EOS>
My
Lord
Keeper
and
our
this
day
's
company
are
to
dine
on
Saturday
with
George
Granville
,
and
to
-
morrow
I
dine
with
Lord
Anglesea
.
  
<EOS>
18
.
 
<EOS>
Did
you
ever
see
such
a
blundering
goosecap
as
Presto
?
 
<EOS>
I
saw
the
number
21
at
top
,
and
so
I
went
on
as
if
it
were
the
day
of
the
month
,
whereas
this
is
but
Wednesday
the
18th
.
 
<EOS>
How
shall
I
do
to
blot
and
alter
them
?
 
<EOS>
I
have
made
a
shift
to
do
it
behind
,
but
it
is
a
great
botch
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Lord
Anglesea
to
-
day
,
but
did
not
go
to
the
House
of
Commons
about
the
yarn
;
my
head
was
not
well
enough
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
not
what
is
the
matter
;
it
has
never
been
thus
before
:
 
two
days
together
giddy
from
morning
till
night
,
but
not
with
any
violence
or
pain
;
and
I
totter
a
little
,
but
can
make
shift
to
walk
.
 
<EOS>
I
doubt
I
must
fall
to
my
pills
again
:
 
<EOS>
I
think
of
going
into
the
country
a
little
way
.
 
<EOS>
I
tell
you
what
you
must
do
henceforward
:
 
you
must
enclose
your
letter
in
a
fair
half
-
sheet
of
paper
,
and
direct
the
outside
"
To
Erasmus
Lewis
,
Esquire
,
at
my
Lord
Dartmouth
's
office
at
Whitehall
"
:
 
<EOS>
for
I
never
go
to
the
Coffee
-
house
,
and
they
will
grudge
to
take
in
my
letters
.
 
<EOS>
I
forgot
to
tell
you
that
your
mother
was
to
see
me
this
morning
,
and
brought
me
a
flask
of
sweet
-
water
for
a
present
,
admirable
for
my
head
;
but
I
shall
not
smell
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
going
to
Sheen
,
with
Lady
Giffard
:
 
<EOS>
she
would
fain
send
your
papers
over
to
you
,
or
give
them
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
Say
what
you
would
have
done
,
and
it
shall
be
done
;
because
I
love
Stella
,
and
she
is
a
good
daughter
,
they
say
,
and
so
is
Dingley
.
  
<EOS>
19
.
 
<EOS>
This
morning
General
Webb
was
to
give
me
a
visit
:
 
<EOS>
he
goes
with
a
crutch
and
stick
,
yet
was
forced
to
come
up
two
pair
of
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
I
promised
to
dine
with
him
,
but
afterwards
sent
my
excuses
,
and
dined
privately
in
my
friend
Lewis
's
lodgings
at
Whitehall
,
with
whom
I
had
much
business
to
talk
of
,
relating
to
the
public
and
myself
.
 
<EOS>
Little
Harrison
the
Tatler
goes
to
-
morrow
to
the
secretaryship
I
got
him
at
the
Hague
,
and
Mr.
St.
John
has
made
him
a
present
of
fifty
guineas
to
bear
his
charges
.
 
<EOS>
An't
<EOS>
I
a
good
friend
?
 
<EOS>
Why
are
not
you
a
young
fellow
,
that
I
might
prefer
you
?
 
<EOS>
I
had
a
letter
from
Bernage
from
Kinsale
:
 
<EOS>
he
tells
me
his
commission
for
captain
-
lieutenant
was
ready
for
him
at
his
arrival
:
 
<EOS>
so
there
are
two
jackanapeses
I
have
done
with
.
 
<EOS>
My
head
is
something
better
this
evening
,
though
not
well
.
  
<EOS>
20
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this
morning
with
Mr.
Secretary
,
whose
packets
were
just
come
in
,
and
among
them
a
letter
from
Lord
Peterborow
to
me
:
 
<EOS>
he
writes
so
well
,
I
have
no
mind
to
answer
him
,
and
so
kind
,
that
I
must
answer
him
.
 
<EOS>
The
Emperor
's
death
must
,
I
think
,
cause
great
alterations
in
Europe
,
and
,
I
believe
,
will
hasten
a
peace
.
 
<EOS>
We
reckon
our
King
Charles
will
be
chosen
Emperor
,
and
the
Duke
of
Savoy
set
up
for
Spain
;
but
I
believe
he
will
make
nothing
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
Dr.
Freind
and
<EOS>
I
dined
in
the
City
at
a
printer
's
,
and
it
has
cost
me
two
shillings
in
coach
-
hire
,
and
a
great
deal
more
this
week
and
month
,
which
has
been
almost
all
rain
,
with
now
and
then
sunshine
,
and
is
the
truest
April
that
I
have
known
these
many
years
.
 
<EOS>
The
lime
-
trees
in
the
Park
are
all
out
in
leaves
,
though
not
large
leaves
yet
.
 
<EOS>
Wise
people
are
going
into
the
country
;
but
many
think
the
Parliament
can
hardly
be
up
these
six
weeks
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Harley
was
with
the
Queen
on
Tuesday
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
certainly
he
will
be
Lord
Treasurer
<EOS>
:
I
have
not
seen
him
this
week
.
  
<EOS>
21
.
 
<EOS>
Morning
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Keeper
,
and
I
,
and
Prior
,
and
Sir
Thomas
Mansel
,
have
appointed
to
dine
this
day
with
George
Granville
.
 
<EOS>
My
head
,
I
thank
God
,
is
better
;
but
to
be
giddyish
three
or
four
days
together
mortified
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
take
no
snuff
,
and
I
will
be
very
regular
in
eating
little
and
the
gentlest
meats
.
<EOS>
How
does
poor
Stella
just
now
,
with
her
deans
and
her
Stoytes
?
 
<EOS>
Do
they
give
you
health
for
the
money
you
lose
at
ombre
,
sirrah
?
 
<EOS>
What
say
you
to
that
?
<EOS>
Poor
Dingley
frets
to
see
Stella
lose
that
four
and
elevenpence
,
the
other
night
.
 
<EOS>
Let
us
rise
.
 
<EOS>
Morrow
,
sirrahs
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
rise
,
spite
of
your
little
teeth
;
good
-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
At
night
.
 
<EOS>
O
,
faith
,
you
are
little
dear
saucyboxes
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
just
going
in
the
morning
to
tell
you
that
I
began
to
want
a
letter
from
MD
,
and
in
four
minutes
after
Mr.
Ford
sends
me
one
that
he
had
picked
up
at
St.
James
's
Coffee
-
house
;
for
I
go
to
no
coffee

at

.
 
<EOS>
And
,
faith
,
I
was
glad
at
heart
to
see

,
and
to
see
Stella
so
brisk
.
 
<EOS>
O
Lord
,
what
pretending
?
 
<EOS>
Well
,
but
I
will
not
answer

yet
;
I
'll
keep
it
for
t'other
side
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
we
dined
to
-
day
according
to
appointment
:
 
Lord
Keeper
went
away
at
near
eight
,
I
at
eight
,
and
I
believe
the
rest
will
be
fairly
fuddled
;
for
young
Harcourt
,
Lord
Keeper
's
son
,
began
to
prattle
before
I
came
away
.
 
<EOS>
It
will
not
do
with
Prior
's
lean
carcass
.
 
<EOS>
I
drink
little
,
miss
my
glass
often
,
put
water
in
my
wine
,
and
go
away
before
the
rest
,
which
I
take
to
be
a
good
receipt
for
sobriety
.
 
<EOS>
Let
us
put
it
into
rhyme
,
and
so
make
a
proverb
        
Drink
little
at
a
time
;
     
Put
water
with
your
wine
;
     
Miss
your
glass
<EOS>
when
you
can
;
     
And
go
off
the
first
man
.
  
<EOS>
God
be
thanked
,
I
am
much
better
than
I
was
,
though
something
of
a
totterer
.
<EOS>
I
ate
but
little
to
-
day
,
and
of
the
gentlest
meat
.
 
<EOS>
I
refused
ham
and
pigeons
,
pease
-
soup
,
stewed
beef
,
cold
salmon
,
because
they
were
too
strong
.
 
<EOS>
I
take
no
snuff
at
all
,
but
some
herb
snuff
prescribed
by
Dr.
Radcliffe
.
       
<EOS>
Go
to
your
deans
,
     
You
couple
of
queans
.
  
<EOS>
I
believe
I
said
that
already
.
 
<EOS>
What
care
I
?
 
<EOS>
what
cares
Presto
?
  
<EOS>
22
.
 
<EOS>
Morning
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
rise
and
go
to
the
Secretary
's
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Harley
has

this
week
to

before

.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,

I

,

;
and
so
morrow
,
sirrahs

.
  
<EOS>
Night
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
with
the
Secretary
,
who
has
engaged
me
for
every
Sunday
;
and
I
was
an
hour
with
him
this
morning
deep
in
politics
,
where
I
told
him
the
objections
of
the
October
Club
,
and
he
answered
all
except
one
,
that
no
inquiries
are
made
into
past
mismanagement
.
 
<EOS>
But
indeed
I
believe
they
are
not
yet
able
to
make
any
:
 
<EOS>
the
late
Ministry
were
too
cunning
in
their
rogueries
,
and
fenced
themselves
with
an
Act
of
general
pardon
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
Mr.
Harley
must
be
Lord
Treasurer
;
yet
he
makes
one
difficulty
which
is
hard
to
answer
:
 
<EOS>
he
must
be
made
a
lord
,
and
his
estate
is
not
large
enough
,
and
he
is
too
generous
to
make
it
larger
;
and
if
the
Ministry
should
change
soon
by
any
accident
,
he
will
be
left
in
the
suds
.
 
<EOS>
Another
difficulty
is
,
that
if
he
be
made
a
peer
,
they
will
want
him
prodigiously
in
the
House
of
Commons
,
of
which
he
is
the
great
mover
,
and
after
him
the
Secretary
,
and
hardly
any
else
of
weight
.
 
<EOS>
Two
shillings
more
to
-
day
for
coach
and
chair
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
be
ruined
.
  
<EOS>
23
.
 
<EOS>
So
you
expect
an
answer
to
your
letter
,
do
you
so
?
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
,
you
shall
have
an
answer
,
you
shall
,
young
women
.
 
<EOS>
I
made
a
good
pun
on
Saturday
to
my
Lord
Keeper
.
 
<EOS>
After
dinner
we
had
coarse
Doiley
napkins
,
fringed
at
each
end
,
upon
the
table
,
to
drink
with
:
 
my
Lord
Keeper
spread
one
of
them
between
him
and
Mr.
Prior
;
I
told
him
I
was
glad
to
see
there
was
such
a
fringeship
[
friendship
]
between
Mr.
Prior
and
his
lordship
.
 
<EOS>
Prior
swore
it
was
the
worst
he
ever
heard
:
 
<EOS>
I
said
I
thought
so
too
;
but
at
the
same
time
I
thought
it
was
most
like
one
of
Stella
's
that
<EOS>
ever
I
heard
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
with
Lord
Mountjoy
,
and
this
evening
saw
the
Venetian
Ambassador
coming
from
his
first
public

.
 
<EOS>
His
coach
was
the
most
monstrous
,
huge
,
fine
,
rich
gilt
thing
that
ever
I
saw
.
 
<EOS>
I
loitered
this
evening
,
and
came
home
late
.
  
<EOS>
24
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this
morning
to
visit
the
Duchess
of
Ormond
,
who
has
long
desired
it
,
or
threatened
she
would
not
let
me
visit
her
daughters
.
 
<EOS>
I
sat
an
hour
with
her
,
and
we
were
good
company
,
when
in
came
the
Countess
of
Bellamont
,
with
a
pox
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
out
,
and
we
did
not
know
one
another
;
yet
hearing
me
named
<EOS>
,
she
asked
,
"
What
,
is
that
Dr.
Swift
?
"
said
she
and
I
were
very
well
acquainted
,
and
fell
a
railing
at
me
without
mercy
,
as
a
lady
told
me
that
was
there
;
yet
I
never
was
but
once
in
the
company
of
that
drab
of
a
Countess
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Andrew
Fountaine
and
I
dined
with
my
neighbour
Van
.
 
<EOS>
I
design
in
two
days
,
if
possible
,
to
go
lodge
at
Chelsea
for
the
air
,
and
put
myself
under
a
necessity
of
walking
to
and
from
London
every
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
writ
this
post
to
the
Bishop
of
Clogher
a
long
politic
letter
,
to
entertain
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
to
buy
statues
and
harnese
for
them
,
with
a
vengeance
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
packed
and
sealed
up
<EOS>
MD
's
twelve
letters
against
I
go
to
Chelsea
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
put
the
last
commissions
of
MD
in
my
account
-
book
;
but
if
there
be
any
former
ones
,
I
have
forgot

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
Dingley
's
pocket
-
book
down
,
and
Stella
's
green
silk
apron
,
and
the
pound
of
tea
;
pray
send
me
word
if
you
have
any
other
,
and
down
they
shall

.
 
<EOS>
I
will
not
answer
your
letter
yet
,
saucy
boxes
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
with
the
Dean
just
now
,
Madam
Stella
,
losing
your
money
.
 
<EOS>
Why
do
not
you
name
what
number
you
have

?
 
<EOS>
You
say
you
have
received
my
letters
,
but
do
not
tell
the
number
.
  
<EOS>
25
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this
day
dining
in
the
City
with
very
insignificant
,
low
,
and
scurvy
company
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
a
letter
from
the
Archbishop
of
Dublin
,
with
a
long
denial
of
the
report
raised
on
him
,
which
yet
has
been
since
assured
to
me
from
those
who
say
they
have
it
from
the
first
hand
;
but
I
can
not
believe
them
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
show
it
to
the
Secretary
to
-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
not
answer
yours
till
I
get
to
Chelsea
.
  
<EOS>
26
.
 
<EOS>
Chelsea
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
sent
two
boxes
of
lumber
to
my
friend
Darteneuf
's
house
,
and
my
chest
of
Florence
and
other
things
to
Mrs.
Vanhomrigb
,
where
I
dined
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this
morning
with
the
Secretary
,
and
showed
him
the
Archbishop
's
letter
,
and
convinced
him
of
his
Grace
's
innocence
,
and
I
will
do
the
same
to
Mr.
Harley
.
 
<EOS>
I
got
here
in
the
stage
-
coach
with
Patrick
and
my
portmanteau
for
sixpence
,
and
pay
six
shillings
a
week
for
one
silly
room
with
confounded
coarse
sheets
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
had
such
a
horrible
deal
of
rain
,
that
there
is
no
walking
to
London
,
and
I
must
go
as
I
came
until
it
mends
;
and
besides
the
whelp
has
taken
my
lodging
as
far
from
London
as
this
town
could
afford
,
at
least
half
a
mile
farther
than
he
need
;
but
I
must
be
content
.
 
<EOS>
The
best
is
,
I
lodge
just
over
against
Dr.
Atterbury
's
house
,
and
yet
perhaps
I
shall
not
like
the
place
the
better
for
that
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
I
will

till

-

answer

;
and
you
must
suppose

always

Chelsea

,

,
and

London
.
 
<EOS>
This

on

,
which

be
just
a

;
so

Goody

,

.
  
<EOS>
27
.
 
<EOS>
Do

I

,

,

<EOS>
How

!
<EOS>
and

;

not

,

.
<EOS>
I

;
and

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

seven

at
play
 
with
a####a####a
#

#

,

.
 
<EOS>

now
<EOS>
,

<EOS>

,

,

,

,

<EOS>
I

CHELSEA

<EOS>
At
night
.
 
<EOS>
I
say
at
night
,
because
I
finished
my
twenty
-
first
this
morning
here
,
and
put
it
into
the
post
-
office
my
own
self
,
like
a
good
boy
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
I
am
a
little
before
you
now
,
young
women
:
 
<EOS>
I
am
writing
my
twenty
-
second
,
and
have
received
your
thirteenth
.
 
<EOS>
I
got
to
town
between
twelve
and
one
,
and
put
on
my
new
gown
and
periwig
,
and
dined
with
Lord
Abercorn
,
where
I
had
not
been
since
the
marriage
of
his
son
Lord
Peasley
,
who
has
got
ten
thousand
pounds
with
a
wife
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
now
a
country
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
I
walked
home
as
I
went
,
and
am
a
little
weary
,
and
am
got
into
bed
:
 
<EOS>
I
hope
in
God
the
air
and
exercise
will
do
me
a
little
good
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
inquiring
about
statues
for
Mrs.
Ashe
:
 
<EOS>
I
made
Lady
Abercorn
go
with
me
;
and
will
send
them
word
next
post
to
Clogher
.
 
<EOS>
I
hate
to
buy
for
her
:
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
she
will
maunder
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
going
to
study
.
  
<EOS>
29
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
a
charming
walk
to
and
from
town
to
-
day
:
 
<EOS>
I
washed
,
shaved
and
all
,
and
changed
gown
and
periwig
,
by
half
an
hour
after
nine
,
and
went
to
the
Secretary
,
who
told
me
how
he
had
differed
with
his
friends
in
Parliament
:
 
<EOS>
I
apprehended
this
division
,
and
told
him
a
great
deal
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
to
Court
,
and
there
several
mentioned
it
to
me
as
what
they
much
disliked
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
the
Secretary
;
and
we
proposed
doing
some
business
of
importance
in
the
afternoon
,
which
he
broke
to
me
first
,
and
said
how
he
and
Mr.
Harley
were
convinced
of
the
necessity
of
it
;
yet
he
suffered
one
of
his
under
-
secretaries
to
come
upon
us
after
dinner
,
who
stayed
till
six
,
and
so
nothing
was
done
:
and
what
care
I
?
<EOS>
he
shall
send
to
me
the
next
time
,
and
ask
twice
.
 
<EOS>
To
-
morrow
<EOS>
I
go
to
the
election
at
Westminster
School
,
where
lads
are
chosen
for
the
University
:
 
<EOS>
they
say
it
is
a
sight
,
and
<EOS>
a
great
trial
of
wits
.
 
<EOS>
Our
Expedition
Fleet
is
but
just
sailed
:
 
<EOS>
I
believe
it
will
come
to
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Secretary
frets
at
their
tediousness
,
but
hopes
great
things
from
it
,
though
he
owns
four
or
five
princes
are
in
the
secret
;
and
,
for
that
reason
,
I
fear
it
is
no
secret
to
France
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
eight
regiments
;
and
the
Admiral
is
your
Walker
's
brother
the
midwife
.
  
<EOS>
30
.
 
<EOS>
Morn
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
here
in
a
pretty
pickle
:
 
<EOS>
it
rains
hard
;
and
the
cunning
natives
of
Chelsea
have
outwitted
me
,
and
taken
up
all
the
three
stage
coaches
.
 
<EOS>
What
shall
I
do
?
 
<EOS>
I
must
go
to
town
:
 
<EOS>
this
is
your
fault
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
walk
:
 
<EOS>
I
will
borrow
a
coat
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
the
blind
side
of
my
lodging
out
of
town
;
I
must
expect
such
inconveniences
as
these
.
 
<EOS>
Faith
,
I
'll
walk
in
the
rain
.
 
<EOS>
Morrow
.
 
<EOS>
At
night
.
 
<EOS>
I
got
a
gentleman
's
chaise
by
chance
,
and
so
went
to
town
for
a
shilling
,
and
lie
this
night
in
town
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
at
the
election
of
lads
at
Westminster
to
-
day
,
and
a
very
silly
thing
it
is
;
but
they
say
there
will
be
fine
doings
to
-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Dr.
Freind
,
the
second
master
of
the
school
,
with
a
dozen
parsons
and
others
:
 
<EOS>
Prior
would
make
me
stay
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harley
is
to
hear
the
election
to
-
morrow
;
and
we
are
all
to
dine
with
tickets
,
and
hear
fine
speeches
.
 
<EOS>
'
Tis
terrible
rainy
weather
again
:
 
<EOS>
I
lie
at
a
friend
's
in
the
City
.
  
<EOS>
May
1
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
you
a
merry
May
Day
,
and
a
thousand
more
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
baulked
at
Westminster
;
I
came
too
late
:
 
<EOS>
I
heard
no
speeches
nor
verses
.
 
<EOS>
They
would
not
let
me
in
to
their
dining
-
place
for
want
of
a
ticket
;
and
I
would
not
send
in
for
one
,
because
Mr.
Harley
excused
his
coming
,
and
Atterbury
was
not
there
;
and
I
cared
not
for
the
rest
:
 
and
so
my
friend
Lewis
<EOS>
and
I
dined
with
Kitt
Musgrave
,
<EOS>
if
you
know
such
a
man
:
 
and
,
the
weather
mending
,
I
walked
gravely
home
this
evening
;
and
so
I
design
to
walk
and
walk
till
I
am
well
:
 
<EOS>
I
fancy
myself
a
little
better
already
.
 
<EOS>
How
does
poor
Stella
?
 
<EOS>
Dingley
is
well
enough
.
 
<EOS>
Go
,
get
you
gone
,
naughty
girl
,
you
are
well
enough
.
 
<EOS>
O
dear
MD
,
contrive
to
have
some
share
of
the
country
this
spring
:
 
go
to
Finglas
,
or
Donnybrook
,
or
Clogher
,
or
Killala
,
or
Lowth
.
 
<EOS>
Have
you
got
your
box
yet
?
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
.
 
<EOS>
Do
not
write
to
me
again
till
this
letter
goes
:
 
<EOS>
I
must
make
haste
,
that
I
may
write
two
for
one
.
 
<EOS>
Go
to
the
Bath
:
 
<EOS>
I
hope
you
are
now
at
the
Bath
,
if
you
had
a
mind
to
go
;
or
go
to
Wexford
:
 
do
something
for
your
living
.
 
<EOS>
Have
you
given
up
my
lodging
,
according
to
order
?
 
<EOS>
I
have
had
just
now
a
compliment
from
Dean
Atterbury
's
lady
,
to
command
the
garden
and
library
,
and
whatever
the
house
affords
.
 
<EOS>
I
lodge
just
over
against
them
;
but
the
Dean
is
in
town
with
his
Convocation
:
 
<EOS>
so
I
have
my
Dean
and
Prolocutor
as
well
as
you
,
young
women
,
though
he
has
not
so
good
wine
,
nor
so
much
meat
.
  
<EOS>
2
.
 
<EOS>
A
fine
day
,
but
begins
to
grow
a
little
warm
;
and
that
makes
your
little
fat
Presto
sweat
in
the
forehead
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
,
are
not
the
fine
buns
sold
here
in
our
town
;
was
it
not
Rrrrrrrrrare
Chelsea
buns
?
 
<EOS>
I
bought
one
to
-
day
in
my
walk
;
it
cost
me
a
penny
;
it
was
stale
,
and
I
did
not
like
it
,
as
the
man
said
,
etc
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Andrew
Fountaine
and
I
dined
at
Mrs.
Vanhomrigh
's
,
and
had
a
flask
of
my
Florence
,
which
lies
in
their
cellar
;
and
so
I
came
home
gravely
,
and
saw
nobody
of
consequence
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
very
easy
here
,
nobody
plaguing
me
in
a
morning
;
and
Patrick
saves
many
a
score
lies
.
 
<EOS>
I
sent
over
to
Mrs
Atterbury
to
know
whether
I
might
wait
on
her
;
but
she
is
gone
a
visiting
:
 
we
have
exchanged
some
compliments
,
but
I
have
not
seen
her
yet
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
no
news
in
our
town
.
  
<EOS>
3
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
not
go
to
town
to
-
day
,
it
was
so
terrible
rainy
;
nor
have
I
stirred
out
of
my
room
till
eight
<EOS>
this
evening
,
when
I
crossed
the
way
to
see
Mrs.
Atterbury
,
and
thank
her
for
her
civilities
.
 
<EOS>
She
would
needs
send
me
some
veal
,
and
small
beer
,
and
ale
,
to
-
day
at
dinner
;
and
I
have
lived
a
scurvy
,
dull
,
splenetic
day
,
for
want
of
MD
:
 
<EOS>
I
often
thought
how
happy
I
could
have
been
,
had
it
rained
eight
thousand
times
more
,
if
MD
had
been
with
a
body
.
 
<EOS>
My
Lord
Rochester
is
dead
this
morning
;
they
say
at
one
o'clock
;
and
I
hear
he
died
suddenly
.
 
<EOS>
To
-
morrow
<EOS>
I
shall
know
more
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a
great
loss
to
us
:
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
think
who
will
succeed
him
as
Lord
President
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
writing
a
long
letter
to
Lord
Peterborow
,
and
am
dull
.
  
<EOS>
4
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
at
Lord
Shelburne
's
,
where
Lady
Kerry
made
me
a
present
of
four
India
handkerchiefs
,
which
I
have
a
mind
to
keep
for
little
MD
,
only
that
I
had
rather
,
etc
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
a
mighty
handkerchief
-
monger
,
and
have
bought
abundance
of
snuff
ones
since
I
have
left
off
taking
snuff
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
am
resolved
,
when
I
come
over
,
MD
shall
be
acquainted
with
Lady
Kerry
:
 
we
have
struck
up
a
mighty
friendship
;
and
she
has
much
better
sense
than
any
other
lady
of
your
country
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
almost
in
love
with
one
another
:
 
<EOS>
but
she
is
most
egregiously
ugly
;
but
perfectly
well
-
bred
,
and
governable
as
I
please
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
resolved
,
when
I
come
,
to
keep
no
company
but
MD
:
 
<EOS>
you
know
I
kept
my
resolution
last
time
;
and
,
except
Mr.
Addison
,
conversed
with
none
but
you
and
your
club
of
deans
and
Stoytes
.
 
<EOS>
'
Tis
three
weeks
,
young
women
,
since
I
had
a
letter
from
you
;
and
yet
,
methinks
,
I
would
not
have
another
for
five
pounds
till
this
is
gone
;
and
yet
I
send
every
day
to
the
Coffee
-
house
,
and
I
would
fain
have
a
letter
,
and
not
have
a
letter
:
 
<EOS>
and
I
do
not
know
what
,
nor
<EOS>
I
do
not
know
how
,
and
this
goes
on
very
slow
;
it
is
a
week
to
-
morrow
since
I
began
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
a
poor
country
gentleman
,
and
do
not
know
how
the
world
passes
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
know
that
every
syllable
I
write
I
hold
my
lips
just
for
all
the
world
as
if
I
were
talking
in
our
own
little
language
to
MD
?
 
<EOS>
Faith
,
I
am
very
silly
;
but
I
can
not
help
it
for
my
life
.
 
<EOS>
I
got
home
early
to
-
night
.
 
<EOS>
My
solicitors
,
that
used
to
ply
me
every
morning
,
knew
not
where
to
find
me
;
and
I
am
so
happy
not
to
hear
"
Patrick
,
Patrick
,
"
called
a
hundred
times
every
morning
.
<EOS>
But
I
looked
backward
,
and
find
I
have
said
this
before
.
 
<EOS>
What
care
I
?
 
<EOS>
Go
to
the
Dean
,
and
roast
the
oranges
.
  
<EOS>
5
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
with
my
friend
Lewis
,
and
we
were
deep
in
politics
how
to
save
the
present
Ministry
;
for
I
am
afraid
of
Mr.
Secretary
,
as
I
believe
I
told
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
in
the
evening
to
see
Mr.
Harley
;
and
,
upon
my
word
,
I
was
in
perfect
joy
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Secretary
was
just
going
out
of
the
door
;
but
I
made
him
come
back
,
and
there
was
the
old
Saturday
Club
,
Lord
Keeper
,
Lord
Rivers
,
Mr.
Secretary
,
Mr.
Harley
,
and
I
;
the
first
time
since
his
stabbing
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Secretary
went
away
;
but
I
stayed
till
nine
,
and
made
Mr.
Harley
show
me
his
breast
,
and
tell
all
the
story
;
and
I
showed
him
the
Archbishop
of
Dublin
's
letter
,
and
defended
him
effectually
.
 
<EOS>
We
were
all
in
mighty
good
humour
.
<EOS>
Lord
Keeper
and
I
left
them
together
,
and
I
walked
here
after
nine
two
miles
,
and
I
found
a
parson
drunk
fighting
with
a
seaman
,
and
Patrick
and
I
were
so
wise
to
part
them
,
but
the
seaman
followed
him
to
Chelsea
,
cursing
at
him
,
and
the
parson
slipped
into
a
house
,
and
I
know
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
It
mortified
me
to
see
a
man
in
my
coat
so
overtaken
.
 
<EOS>
A
pretty
scene
for
one
that
just
came
from
sitting
with
the
Prime
Ministers
!
 
<EOS>
I
had
no
money
in
my
pocket
,
and
so
could
not
be
robbed
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
nothing
but
Mr.
Harley
shall
make
me
take
such
a
journey
again
.
 
<EOS>
We
do
n't
yet
know
who
will
be
President
in
Lord
Rochester
's
room
.
 
<EOS>
I
measured
,
and
found
that
the
penknife
would
have
killed
Mr.
Harley
if
it
had
gone
but
<EOS>
half
the
breadth
of
my
thumb
-
nail
<EOS>
lower
,
<EOS>
so
near
was
he
to
death
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
so
curious
as
to
ask
him
what
were
his
thoughts
while
they
were
carrying
him
home
in
the
chair
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
he
concluded
himself
a
dead
man
.
 
<EOS>
He
will
not
allow
that
Guiscard
gave
him
the
second
stab
;
though
my
Lord
Keeper
,
who
is
blind
,
and
I
that
was
not
there
,
are
positive
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
wears
a
plaster
still
as
broad
as
half
a
crown
.
 
<EOS>
Smoke
how
wide
the
lines
are
,
but
,
faith
,
I
do
n't
do
it
on
purpose
:
 
<EOS>
but
I
have
changed
my
side
in
this
new
Chelsea
bed
,
and
I
do
not
know
how
,
methinks
,
but
it
is
so
unfit
,
and
so
awkward
,
never
saw
the
like
.
  
<EOS>
6
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
remember
to
enclose
your
letters
in
a
fair
paper
,
and
direct
the
outside
thus
:
 
"
To
Erasmus
Lewis
,
Esq
.
;
at
my
Lord
Dartmouth
's
office
at
Whitehall
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
I
said
so
before
,
but
it
may
miscarry
,
you
know
,
yet
I
think
none
of
my
letters
did
ever
miscarry
;
faith
<EOS>
,
I
think
never
one
;
among
all
the
privateers
and
the
storms
.
 
<EOS>
O
,
faith
,
my
letters
are
too
good
to
be
lost
.
<EOS>
MD
's
letters
may
tarry
,
but
never
miscarry
,
as
the
old
woman
used
to
say
.
 
<EOS>
And
indeed
,
how
should
they
miscarry
,
when
they
never
come
before
their
time
?
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
terrible
rainy
day
;
yet
I
made
a
shift
to
steal
fair
weather
overhead
enough
to
go
and
come
in
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
early
with
the
Secretary
,
and
dined
with
him
afterwards
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
morning
I
began
to
chide
him
,
and
tell
him
my
fears
of
his
proceedings
.
 
<EOS>
But
Arthur
Moore
came
up
and
relieved
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
forgot
,
for
you
never
heard
of
Arthur
Moore
.
 
<EOS>
But
when
I
get
Mr.
Harley
alone
,
I
will
know
the
bottom
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
have
Dr.
Raymond
over
before
this
letter
,
and
what
care
you
?
  
<EOS>
7
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
and
believe
my
walks
every
day
do
me
good
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
busy
at
home
,
and
set
out
late
this
morning
,
and
dined
with
Mrs.
Vanhomrigh
,
at
whose
lodgings
I
always
change
my
gown
and
periwig
.
 
<EOS>
I
visited
this
afternoon
,
and
among
others
,
poor
Biddy
Floyd
,
who
is
very
red
,
but
I
believe
wo
n't
be
much
marked
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
was
coming
home
,
I
met
Sir
George
Beaumont
in
the
Pall
Mall
,
who
would
needs
walk
with
me
as
far
as
Buckingham
House
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
telling
him
of
my
head
;
he
said
he
had
been
ill
of
the
same
disorder
,
and
by
all
means
forbid
me
bohea
tea
,
which
,
he
said
,
always
gave
it
him
;
and
that
Dr.
Radcliffe
said
it
was
very
bad
.
 
<EOS>
Now
I
had
observed
the
same
thing
,
and
have
left
it
off
this
month
,
having
found
myself
ill
after
it
several
times
;
and
I
mention
it
that
Stella
may
consider
it
for
her
own
poor
little
head
:
 
<EOS>
a
pound
lies
ready
packed
up
and
directed
for
Mrs.
Walls
,
to
be
sent
by
the
first
convenience
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Secretary
told
me
yesterday
that
Mr.
Harley
would
this
week
be
Lord
Treasurer
and
a
peer
;
so
I
expect
it
every
day
;
yet
perhaps
it
may
not
be
till
Parliament
is
up
,
which
will
be
in
a
fortnight
.
  
<EOS>
8
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
to
-
day
with
the
Duke
of
Ormond
,
and
recommended
to
him
the
care
of
poor
Joe
Beaumont
,
who
promises
me
to
do
him
all
justice
and
favour
,
and
give
him
encouragement
;
and
desired
I
would
give
a
memorial
to
Ned
Southwell
about
it
,
which
I
will
,
and
so
tell
Joe
when
you
see
him
,
though
he
knows
it
already
by
a
letter
I
writ
to
Mr.
Warburton
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
bloody
hot
walking
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
in
the
City
,
and
went
and
came
by
water
;
and
it
rained
so
this
evening
again
,
that
I
thought
I
should
hardly
be
able
to
get
a
dry
hour
to
walk
home
in
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
send
to
-
morrow
to
the
Coffee
-
house
for
a
letter
from
MD
;
but
I
would
not
have
one
methinks
till
this
is
gone
,
as
it
shall
on
Saturday
.
 
<EOS>
I
visited
the
Duchess
of
Ormond
this
morning
;
she
does
not
go
over
with
the
Duke
.
 
<EOS>
I
spoke

to

for

,

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Mary

.
 
<EOS>
This

's

;

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

;
and

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Dering

<EOS>
This

,

<EOS>
CHELSEA
,
May
12
,
1711
.
  
<EOS>
I
sent
you
my
twenty
-
second
this
afternoon
in
town
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Mr.
Harley
and
the
old
Club
,
Lord
Rivers
,
Lord
Keeper
,
and
Mr.
Secretary
.
 
<EOS>
They
rallied
me
last
week
,
and
said
I
must
have
Mr.
St.
John
's
leave
;
so
I
writ
to
him
yesterday
,
that
foreseeing
I
should
never
dine
again
with
Sir
Simon
Harcourt
,
Knight
,
and
Robert
Harley
,
Esq
.
<EOS>
,
I
was
resolved
to
do
it
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
The
jest
is
,
that
before
Saturday
next
we
expect
they
will
be
lords
;
for
Mr.
Harley
's
patent
is
drawing
,
to
be
Earl
of
Oxford
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Secretary
and
I
came
away
at
seven
,
and
he
brought
me
to
our
town
's
end
in
his
coach
;
<EOS>
so
I
lost
my
walk
.
<EOS>
St.
John
read
my
letter
to
the
company
,
which
was
all
raillery
,
and
passed
purely
.
  
<EOS>
13
.
 
<EOS>
It
rained
all
last
night
and
this
morning
as
heavy
as
lead
;
but
I
just
got
fair
weather
to
walk
to
town
before
church
.
 
<EOS>
The
roads
are
all
over
in
deep
puddle
.
 
<EOS>
The
hay
of
our
town
is
almost
fit
to
be
mowed
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
to
Court
after
church
(
as
I
always
do
on
Sundays
,
and
then
dined
with
Mr.
Secretary
,
who
has
engaged
me
for
every
Sunday
;
and
poor
MD
dined
at
home
upon
a
bit
of
veal
and
a
pint
of
wine
.
 
<EOS>
Is
it
not
plaguy
insipid
to
tell
you
every
day
where
I
dine
?
<EOS>
yet
now
I
have
got
into
the
way
of
it
<EOS>
,
I
can
not

neither
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
Mr.
Presto
,

's

,
N.14
.
 
<EOS>
I
will

when

,
Mr.
Doctor
.
 
<EOS>
What
is
that
you
say
?
 
<EOS>
The
Court
was
very
full
this
morning
,
expecting
Mr.
Harley
would
be
declared
Earl
of
Oxford
and
have
the
Treasurer
's
staff
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Harley
never
comes
to
Court
at
all
;
somebody
there
asked
me
the
reason
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
"
said
I
,
"
the
Lord
of
Oxford
knows
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He
always
goes
to
the
Queen
by
the
back
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
told
for
certain
,
you
jackanapes
,
Lord
Santry
was
dead
,
Captain
Cammock
assured
me
so
;
and
now
he
's
alive
again
,
they
say
;
but
that
sha
n't
do
:
 
<EOS>
he
shall
be
dead
to
me
as
long
as
he
lives
.
 
<EOS>
Dick
Tighe
and
I
meet
,
and
never
stir
our
hats
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
resolved
to
mistake
him
for
Witherington
,
the
little
nasty
lawyer
that
came
up
to
me
so
sternly
at
the
Castle
the
day

left

.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
ask
the
gentleman
I
saw
walking
with
him
how
long
Witherington
has
been
in
town
.
  
<EOS>
14
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
to
town
to
-
day
by
water
.
 
<EOS>
The
hail
quite
discouraged
me
from
walking
,
and
there
is
no
shade
in
the
greatest
part
of
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
I
took
the
first
boat
,
and
had
a
footman
my
companion
;
then
I
went
again
by
water
,
and
dined
in
the
City
with
a
printer
,
to
whom
I
carried
a
pamphlet
in
manuscript
,
that
Mr.
Secretary
gave
me
.
 
<EOS>
The
printer
sent
it
to
the
Secretary
for
his
approbation
,
and
he
desired
me
to
look
it
over
,
which
I
did
,
and
found
it
a
very
scurvy
piece
.
 
<EOS>
The
reason
I
tell
you
so
,
is
because
it
was
done
by
your
parson
Slap
,
Scrap
,
Flap
(
what
d'ye
call
him
)
,
Trapp
,
your
Chancellor
's
chaplain
.
 
<EOS>
'
Tis
called
A
Character
of
the
Present
Set
of
Whigs
,
and
is
going
to
be
printed
,
and
no
doubt
the
author
will
take
care
to
produce
it
in
Ireland
.
 
<EOS>
Dr.
Freind
was
with
me
,
and
pulled
out
a
twopenny
pamphlet
just
published
,
called
The
State
of
Wit
,
giving
a
character
of
all
the
papers
that
have
come
out
of
late
.
 
<EOS>
The
author
seems
to
be
a
Whig
,
yet
he
speaks
very
highly
of
a
paper
called
the
Examiner
,
and
says
the
supposed
author
of
it
is
Dr.
Swift
.
 
<EOS>
But
above
all
things
he
praises
the
Tatlers
and
Spectators
;
and
I
believe
Steele
and
Addison
were
privy
to
the
printing
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
is
one
treated
by
these
impudent
dogs
.
 
<EOS>
And
that
villain
Curll
has
scraped
up
some
trash
,
and
calls
it
Dr.
Swift
's
Miscellanies
,
with
the
name
at
large
:
 
<EOS>
and
I
can
get
no
satisfaction
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
Nay
,
Mr.
Harley
told
me
he
had
read
it
,
and
only
laughed
at
me
before
Lord
Keeper
and
the
rest
.
 
<EOS>
Since
I
came
home
,
I
have
been
sitting
with
the
Prolocutor
,
Dean
Atterbury
,
who
is
my
neighbour
over
the
way
,
but
generally
keeps
in
town
with
his
Convocation
.
 
<EOS>
'
Tis
late
,
etc
.
  
<EOS>
15
.
 
<EOS>
My
walk
to
town
to
-
day
was
after
ten
,
and
prodigiously
hot
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Lord
Shelburne
,
and
have
desired
Mrs.
Pratt
,
who
lodges
there
,
to
carry
over
Mrs.
Walls
's
tea
;
I
hope
she
will
do
it
,
and
they
talk
of
going
in
a
fortnight
.
 
<EOS>
My
way
is
this
:
 
I
leave
my
best
gown
and
periwig
at
Mrs.
Vanhomrigh
's
,
then
walk
up
the
Pall
Mall
,
through
the
Park
,
out
at
Buckingham
House
,
and
so
to
Chelsea
a
little
beyond
the
church
:
 
<EOS>
I
set
out
about
sunset
,
and
get
here
in
something
less
than
an
hour
;
it
is
two
good
miles
,
and
just
five
thousand
seven
hundred
and
forty
-
eight
steps
;
so
there
is
four
miles
a
day
walking
,
without
reckoning
what
I
walk
while
I
stay
in
town
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
pass
the
Mall
in
the
evening
,
it
is
prodigious
to
see
the
number
of
ladies
walking
there
;
and
I
always
cry
shame
at
the
ladies
of
Ireland
,
who
never
walk
at
all
,
as
if
their
legs
were
of
no
use
,
but
to
be
laid
aside
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
now
almost
three
weeks
here
,
and
I
thank
God
,
am
much
better
in
my
head
,
if
it
does
but
continue
.
 
<EOS>
I
tell
you
what
,
if
I
was
with
you
,
when
we
went
to
Stoyte
at
Donnybrook
,
we
would
only
take
a
coach
to
the
hither
end
of
Stephen
's
Green
,
and
from
thence
go
every
step
on
foot
,
yes
,
faith
,
every
step
;
it
would
do
DD
good
as
well
as
Presto
.
 
<EOS>
Everybody
tells
me
I
look
better
already
;
for
,
faith
,
I
looked
sadly
,
that
is
certain
.
 
<EOS>
My
breakfast
is
milk
porridge
:
<EOS>
I
do
not
love
it
;
faith
,
I
hate
it
,
but
it
is
cheap
and
wholesome
;
and
I
hate
to
be
obliged
to
either
of
those
qualities
for
anything
.
  
<EOS>
16
.
 
<EOS>
I
wonder
why
Presto
will
be
so
tedious
in
answering
MD
's
letters
;
because
he
would
keep
the
best
to
the
last
,
I
suppose
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
Presto
must
be
humoured
,
it
must
be
as
he
will
have
it
,
or
there
will
be
an
old
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
Dead
with
heat
;
are
not
you
very
hot
?
 
<EOS>
My
walks
make
my
forehead
sweat
rarely
;
sometimes
my
morning
journey
is
by
water
,
as
it
was
to
-
day
with
one
Parson
Richardson
,

;

.
 
<EOS>
Lord
!
<EOS>
I

,

17
.
 
<EOS>
Sterne

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

Colledge
:

,

,
<EOS>
worth

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
This

<EOS>
I

:
 
<EOS>

:
 
<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>
"

18
.

<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
There

a
mighty

dirty

in

since

London
.
 
<EOS>
I
stayed

,

;
then

by

's
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

Lord

;
and
the

writ

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr.

Buckingham

.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
Then

<EOS>

<EOS>

;

;

:
 
<EOS>
and

.
 
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

'

,

23
.
 
<EOS>
Morning
.
 
<EOS>
I
sat

,

;
but

;

.
 
<EOS>
No
,

;

14
,

;

?
 
<EOS>
What

?
 
<EOS>
Go
to

,

's

:
 
<EOS>
I
wish

to

three

,

's

.
 
<EOS>
Walking

,
that
I
can
not
but

.
 
<EOS>
Parvisol
has

,

,

,

;

:
 
<EOS>
he

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

;

,

,

MD
's

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

;

:
 
yet

I

,
faith
.
 
<EOS>
No
,

,

;

;

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
Will

say
?
 
<EOS>
A

would

,
or

the

.
<EOS>
O
,

,

MD
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

,

,
if

.
 
<EOS>
To

without
some
mark

would

little
;
and
I
would
likewise
gladly

somewhat
richer
than
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
will
say
no
more
,
but

to
be

till
Fortune
take
her

,
and
to
believe
that
MD
's

is
the
great
end
I
aim

in

.
 
<EOS>
And
so

no

on
this

,
which

,
and
that
I
would
fain

.
<EOS>
Believe
me
,
no
man
breathing
at
present
has
less
share
of
happiness
in

than
I
:
 
<EOS>
I
do

at

,
but
that

here

for

as

.
 
<EOS>
And

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Well
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Pox

!
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

at
his
lodgings
,
and
I
found
wine
out
of
my
own
cellar
<EOS>
,
some
of
my
own
chest
of
the
great
Duke
's
wine
:
 
it
begins
to
turn
.
 
<EOS>
They
say
wine
with
you
in
Ireland
is
half
a
crown
a
bottle
.
 
<EOS>
'
Tis
as
Stella
says
;
nothing
that
once
grows
dear
in
Ireland
ever
grows
cheap
again
,
except
corn
,
with
a
pox
,
to
ruin
the
parson
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
a
letter
to
-
day
from
the
Archbishop
of
Dublin
,
giving
me
further
thanks
about
vindicating
him
to
Mr.
Harley
and
Mr.
St.
John
,
and
telling
me
a
long
story
about
your
Mayor
's
election
<EOS>
,
wherein
I
find
he
has
had
a
finger
,
and
given
way
to
further
talk
about
him
;
but
we
know
nothing
of
it
here
yet
.
 
<EOS>
This
walking
to
and
fro
,
and
dressing
myself
,
takes
up
so
much
of
my
time
that
I
can
not
go
among
company
so
much
as
formerly
;
yet
what
must
a
body
do
?
 
<EOS>
I
thank
God
I
yet
continue
much
better
since
I
left
the
town
;
I
know
not
how
long
it
may
last
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
it
has
done
me
some
good
for
the
present
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
not
totter
as
I
did
,
but
walk
firm
as
a
cock
,
only
once
or
twice
for
a
minute
<EOS>
,
I
do
not
know
how
;
but
it
went
off
,
and
I
never
followed
it
.
 
<EOS>
Does
Dingley
read
my
hand
as
well
as
ever
?
<EOS>
do
you
,
sirrah
?
 
<EOS>
Poor
Stella
must
not
read
Presto
's
ugly
small
hand
.
       
<EOS>
Preserve
your
eyes
,
     
<EOS>
If
you
be
wise
.
  
<EOS>
Your
friend
Walls
's
tea
will
go
in
a
day
or
two
towards
Chester
by
one
Parson
Richardson
.
 
<EOS>
My
humble
service
to
her
,
and
to
good
Mrs.
Stoyte
,
and
Catherine
;
and
pray
walk
while
you
continue
in
Dublin
.
 
<EOS>
I
expect
your
next
but
one
will
be
from
Wexford
.
 
<EOS>
God
bless
dearest
MD
.
  
<EOS>
24
.
 
<EOS>
Morning
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Secretary
has
sent
his
groom
hither
,
to
invite
me
to
dinner
to
-
day
,
etc
.
 
<EOS>
God
Almighty
for
ever
bless
and
preserve
you
both
,
and
give
you
health
,
etc
.
 
<EOS>
Amen
.
 
<EOS>
Farewell
,
etc
.
  
<EOS>
Do
not
I
often
say
the
same
thing
two
or
three
times
in
the
same
letter
,
sirrah
?
  
<EOS>
Great
wits
,
they
say
,
have
but
short
memories
;
that
's
good
vile
conversation
.
   
<EOS>
LETTER
24
.
 
<EOS>
CHELSEA
,
May
24
,
1711
.
  
<EOS>
Morning
.
 
<EOS>
Once
in
my
life
the
number
of
my
letters
and
of
the
day
of
the
month
is
the
same
;
that
's
lucky
,
boys
;
that
's
a
sign
that
things
will
meet
,
and
that
we
shall
make
a
figure
together
.
 
<EOS>
What
,
will
you
still
have
the
impudence
to
say
London
,
England
,
because
I
say
Dublin
,
Ireland
?
 
<EOS>
Is
there
no
difference
between
London
and
Dublin
,
saucyboxes
?
 
<EOS>
I
have
sealed
up
my
letter
,
and
am
going
to
town
.
 
<EOS>
Morrow
,
sirrahs
.
 
<EOS>
At
night
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
the
Secretary
to
-
day
;
we
sat
down
between
five
and
six
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Harley
's
patent
passed
this
morning
:
 
<EOS>
he
is
now
Earl
of
Oxford
,
Earl
Mortimer
,
and
Lord
Harley
of
Wigmore
Castle
.
 
<EOS>
My
letter
was
sealed
,
or
I
would
have
told
you
this
yesterday
;
but
the
public
news
may
tell
it
you
.
 
<EOS>
The
Queen
,
for
all
her
favour
,
has
kept
a
rod
for
him
in
her
closet
this
week
;
I
suppose
he
will
take
it
from
her
,
though
,
in
a
day
or
two
.
 
<EOS>
At
eight
o'clock
this
evening
it
rained
prodigiously
,
as
it
did
from
five
;
however
,
I
set
out
,
and
in
half
-
way
the
rain
lessened
,
and
I
got
home
,
but
tolerably
wet
;
and
this
is
the
first
wet
walk
I
have
had
in
a
month
's
time
that
I
am
here
<EOS>
but
,
however
,
I
got
to
bed
,
after
a
short
visit
to
Atterbury
.
  
<EOS>
25
.
 
<EOS>
It
rained
this
morning
,
and
I
went
to
town
by
water
;
and
Ford
and
I
dined
with
Mr.
Lewis
by
appointment
.
 
<EOS>
I
ordered
Patrick
to
bring
my
gown
and
periwig
to
Mr.
Lewis
,
because
I
designed
to
go
to
see
Lord
Oxford
,
and
so
I
told
the
dog
;
but
he
never
came
,
though
I
stayed
an
hour
longer
than
I
appointed
;
so
I
went
in
my
old
gown
,
and
sat
with
him
two
hours
,
but
could
not
talk
over
some
business
I
had
with
him
;
so
he
has
desired
me
to
dine
with
him
on
Sunday
,
and
I
must
disappoint
the
Secretary
.
 
<EOS>
My
lord
set
me
down
at
a
coffee
-
house
,
where
I
waited
for
the
Dean
of
Carlisle
's
chariot
to
bring
me
to
Chelsea
;
for
it
has
rained
prodigiously
all
this
afternoon
.
 
<EOS>
The
Dean
did
not
come
himself
,
but
sent
me
his
chariot
,
which
has
cost
me
two
shillings
to
the
coachman
;
and
so
I
am
got
home
,
and
Lord
knows
what
is
become
of
Patrick
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
I
must
send
him
over
to
you
;
for
he
is
an
intolerable
rascal
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
had
come
without
a
gown
,
he
would
have
served
me
so
,
though
my
life
and
preferment
should
have
lain
upon
it
:
 
and
I
am
making
a
livery
for
him
will
cost
me
four
pounds
;
but
I
will
order
the
tailor
to
-
morrow
to
stop
till
further
orders
.
 
<EOS>
My
Lord
Oxford
ca
n't
yet
abide
to
be
called
"
my
lord
"
;
and
when
I
called
him
"
my
lord
,
"
he
called
me
"
Dr.
Thomas
Swift
,
"
which
he
always
does
when
he
has
a
mind
to
tease
me
.
 
<EOS>
By
a
second
hand
,
he
proposed
my
being
his
chaplain
,
which
I
by
a
second
hand
excused
;
but
we
had
no
talk
of
it
to
-
day
:
 
but
I
will
be
no
man
's
chaplain
alive
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
must
go
and
be
busy
.
  
<EOS>
26
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
saw
Patrick
till
this
morning
,
and
that
only
once
,
for
I
dressed
myself
without
him
;
and
when
I
went
to
town
he
was
out
of
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
I
immediately
sent
for
the
tailor
,
and
ordered
him
to
stop
his
hand
in
Patrick
's
clothes
till
further
orders
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
if
it
were
in
Ireland
,
I
should
have
turned
him
off
ten
times
ago
;
and
it
is
no
regard
to
him
,
but
myself
,
that
has
made
me
keep
him
so
long
.
 
<EOS>
Now
I
am
afraid
to
give
the
rogue
his
clothes
.
 
<EOS>
What
shall
I
do
?
 
<EOS>
I
wish
MD
were
here
to
entreat
for
him
,
just
here
at
the
bed
's
side
.
 
<EOS>
Lady
Ashburnham
has
been
engaging
me
this
long
time
to
dine
with
her
,
and
I
set
to
-
day
apart
for
it
;
and
whatever
was
the
mistake
,
she
sent
me
word
she
was
at
dinner
and
undressed
,
but
would
be
glad
to
see
me
in
the
afternoon
:
 
<EOS>
so
I
dined
with
Mrs.
Vanhomrigh
,
and
would
not
go
to
see
her
at
all
,
in
a
huff
.
 
<EOS>
My
fine
Florence
is
turning
sour
with
a
vengeance
,
and
I
have
not
drunk
half
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
was
coming
home
to
-
night
,
Sir
Thomas
Mansel
and
Tom
Harley
met
me
in
the
Park
,
and
made
me
walk
with
them
till
nine
,
like
unreasonable
whelps
;
<EOS>
so
I
got
not
here
till
ten
:
 
<EOS>
but
it
was
a
fine
evening
,
and
the
foot
-
path
clean
enough
already
after
this
hard
rain
.
  
<EOS>
27
.
 
<EOS>
Going
this
morning
to
town
,
I
saw
two
old
lame
fellows
,
walking
to
a
brandy
-
shop
,
and
when
they
got
to
the
door
,
stood
a
long
time
complimenting
who
should
go
in
first
.
 
<EOS>
Though
this
be
no
jest
to
tell
,
it
was
an
admirable
one
to
see
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
with
my
Lord
Oxford
and
the
ladies
,
the
new
Countess
,
and
Lady
Betty
,
who
has
been
these
three
days
a
lady
born
.
 
<EOS>
My
lord
left
us
at
seven
,
and
I
had
no
time
to
speak
to
him
about
some
affairs
;
but
he
promises
in
a
day
or
two
we
shall
dine
alone
;
which
is
mighty
likely
,
considering
we
expect
every
moment
that
the
Queen
will
give
him
the
staff
,
and
then
he
will
be
so
crowded
he
will
be
good
for
nothing
:
 
for
aught
<EOS>
I
know
he
may
have
it
to
-
night
at
Council
.
  
<EOS>
28
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
a
petition
sent
me
t'other
day
from
one
Stephen
Gernon
,
setting
forth
that
he
formerly
lived
with
Harry
Tenison
,
who
gave
him
an
employment
of
gauger
,
and
that
he
was
turned
out
after
Harry
's
death
,
and
came
for
England
,
and
is
now
starving
,
or
,
as
he
expresses
it
,
<EOS>
THAT
THE
STAFF
OF
LIFE
HAS
BEEN
OF
LATE
A
STRANGER
TO
HIS
APPETITE
.
 
<EOS>
Today
the
poor
fellow
called
,
and
I
knew
him
very
well
,
a
young
slender
fellow
with
freckles
in
his
face
:
you
must
remember
him
;
he
waited
at
table
as
a
better
sort
of
servant
.
 
<EOS>
I
gave
him
a
crown
,
and
promised
to
do
what
I
could
to
help
him
to
a
service
,
which
I
did
for
Harry
Tenison
's
memory
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
bloody
hot
walking
to
-
day
,
and
I
was
so
lazy
<EOS>
I
dined
where
my
new
gown
was
,
at
Mrs.
Vanhomrigh
's
,
and
came
back
like
a
fool
,
and
the
Dean
of
Carlisle
has
sat
with
me
till
eleven
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Oxford
has
not
the
staff
yet
.
  
<EOS>
29
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this
morning
in
town
by
ten
,
though
it
was
shaving
-
day
,
and
went
to
the
Secretary
about
some
affairs
,
then
visited
the
Duke
and
Duchess
of
Ormond
;
but
the
latter
was
dressing
to
go
out
,
and
I
could
not
see
her
.
 
<EOS>
My
Lord
Oxford
had
the
staff
given
him
this
morning
;
so
now
I
must
call
him
Lord
Oxford
no
more
,
but
Lord
Treasurer
:
 
<EOS>
I
hope
he
will
stick
there
:
 
<EOS>
this
is
twice
he
has
changed
his
name
this
week
;
and
I
heard
to
-
day
in
the
City
(
where
I
dined
)
that
he
will
very
soon
have
the
Garter
.
 
<EOS>
Pr'ythee
,
do
not
you
observe
how
strangely
I
have
changed
my
company
and
manner
of
living
?
 
<EOS>
I
never
go
to
a
coffee
-
house
;
you
hear
no
more
of
Addison
,
Steele
,
Henley
,
Lady
Lucy
,
Mrs.
Finch
,
Lord
Somers
,
Lord
Halifax
,
etc
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
I
have
altered
for
the
better
.
 
<EOS>
Did
I
tell
you
the
Archbishop
of
Dublin
has
writ
me
a
long
letter
of
a
squabble
in
your
town
about
choosing
a
Mayor
,
and
that
he
apprehended
some
censure
for
the
share
he
had
in
