?
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
heard
anything
of
it
here
;
but
I
shall
not
be
always
able
to
defend
him
.
 
<EOS>
We
hear
your
Bishop
Hickman
is
dead
;
but
nobody
here
will
do
anything
for
me
in
Ireland
;
so
they
may
die
as
fast
or
slow
as
they
please
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
you
are
constant
to
your
deans
,
and
your
Stoyte
,
and
your
Walls
.
 
<EOS>
Walls
will
have
her
tea
soon
;
Parson
Richardson
is
either
going
or
gone
to
Ireland
,
and
has
it
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
hear
Mr.
Lewis
has
two
letters
for
me
:
 
I
could
not
call
for
them
to
-
day
,
but
will
to
-
morrow
;
and
perhaps
one
of
them
may
be
from
our
little
MD
,
who
knows
,
man
?
<EOS>
who
can
tell
?
<EOS>
Many
a
more
unlikely
thing
has
happened
.
 
<EOS>
Pshaw
,
I
write
so
plaguy
little
,
I
can
hardly
see
it
myself
.
 
<EOS>
WRITE
BIGGER
,
SIRRAH
Presto
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
<EOS>
but
I
wo
n't
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
you
are
a
saucy
rogue
,
Mr.
Presto
,
you
are
so
impudent
.
 
<EOS>
Come
,
dear
rogues
,
let
Presto
go
to
sleep
;
I
have
been
with
the
Dean
,
and
'
tis
near
twelve
.
  
<EOS>
30
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
so
hot
and
lazy
after
my
morning
's
walk
,
that
I
loitered
at
Mrs.
Vanhomrigh
's
,
where
my
best
gown
and
periwig
are
,
and
out
of
mere
listlessness
dine
there
very
often
;
so
I
did
to
-
day
;
but
I
got
little
MD
's
letter
,
N.15
<EOS>
(
you
see
,
sirrahs
,
I
remember
to
tell
the
number
)
,
from
Mr.
Lewis
,
and
I
read
it
in
a
closet
they
lend
me
at
Mrs.
Van
's
;
and
I
find
Stella
is
a
saucy
rogue
and
a
great
writer
,
and
can
write
finely
still
when
her
hand
is
in
,
and
her
pen
good
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
came
here
to
-
night
,
I
had
a
mighty
mind
to
go
swim
after
I
was
cool
,
for
my
lodging
is
just
by
the
river
;
and
I
went
down
with
only
my
nightgown
and
slippers
on
at
eleven
,
but
came
up
again
;
however
,
one
of
these
nights
I
will
venture
.
  
<EOS>
31
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
so
hot
this
morning
with
my
walk
,
that
I
resolve
to
do
so
no
more
during
this
violent
burning
weather
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
comical
that
now
we
happen
to
have
such
heat
to
ripen
the
fruit
there
has
been
the
greatest
blast
that
was
ever
known
,
and
almost
all
the
fruit
is
despaired
of
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Lord
Shelburne
:
<EOS>
Lady
Kerry
and
Mrs.
Pratt
are
going
to
Ireland
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
this
evening
to
Lord
Treasurer
,
and
sat
about
two
hours
with
him
in
mixed
company
;
he
left
us
,
and
went
to
Court
,
and
carried
two
staves
with
him
,
so
I
suppose
we
shall
have
a
new
Lord
Steward
or
Comptroller
to
-
morrow
;
I
smoked
that
State
secret
out
by
that
accident
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
not
answer
your
letter
yet
,
sirrahs
;
<EOS>
no
I
wo
n't
,
madam
.
  
<EOS>
June
1
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
you
a
merry
month
of
June
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
again
with
the
Vans
and
Sir
Andrew
Fountaine
.
 
<EOS>
I
always
give
them
a
flask
of
my
Florence
,
which
now
begins
to
spoil
,
but
it
is
near
an
end
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
this
afternoon
to
Mrs.
Vedeau
's
,
and
brought
away
Madam
Dingley
's
parchment
and
letter
of

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Vedeau
tells

she
has
sent
the
bill
a

.
 
<EOS>
I
will
give

to
Ben
Tooke
,
and
you

a
letter

attorney

,

Presto
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
I
now
think
your
mackerel
is
full
as
good
as
ours
,
which
I
did
not
think
formerly
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
bit
about
two
staves
,
for
there
is
no
new
officer
made
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
This
letter
will
find
you
still
in
Dublin
,
I

,
or
at

,
or
losing
your
money
at
Walls
'
(
how

do
?
)
.
  
<EOS>
2
.
 
<EOS>
I
missed
this

by
a

and
dining
in
the
City
.
  
<EOS>
3
.
 
<EOS>
No
boats
on
Sunday
,
never
:
 
<EOS>
so
I
was
forced
to
walk
,
and
so
hot
by
the
time
I
got
to
Ford
's
lodging
<EOS>
that
I
was
quite
spent
<EOS>
;
I
think
the
weather
is
mad
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
go
to
church
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
the
Secretary
as
usual
,
and
old
Colonel
Graham
that
lived
at
Bagshot
Heath
,
and
they
said
it
was
Colonel
Graham
's
house
.
 
<EOS>
Pshaw
,
I
remember
it
very
well
,
when
I
used
to
go
for
a
walk
to
London
from
Moor

.
 
<EOS>
What
,
I
warrant
you
do
not
remember
the
Golden
Farmer
neither
,
figgarkick
soley
?
  
<EOS>
4
.
 
<EOS>
When
must
we
answer
this
letter
,
this
N.15
of
our
little
MD
?
 
<EOS>
Heat
and
laziness
,
and
Sir
Andrew
Fountaine
,
made
me
dine
to
-
day
again
at
Mrs.
Van
's
;
and
,
in
short
,
this
weather
is
unsupportable
:
 
<EOS>
how
is
it
with
you
?
 
<EOS>
Lady
Betty
Butler
and
Lady
Ashburnham
sat
with

two

this

in

Mrs.
Van
's
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
very
good
girls
;
and
if
Lady
Betty
went
to
Ireland
,
you
should
let
her
be

.
 
<EOS>
How
does
Dingley
do
this
hot
weather
?
 
<EOS>
Stella
,
I
think
,
never
complains
of
it
;
she
loves
hot
weather
.
<EOS>
There
has
not
been
a
drop
of
rain
since
Friday
se'ennight
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
you
do
love
hot
weather
,
<EOS>
naughty
Stella
,
you
do
so
;
and
Presto
ca
n't
abide

.
 
<EOS>
Be
a
good
girl
then
,
and
I
will
love
you
;
and
love
one
another
,
and
do
n't

.
  
<EOS>
5
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
in
the
City
to
-
day
,
and
went
from
hence
early
to
town
,
and
visited
the
Duke
of
Ormond
and
Mr.
Secretary
.
 
<EOS>
They
say
my
Lord
Treasurer
has
a
dead
warrant
in
his
pocket
;
they
mean
a
list
of
those
who
are
to
be
turned
out
of
employment
;
and
we
every
day
now
expect
those
changes
.
 
<EOS>
I
passed
by
the
Treasury
to
-
day
,
and
saw
vast
crowds
waiting
to
give
Lord
Treasurer
petitions
as
he
passes
by
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
now
at
the
top
of
power
and
favour
:
 
<EOS>
he
keeps
no
levees
yet
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
cruel
thirsty
this
hot
weather
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
just
this
minute
going
to
swim
.
 
<EOS>
I
take
Patrick
down
with
me
,
to
hold
my
nightgown
,
shirt
,
and
slippers
,
and
borrow
a
napkin
of
my
landlady
for
a
cap
.
 
<EOS>
So
farewell
till
I
come
up
;
but
there
is
no
danger
,
do
n't
be
frighted
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
swimming
this
half
-
hour
and
more
;
and
when
I
was
coming
out
I
dived
,
to
make
my
head
and
all
through
wet
,
like
a
cold
bath
;
but
,
as
I
dived
,
the
napkin
fell
off
and
is
lost
,
and
I
have
that
to
pay
for
.
 
<EOS>
O
,
faith
,
the
great
stones
were
so
sharp
<EOS>
,
I
could
hardly
set
my
feet
on
them
as
I
came
out
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
pure
and
warm
.
 
<EOS>
I
got
to
bed
,
and
will
now
go
sleep
.
  
<EOS>
6
.
 
<EOS>
Morning
.
 
<EOS>
This
letter
shall
go
to
-
morrow
;
so
I
will
answer
yours
when
I
come
home
to
-
night
.
 
<EOS>
I
feel
no
hurt
from
last
night
's
swimming
.
 
<EOS>
I
lie
with
nothing
but
the
sheet
over
me
,
and
my
feet
quite
bare
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
rise
and
go
to
town
before
the
tide
is
against
me
.
 
<EOS>
Morrow
,
sirrahs
;
dear
sirrahs
,
morrow
.
  
<EOS>
At
night
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
felt
so
hot
a
day
as
this
since
I
was
born
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Lady
Betty
Germaine
,
and
there
was
the
young
Earl
of
Berkeley
and
his
fine
lady
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
saw
her
before
,
nor
think
her
near
so
handsome
as
she
passes
for
.
 
<EOS>
After
dinner
,
Mr.
Bertue
would
not
let
me
put
ice
in
my
wine
,
but
said
my
Lord
Dorchester
got
the
bloody
flux
with
it
,
and
that
it
was
the
worst
thing
in
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
are
we
plagued
,
thus
are
we
plagued
;
yet
I
have
done
it
five
or
six
times
this
summer
,
and
was
but
the
drier
and
the
hotter
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
makes
me
so
excessively
peevish
as
hot
weather
.
 
<EOS>
Lady
Berkeley
after
dinner
clapped
my
hat
on
another
lady
's
head
,
and
she
in
roguery
put
it
upon
the
rails
.
 
<EOS>
I
minded
them
not
;
but
in
two
minutes
they
called
me
to
the
window
,
and
Lady
Carteret
showed
me
my
hat
out
of
her
window
five
doors
off
,
where
I
was
forced
to
walk
to
it
,
and
pay
her
and
old
Lady
Weymouth
a
visit
,
with
some
more
beldames
.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
went
and
drank
coffee
,
and
made
one
or
two
puns
,
with
Lord
Pembroke
,
and
designed
to
go
to
Lord
Treasurer
;
but
it
was
too
late
,
and
beside
I
was
half
broiled
,
and
broiled
without
butter
;
for
I
never
sweat
after
dinner
,
if
I
drink
any
wine
.
<EOS>
Then
I
sat
an
hour
with
Lady
Betty
Butler
at
tea
,
and
everything
made
me
hotter
and
drier
.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
walked
home
,
and
was
here
by
ten
,
so
miserably
hot
,
that
I
was
in
as
perfect
a
passion
as
ever
<EOS>
I
was
in
my
life
at
the
greatest
affront
or
provocation
.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
sat
an
hour
,
till
I
was
quite
dry
and
cool
enough
to
go
swim
;
which
I
did
,
but
with
so
much
vexation
that
I
think
I
have
given
it
over
:
 
for
I
was
every
moment
disturbed
by
boats
,
rot
them
;
and
that
puppy
Patrick
,
standing
ashore
,
would
let
them
come
within
a
yard
or
two
,
and
then
call
sneakingly
to
them
.
 
<EOS>
The
only
comfort
I
proposed
here
in
hot
weather
is
gone
;
for
there
is
no
jesting
with
those
boats
after
it
is
dark
:
 
<EOS>
I
had
none
last
night
.
 
<EOS>
I
dived
to
dip
my
head
,
and
held
my
cap
on
with
both
my
hands
,
for
fear
of
losing
it
.
 
<EOS>
Pox
take
the
boats
!
 
<EOS>
Amen
.
 
<EOS>
'
Tis
near
twelve
,
and
<EOS>
so
I
'll
answer
your
letter
<EOS>
(
it

twelve
now
)
to

.
  
<EOS>
7
.
 
<EOS>
Morning
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
now
let

MD
's

,
N.15
,
15
,
15

15
.
 
<EOS>
Now
have

?
 
<EOS>
15
,
15
;
there
,
impudence
,
to
call
names
in
the

of
your

,
before
you
say
,
How
do

do
,
Mr.
Presto
?
 
<EOS>
There
is
your

!
 
<EOS>
Where
is

manners
,
sirrah
,
to
a

?
 
<EOS>
Get
<EOS>
you
gone
,
you

.
 
<EOS>
No
,
I
never
sit
up
late
now
;
but
this
abominable
hot
weather
will
force
me
to
eat
or
drink
something
that
will
do
me
hurt
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
venture
to
eat
a
few
strawberries
.
 
<EOS>
Why
then
,
do
you
know
in
Ireland
that
Mr.
St.
John
talked
so
in
Parliament
?
 
<EOS>
Your
Whigs
are
plaguily
bit
;
for
he
is
entirely
for
their
being
all
out
.
 
<EOS>
And
are
you
as
vicious
in
snuff
as
ever
?
 
<EOS>
I
believe
,
as
you
say
,
it
does
neither
hurt
nor
good
;
but
I
have
left
it
off
,
and
when
anybody
offers
me
their
box
,
I
take
about
a
tenth
part
of
what
I
used
to
do
,
and
then
just
smell
to
it
,
and
privately
fling
the
rest
away
.
 
<EOS>
I
keep
to
my
tobacco
still
,
as
you
say
;
but
even
much
less
of
that
than
formerly
,
only
mornings
and
evenings
,
and
very
seldom
in
the
day
.
 
<EOS>
As
for
Joe
,
I
have
recommended
his
case
heartily
to
my
Lord
Lieutenant
;
and
,
by
his
direction
,
given
a
memorial
of
it
to
Mr.
Southwell
,
to
whom
I
have
recommended
it
likewise
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
do
no
more
,
if
he
were
my
brother
.
 
<EOS>
His
business
will
be
to
apply
himself
to
Southwell
.
 
<EOS>
And
you
must
desire
Raymond
,
if
Price
of
Galway
comes
to
town
,
to
desire
him
to
wait
on
Mr.
Southwell
,
as
recommended
by
me
for
one
of
the
Duke
's
chaplains
,
which
was
all
I
could
do
for
him
;
and
he
must
be
presented
to
the
Duke
,
and
make
his
court
,
and
ply
about
,
and
find
out
some
vacancy
,
and
solicit
early
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
bustle
about
your
Mayor
<EOS>
I
had
before
,
as
I
told
you
,
from
the
Archbishop
of
Dublin
.
 
<EOS>
Was
Raymond
not
come
till
May
18
?
 
<EOS>
So
he
says
fine
things
of
me
?
 
<EOS>
Certainly
he
lies
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
I
used
him
indifferently
enough
;
and
we
never
once
dined
together
,
or
walked
,
or
were
in
any
third
place
;
only
he
came
sometimes
to
my
lodgings
,
and
even
there
was
oftener
denied
than
admitted
.
 
<EOS>
What
an
odd
bill
is
that
you
sent
of
Raymond
's
!
 
<EOS>
A
bill
upon
one
Murry
in
Chester
,
which
depends
entirely
not
only
upon
Raymond
's
honesty
,
but
his
discretion
;
and
in
money
matters
he
is
the
last
man
I
would
depend
on
.
 
<EOS>
Why
should
Sir
Alexander
Cairnes
in
London
pay
me
a
bill
,
drawn
by
God
<EOS>
knows
who
,
upon
Murry
in
Chester
?
 
<EOS>
I
was
at
Cairnes
's
,
and
they
can
do
no
such
thing
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
among
some
friends
,
who
are
merchants
,
and
I
find
the
bill
must
be
sent
to
Murry
,
accepted
by
him
,
and
then
returned
back
,
and
then
Cairnes
may
accept
or
refuse
it
as
he
pleases
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
I
gave
Sir
Thomas
Frankland
the
bill
,
who
has
sent
it
to
Chester
,
and
ordered
the
postmaster
there
to
get
it
accepted
,
and
then
send
it
back
,
and
in
a
day
or
two
I
shall
have
an
answer
;
and
therefore
this
letter
must
stay
a
day
or
two
longer
than
I
intended
,
and
see
what
answer
I
get
.
 
<EOS>
Raymond
should
have
written
to
Murry
at
the
same
time
,
to
desire
Sir
Alexander
Cairnes
to
have
answered
such
a
bill
,
if
it
come
.
 
<EOS>
But
Cairnes
's
clerks
(
himself
was
not
at
home
)
said
they
had
received
no
notice
of
it
,
and
could
do
nothing
;
and
advised
me
to
send
to
Murry
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
six
weeks
to
-
day
at
Chelsea
,
and
you
know
it
<EOS>
but
just
now
.
 
<EOS>
And
so
Dean
  
thinks
I
write
the
Medley
.
 
<EOS>
Pox
of
his
judgment
!
 
<EOS>
It
is
equal
to
his
honesty
.
 
<EOS>
Then
you
han't
seen
the
Miscellany
yet
?
 
<EOS>
Why
,
'
tis
a
four
-
shilling
book
:
 
<EOS>
has
nobody
carried
it
over
?
 
<EOS>
No
,
I
believe
Manley
will
not
lose
his
place
;
for
his
friend
in
England
is
so
far
from
being
out
that
he
has
taken
a
new
patent
since
the
Post
Office
Act
;
and
his
brother
Jack
Manley
here
takes
his
part
firmly
;
and
I
have
often
spoken
to
Southwell
in
his
behalf
,
and
he
seems
very
well
inclined
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
Irish
folks
here
in
general
are
horribly
violent
against
him
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
he
must
consider
he
could
not
send
Stella
wine
if
he
were
put
out
.
<EOS>
And
so
he
is
very

,
and

AT
<EOS>
A

,
<EOS>
and
you

eight

<EOS>
AT

;
and
how

?
 
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
never
one

about
that
,
I

.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
this
same
Stella
is
so

writer
,
she
has

Dingley
.
 
<EOS>
If

have
such

there
as
here
,
sure

Wexford

are
good

this

.
 
<EOS>
I
forgot

weather
we
had
May
6th
;
go

.
 
<EOS>
We
had
terrible
rain
the
24th
and
25th
,
and
never
a
drop
since
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
,
I
remember
Berested
's

;
the

up

down
as
one

that

,
just
as
at

-

.
 
<EOS>
I
never

any
illness
or
health
<EOS>
I

to
good

,
but
to

,

,

something

,

,

;
and
so
I
fence

as

I

:
 
but
who
a

weather
?
 
<EOS>
Will
Seymour
,
the
General
,
was

hot
with
the

;

,

,

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
Another

,

,

such
weather
as

God
:
 
<EOS>
Seymour

,
"
Perhaps

;
but
I

.
"
 
<EOS>
Why
,

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

;

<EOS>

,
that

:
 
it

fifty

,
and
the
air
is
so
cool
that
a
body
is
able
to

;
and
I

to

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

,

Thomas

fifty

:
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

;

,

:

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

:

I

,

.
 
<EOS>
This

<EOS>
O

CHELSEA

.
  
<EOS>
I
have
been
all
this
time
at
Wycombe
,
between
Oxford
and
London
,
with
Lord
Shelburne
,
who
has
the
squire
's
house
at
the
town
's
end
,
and
an
estate
there
in
a
delicious
country
.
 
<EOS>
Lady
Kerry
and
Mrs.
Pratt
were
with
us
,
and
we
passed
our
time
well
enough
;
and
there
I
wholly
disengaged
myself
from
all
public
thoughts
,
and
everything
but
MD
,
who
had
the
impudence
to
send
me
a
letter
there
;
but
I
'll
be
revenged
:
 
I
will
answer
it
.
 
<EOS>
This
day
,
the
20th
,
I
came
from
Wycombe
with
Lady
Kerry
after

,
lighted
at
Hyde
Park
Corner
,
and
walked
:
 
<EOS>
it
was
twenty
-
seven
miles
,
and
we
came
it
in
about
five
hours
.
  
<EOS>
21
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
at
noon
to
see
Mr.
Secretary
at
his
office
,
and
there
was
Lord
Treasurer
:
 
<EOS>
so
I
killed
two
birds
,
etc
.
,
and
we
were
glad
to
see
one
another
,
and
so
forth
.
 
<EOS>
And
the
Secretary
and
I
dined
at
Sir
William
Wyndham
's
,
who
married
Lady
Catharine
Seymour
,
your
acquaintance
,
I
suppose
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
ten
of
us
at
dinner
.
 
<EOS>
It
seems
,
in
my
absence
,
they
had
erected
a
Club
,
and
made
me
one
;
and
we
made
some
laws
to
-
day
,
which
I
am
to
digest
and
add
to
,
against
next
meeting
.
 
<EOS>
Our
meetings
are
to
be
every
Thursday
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
yet
but
twelve
:
 
<EOS>
Lord
Keeper
and
Lord
Treasurer
were
proposed
;
but
I
was
against
them
,
and
so
was
Mr.
Secretary
,
though
their
sons
are
of
it
,
and
so
they
are
excluded
;
but
we
design
to
admit
the
Duke
of
Shrewsbury
.
 
<EOS>
The
end
of
our
Club
is
,
to
advance
conversation
and
friendship
,
and
to
reward
deserving
persons
with
our
interest
and
recommendation
.
 
<EOS>
We
take
in
none
but
men
of
wit
or
men
of
interest
;
and
if
we
go
on
as
we
begin
,
no
other
Club
in
this
town
will
be
worth
talking
of
.
 
<EOS>
The
Solicitor
-
General
,
Sir
Robert
Raymond
,
is
one
of
our
Club
;
and
I
ordered
him
immediately
to
write
to
your
Lord
Chancellor
in
favour

Dr.
Raymond
:
 
<EOS>
so
tell
Raymond
,
if
you
see

;
but
I
believe
this

Wexford
.
 
<EOS>
This
letter
will
come
three
weeks
after
the
last
,
so
there
is
a
week
lost
;
but
that
is
owing
to
my
being
out
of
town
;
yet
I
think

is
right
,
because

Mr.
Reading
:
 
<EOS>
and
why

often

MD
,
pray
?
 
<EOS>
I
sat
this
evening
with
Lady
Betty
Butler
and
Lady
Ashburnham
,
and
then
came
home
by
eleven
,
and
had
a
good
cool

;
for
we
have

no

this
fortnight
,
but
a
great
deal

rain
at
times
,
and
a
body
can
live
and
breathe
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
it
will
hold
so
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
peaches
to
-
day
.
  
<EOS>
22
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
late
to
-
day
to
town
,
and
dined
with
my
friend
Lewis
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
Will
Congreve
attending
at
the
Treasury
,
by
order
,
with
his
brethren
,
the
Commissioners
of
the
Wine
Licences
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
often
mentioned
him
with
kindness
to
Lord
Treasurer
;
and
Congreve
told
me
that
,
after
they
had
answered
to
what
they
were
sent
for
,
my
lord
called
him
privately
,
and
spoke
to
him
with
great
kindness
,
promising
his
protection
,
etc
.
 
<EOS>
The
poor
man
said
he
had
been
used
so
ill
of
late
years
that
he
was
quite
astonished
at
my
lord
's
goodness
,
etc
.
,
and
desired
me
to
tell
my
lord
so
;
which
I
did
this
evening
,
and
recommended
him
heartily
.
 
<EOS>
My
lord
assured
me
he
esteemed
him
very
much
,
and
would
be
always
kind
to
him
;
<EOS>
that
what
he
said
was
to
make
Congreve
easy
,
because
he
knew
people
talked
as
if
his
lordship
designed
to
turn
everybody
out
,
and
particularly
Congreve
:
 
which
indeed
was
true
,
for
the
poor
man
told
me
he
apprehended
it
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
left
my
Lord
Treasurer
,
I
called
on
Congreve
(
knowing
where
he
dined
)
,
and
told
him
what
had
passed
between
my
lord
and
me
;
so
I
have
made
a
worthy
man
easy
,
and
that
is
a
good
day
's
work
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
proposing
to
my
lord
to
erect
a
society
or
academy
for
correcting
and
settling
our
language
,
that
we
may
not
perpetually
be
changing
as
we
do
.
 
<EOS>
He
enters
mightily
into
it
,
so
does
the
Dean
of
Carlisle
;
and
I
design
to
write
a
letter
to
Lord
Treasurer
with
the
proposals
of
it
,
and
publish
it
;
and
so
I
told
my
lord
,
and
he
approves
it
.
 
<EOS>
Yesterday
's
was
a
sad
Examiner
,
and
last
week
was
very
indifferent
,
though
some
little
scraps
of
the
old
spirit
,
as

had
given

;
but
yesterday
's
is
all
trash
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
plain
the
hand
is
changed
.
  
<EOS>
23
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
been
in
London
to
-
day
:
 
for
Dr.
Gastrell
<EOS>
and
I
dined
,
by
invitation
,
with
the
Dean
of
Carlisle
,
my
neighbour
;
<EOS>
so
I
know
not
what
they
are
doing
in
the
world
,
a
mere
country
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
And
are
not
you
ashamed
both
to
go
into
the
country
just
when
I
did
,
and
stay
ten
days
,
just
as
I
did
,
saucy
monkeys
?
 
<EOS>
But
I
never
rode
;
I
had
no
horses
,
and
our
coach
was
out
of
order
,
and
we
went
and
came
in
a
hired
one
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
keep
your
lodgings
when
you
go
to
Wexford
?
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
you
do
;
for
you
will
hardly
stay
above
two
months
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
walking
about
our
town
to
-
night
,
and
it
is
a
very
scurvy
place
for
walking
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
thinking
to
leave
it
,
and
return
to
town
,
now
the
Irish
folks
are
gone
.
 
<EOS>
Ford
goes
in
three
days
.
 
<EOS>
How
does
Dingley
divert
herself
while
Stella
is
riding
?
<EOS>
work
,
or
read
,
or
walk
?
 
<EOS>
Does
Dingley
ever
read
to
you
?
 
<EOS>
Had
you
ever
a
book
with
you
in
the
country
?
 
<EOS>
Is
all
that
left
off
?
 
<EOS>
Confess
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
I
'll
go
sleep
;
'
tis
past
eleven
,
and
I
go
early
to
sleep
:
 
<EOS>
I
write
nothing
at

but
to
MD
.
  
<EOS>
24
.
 
<EOS>
Stratford
and
I
,
and
Pastoral
Philips
(
just

)
dined
at
Ford
's
to
-

,
who
paid

,
and

for

.
 
<EOS>
The
Earl
of
Peterborow
is
returned
from
Vienna
without
one
servant
:
 
he
left
them
scattered
in
several
towns
of
Germany
.
 
<EOS>
I
had

letter
from
him
,
four
days
ago
,
from
Hanover
,
where
he
desires
I
would
immediately
send

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

<EOS>

25
.
 
<EOS>
Poor

:
 
<EOS>
we

:
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

:
 
<EOS>

26
.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Prior
never

:
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>
Your

of

;

.
 
<EOS>
Morning
.
 
<EOS>
I

;

:
 
faith

,

.
 
<EOS>
Patrick

,

;

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
Does

?
 
<EOS>
I

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
No
,

I

;

,

.

So

.
 
<EOS>
Faith
,
that

.
 
<EOS>
All

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been

,

;
which

of

,
because
they
say

.
 
<EOS>
But

,

.
 
<EOS>
And
so

Fate
govern
.
 
<EOS>
Now
I
think
your
letter
is
answered
;
and
mine
will

shorter
than
ordinary
,
because
it
must
go
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
had
a
great
deal

scattering
rain
for
some
days
past
,
yet
it
hardly
keeps
down

dust
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
plays
acted
in
our
town
;
and
Patrick
was
at
one
of
them
,
<EOS>
oh
oh
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
damnably
mauled
one
day
when
he
was

;
he
was
at
cuffs
with
a
brother
-

,
who

upon

,
which
looked

as

;
and
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
ten

him
over
to
you
;
yet
now
he
has
new

,
and

,
which
the

by

,
and
he
offered

.
 
<EOS>
I
am

at
Sir
Andrew

's
,
who
has

new

,
and
will

weary
of

in

.
 
<EOS>
I
must
rise

,
and
walk
to
town
,
unless
I
go
with
the
Dean
in

twelve
,
which

:
 
<EOS>
and

not

Lord
Peterborow
yet
.
 
<EOS>
The
Duke
of
Shrewsbury
is
almost

,

:
 
<EOS>
what

?
 
<EOS>
There

:
 
you

.
 
<EOS>
Farewell
,

;

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
God

,

!
 
<EOS>
I

this
twice
every
day
;
and
I
hope
God
will
hear
my
poor
hearty
prayers
.
 
<EOS>
Remember
,
if
I
am
used
ill
and
ungratefully
,
as
I
have
formerly
been
,
'
tis
what
I
am
prepared
for
,
and
shall
not
wonder
at
it
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
I
am
now
envied
,
and
thought
in
high
favour
,
and
have
every
day
numbers
of
considerable
men
teasing
me
to
solicit
for
them
.
 
<EOS>
And
the
Ministry
all
use
me
perfectly
well
;
and
<EOS>
all
that
know
them
say
they
love
me
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
I
can
count
upon
nothing
,
nor
will
,
but
upon
MD
's
love
and
kindness
.
 
<EOS>
They
think
me
useful
;
they
pretended
they
were
afraid
of
none
but
me
,
and
that
they
resolved
to
have
me
;
they
have
often
confessed
this
:
yet
all
makes
little
impression
on
me
.
 
<EOS>
Pox
of
these
speculations
!
<EOS>
they
give
me
the
spleen
;
and
that
is
a
disease
I
was
not
born
to
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
alone
,
sirrahs
,
and
be
satisfied
:
 
<EOS>
I
am
,
as
long
as
MD
and
Presto
are
well
.
       
<EOS>
Little
wealth
,
     
And
much
health
,
     
And
a
life
by
stealth
:
  
<EOS>
that
is
all
we
want
;
and
so
farewell
,
dearest
MD
;
Stella
,
Dingley
,
Presto
,
all
together
,
now
<EOS>
and
for
ever
all
together
.
 
<EOS>
Farewell
again
and
again
.
   
<EOS>
LETTER
26
.
 
<EOS>
CHELSEA
,
June
30
,
1711
.
  
<EOS>
See
what
large
paper
I
am
forced
to
take
,
to
write
to
MD
;
Patrick
has
brought
me
none
clipped
;
but
,
faith
,
the
next
shall
be
smaller
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
,
as
I
told
you
,
with
Dilly
at
Sir
Andrew
Fountaine
's
:
 
there
were
we
wretchedly
punning
,
and
writing
together
to
Lord
Pembroke
.
 
<EOS>
Dilly
is
just
such
a
puppy
as
ever
;
and
it
is
so
uncouth
,
after
so
long
an
intermission
.
 
<EOS>
My
twenty
-
fifth
is
gone
this
evening
to
the
post
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
I
will
direct
my
next
(
which
is
this
)
to
Mr.
Curry
's
,
and
let
them
send
it
to
Wexford
;
and
then
the
next
enclosed
to
Reading
.
 
<EOS>
Instruct
me
how
I
shall
do
.
 
<EOS>
I
long
to
hear
from
you
from
Wexford
,
and
what
sort
of
place
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
The
town
grows
very
empty
and
dull
.
 
<EOS>
This
evening
I
have
had
a
letter
from
Mr.
Philips
,
the
pastoral
poet
,
to
get
him
a
certain
employment
from
Lord
Treasurer
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
now
had
almost
all
the
Whig
poets
my
solicitors
;
and
I
have
been
useful
to
Congreve
,
Steele
,
and
Harrison
:
<EOS>
but
I
will
do
nothing
for
Philips
<EOS>
;
I
find
he
is
more
a
puppy
than
ever
,
so
do
n't
solicit
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
Besides
,
I
will
not
trouble
Lord
Treasurer
,
unless
upon
some
very
extraordinary
occasion
.
  
<EOS>
July
1
.
 
<EOS>
Dilly
lies
conveniently
for
me
when
I
come
to
town
from
Chelsea
of
a
Sunday
,
and
go
to
the
Secretary
's
;
so
I
called
at
his
lodgings
this
morning
,
and
sent
for
my
gown
,
and
dressed
myself
there
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
letter
from
the
Bishop
,
with
an
account
that
you
were
set
out
for
Wexford
the
morning
he
writ
,
which
was
June
26
,
and
he
had
the
letter
the
30th
;
that
was
very
quick
:
 
<EOS>
the
Bishop
says
you
design
to
stay
there
two
months
or
more
.
 
<EOS>
Dilly
had
also
a
letter
from
Tom
Ashe
,
full
of
Irish
news
;
that
your
Lady
Lyndon
is
dead
,
and
I
know
not
what
besides
of
Dr.
Coghill
losing
his
drab
,
etc
.
 
<EOS>
The
Secretary
was
gone
to
Windsor
,
and
I
dined
with
Mrs.
Vanhomrigh
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
is
at
Windsor
too
;
they
will
be
going
and
coming
all
summer
,
while
the
Queen
is
there
,
and
the
town
is
empty
,
and
I
fear
I
shall
be
sometimes
forced
to
stoop
beneath
my
dignity
,
and
send
to
the
ale
-
house
for
a
dinner
.
<EOS>
Well
,
sirrahs
,
had
you
a
good
journey
to
Wexford
?
<EOS>
did
you
drink
ale
by
the
way
?
<EOS>
were
you
never
overturned
?
<EOS>
how
many
things
did
you
forget
?
<EOS>
do
you
lie
on
straw
in
your
new
town
where
you
are
?
 
<EOS>
Cudshoe
,
the
next
letter
to
Presto
will
be
dated
from
Wexford
.
 
<EOS>
What
fine
company
have
you
there
?
<EOS>
what
new
acquaintance
have
you
got
?
 
<EOS>
You
are
to
write
constantly
to
Mrs.
Walls
and
Mrs.
Stoyte
:
 
and
the
Dean
said
,
"
Shall
we
never
hear
from
you
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Mr.
Dean
,
we
'll
make
bold
to
trouble
you
with
a
letter
.
"
 
<EOS>
Then
at
Wexford
;
when
you
meet
a
lady
,
"
Did
your
waters
pass
well
this
morning
,
madam
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Will
Dingley
drink
them
too
?
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
I
warrant
;
to
get
her
a
stomach
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
you
are
all
gamesters
at
Wexford
.
 
<EOS>
Do
not
lose
your
money
,
sirrah
,
far
from
home
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
I
shall
go
to
Windsor
in
a
few
days
;
at
least
,
the
Secretary
tells
me
so
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
a
small
house
there
,
with
just
room
enough
for
him
and
me
;
and
I
would
be
satisfied
to
pass
a
few
days
there
sometimes
.
 
<EOS>
Sirrahs
,
let
me
go
to
sleep
,
it
is
past
twelve
in
our
town
.
  
<EOS>
2
.
 
<EOS>
Sterne
came
to
me
this
morning
,
and
tells
me
he
has
yet
some
hopes
of
compassing
his
business
:
 
he
was
with
Tom
Harley
,
the
secretary
of
the
Treasury
,
and
made
him
doubt
a
little
he
was
in
the
wrong
;
the
poor
man
tells
me
it
will
almost
undo
him
if
he
fails
.
 
<EOS>
I
called
this
morning
to
see
Will
Congreve
,
who
lives
much
by
himself
,
is
forced
to
read
for
amusement
,
and
can
not
do
it
without
a
magnifying
-
glass
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
set
him
very
well
with
the
Ministry
,
and
I
hope
he
is
in
no
danger
of
losing
his
place
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
in
the
City
with
Dr.
Freind
,
not
among
my
merchants
,
but
with
a
scrub
instrument
of
mischief
of
mine
,
whom
I
never
mentioned
to
you
,
nor
am
like
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
You
two
little
saucy
Wexfordians
<EOS>
,
you
are
now
drinking
waters
.
 
<EOS>
You
drink
waters
!
<EOS>
you
go
fiddlestick
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
God
send
them
to
do
you
good
;
if
not
,
faith
,
next
summer
you
shall
come
to
the
Bath
.
  
<EOS>
3
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Peterborow
desired
to
see
me
this
morning
at
nine
;
I
had
not
seen
him
before
since
he
came
home
.
 
<EOS>
I
met
Mrs.
Manley
there
,
who
was
soliciting
him
to
get
some
pension
or
reward
for
her
service
in
the
cause
,
by
writing
her
Atalantis
,
and
prosecution
,
etc
.
,
upon
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
seconded
her
,
and
hope
they
will
do
something
for
the
poor
woman
.
 
<EOS>
My
lord
kept
me
two
hours
upon
politics
:
 
he
comes
home
very
sanguine
;
he
has
certainly
done
great
things
at
Savoy
and
Vienna
,
by
his
negotiations
:
 
he
is
violent
against
a
peace
,
and
finds
true
what
I
writ
to
him
,
that
the
Ministry
seems
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
reasons
well
;
yet
I
am
for
a
peace
.
 
<EOS>
I
took
leave
of
Lady
Kerry
,
who
goes
to
-
morrow
for
Ireland
;
she
picks
up
Lord
Shelburne
and
Mrs.
Pratt
at
Lord
Shelburne
's
house
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this
evening
with
Lord
Treasurer
:
 
<EOS>
Tom
Harley
was
there
,
and
whispered
me
that
he
began
to
doubt
about
Sterne
's
business
;
I
told
him
he
would
find
he
was
in
the
wrong
.
 
<EOS>
I
sat
two
or
three
hours
at
Lord
Treasurer
's
;
he
rallied
me
sufficiently
upon
my
refusing
to
take
him
into
our
Club
,
and
told
a
judge
who
was
with
us
that
my
name
was
Thomas
Swift
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
a
mind
to
prevent
Sir
H.
Belasyse
going
to
Spain
,
who
is
a
most
covetous
cur
,
and
I
fell
a
railing
against
avarice
,
and
turned
it
so
that
he
smoked
me
,
and
named
Belasyse
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
on
,
and
said
it
was
a
shame
to
send
him
;
to
which
he
agreed
,
but
desired
I
would
name
some
who
understood
business
,
and
do
not
love
money
,
for
he
could
not
find
them
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
there
was
something
in
a
Treasurer
different
from
other
men
;
that
we
ought
not
to
make
a
man
a
Bishop
who
does
not
love
divinity
,
or
a
General
who
does
not
love
war
;
and
I
wondered
why
the
Queen
would
make
a
man
Lord
Treasurer
who
does
not
love
money
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
mightily
pleased
with
what
I
said
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
talking
of
the
First
-
Fruits
of
England
,
and
I
took
occasion
to
tell
him
that
I
would
not
for
a
thousand
pounds
anybody
<EOS>
but
he
had
got
them
for
Ireland
,
who
got
them
for
England
too
.
 
<EOS>
He
bid
me
consider
what
a
thousand
pounds
was
;
I
said
I
would
have
him
to
know
<EOS>
I
valued
a
thousand
pounds
as
little
as
he
valued
a
million
.
 
<EOS>
Is
it
not
silly
to
write
all
this
?
<EOS>
but
it
gives
you
an
idea
what
our
conversation
is
with
mixed
company
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
taken
a
lodging
in
Suffolk
Street
,
and
go
to
it
on
Thursday
;
and
design
to
walk
the
Park
and
the
town
,
to
supply
my
walking
here
:
 
yet
I
will
walk
here
sometimes
too
,
in
a
visit
now
and
then
to
the
Dean
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
was
almost
at
home
,
Patrick
told
me
he
had
two
letters
for
me
,
and
gave
them
to
me
in
the
dark
,
yet
I
could
see
one
of
them
was
from
saucy
MD
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
to
visit
the
Dean
for
half
an
hour
;
and
then
came
home
,
and
first
read
the
other
letter
,
which
was
from
the
Bishop
of
Clogher
,
who
tells
me
the
Archbishop
of
Dublin
mentioned
in
a
full
assembly
of
the
clergy
<EOS>
the
Queen
's
granting
the
First
-
Fruits
,
said
it
was
done
by
the
Lord
Treasurer
,
and
talked
much
of
my
merit
in
it
:
 
but
reading
yours
<EOS>
I
find
nothing
of
that
:
 
<EOS>
perhaps
the
Bishop
lies
,
out
of
a
desire
to
please
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Mrs.
Vanhomrigh
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
sirrahs
,
you
are
gone
to
Wexford
;
but
I
'll
follow
you
.
  
<EOS>
4
.
 
<EOS>
Sterne
came
to
me
again
this
morning
,
to
advise
about
reasons
and
memorials
he
is
drawing
up
;
and
we
went
to
town
by
water
together
;
and
having
nothing
to
do
,
I
stole
into
the
City
to
an
instrument
of
mine
,
and
then
went
to
see
poor
Patty
Rolt
,
who
has
been
in
town
these
two
months
with
a
cousin
of
hers
.
 
<EOS>
Her
life
passes
with
boarding
in
some
country
town
as
cheap
as
she
can
,
and
,
when
she
runs
out
,
shifting
to
some
cheaper
place
,
or
coming
to
town
for
a
month
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
were
rich
,
I
would
ease
her
,
which
a
little
thing
would
do
.
<EOS>
Some
months
ago
I
sent
her
a
guinea
,
and
it
patched
up
twenty
circumstances
.
<EOS>
She
is
now
going
to
Berkhamstead
in
Hertfordshire
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
rained
and
hailed
prodigiously
to
-
day
,
with
some
thunder
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
the
last
night
I
lie
at
Chelsea
;
and
I
got
home
early
,
and
sat
two
hours
with
the
Dean
,
and
ate
victuals
,
having
had
a
very
scurvy
dinner
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
answer
your
letter
when
I
come
to
live
in
town
.
 
<EOS>
You
shall
have
a
fine
London
answer
:
 
<EOS>
but
first
I
will
go
sleep
,
and
dream
of
MD
.
  
<EOS>
London
,
July
5
.
 
<EOS>
This
day
I
left
Chelsea
for
good
(
that
's
a
genteel
phrase
)
,
and
am
got
into
Suffolk
Street
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
at
our
Society
,
and
we
are
adjourned
for
a
month
,
because
most
of
us
go
into
the
country
:
 
<EOS>
we
dined
at
Lord
Keeper
's
with
young
Harcourt
,
and
Lord
Keeper
was
forced
to
sneak
off
,
and
dine
with
Lord
Treasurer
,
who
had
invited
the
Secretary
and
me
to
dine
with
him
;
but
we
scorned
to
leave
our
company
,
as
George
Granville
did
,
whom
we
have
threatened
to
expel
:
 
however
<EOS>
,
in
the
evening
I
went
to
Lord
Treasurer
,
and
,
among
other
company
,
found
a
couple
of
judges
with
him
;
one
of
them
,
Judge
Powell
,
an
old
fellow
with
grey
hairs
,
was
the
merriest
old
gentleman
I
ever
saw
,
spoke
pleasant
things
,
and
laughed
and
chuckled
till
he
cried
again
.
 
<EOS>
I
stayed
till
eleven
,
because
I
was
not
now
to
walk
to
Chelsea
.
  
<EOS>
6
.
 
<EOS>
An
ugly
rainy
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
to
visit
Mrs.
Barton
,
then
called
at
Mrs.
Vanhomrigh
's
,
where
Sir
Andrew
Fountaine
and
the
rain
kept
me
to
dinner
;
and
there
did
<EOS>
I
loiter
all
the
afternoon
,
like
a
fool
,
out
of
perfect
laziness
,
and
the
weather
not
permitting
me
to
walk
:
 
<EOS>
but
I
'll
do
so
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
Are
your
waters
at
Wexford
good
in
this
rain
?
 
<EOS>
I
long
to
hear
how
you
are
established
there
,
how
and
whom
you
visit
,
what
is
your
lodging
,
what

your
entertainments
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
got
far
southwards
;
but
I
think
you
must
eat
no
fruit
while
you
drink
the
waters
.
 
<EOS>
I
ate
some
Kentish
cherries
t'other
day
,
and
I
repent
it
already
;
I
have
felt
my
head
a
little
disordered
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
not
a
hot
day
all
June
,
or
since
,
which
I
reckon
a
mighty
happiness
.
 
<EOS>
Have
you
left
a
direction
with
Reading
for
Wexford
?
 
<EOS>
I
will
,
as
I
said
,
direct
this
to
Curry
's
,
and
the
next
to
Reading
;
or
suppose
I
send
this
at
a
venture
straight
to
Wexford
?
 
<EOS>
It
would
vex
me
to
have
it
miscarry
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
a
letter
to
-
night
from
Parvisol
,
that
White
has
paid
me
most
of
my
remaining
money
;
and
another
from
Joe
,
that
they
have
had
their
election
at
Trim
,
but
not
a
word
of
who
is
chosen
portreeve
.
 
<EOS>
Poor
Joe
is
full
of
complaints
,
says
he
has
enemies
,
and
fears
he
will
never
get
his
two
hundred
pounds
;
and
I
fear
so
too
,
although
I
have
done
what

.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
answer
your
letter
when
I
think
fit
,
when
saucy
Presto
thinks
fit
,
sirrahs
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
at

yet
;
when
I
have
nothing
to

,
perhaps
I
may
vouchsafe
.
 
<EOS>
O
Lord
,
the
two
Wexford
ladies
;
I
'll
go
dream
of
you

.
  
<EOS>
7
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
dismallest
rainy
day
I
ever
saw
:
 
<EOS>
I
went
to
the
Secretary
in
the
morning
,
and
he
was
gone
to
Windsor
.
 
<EOS>
Then
it
began
raining
,
and
I
struck
in
to
Mrs.
Vanhomrigh
's
,
and
dined
,
and
stayed
till
night
very
dull
and

.
 
<EOS>
I
hate
this
town
in
summer
;
I
'll
leave

for
a
while
,
if
I
can
have

.
  
<EOS>
8
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
fellow
of
your

,
one
Tisdall
,
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Patrick

Squire

.
 
<EOS>
I
pretended
<EOS>
I
never

;

,

,

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Dr.

<EOS>
I

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
People

with
agues
by

,

;

.
 
<EOS>

this

,

.

9
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
to
-
day
in
the
City
,
and

with
Mr.
Stratford
,
who
tells

Sir
Alexander
Cairnes
makes

about

;
so
that
I
can
not

order
yet
to
Parvisol
to

to

.
 
<EOS>
To
-
morrow
I
shall
have
a
positive
answer
:
 
that
Cairnes
is
a
shuffling
scoundrel
;
and
several
merchants
have
told
me
so
:
 
what
can
one
expect
from
a
Scot
and

?
 
<EOS>
I
was
at
Bateman
's
the
bookseller
's
,
to
see
a
fine
old
library
he
has
bought
;
and
my

itched
,
as

would
do
at
a
china
-

;
but
I
resisted
,
and
found
everything
too
dear
,
and
I
have

that
way
already
.
 
<EOS>
So
go
and

your
waters
,
saucy
rogue
,
and
make
yourself
well
;
and
pray
walk
while
you
are
there
:
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
notion
there
is
never
a
good
walk
in
Ireland
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
find
all
places
without
trees
?
 
<EOS>
Pray
observe
the
inhabitants
about
Wexford
;
they
are
old
English
;
see
what
they
have
particular
in
their
manners
,

,
and

:
 
magpies
have
been
always
there
,
and
nowhere
else

,

.
 
<EOS>
They
say

cocks

,

.
 
<EOS>
Write

,

.
  
<EOS>
10
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to

:
 
<EOS>
we

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
Stella
,

,

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
And

I

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

.

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
This

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

:
 
I

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Your

,

.

,

,

14
.
 
<EOS>

,

,

,

<EOS>

,

,

's

,

.
 
<EOS>
Bank

.

<EOS>

.

17
.
 
<EOS>
Morning
.
 
<EOS>
I
have

,

.
<EOS>
Hold
your

:
 
stand

.
 
<EOS>
Your
weather
and
ours
were
not
alike
;
we
had
not
a
bit

weather
in
June
,
yet
you
complain

it
on

19th

.
 
<EOS>
What
,
you
used
to
love
hot
weather
then
?
 
<EOS>
I
could
never
endure
it
:
 
<EOS>
I
detest
and
abominate

.
 
<EOS>
I
would
not
live
in
a
hot
country
,
to
be
king

.
 
<EOS>
What
a
splutter
you
keep
about
my

with
Raymond
,
and
all
to

!
<EOS>
Presto
will
be
suspicious
of
everything
but
MD
,
in
spite

your
little
nose
.
<EOS>
Soft
and
fair
,
Madam
Stella
,
how
you
gallop
away
,
in
your

and
your
rage
,
about

my

,
and

here
,
and

,
and
nasty
England
,
and
Laracor
all

.
 
<EOS>
Hey
-
dazy
,
will
you
never
have
done
?
 
<EOS>
I
had
no
offers
of
any
living
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Keeper
told
me
some
months
ago
he
would
give
me
one
when
I
pleased
;
but
I
told
him
I
would
not
take
any
from

;
and
the
Secretary
told
me
t'other

he
had
refused
a

for

,
but
it
was
in

he

not

;
and
I

nothing
of

anything
here
,
and
,

would

,
I
would
come
over
just
now
.
<EOS>
Addison
,
I
hear
,
has
changed
his

about
going
over
;
but
I
have
not

these
four

.
 
<EOS>
Oh

,
that
's
true
,
Dingley
;
that
's
like

:
millions
of
businesses
to
do
before
she

.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
my
head
has
been
pretty
well
,
but
threatening
within
these
two

three
days
,
which
I
impute
to
some
fruit
I
ate
;
but
I
will
eat
no

:
 
not
a
bit
of
any
sort
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
you
had
a
journey
without
dust
,
and
that

happy
.
 
<EOS>
I
long
for
a
Wexford
letter
,
but
must
not

yet
:
 
<EOS>
your
last
was

.
 
<EOS>
It

d####d

of

.
 
<EOS>
I

trunk

left

;
<EOS>
so
'

odd

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
I

;
 
that

will

.
<EOS>
Let

:
 
<EOS>
I
hope

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs.

needed
not

;

.
 
<EOS>
No

after

,

;

,

,

and

,
<EOS>
which
I

:
 
and
I

little

.
 
<EOS>
(
Mr.
Tooke
is

,
and

.
)
 
<EOS>
At
night
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Lord
Treasurer
to
-
day
,
and
he
kept
me
till
nine
;
so
I
can
not
send
this
to
-
night
,
as
I
intended
,
nor
write
some
other
letters
.
 
<EOS>
Green
,
his
surgeon
,
was
there
,
and
dressed
his
breast
;
that
is
,
put
on
a
plaster
,
which
is
still
requisite
:
 
and
I
took
an
opportunity
to
speak
to
him
of
the
Queen
;
but
he
cut
me
short
with
this
saying
,
"
Laissez
faire
a
Don
Antoine
,
"
which
is
a
French
proverb
,
expressing
,
"
Leave
that
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
I
find
he
is
against
her
taking
much
physic
;
and
I
doubt
he
can
not
persuade
her
to
take
Dr.
Radcliffe
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
she
is
very
well
now
,
and
all
the
story
of
her
illness
,
except
the
first
day
or

,
was
a

.
 
<EOS>
We
had
some
business
,
that
company
hindered
us
from
doing
,
though
he
is
earnest
for
it
,
yet
would
not
appoint
me
a
certain
day
,
but
bids
me
come
at
all
times
till

can

.
 
<EOS>
This
takes
up
a
great
deal
of
my
time
,
and
I
can
do
nothing
I
would
do
for
them
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
with
the
Secretary
this
morning
,
and
we
both
think
to
go
to
Windsor
for
some
days
,
to
despatch
an

,
if
we
can

.
 
<EOS>
Sterne
met
me
just
now
in
the

by
his

,
and
I
went
in
for
an
hour
to
Jemmy
Leigh
,
who
loves
London
dearly
:
 
<EOS>
he
asked
after
you
with
great
respect

.
 
<EOS>
To
return
to
your
letter
.
 
<EOS>
Your
Bishop
Mills
hates
me
mortally
:
 
<EOS>
I
wonder
he
should
speak
well
of
me
,
having
abused
me
in
all

where
he
went
.
 
<EOS>
So
you
pay
your

.
 
<EOS>
Cudsho
:
 
<EOS>
you
had
a
fine
supper
<EOS>
,
I
warrant
;
two

,
and
a

,

some

.
 
<EOS>
It
is
just

you

Wexford
;
you
were
three

,
and
I

these

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
got

Ben

this

Mr.
Secretary
:
 
<EOS>
it
will

.
  
<EOS>
18
.
 
<EOS>
To

I
took

Mrs.
Barton
,
who
is
going
into
the
country
;
and
I
dined
with
Sir
John
Stanley
,
where
I
have
not

this

.
<EOS>
There

with
us
Lord
Rochester
,
and
his
fine
daughter
,
Lady
Jane
,
just

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been

to
save
Sir
Matthew
Dudley
,
but
fear
I
can
not
.
 
<EOS>
I
walked
the
Mall
six
times
to
-
night
for

,
and
would
have
done
more
;
but
,
as
empty
as
the
town
is
,
a
fool

,
and
so
I
came

,
to

this
shall
go
to

,
without
fail
,
and
follow

Wexford
,

.
  
<EOS>
19
.
 
<EOS>
Dean
Atterbury
sent

.
 
<EOS>
I
refused
his

,

,
and
am

by
seven
,
because
I
would

,

.
 
<EOS>
Patrick
tells

the
maid

one
Mr.
Walls
,
a

,
a

,
was

.
 
<EOS>
Is

Irish

?
 
<EOS>
I

;
but
I

seldom

,
as

do
Dilly
.
 
<EOS>
What

he
do
here
?
<EOS>
or

somebody
else
?
 
<EOS>
The
Duke
of
Newcastle
is
dead
by

fall

from

.
 
<EOS>
God
send
poor
Stella
her

,
and

MD

!
 
<EOS>
Farewell
,

,
who

MD

.
 
<EOS>
God

.
<EOS>
Farewell

,
etc
.
<EOS>
etc
.
   
<EOS>
LETTER
27
.
 
<EOS>
LONDON
,
July
19
,
1711
.
  
<EOS>
I
have
just
sent
my
26th
,
and
have
nothing
to
say
,
because
I
have
other
letters
to
write
(
pshaw
<EOS>
,
I
began
too
high
)
;
but
I
must
lay
the
beginning
like
a
nest
-
egg
:
 
to
-
morrow
<EOS>
I
will
say
more
,
and
fetch
up
this
line
to
be
straight
.
<EOS>
This
is
enough
at
present
for
two
dear
saucy
naughty
girls
.
  
<EOS>
20
.
 
<EOS>
Have
I
told
you
that
Walls
has
been
with
me
,
and
leaves
the
town
in
three
days
?
 
<EOS>
He
has
brought
no
gown
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
Dilly
carried
him
to
a
play
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
come
upon
a
foolish
errand
,
and
goes
back
as
he
comes
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this
day
with
Lord
Peterborow
,
who
is
going
another
ramble
:
 
<EOS>
I
believe
I
told
you
so
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Lord
Treasurer
,
but
can
not
get
him
to
do
his
own
business
with
me
;
he
has
put
me
off
till
to
-
morrow
.
  
<EOS>
21
,
22
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
yesterday
with
Lord
Treasurer
,
who
would
needs
take
me
along
with
him
to
Windsor
,
although
I
refused
him
several
times
,
having
no
linen
,
etc
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
just
time
to
desire
Lord
Forbes
to
call
at
my
lodging
and
order
my
man
to
send
my
things
to
-
day
to
Windsor
by
his
servant
.
 
<EOS>
I
lay
last
night
at
the
Secretary
's
lodgings
at
Windsor
,
and
borrowed
one
of
his
shirts
to
go
to
Court
in
.
 
<EOS>
The
Queen
is
very
well
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Mr.
Masham
;
and
not
hearing
anything
of
my
things
,
I
got
Lord
Winchelsea
to
bring
me
to
town
.
<EOS>
Here
I
found
that
Patrick
had
broke
open
the
closet
to
get
my
linen
and
nightgown
,
and
sent
them
to
Windsor
,
and
there
they
are
;
and
he
,
not
thinking
I
would
return
so
soon
,
is
gone
upon
his
rambles
:
 
<EOS>
so
here
I
am
left
destitute
,
and
forced
to
borrow
a
nightgown
of
my
landlady
,
and
have
not
a
rag
to
put
on
to
-
morrow
:
 
faith
,
it
gives
me
the
spleen
.
  
<EOS>
23
.
 
<EOS>
Morning
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
terrible
rainy
day
,
and
rained
prodigiously
on
Saturday
night
.
 
<EOS>
Patrick
lay
out
last
night
,
and
is
not
yet
returned
:
 
faith
<EOS>
,
poor
Presto
is
a
desolate
creature
;
neither
servant
,
nor
linen
,
nor
anything
.
  
<EOS>
Night
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Forbes
's
man
has
brought
back
my
portmantua
,
and
Patrick
is
come
;
so
I
am
in
Christian
circumstances
:
 
<EOS>
I
shall
hardly
commit
such
a
frolic
again
.
 
<EOS>
I
just
crept
out
to
Mrs.
Van
's
,
and
dined
,
and
stayed
there
the
afternoon
:
 
<EOS>
it
has
rained
all
this
day
.
 
<EOS>
Windsor
is
a
delicious
place
:
 
<EOS>
I
never
saw
it
before
,
except
for
an
hour
about
seventeen
years
ago
.
 
<EOS>
Walls
has
been
here
in
my
absence
,
I
suppose
,
to
take
his
leave
;
for
he
designed
not
to
stay
above
five
days
in
London
.
 
<EOS>
He
says
he
and
his
wife
will
come
here
for
some
months
next
year
;
and
,
in
short
,
he
dares
not
stay
now
for
fear
of
her
.
  
<EOS>
24
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
with
a
hedge
friend
in
the
City
;
and
Walls
overtook
me
in
the
street
,
and
told
me
he
was
just
getting
on
horseback
for
Chester
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
as
much
curiosity
as
a
cow
:
 
<EOS>
he
lodged
with
his
horse
in
Aldersgate
Street
:
 
<EOS>
he
has
bought
his
wife
a
silk
gown
,
and
himself
a
hat
.
 
<EOS>
And
what
are
you
doing
?
<EOS>
what
is
poor
MD
doing
now
?
<EOS>
how
do
you
pass
your
time
at
Wexford
?
<EOS>
how
do
the
waters
agree
with
you
?
 
<EOS>
Let
Presto
know
soon
;
for
Presto
longs
to
know
,
and
must
know
.
 
<EOS>
Is
not
Madam
Proby
curious
company
?
 
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
this
rainy
weather
will
spoil
your
waters
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
had
a
great
deal
of
wet
these
three
days
.
 
<EOS>
Tell
me
all
the
particulars
of
Wexford
:
 
<EOS>
the
place
,
the
company
,
the
diversions
,
the
victuals
,
the
wants
,
the
vexations
.
 
<EOS>
Poor
Dingley
never
saw
such
a
place
in
her
life
;
sent
all
over
the
town
for
a
little
parsley
to
a
boiled
chicken
,
and
it
was
not
to
be
had
;
the
butter
is
stark
naught
,
except
an
old
English
woman
's
;
and
it
is
such
a
favour
to
get
a
pound
from
her
now
<EOS>
and
then
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
glad
you
carried
down
your
sheets
with
you
,
else
you
must
have
lain
in
sackcloth
.
 
<EOS>
O
Lord
!
  
<EOS>
25
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this
forenoon
with
Mr.
Secretary
at
his
office
,
and
helped
to
hinder
a
man
of
his
pardon
,
who
is
condemned
for
a
rape
.
 
<EOS>
The
Under
Secretary
was
willing
to
save
him
,
upon
an
old
notion
that
a
woman
can
not
be
ravished
;
but
I
told
the
Secretary
he
could
not
pardon
him
without
a
favourable
report
from
the
judge
;
besides
,
he
was
a
fiddler
,
and
consequently
a
rogue
,
and
deserved
hanging
for
some
thing
else
;
and
so
he
shall
swing
.
 
<EOS>
What
,
I
must
stand
up
for
the
honour
of
the
fair
sex
!
 
<EOS>
'
Tis
true
the
fellow
had
lain
with
her
a
hundred
times
before
,
but
what
care
I
for
that
!
 
<EOS>
What
,
must
a
woman
be
ravished
because
she
is
a
whore
?
 
<EOS>
The
Secretary
<EOS>
and
I
go
on
Saturday
to
Windsor
for
a
week
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Lord
Treasurer
,
and
stayed
with
him
till
past
ten
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
to
-
day
at
his
levee
,
where
I
went
against
my
custom
,
because
I
had
a
mind
to
do
a
good
office
for
a
gentleman
:
 
<EOS>
so
I
talked
with
him
before
my
lord
,
that
he
might
see
me
,
and
then
found
occasion
to
recommend
him
this
afternoon
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
forced
to
excuse
my
coming
to
the
levee
,
that
I
did
it
to
see
the
sight
;
for
he
was
going
to
chide
me
away
:
 
<EOS>
I
had
never
been
there
but
once
,
and
that
was
long
before
he
was
Treasurer
.
 
<EOS>
The
rooms
were
all
full
,
and
as
many
Whigs
as
Tories
.
 
<EOS>
He
whispered
me
a
jest
or
two
,
and
bid
me
come
to
dinner
.
 
<EOS>
I
left
him
but
just
now
;
and
'
tis
late
.
  
<EOS>
26
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Addison
and
I
have
at
last
met
again
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
him
and
Steele
to
-
day
at
young
Jacob
Tonson
's
.
 
<EOS>
The
two
Jacobs
think
it
is
I
who
have
made
the
Secretary
take
from
them
the
printing
of
the
Gazette
,
which
they
are
going
to
lose
,
and
Ben
Tooke
and
another
are
to
have
it
.
 
<EOS>
Jacob
came
to
me
the
other
day
,
to
make
his
court
;
but
I
told
him
it
was
too
late
,
and
that
it
was
not
my
doing
.
 
<EOS>
I
reckon
they
will
lose
it
in
a
week
or
two
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Addison
and
I
talked
as
usual
,
and
as
if
we
had
seen
one
another
yesterday
;
and
Steele
and
I
were
very
easy
,
though
I
writ
him
lately
a
biting
letter
,
in
answer
to
one
of
his
,
where
he
desired
me
to
recommend
a
friend
of
his
to
Lord
Treasurer
.
 
<EOS>
Go
,
get
you
gone
to
your
waters
,
sirrah
.
 
<EOS>
Do
they
give
you
a
stomach
?
 
<EOS>
Do
you
eat
heartily
?
 
<EOS>
We
have
had
much
rain
to
-
day
and
yesterday
.
  
<EOS>
27
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
in
the
City
,
and
saw
poor
Patty
Rolt
,
and
gave
her
a
pistole
to
help
her
a
little
forward
against
she
goes
to
board
in
the
country
.
<EOS>
She
has
but
eighteen
pounds
a
year
to
live
on
,
and
is
forced
to
seek
out
for
cheap
places
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
they
raise
their
price
,
and
sometimes
they
starve
her
,
and
then
she
is
forced
to
shift
.
 
<EOS>
Patrick
the
puppy
put
too
much
ink
in
my
standish
,
and
,
carrying
too
many
things
together
<EOS>
,
I
spilled
it
on
my
paper
and
floor
.
 
<EOS>
The
town
is
dull
,
wet
,
and
empty
;
Wexford
is
worth
two
of
it
;
I
hope
so
at
least
,
and
that
poor
little
MD
finds
it
so
.
 
<EOS>
I
reckon
upon
going
to
Windsor
to
-
morrow
with
Mr.
Secretary
,
unless
he
changes
his
mind
,
or
some
other
business
prevents
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
stay
there
a
week
,
I
hope
.
  
<EOS>
28
.
 
<EOS>
Morning
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Secretary
sent
me
word
he
will
call
at
my
lodgings
by
two
this
afternoon
,
to
take
me
to
Windsor
;
so
I
must
dine
nowhere
;
and
I
promised
Lord
Treasurer
to
dine
with
him
to
-
day
;
but
I
suppose
we
shall
dine
at
Windsor
at
five
,
for
we
make
but
three
hours
there
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
going
abroad
,
but
have
left
Patrick
to
put
up
my
things
,
and
to
be
sure
to
be
at
home
half
an
hour
before
two
.
 
<EOS>
Windsor
,
at
night
.
 
<EOS>
We
did
not
leave
London
till
three
,
and
dined
here
between
six
and
seven
;
at
nine
I
left
the
company
,
and
went
to
see
Lord
Treasurer
,
who
is
just
come
.
 
<EOS>
I
chid
him
for
coming
so
late
;
he
chid
me
for
not
dining
with
him
;
said
he
stayed
an
hour
for
me
.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
went
and
sat
with
Mr.
Lewis
till
just
now
,
and
it
is
past
eleven
.
 
<EOS>
I
lie
in
the
same
house
with
the
Secretary
,
one
of
the
Prebendary
's
houses
.
 
<EOS>
The
Secretary
is
not
come
from
his
apartment
in
the
Castle
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
think
that
abominable
dog
Patrick
was
out
after
two
to
-
day
,
and
I
in
a
fright
every
moment
,
for
fear
the
chariot
should
come
;
and
when
he
came
in
,
he
had
not
put
up
one
rag
of
my
things
!
 
<EOS>
I
never
was
in
a
greater
passion
,
and
would
certainly
have
cropped
one
of
his
ears
,
if
I
had
not
looked
every
moment
for
the
Secretary
,
who
sent
his
equipage
to
my
lodging
before
,
and
came
in
a
chair
from
Whitehall
to
me
,
and
happened
to
stay
half
an
hour
later
than
he
intended
.
 
<EOS>
One
of
Lord
Treasurer
's
servants
gave
me
a
letter
to
-
night
:
 
<EOS>
I
found
it
was
from
#
#
#
#
,
 
with
an
offer
of
fifty
pounds
,
to
be
paid
me
in
what
manner
I
pleased
;
because
,
he
said
,
he
desired
to
be
well
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
in
a
rage
;
but
my
friend
Lewis
cooled
me
,
and
said
it
is
what
the
best
men
sometimes
meet
with
;
and
I
have
been
not
seldom
served
in
the
like
manner
,
although
not
so
grossly
.
 
<EOS>
In
these
cases
I
never
demur
a
moment
,
nor
ever
found
the
least
inclination
to
take
anything
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
I
will
go
try
to
sleep
in
my
new
bed
,
and
to
dream
of
poor
Wexford
MD
,
and
Stella
that
drinks
water
,
and
Dingley
that
drinks
ale
.
  
<EOS>
29
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
at
Court
and
church
to
-
day
,
as
I
was
this
day
<EOS>
se'ennight
:
 
<EOS>
I
generally
am
acquainted
with
about
thirty
in
the
drawing
-
room
,
and
I
am
so
proud
<EOS>
I
make
all
the
lords
come
up
to
me
:
 
<EOS>
one
passes
half
an
hour
pleasant
enough
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
a
dunce
to
preach
before
the
Queen
to
-
day
,
which
often
happens
.
 
<EOS>
Windsor
is
a
delicious
situation
,
but
the
town
is
scoundrel
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
this
morning
got
the
Gazette
for
Ben
Tooke
and
one
Barber
a
printer
;
it
will
be
about
three
hundred
pounds
a
year
between
them
.
 
<EOS>
The
other
fellow
was
printer
of
the
Examiner
,
which
is
now
laid
down
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
the
Secretary
:
 
<EOS>
we
were
a
dozen
in
all
,
three
Scotch
lords
,
and
Lord
Peterborow
.
<EOS>
The
Duke
of
Hamilton
would
needs
be
witty
,
and
hold
up
my
train
as
I
walked
upstairs
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
an
ill
circumstance
that
on
Sundays
much
company
always
meet
at
the
great
tables
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
told
at
Court
what
I
said
to
Mr.
Secretary
on
this
occasion
.
 
<EOS>
The
Secretary
showed
me
his
bill
of
fare
,
to
encourage
me
to
dine
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Poh
,
"
said
I
,
"
show
me
a
bill
of
company
,
for
I
value
not
your
dinner
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
See
how
this
is
all
blotted
,
I
can
write
no
more
here
,
but
to
tell
you
I
love
MD
dearly
,
and
God
bless
them
.
  
<EOS>
30
.
 
<EOS>
In
my
conscience
,
I
fear
I
shall
have
the
gout
.
 
<EOS>
I
sometimes
feel
pains
about
my
feet
and
toes
:
 
<EOS>
I
never
drank
till
within
these
two
years
,
and
I
did
it
to
cure
my
head
.
 
<EOS>
I
often
sit
evenings
with
some
of
these
people
,
and
drink
in
my
turn
;
but
I
am
now
resolved
to
drink
ten
times
less
than
before
;
but
they
advise
me
to
let
what
I
drink
be
all
wine
,
and
not
to
put
water
to
it
.
<EOS>
Tooke
and
the
printer
stayed
to
-
day
to
finish
their
affair
,
and
treated
me
and
two
of
the
Under
Secretaries
upon
their
getting
the
Gazette
.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
went
to
see
Lord
Treasurer
,
and
chid
him
for
not
taking
notice
of
me
at
Windsor
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
he
kept
a
place
for
me
yesterday
at
dinner
,
and
expected
me
there
;
but
I
was
glad
I
did
not
go
,
because
the
Duke
of
Buckingham
was
there
,
and
that
would
have
made
us
acquainted
;
which
I
have
no
mind
to
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
we
appointed
to
sup
at
Mr.
Masham
's
,
and
there
stayed
till
past
one
o'clock
;
and
that
is
late
,
sirrahs
:
 
<EOS>
and
I
have
much
business
.
  
<EOS>
31
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
sent
a
noble
haunch
of
venison
this
afternoon
to
Mrs.
Vanhomrigh
:
I
wish
you
had
it
,
sirrahs
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
gravely
with
my
landlord
the
Secretary
.
<EOS>
The
Queen
was
abroad
to
-
day
in
order
to
hunt
;
but
,
finding
it
disposed
to
rain
,
she
kept
in
her
coach
;
she
hunts
in
a
chaise
with
one
horse
,
which
she
drives
herself
,
and
drives
furiously
,
like
Jehu
,
and
is
a
mighty
hunter
,
like
Nimrod
.
 
<EOS>
Dingley
has
heard
of
Nimrod
,
but
not
Stella
,
for
it
is
in
the
Bible
.
<EOS>
I
was
to
-
day
at
Eton
,
which
is
but
just
cross
the
bridge
,
to
see
my
Lord
Kerry
's
son
,
who
is
at
school
there
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Secretary
has
given
me
a
warrant
for
a
buck
;
I
ca
n't
send
it
to
MD
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
sad
thing
,
faith
,
considering
how
Presto
loves
MD
,
and
how
MD
would
love
Presto
's
venison
for
Presto
's
sake
.
<EOS>
God
bless
the
two
dear
Wexford
girls
!
  
<EOS>
Aug.
1
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
for
dinner
the
fellow
of
that
haunch
of
venison
I
sent
to
London
;
'
twas
mighty
fat
and
good
,
and
eight
people
at
dinner
;
that
was
bad
.
<EOS>
The
Queen
and
I
were
going
to
take
the
air
this
afternoon
,
but
not
together
;
and
were
both
hindered
by
a
sudden
rain
.
 
<EOS>
Her
coaches
and
chaises
all
went
back
,
and
the
guards
too
;
and
I
scoured
into
the
market
-
place
for
shelter
.
 
<EOS>
I
intended
to
have
walked
up
the
finest
avenue
I
ever
saw
,
two
miles
long
,
with
two
rows
of
elms
on
each
side
.
 
<EOS>
I
walked
in
the
evening
a
little
upon
the
terrace
,
and
came
home
at
eight
:
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Secretary
came
soon
after
,
and
we
were
engaging
in
deep
discourse
,
and
I
was
endeavouring
to
settle
some
points
of
the
greatest
consequence
,
and
had
wormed
myself
pretty
well
into
him
,
when
his
Under
Secretary
came
in
(
who
lodges
in
the
same
house
with
us
)
and
interrupted
all
my
scheme
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
just
left
him
:
 
<EOS>
it
is
late
,
etc
.
  
<EOS>
2
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
now
five
days
at
Windsor
,
and
Patrick
has
been
drunk
three
times
that
I
have
seen
,
and
oftener
I
believe
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
lately
had
clothes
that
have
cost
me
five
pounds
,
and
the
dog
thinks
he
has
the
whip
-
hand
of
me
:
 
he
begins
to
master
me
;
so
now
I
am
resolved
to
part
with
him
,
and
will
use
him
without
the
least
pity
.
 
<EOS>
The
Secretary
<EOS>
and
I
have
been
walking
three
or
four
hours
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
The
Duchess
of
Shrewsbury
asked
him
,
was
not
that
Dr.
 
Dr.
 
<EOS>
and
she
could
not
say
my
name
in
English
,
but
said
Dr.
Presto
,
which
is
Italian
for
Swift
.
 
<EOS>
Whimsical
enough
,
as
Billy
Swift
says
.
 
<EOS>
I
go
to
-
morrow
with
the
Secretary
to
his
house
at
Bucklebury
,
twenty
-
five
miles
from
hence
,
and
return
early
on
Sunday
morning
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
leave
this
letter
behind
me
locked
up
,
and
give
you
an
account
of
my
journey
when
I
return
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
a
letter
yesterday
from
the
Bishop
of
Clogher
,
who
is
coming
up
to
his
Parliament
.
<EOS>
Have
you
any
correspondence
with
him
to
Wexford
?
 
<EOS>
Methinks
,
I
now
long
for
a
letter
from
you
,
dated
Wexford
,
July
24
,
etc
.
 
<EOS>
O
Lord
,
that
would
be
so
pretending
;
and
then
,
says
you
,
Stella
ca
n't
write
much
,
because
it
is
bad
to
write
when
one
drinks
the
waters
;
and
I
think
,
says
you
,
I
find
myself
better
already
,
but
I
can
not
tell
yet
whether
it
be
the
journey
or
the
waters
.
<EOS>
Presto
is
so
silly
to
-
night
;
yes
he
be
;
but
Presto
loves
MD
dearly
,
as
hope
saved
.
  
<EOS>
3
.
 
<EOS>
Morning
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
to
go
this
day
at
noon
,
as
I
told
you
,
to
Bucklebury
:
 
<EOS>
we
dine
at
twelve
,
and
expect
to
be
there
in
four
hours
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
bid
you
good
-
night
now
,
because
I
shall
be
twenty
-
five
miles
from
this
paper
to
-
night
,
and
so
my
journal
must
have
a
break
;
so
good
-
morrow
,
etc
.
  
<EOS>
4
,
5
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
yesterday
at
Bucklebury
,
where
we
lay
two
nights
,
and
set
out
this
morning
at
eight
,
and
were
here
at
twelve
;
in
four
hours
we
went
twenty
-
six
miles
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Secretary
was
a
perfect
country
gentleman
at
Bucklebury
:
 
<EOS>
he
smoked
tobacco
with
one
or
two
neighbours
;
he
inquired
after
the
wheat
in
such
a
field
;
he
went
to
visit
his
hounds
,
and
knew
all
their
names
;
he
and
his
lady
saw
me
to
my
chamber
just
in
the
country
fashion
.
 
<EOS>
His
house
is
in
the
midst
of
near
three
thousand
pounds
a
year
he
had
by
his
lady
,
who
is
descended
from
Jack
Newbury
,
of
whom
books
and
ballads
are
written
;
and
there
is
an
old
picture
of
him
in
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
a
great
favourite
of
mine
.
 
<EOS>
I
lost
church
to
-
day
;
but
I
dressed
and
shaved
,
and
went
to
Court
,
and
would
not
dine
with
the
Secretary
,
but
engaged
myself
to
a
private
dinner
with
Mr.
Lewis
,
and
one
friend
more
.
 
<EOS>
We
go
to
London
to
-
morrow
;
for
Lord
Dartmouth
,
the
other
Secretary
,
is
come
,
and
they
are
here
their
weeks
by
turns
.
  
<EOS>
6
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
comes
every
Saturday
to
Windsor
,
and
goes
away
on
Monday
or
Tuesday
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
with
him
this
morning
at
his
levee
<EOS>
,
for
one
can
not
see
him
otherwise
here
,
he
is
so
hurried
:
 
we
had
some
talk
;
and
I
told
him
I
would
stay
this
week
at
Windsor
by
myself
,
where
I
can
have
more
leisure
to
do
some
business
that
concerns
them
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
and
the
Secretary
thought
to
mortify
me
;
for
they
told
me
they
had
been
talking
a
great
deal
of
me
to
-
day
to
the
Queen
,
and
she
said
she
had
never
heard
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
them
that
was
their
fault
,
and
not
hers
,
etc
.
,
<EOS>
and
so
we
laughed
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
the
Secretary
,
and
let
him
go
to
London
at
five
without
me
;
and
here
am
I
alone
in
the
Prebendary
's
house
,
which
Mr.
Secretary
has
taken
;
only
Mr.
Lewis
is
in
my
neighbourhood
,
and
we
shall
be
good
company
.
 
<EOS>
The
Vice
-
Chamberlain
,
and
Mr.
Masham
,
and
the
Green
Cloth
,
have
promised
me
dinners
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
want
but
four
till
Mr.
Secretary
returns
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
a
music
-
meeting
in
our
town
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
I
went
to
the
rehearsal
of
it
,
and
there
was
Margarita
,
and
her
sister
,
and
another
drab
,
and
a
parcel
of
fiddlers
:
 
<EOS>
I
was
weary
,
and
would
not
go
to
the
meeting
,
which
I
am
sorry
for
,
because
I
heard
it
was
a
great
assembly
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Lewis
came
from
it
,
and
sat
with
me
till
just
now
;
and
'
tis
late
.
  
<EOS>
7
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
do
no
business
,
I
fear
,
because
Mr.
Lewis
,
who
has
nothing
or
little
to
do
here
,
sticks
close
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
today
with
the
gentlemen
ushers
,
among
scurvy
company
;
but
the
Queen
was
hunting
the
stag
till
four
this
afternoon
,
and
she
drove
in
her
chaise
above
forty
miles
,
and
it
was
five
before
we
went
to
dinner
.
 
<EOS>
Here
are
fine
walks
about
this
town
.
 
<EOS>
I
sometimes
walk
up
the
avenue
.
  
<EOS>
8
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
Drawing
-
room
to
-
day
at
Court
;
but
so
few
company
,
that
the
Queen
sent
for
us
into
her
bed
-
chamber
,
where
we
made
our
bows
,
and
stood
about
twenty
of
us
round
the
room
,
while
she
looked
at
us
round
with
her
fan
in
her
mouth
,
and
once
a
minute
said
about
three
words
to
some
that
were
nearest
her
,
and
then
she
was
told
dinner
was
ready
,
and
went
out
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
at
the
Green
Cloth
,
by
Mr.
Scarborow
's
invitation
,
who
is
in
waiting
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
much
the
best
table
in
England
,
and
costs
the
Queen
a
thousand
pounds
a
month
while
she
is
at
Windsor
or
Hampton
Court
,
and
is
the
only
mark
of
magnificence
or
hospitality
I
can
see
in
the
Queen
's
family
:
 
<EOS>
it
is
designed
to
entertain
foreign
Ministers
,
and
people
of
quality
,
who
come
to
see
the
Queen
,
and
have
no
place
to
dine
at
.
  
<EOS>
9
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Coke
,
the
Vice
-
Chamberlain
,
made
me
a
long
visit
this
morning
,
and
invited
me
to
dinner
;
but
the
toast
,
his
lady
,
was
unfortunately
engaged
to
Lady
Sunderland
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
stole
here
last
night
,
but
did
not
lie
at
his
lodgings
in
the
Castle
;
and
,
after
seeing
the
Queen
,
went
back
again
.
<EOS>
I
just
drank
a
dish
of
chocolate
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
fancy
<EOS>
I
shall
have
reason
to
be
angry
with
him
very
soon
;
but
what
care
I
?
 
<EOS>
I
believe
I
shall
die
with
Ministries
in
my
debt
.
 
<EOS>
This
night
I
received
a
certain
letter
from
a
place
called
Wexford
,
from
two
dear
naughty
girls
of
my
acquaintance
;
but
,
faith
,
I
will
not
answer
it
here
,
no
in
troth
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
send
this
to
Mr.
Reading
,
supposing
it
will
find
you
returned
;
and
I
hope
better
for
the
waters
.
  
<EOS>
10
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Vice
-
Chamberlain
lent
me
his
horses
to
ride
about
and
see
the
country
this
morning
.
 
<EOS>
Dr.
Arbuthnot
,
the
Queen
's
physician
and
favourite
,
went
out
with
me
to
show
me
the
places
:
 
<EOS>
we
went
a
little
after
the
Queen
,
and
overtook
Miss
Forester
,
a
maid
of
honour
,
on
her
palfrey
,
taking
the
air
;
we
made
her
go
along
with
us
.
 
<EOS>
We
saw
a
place
they
have
made
for
a
famous
horse
-
race
to
-
morrow
,
where
the
Queen
will
come
.
 
<EOS>
We
met
the
Queen
coming
back
,
and
Miss
Forester
stood
,
like
us
,
with
her
hat
off
while
the
Queen
went
by
.
 
<EOS>
The
Doctor
<EOS>
and
I
left
the
lady
where
we
found
her
,
but
under
other
conductors
;
and
we
dined
at
a
little
place
he
has
taken
,
about
a
mile
off
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
came
back
<EOS>
I
found
Mr.
Scarborow
had
sent
all
about
to
invite
me
to
the
Green
Cloth
,
and
lessened
his
company
on
purpose
to
make
me
easy
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
very
obliging
,
and
will
cost
me
thanks
.
 
<EOS>
Much
company
is
come
to
town
this
evening
,
to
see
to-
morrow
's
race
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
tired
with
riding
a
trotting
mettlesome
horse
a
dozen
miles
,
having
not
been
on
horseback
this
twelvemonth
.
 
<EOS>
And
Miss
Forester
did
not
make
it
easier
;
she
is
a
silly
true
maid
of
honour
,
and
I
did
not
like
her
,
although
she
be
a
toast
,
and
was
dressed
like
a
man
.
  
<EOS>
11
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
send
this
letter
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
expect
the
Secretary
by
noon
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
not
go
to
the
race
unless
I
can
get
room
in
some
coach
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
now
morning
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
rise
,
and
fold
up
and
seal
my
letter
.
 
<EOS>
Farewell
,
and
God
preserve
dearest
MD
.
  
<EOS>
I
believe
I
shall
leave
this
town
on
Monday
.
   
<EOS>
LETTER
28
.
 
<EOS>
WINDSOR
,
Aug.
11
,
1711
.
  
<EOS>
I
sent
away
my
twenty
-
seventh
this
morning
in
an
express
to
London
,
and
directed
to
Mr.
Reading
:
 
this
shall
go
to
your
lodgings
,
where
I
reckon
you
will
be
returned
before
it
reaches
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
intended
to
go
to
the
race
to
-
day
,
but
was
hindered
by
a
visit
:
 
<EOS>
I
believe
I
told
you
so
in
my
last
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
at
the
Green
Cloth
,
where
everybody
had
been
at
the
race
but
myself
,
and
we
were
twenty
in
all
,
and
very
noisy
company
;
but
I
made
the
Vice
-
Chamberlain
and
two
friends
more
sit
at
a
side
table
,
to
be
a
little
quiet
.
 
<EOS>
At
six
I
went
to
see
the
Secretary
,
who
is
returned
;
but
Lord
Keeper
sent
to
desire
I
would
sup
with
him
,
where
I
stayed
till
just
now
:
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
and
Secretary
were
to
come
to
us
,
but
both
failed
.
 
<EOS>
'
Tis
late
,
etc
.
  
<EOS>
12
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this
morning
to
visit
Lord
Keeper
,
who
made
me
reproaches
that
I
had
never
visited
him
at
Windsor
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
present
sent
him
of
delicious
peaches
,
and
he
was
champing
and
champing
,
but
<EOS>
I
durst
not
eat
one
;
I
wished
Dingley
had
some
of
them
,
for
poor
Stella
can
no
more
eat
fruit
than
Presto
.
<EOS>
Dilly
Ashe
is
come
to
Windsor
;
and
after
church
I
carried
him
up
to
the
drawing
-
room
,
and
talked
to
the
Keeper
and
Treasurer
,
on
purpose
to
show
them
to
him
;
and
he
saw
the
Queen
and
several
great
lords
,
and
the
Duchess
of
Montagu
;
he
was
mighty
happy
,
and
resolves
to
fill
a
letter
to
the
Bishop
.
 
<EOS>
My
friend
Lewis
<EOS>
and
I
dined
soberly
with
Dr.
Adams
,
the
only
neighbour
prebendary
.
 
<EOS>
One
of
the
prebendaries
here
is
lately
a
peer
,
by
the
death
of
his
father
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
now
Lord
Willoughby
of
Broke
,
and
will
sit
in
the
House
of
Lords
with
his
gown
.
 
<EOS>
I
supped
to
-
night
at
Masham
's
with
Lord
Treasurer
,
Mr.
Secretary
,
and
Prior
.
 
<EOS>
The
Treasurer
made
us
stay
till
twelve
,
before
he
came
from
the
Queen
,
and
'
tis
now
past
two
.
  
<EOS>
13
.
 
<EOS>
I
reckoned
upon
going
to
London
to
-
day
;
but
by
an
accident
the
Cabinet
Council
did
not
sit
last
night
,
and
sat
to
-
day
,
so
we
go
to
-
morrow
at
six
in
the
morning
.
 
<EOS>
I
missed
the
race
to
-
day
by
coming
out
too
late
,
when
everybody
's
coach
was
gone
,
and
ride
I
would
not
:
 
<EOS>
I
felt
my
last
riding
three
days
after
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
a
dinner
to
-
day
at
the
Secretary
's
lodgings
without
him
:
<EOS>
Mr.
Hare
,
his
Under
Secretary
,
Mr.
Lewis
,
Brigadier
Sutton
,
and
I
,
dined
together
;
and
I
made
the
Vice
-
Chamberlain
take
a
snap
with
us
,
rather
than
stay
till
five
for
his
lady
,
who
was
gone
to
the
race
.
 
<EOS>
The
reason
why
the
Cabinet
Council
was
not
held
last
night
was
because
Mr.
Secretary
St.
John
would
not
sit
with
your
Duke
of
Somerset
.
 
<EOS>
So
to
-
day
the
Duke
was
forced
to
go
to
the
race
while
the
Cabinet
was
held
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
music
-
meetings
in
our
town
,
and
I
was
at
the
rehearsal
t'other
day
;
but
I
did
not
value
it
,
nor
would
go
to
the
meeting
.
 
<EOS>
Did
I
tell
you
this
before
?
  
<EOS>
London
,
14
.
 
<EOS>
We
came
to
town
this
day
in
two
hours
and
forty
minutes
:
 
<EOS>
twenty
miles
are
nothing
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
found
a
letter
from
the
Archbishop
of
Dublin
,
sent
me
the
Lord
knows
how
.
 
<EOS>
He
says
some
of
the
bishops
will
hardly
believe
that
Lord
Treasurer
got
the
Queen
to
remit
the
First
-
Fruits
before
the
Duke
of
Ormond
was
declared
Lord
Lieutenant
,
and
that
the
bishops
have
written
a
letter
to
Lord
Treasurer
to
thank
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
sent
me
the
address
of
the
Convocation
,
ascribing
,
in
good
part
,
that
affair
to
the
Duke
,
who
had
less
share
in
it
than
MD
;
for
if
it
had
not
been
for
MD
,
I
should
not
have
been
so
good
a
solicitor
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
in
the
City
,
about
a
little
bit
of
mischief
,
with
a
printer
.
 
<EOS>
I
found
Mrs.
Vanhomrigh
all
in
combustion
,
squabbling
with
her
rogue
of
a
landlord
;
she
has
left
her
house
,
and
gone
out
of
our
neighbourhood
a
good
way
.
 
<EOS>
Her
eldest
daughter
is
come
of
age
,
and
going
to
Ireland
to
look
after
her
fortune
,
and
get
it
in
her
own
hands
.
  
<EOS>
15
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
with
Mrs.
Van
,
who
goes
to
-
night
to
her
new
lodgings
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
at
six
to
see
Lord
Treasurer
;
but
his
company
was
gone
,
contrary
to
custom
,
and
he
was
busy
,
and
I
was
forced
to
stay
some
time
before
I
could
see
him
.
 
<EOS>
We
were
together
hardly
an
hour
,
and
he
went
away
,
being
in
haste
.
 
<EOS>
He
desired
me
to
dine
with
him
on
Friday
,
because
there
would
be
a
friend
of
his
that
I
must
see
:
 
<EOS>
my
Lord
Harley
told
me
,
when
he
was
gone
,
that
it
was
Mrs.
Masham
his
father
meant
,
who
is
come
to
town
to
lie
-
in
,
and
whom
I
never
saw
,
though
her
husband
is
one
of
our
Society
.
 
<EOS>
God
send
her
a
good
time
!
<EOS>
her
death
would
be
a
terrible
thing
.
 
<EOS>
D
o
you
know
that
I
have
ventured
all
my
credit
with
these
great
Ministers
,
to
clear
some
misunderstandings
betwixt
them
;
and
<EOS>
if
there
be
no
breach
,
I
ought
to
have
the
merit
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
'
Tis
a
plaguy
ticklish
piece
of
work
,
and
<EOS>
a
man
hazards
losing
both
sides
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
pity
the
world
does
not
know
my
virtue
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
the
clergy
in
Convocation
in
Ireland
would
have
given
me
thanks
for
being
their
solicitor
;
but
I
hear
of
no
such
thing
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
talk
occasionally
on
that
subject
,
and
let
me
know
what
you
hear
.
<EOS>
Do
you
know
the
greatness
of
my
spirit
,
that
I
value
their
thanks
not
a
rush
,
but
at
my
return
shall
freely
let
all
people
know
that
it
was
my
Lord
Treasurer
's
action
,
wherein
the
Duke
of
Ormond
had
no
more
share
than
a
cat
?
<EOS>
And
so
they
may
go
whistle
,
and
I
'll
go
sleep
.
  
<EOS>
16
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this
day
in
the
City
,
and
dined
at
Pontack
's
with
Stratford
,
and
two
other
merchants
.
 
<EOS>
Pontack
told
us
,
although
his
wine
was
so
good
,
he
sold
it
cheaper
than
others
;
he
took
but
seven
shillings
a
flask
.
 
<EOS>
Are
not
these
pretty
rates
?
 
<EOS>
The
books
he
sent
for
from
Hamburg
are
come
,
but
not
yet
got
out
of
the
custom
-
house
.
 
<EOS>
My
library
will
be
at
least
double
when
I
come
back
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
go
to
Windsor
again
on
Saturday
,
to
meet
our
Society
,
who
are
to
sup
at
Mr.
Secretary
's
;
but
I
believe
I
shall
return
on
Monday
,
and
then
I
will
answer
your
letter
,
<EOS>
that
lies
here
safe
underneath
;
 
<EOS>
I
see
it
;
lie
still
:
<EOS>
I
will
answer
you
when
the
ducks
have
eaten
up
the
dirt
.
  
<EOS>
17
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
at
Lord
Treasurer
's
with
Mrs.
Masham
,
and
she
is
extremely
like
one
<EOS>
Mrs.
Malolly
,
that
was
once
my
landlady
in
Trim
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
used
with
mighty
kindness
and
respect
,
like
a
favourite
.
 
<EOS>
It
signifies
nothing
going
to
this
Lord
Treasurer
about
business
,
although
it
be
his
own
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
in
haste
,
and
desires
I
will
come
again
,
and
dine
with
him
to
-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
His
famous
lying
porter
is
fallen
sick
,
and
they
think
he
will
die
:
 
<EOS>
I
wish
I
had
all
my
half
-
crowns
again
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
I
have
told
you
he
is
an
old
Scotch
fanatic
,
and
the
damn'dest
liar
in
his
office
alive
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
mind
to
recommend
Patrick
to
succeed
him
:
 
<EOS>
I
have
trained
him
up
pretty
well
.
 
<EOS>
I
reckon
for
certain
you
are
now
in
town
.
 
<EOS>
The
weather
now
begins
to
alter
to
rain
.
  
<EOS>
Windsor
,
18
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
with
Lord
Treasurer
,
and
he
would
make
me
go
with
him
to
Windsor
,
although
I
was
engaged
to
the
Secretary
,
to

:
 
we

in

,

son

son

,

.
 
<EOS>
It
was

before

,
but
<EOS>
a

.
 
<EOS>
I
shall

,

,

.
'
<EOS>
Tis
very

.
  
<EOS>
19
.
 
<EOS>
The
Queen
did
not

,

is

.
 
<EOS>
I
dined

Mr.
Masham

;

none

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
London
,
20
.
 
<EOS>
It
rained

to

:
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
grow

,

.
<EOS>

;

glad

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

21
.
 
<EOS>
I

Dublin
,

.
 
<EOS>
You
know

(

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

'
<EOS>
Twas

,

Sir

,

.
<EOS>
Thornhill
,

Sir
Cholmley

,

,

,

:

<EOS>

We

<EOS>
I

,

.
  
<EOS>
22
.
 
<EOS>
We

.
 
<EOS>
I

's
,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
His
porter
is

.
 
<EOS>
I
sat
with
my
lord
about
three

,
and
am

early
to

.
 
<EOS>
Passing
by
White
's
Chocolate
-

,

,

his
wife
was

to
bed

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
(
Our

,

,

.
)
 
<EOS>
Dr.
Garth
told

that
Mr.
Henley
is

.
 
<EOS>
His

-

,
Earl

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
long

begin

have
any
good
effect
by

.
 
<EOS>
Methinks

;
'
twill

next
Saturday
since

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
O

,

!
 
<EOS>
Faith

,

<EOS>
So

<EOS>
Dilly

<EOS>
It

this

;

.
 
<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>
The

;
but

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Lord

;

,

,

,

;
and

-

will

the
Cabinet

Queen
:
 
so

the
world
!
<EOS>
Prior
has
been
out
of
town
<EOS>
these

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
People

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
have

and

with

,

did
,

,

.
;

.
 
<EOS>
And

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
know

is
bad
;
I
mean

is
bad
in

;
and
was

's

.
 
<EOS>
But
why
Dingley
drinks

,
I

;
but

'll

as

:
 
<EOS>
why
not
?
 
<EOS>
I
hope

now

of
them
since
you
are

;
pray

.
 
<EOS>
I

are
forced
upon

,
which
,

,
is
as

as
the
waters
for
the

.
'
<EOS>
Tis
now
past
the
middle

August
;
so
by
your

are
in

.
<EOS>
It
would

to
the

that
letters
should

between
Dublin
and
Wexford
,
after
"
scaping

.
 
<EOS>
I
will
write
no
more
to
that
nasty
town
in

again
,
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
four
Sundays
together
at
Windsor
,
of
which
a
fortnight
together
;
but
I
believe
I
shall
not
go
to
-
morrow
,
for
I
will
not
,
unless
the

.
 
<EOS>
I
know
all
your
news
about
the
Mayor
:
 
<EOS>
it
makes
no
noise
here
at
all
,
but
the
quarrel
of
your
Parliament
does
;
it
is
so
very
extraordinary
,
and
the
language
of
the
Commons
so
very
pretty
.
 
<EOS>
The
Examiner
has
been
down
this
month
,
and
was
very
silly
the
five
or
six
last
papers
;
but
there
is
a
pamphlet
come
out
,
in
answer
to
a
letter
to
the
seven
Lords
who
examined
Gregg
.
 
<EOS>
The
Answer
is
by
the
real
author
of
the
Examiner
,
as
I
believe
;
for
it
is
very
well

.
 
<EOS>
We
had
Trapp
's
poem
on
the
Duke
of
Ormond
printed
here
,
and
the
printer
sold
just
eleven
of
them
.
 
<EOS>
'
Tis
a
dull
piece
,
not
half
so
good
as
Stella
's
;
and
<EOS>
she
is
very
modest
to
compare
herself
with
such
a
poetaster
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
heartily
sorry
for
poor
Mrs.
Parnell
's
death
;
she
seemed
to
be
an
excellent
good
-
natured
young
woman
,
and
I
believe
the
poor
lad
is
much
afflicted
;
they
appeared
to
live
perfectly
well
together
.
 
<EOS>
Dilly
is
not
tired
at
all
with
England
,
but
intends
to
continue
here
a
good
while
:
 
<EOS>
he
is
mighty
easy
to
be
at
distance
from
his
two
sisters
-
in
-
law
.
 
<EOS>
He
finds
some
sort
of
scrub
acquaintance
;
goes
now
and
then
in
disguise
to
a
play
;
smokes
his
pipe
;
reads
now
and
then
a
little
trash
,
and
what
else
the
Lord
knows
.
 
<EOS>
I
see
him
now
and
then
;
for
he
calls
here
,
and
the
town
being
thin
,
I
am
less
pestered
with
company
than
usual
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
got
rid
of
many
of
my
solicitors
,
by
doing
nothing
for
them
:
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
above
eight
or
nine
left
,
and
I
'll
be
as
kind
to
them
.
 
<EOS>
Did
I
tell
you
of
a
knight
who
desired
me
to
speak
to
Lord
Treasurer
to
give
him
two
thousand
pounds
,
or
five
hundred
pounds
a
year
,
until
he
could
get
something
better
?
 
<EOS>
I
honestly
delivered
my
message
to
the
Treasurer
,
adding
,
the
knight
was
a
puppy
,
whom
I
would
not
give
a
groat
to
save
from
the
gallows
.
 
<EOS>
Cole
Reading
's
father
-
in
-
law
has
been
two
or
three
times
at
me
,
to
recommend
his
lights
to
the
Ministry
,
assuring
me
that
a
word
of
mine
would
,
etc
.
 
<EOS>
Did
not
that
dog
use
to
speak
ill
of
me
,
and
profess
to
hate
me
?
 
<EOS>
He
knows
not
where
I
lodge
,
for
I
told
him
I
lived
in
the
country
;
and
I
have
ordered
Patrick
to
deny
me
constantly
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
Did
the
Bishop
of
London
die
in
Wexford
?
<EOS>
poor
gentleman
!
 
<EOS>
Did
he
drink
the
waters
?
<EOS>
were
you
at
his
burial
?
<EOS>
was
it
a
great
funeral
?
<EOS>
so
far
from
his
friends
!
 
<EOS>
But
he
was
very
old
:
 
<EOS>
we
shall
all
follow
.
<EOS>
And
yet
it
was
a
pity
,
if
God
pleased
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
good
man
;
not
very
learned
:
I
believe
he
died
but
poor
.
 
<EOS>
Did
he
leave
any
charity
legacies
?
<EOS>
who
held
up
his
pall
?
<EOS>
was
there
a
great
sight
of
clergy
?
<EOS>
do
they
design
a
tomb
for
him
?
  
<EOS>
Are
you
sure
it
was
the
Bishop
of
London
?
<EOS>
because
there

:
 
or

?
 
<EOS>
They

.
 
<EOS>
Do

?
<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>
Yes

.
 
<EOS>
O
,
faith
<EOS>
,

what
,
ca

<EOS>
Are

,

?
 
<EOS>
And

?
 
<EOS>
He

,

<EOS>
He

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
but

<EOS>
No

:
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
So

;

this
shall

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Are

literal

in

?
 
<EOS>
I
never
read

over
,
and
I
fancy

.
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
do
then
?
<EOS>
do
you
guess

meaning
,
or
are

?
 
<EOS>
I

in
the

to
-

with
Lord
Radnor
;
but
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
Tisdall
(
that
lodges

)
and
I
have

no

,
nor
do

.
 
<EOS>
There

(

,
)

,
that

;
a

.
 
<EOS>
Dick
Tighe

lodged

;
and
he
has

,
out

,

two

:
 
<EOS>
they

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
Neighbours

to

:
 
in

that

;
and
he
a
hot
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
keep
this
bottom
till
to
-
morrow
:
<EOS>
I
'm

.
  
<EOS>
25
.
 
<EOS>
I

this

,
<EOS>
who

,

;

,

<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Days

,

,

,

that
I

;

<EOS>
They

,

:
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Well
,

MD

;

:
 
<EOS>
consider

,

.
 
<EOS>
There

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
In

,
some

stand

;
I

.
 
<EOS>
Farewell
,

,
dearest

:
 
<EOS>
there

MD
,

else
.
 
<EOS>
They

,
which

;
and

.
 
<EOS>
Farewell
again
<EOS>
,
dearest

;
I

but

<EOS>
I

;

.
<EOS>
Bernage
came

;

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Farewell

etc

.
 
<EOS>
LONDON
,

.
  
<EOS>
I
have
got
a
pretty
small
gilt
sheet
of
paper
,
to
write
to
MD
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
this
moment
sent
my
28th
by
Patrick
,
who
tells
me
he
has
put
it
in
the
post

office
;
'
tis
directed
to
your
lodgings
:
 
if
it
wants

,
you

.
 
<EOS>
It
is
now

your
last
,
N.18
;
and
I
reckon

,

full
of

,

.
 
<EOS>
Where

?
<EOS>
can

?
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Vanhomrigh
boards
now
,
and
can
not

;
and
there
I
used

:
 
and

,

<EOS>

not

,

the

I.
  
26
.
 
<EOS>
People
have
so
left
the
town
that
I
am
at

.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
long

since
I
have
been
at
London
upon

;
and
the
Ministers
are
all
at
Windsor
.
 
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
and
he

,
and
the
drab

looked

window
,
and

up
:
 
<EOS>
so

,
my
Lord
Mountrath

;
my

is

.
 
<EOS>
This
morning
at
five
my
Lord
Jersey
died
of
the
gout
in

,
or

,
or

:
 
<EOS>
he
was
abroad
yesterday
,
and

was

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
Chamberlain
to
King
William
,
and
a

,

as

,

;

,

,
which
has
been

very

at
Court
,
as

.
 
<EOS>
I
never
remember
so
many
people
of
quality
to
have
died
in

short

.
  
<EOS>
27
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
to

into

City
,

#

#
#
a

<EOS>
The

,

forced

.
 
<EOS>
May
my

live
here
in
summer
!
<EOS>
and
yet
I
am
so
unlucky
that
I
can
not

this

.
 
<EOS>
People
leave

town
so
late
in

,
and

so
late
in

,
that
they
have
almost
inverted

.
 
<EOS>
It
is
autumn
<EOS>
this
good
while
in
St.
James
's
Park
;
the
limes
have
been
losing
their

,
and
those
remaining
on
the
trees
are
all
parched
:
 
<EOS>
I
hate
this
season
,
where
everything
grows
worse
and
worse
.
 
<EOS>
The
only

of
it
is
the

,
and

dare

.
 
<EOS>
Had

?
 
<EOS>
A
few

,
and
durst
not

.
 
<EOS>
I
do
not

we

.
 
<EOS>
The
Whigs

that
our

:
 
<EOS>
they

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
The
Whigs

full

;
and
whatever

,
all

.
 
<EOS>
I

's

.
 
<EOS>
I
should

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

is
not

,
but
I
expect

.
 
<EOS>
Burn
all
politics
!
  
<EOS>
28
.
 
<EOS>
We
begin

,
and

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

that

.
 
<EOS>
I

;

;

<EOS>
29
.
 
<EOS>
I

:
 
<EOS>
they

,

.
 
<EOS>
They

:
 
his

;

,

<EOS>
nay
,

,

,

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

I

.
 
<EOS>
The

;
but
I

I

.
 
<EOS>
He

;

that

to

.
 
<EOS>
My
Lord

:
 
Prior

,

;
but

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

who

,

?
  
<EOS>
30
.
 
<EOS>
When

,

Seal
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
his
name
is
Robinson
,
and
that
he
was
many
years
Envoy
in
Sweden
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
friends
of
the
present
Ministry
are
extremely
glad
,
and
the
clergy
above
the
rest
.
 
<EOS>
The
Whigs
will
fret
to
death
to
see
a
civil
employment
given
to
a
clergyman
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
very
handsome
thing
in
my
Lord
Treasurer
,
and
will
bind
the
Church
to
him
for
ever
.
<EOS>
I
dined
with
him
to
-
day
,
but
he
had
not
written
his
letter;[see
above
,
29th
Aug.
]
but
told
me
he
would
not
offer
to
send
it
without
showing
it
to
me
:
 
<EOS>
he
thought
that
would
not
be
just
,
since
I
was
so
deeply
concerned
in
the
affair
.
<EOS>
We
had
much
company
:
 
Lord
Rivers
,
Mar
,
and
Kinnoull
,
Mr.
Secretary
,
George
Granville
,
and
Masham
:
 
the
last
has

to
the

of
his
son
to
-
morrow
se'ennight
;
and
on
Saturday
I
go
to
Windsor
with
Mr.
Secretary
.
  
<EOS>
31
.
 
<EOS>
Dilly
<EOS>
and
I
walked
to
-
day
to
Kensington
to
Lady
Mountjoy
,
who
invited
us
to

.
 
<EOS>
He
returned
soon
,
to
go
to
a
play
,
it
being
the
last
that
will
be
acted
for
some
