:
 
<EOS>
he
dresses
himself
like
a
beau
,
and
no
doubt
makes
a
fine
figure
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
to
visit
some
people
at
Kensington
:
 
<EOS>
Ophy
Butler
's
wife
there
lies
very
ill
of
an
ague
,
which
is
a
very
common
disease
here
,
and
little
known
in
Ireland
.
<EOS>
I
am
apt
to
think
we
shall
soon
have
a
peace
,
by
the
little
words
I
hear
thrown
out
by
the
Ministry
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
just
thought
of
a
project
to
bite
the
town
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
told
you
that
it
is
now
known
that
Mr.
Prior
has
been
lately
in
France
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
make
a
printer
of
my
own
sit
by
me
one
day
,
and
I
will
dictate
to
him
a
formal
relation
of
Prior
's
journey
,
with
several
particulars
,
all
pure
invention
;
and
I
doubt
not
but
it
will
take
.
  
<EOS>
Sept.
1
.
 
<EOS>
Morning
.
 
<EOS>
I
go
to
-
day
to
Windsor
with
Mr.
Secretary
;
and
Lord
Treasurer
has
promised
to
bring
me
back
.
 
<EOS>
The
weather
has
been
fine
for
some
time
,
and
I
believe
we
shall
have
a
great
deal
of
dust
.
 
<EOS>
At
night
.
 
<EOS>
Windsor
.
<EOS>
The
Secretary
and
I
dined
to
-
day
at
Parson
's
Green
,
at
my
Lord
Peterborow
's
house
,
who
has
left
it
and
his
gardens
to
the
Secretary
during
his
absence
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
finest
garden
I
have
ever
seen
about
this
town
;
and
abundance
of
hot
walls
for
grapes
,
where
they
are
in
great
plenty
,
and
ripening
fast
.
 
<EOS>
I
durst
not
eat
any
fruit
but
one
fig
;
but
I
brought
a
basket
full
to
my
friend
Lewis
here
at
Windsor
.
 
<EOS>
Does
Stella
never
eat
any
?
<EOS>
what
,
no
apricots
at
Donnybrook
!
<EOS>
nothing
but
claret
and
ombre
!
 
<EOS>
I
envy
people
maunching
and
maunching
peaches
and
grapes
,
and
I
not
daring
to
eat
a
bit
.
 
<EOS>
My
head
is
pretty
well
,
<EOS>
only
a
sudden
turn
any
time
makes
me
giddy
for
a
moment
,
and
sometimes
it
feels
very
stuffed
;
but
if
it
grows
no
worse
,
I
can
bear
it
very
well
.
 
<EOS>
I
take
all
opportunities
of
walking
;
and
we
have
a
delicious
park
here
just
joining
to
the
Castle
,
and
an
avenue
in
the
great
park
very
wide
and
two
miles
long
,
set
with
a
double
row
of
elms
on
each
side
.
 
<EOS>
Were
you
ever
at
Windsor
?
 
<EOS>
I
was
once
,
a
great
while
ago
;
but
had
quite
forgotten
it
.
  
<EOS>
2
.
 
<EOS>
The
Queen
has
the
gout
,
and
did
not
come
to
chapel
,
nor
stir
out
from
her
chamber
,
but
received
the
sacrament
there
,
as
she
always
does
the
first
Sunday
in
the
month
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
we
had
a
great
Court
;
and
,
among
others
,
I
saw
your
Ingoldsby
,
who
,
seeing
me
talk
very
familiarly
with
the
Keeper
,
Treasurer
,
etc
.
,
came
up
and
saluted
me
,
and
began
a
very
impertinent
discourse
about
the
siege
of
Bouchain
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
him
I
could
not
answer
his
questions
,
but
I
would
bring
him
one
that
should
;
so
I
went
and
fetched
Sutton
(
who
brought
over
the
express
about
a
month
ago
)
,
and
delivered
him
to
the
General
,
and
bid
him
answer
his
questions
;
and
<EOS>
so
I
left
them
together
.
 
<EOS>
Sutton
after
some
time
comes
back
in
a
rage
,
finds
me
with
Lord
Rivers
and
Masham
,
and
there
complains
of
the
trick
I
had
played
him
,
and
swore
he
had
been
plagued
to
death
with
Ingoldsby
's

.
 
<EOS>
But
he
told

Ingoldsby
asked
him
what
I
meant
by
bringing
him
;
so
,
I
suppose
,
he
smoked
me
a

.
 
<EOS>
So
we
laughed
,
etc
.
<EOS>
My
Lord
Willoughby
,
who
is
one
of
the

,
and
Prebendary
of
Windsor
,
read

last

to

;
and

of
Bristol
,
who
is
Dean
of

,

.
 
<EOS>
This
they
do
to
be
popular
;
and
it
pleases
mightily
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Mr.
Masham
,
because
he
lets
me
have
a
select
company
:
 
for
the
Court
here
<EOS>
have
got
by
the
end
a
good
thing
I
said
to
the
Secretary
some

.
 
<EOS>
He
showed
me

bill
of
fare
,
to

.
 
<EOS>
"
Poh
,
"
said

,
"
I
value
not
your
bill
of
fare
;
give

bill
of
company
.
"
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
was

,
and
told
it
everybody
as

.
 
<EOS>
I
reckon
upon

to

:
 
<EOS>
they
say
the
Bishop
will
then

delivered

.
  
<EOS>
3
.
 
Windsor

.
 
<EOS>
The

that
I

.
 
<EOS>
The
Bishop
was

,
and
had
the
Privy
Seal
given

:
 
and
now
the
patents
are
passed
for
those
who
were
this

to

lords
or

.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Raby
,
who
is
Earl
of
Strafford
,
is
on
Thursday
to
marry
a
namesake
of
Stella
's
;
the
daughter
of
Sir
H.
Johnson
in
the
City
;
he
has
three
-
score

with
her
,
ready
money
;
besides
the
rest
at
the
father
's

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
got
my
friend
Stratford
to
be
one
of
the
directors
of
the
South
Sea
Company
,
who
were

to

.
 
<EOS>
My

did

a

;
and
one

whom
I
got
to
be

Gazette
I

to

.
 
<EOS>
He
treated
Mr.
Lewis
and
me
to

.
 
<EOS>
I
supped
last

and
this
with
Lord

,

,
etc
.
,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

;

.
  
<EOS>
London
,
4
.
 
<EOS>
I

's

,
who

Lord

;

's
.
 
<EOS>
We
stopped
at
Kensington
,
where
Lord

went
to
see
Mrs.
Masham
,
who
is
now
what
they
call
in

.
 
<EOS>
We
got
to
town
by
three
,
and
I
lighted
at
Lord
Treasurer
's
,
who
commanded
me
not
to
stir
:
 
<EOS>
but
I
was
not
well
;
and
when
he
went
up
,
I
begged
the
young
lord
to
excuse
me
,
and
so
went
into
the
City
by
water
,
where
I
could
be
easier
,
and
dined
with
the
printer
,
and
dictated
to

some
part
of
Prior
's
Journey
to
France
.
 
<EOS>
I
walked
from
the
City
,
for
I
take
all

of
exercise
.
 
<EOS>
Our
journey
was
horridly
dusty
.
  
<EOS>
5
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
went
out
to
-
day
,
I
found
it
had
rained
mightily
in
the
night
,
and
the
streets
were
as
dirty
as
winter
:
 
<EOS>
it
is
very
refreshing
after
ten
days
dry
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
into
the
City
,
and
dined
with
Stratford
,
thanked
him
for
his
books
,
gave
him
joy
of
his
being
director
,
of
which
he
had
the
first
notice
by
a
letter

.
 
<EOS>
I
ate
sturgeon
,
and
it
lies
on
my

.
 
<EOS>
I
almost
finished
Prior
's
Journey
at
the
printer
's
;
and
came
home
pretty
late
,
with
Patrick
at

.
  
<EOS>
7
.
 
<EOS>
Morning
.
 
<EOS>
But
what

MD
's
,

?
 
<EOS>
Not

,

!
 
<EOS>
I
can
not

in

,
sweethearts
,

.
 
<EOS>
At
night
.
 
<EOS>
O
Lord
,
O
Lord
!
<EOS>
the
greatest
disgrace
that
ever
was
has

to
Presto
.
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
think
?
<EOS>
but
,

was

this

MD
,
N.20
,

.
 
<EOS>
O

,
O

!
 
<EOS>
O

,
O

!
 
<EOS>
Now
I
have
two
letters
together
to

:
 
here
they
are
,
lying

.
 
<EOS>
But
I
will
only
answer

;
for
I
came
in
late
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
my
friend
Lewis
at
his
lodgings
,
and
walked
at
six
to
Kensington
to
Mrs.
Masham
's
son
's

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
very
private
;
nobody
there
but
my
Lord
Treasurer
,

and
son
-
in
-
law
,
that

,
Lord
Harley

,

and

<EOS>
The
Dean
of
Rochester
christened
the
child
,
but
soon
went
away
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
and
Lord
Rivers
were

;
and
Mrs.
Hill
,
Mrs.
Masham
's

,
godmother
.
 
<EOS>
The
child
roared
like
a
bull
,
and
I
gave
Mrs.
Masham
joy
of
it
;
and
she
charged
me
to
take
care
of
my
nephew
,
because
,
Mr.
Masham
being
a
brother
of
our
Society
,
his
son
,
you
know
,
is
consequently
a
nephew
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Masham
sat
up
dressed
in
bed
,
but
not
,
as
they
do
in
Ireland
,
with
all
smooth
about
her
,
as
if
she
was
cut
off
in
the
middle
;
for
you
might
see
the
counterpane
(
what
d'ye
call

?
)
<EOS>
rise
about

and

.
 
<EOS>
There
is
another
name
of
the
counterpane
;
and
you
will
laugh
now
,
sirrahs
.
 
<EOS>
George
Granville
came
in
at
supper
,
and
we
stayed
till
eleven
;
and
Lord
Treasurer
set
me
down
at
my
lodging
in
Suffolk
Street
.
 
<EOS>
Did
I
ever
tell
you
that
Lord
Treasurer
hears
ill
with
the
left
ear
,
just
as
I
do
?
 
<EOS>
He
always
turns
the
right
,
and
his
servants
whisper
him
at
that
only
.
 
<EOS>
I
dare
not
tell
him
that
I
am
so
too
,
<EOS>
for
fear
he
should
think
I
counterfeited
,
to
make

court
.
  
<EOS>
6
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
read
this
before
the
other
;
for
I
mistook
,
and
forgot
to
write
yesterday
's
journal
,
it
was
so

.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Dr.
Cockburn
,
and
sat
the

Lord
Treasurer
till
ten

.
 
<EOS>
On
Thursdays
he
has
always
a
large
select
company
,
and
expects
me
.
 
<EOS>
So
good
-
night
for
last
night
,
etc
.
  
<EOS>
8
.
 
<EOS>
Morning
.
 
<EOS>
I
go
to
Windsor
with
Lord
Treasurer
to
-
day
,
and
will
leave
this
behind
me
,
to
be
sent
to
the
post
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
let
us
hear
what
says
the
first
letter
,
N.19
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
still
at
Wexford
,
as
you
say
,
Madam
Dingley
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
no
letter
from
me
ever
yet
miscarried
.
 
<EOS>
And
so
Inish
-
Corthy
,
and
the
river
Slainy
<EOS>
;
fine
words
those
in
a
lady
's
mouth
.
 
<EOS>
Your
hand
like
Dingley
's
<EOS>
,
you
scambling
,
scattering
sluttikin
!
 
<EOS>
YES
,
MIGHTY
LIKE
INDEED
,
IS
NOT
IT
?
<EOS>
Pisshh
,
do
not
talk
of
writing
or
reading
till
your
eyes
are
well
,
and
long
well
;
only
I
would
have
Dingley
read
sometimes
to
you
,
that
you
may
not
lose
the
desire
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
God
be
thanked
,
that
the
ugly
numbing
is
gone
!
 
<EOS>
Pray
use
exercise
when
you
go
to
town
.
 
<EOS>
What
game
is
that
ombra
which
Dr.
Elwood
and
you
play
at
?
<EOS>
is
it
the
Spanish
game
ombre
?
 
<EOS>
Your
card
-
purse
?
<EOS>
you
a
card
-
purse
!
<EOS>
you
a
fiddlestick
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
luck
indeed
;
and
luck
in
a
bag
.
 
<EOS>
What
a
devil
!
<EOS>
is
that
eight
-
shilling
tea
-
kettle
copper
,
or
tin
japanned
?
 
<EOS>
It
is
like
your
Irish
politeness
,
raffling
for
tea
-
kettles
.
 
<EOS>
What
a
splutter
you
keep
,
to
convince
me
that
Walls
has
no
taste
!
 
<EOS>
My
head
continues
pretty
well
.
 
<EOS>
Why
do
you
write
,
dear
sirrah
<EOS>
Stella
,
when
you
find
your
eyes
so
weak
that
you
can
not
see
?
<EOS>
what
comfort
is
there
in
reading
what
you
write
,
when
one
knows
that
?
 
<EOS>
So
Dingley
can
not
write
,
because
of
the
clutter
of
new
company
come
to
Wexford
!
<EOS>
I
suppose
the
noise
of
their
hundred
horses
disturbs
you
;
or
do
you
lie
in
one
gallery
,
as
in
an
hospital
?
 
<EOS>
What
!
<EOS>
you
are
afraid
of
losing
in
Dublin
the
acquaintance
you
have
got
in
Wexford
,
and
chiefly
the
Bishop
of
Raphoe
,
an
old
,
doting
,
perverse
coxcomb
?
 
<EOS>
Twenty
at
a
time
at
breakfast
.
 
<EOS>
That
is
like
five
pounds
at
a
time
,
when
it
was
never
but
once
.
 
<EOS>
I
doubt
,
Madam
Dingley
,
you
are
apt
to
lie
in
your
travels
,
though
not
so
bad
as
Stella
;
she
tells
thumpers
,
as
I
shall
prove
in
my
next
,
if
I
find
this
receives
encouragement
.
 
<EOS>
So
Dr.
Elwood
says
there
are
a
world
of
pretty
things
in
my
works
.
 
<EOS>
A
pox
on
his
praises
!
<EOS>
an
enemy
here
would
say
more
.
 
<EOS>
The
Duke
of
Buckingham
would
say
as
much
,
though
he
and
I
are
terribly
fallen
out
;
and
the
great
men
are
perpetually
inflaming
me
against
him
:
 
<EOS>
they
bring
me
all
he
says
of
me
,
and
,
I
believe
,
make
it
worse
out
of
roguery
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
'
tis
<EOS>
not
your
pen
is
bewitched
,
Madam
Stella
,
but
your
old
SCRAWLING
,
SPLAY
-
FOOT
POT
-
HOOKS
,
S
,
S
,
ay
<EOS>
that
's
it
:
 
there
<EOS>
the
s
,
s
,
s
,
there
,
there
,
that
's
exact
.
 
<EOS>
Farewell
,
etc
.
  
<EOS>
Our
fine
weather
is
gone
;
and
I
doubt
we
shall
have
a
rainy
journey
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
Faith
,
'
tis
shaving
-
day
,
and
I
have
much
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
When
Stella
says
her
pen
was
bewitched
,
it
was
only
because
there
was
a
hair
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
,
the
fellow
they
call
God
-
help
-
it
had
the
same
thoughts
of
his
wife
,
and
for
the
same
reason
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
this
is
very
well
observed
,
and
I
unfolded
the
letter
to
tell
you
it
.
  
<EOS>
Cut
off
those
two
notes
above
;
and
see
the
nine
pounds
indorsed
,
and
receive
the
other
;
and
send
me
word
how
my
accounts
stand
,
that
they
may
be
adjusted
by
Nov.
1
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
be
very
particular
;
but
the
twenty
pounds
I
lend
you
is
not
to
be
included
:
 
so
make
no
blunder
.
 
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
wrong
you
,
nor
you
sha
n't
wrong
me
;
that
is
the
short
.
 
<EOS>
O
Lord
,
how
stout
Presto
is
of
late
!
 
<EOS>
But
he
loves
MD
more
than
his
life
a
thousand
times
,
for
all
his
stoutness
;
tell
them
that
;
and
that
I
'll
swear
it
,
as
hope
saved
,
ten
millions
of
times
,
etc
.
<EOS>
etc
.
  
<EOS>
I
open
my
letter
once
more
,
to
tell
Stella
that
if
she
does
not
use
exercise
after
her
waters
,
it
will
lose
all
the
effects
of
them
:
 
I
should
not
live
if
I
did
not
take
all
opportunities
of
walking
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
,
pray
,
do
this
,
to
oblige
poor
Presto
.
   
<EOS>
LETTER
30
.
 
<EOS>
WINDSOR
,
Sept.
8
,
1711
.
  
<EOS>
I
made
the
coachman
stop
,
and
put
in
my
twenty
-
ninth
at
the
post
-
office
at
two
o'clock
to
-
day
,
as
I
was
going
to
Lord
Treasurer
,
with
whom
I
dined
,
and
came
here
by
a
quarter
-
past
eight
;
but
the
moon
shone
,
and
so
we
were
not
in
much
danger
of
overturning
;
which
,
however
,
he
values
not
a
straw
,
and
only
laughs
when
I
chide
at
him
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
nobody
but
he
and
I
,
and
we
supped
together
,
with
Mr.
Masham
,
and
Dr.
Arbuthnot
,
the
Queen
's
favourite
physician
,
a
Scotchman
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
keep
myself
awake
after
supper
,
but
did
all
I
was
able
to
disguise
it
,
and
thought
I
came
off
clear
;
but
,
at
parting
,
he
told
me
I
had
got
my
nap
already
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
now
one
o'clock
;
but
he
loves
sitting
up
late
.
  
<EOS>
9
.
 
<EOS>
The
Queen
is
still
in
the
gout
,
but
recovering
:
 
<EOS>
she
saw
company
in
her
bed
-
chamber
after
church
;
but
the
crowd
was
so
great
,
I
could
not
see
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
my
brother
Sir
William
Wyndham
,
and
some
others
of
our
Society
,
to
avoid
the
great
tables
on
Sunday
at
Windsor
,
which
I
hate
.
 
<EOS>
The
usual
company
supped
to
-
night
at
Lord
Treasurer
's
,
which
was
Lord
Keeper
,
Mr.
Secretary
,
George
Granville
,
Masham
,
Arbuthnot
,
and
I.
 
<EOS>
But
showers
have
hindered
me
from
walking
to
-
day
,
and
that
I
do
not
love
.
 
<EOS>
Noble
fruit
,
and
I
dare
not
eat
a
bit
.
 
<EOS>
I
ate
one
fig
to
-
day
,
and
sometimes
a
few
mulberries
,
because
it
is
said
they
are
wholesome
,
and
you
know
a
good
name
does
much
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
return
to
town
to
-
morrow
,
though
I
thought
to
have
stayed
a
week
,
to
be
at
leisure
for
something
I
am
doing
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
have
put
it
off
till
next
;
for
I
shall
come
here
again
on
Saturday
,
when
our
Society
are
to
meet
at
supper
at
Mr.
Secretary
's
.
 
<EOS>
My
life
is
very
regular
here
:
 
on
Sunday
morning
I
constantly
visit
Lord
Keeper
,
and
sup
at
Lord
Treasurer
's
with
the
same
set
of
company
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
not
sleepy
to
-
night
;
I
resolved
I
would
not
;
yet
it
is
past
midnight
at
this
present
writing
.
  
<EOS>
London
,
10
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
and
Masham
and
I
left
Windsor
at
three
this
afternoon
:
 
we
dropped
Masham
at
Kensington
with
his
lady
,
and
got
home
by
six
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
seven
before
we
sat
down
to
dinner
,
and
I
stayed
till
past
eleven
.
 
<EOS>
Patrick
came
home
with
the
Secretary
:
 
<EOS>
I
am
more
plagued
with
Patrick
and
my
portmantua
than
with
myself
.
 
<EOS>
I
forgot
to
tell
you
that
when
I
went
to
Windsor
on
Saturday
I
overtook
Lady
Giffard
and
Mrs.
Fenton
in
a
chariot
,
going
,
I
suppose
,
to
Sheen
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
then
in
a
chariot
too
,
of
Lord
Treasurer
's
brother
,
who
had
business
with
the
Treasurer
;
and
my
lord
came
after
,
and
overtook
me
at
Turnham
Green
,
four
miles
from
London
;
and
then
the
brother
went
back
,
and
I
went
in
the
coach
with
Lord
Treasurer
:
 
<EOS>
so
it
happened
that
those
people
saw
me
,
and
not
with
Lord
Treasurer
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
F.
was
to
see
me
about
a
week
ago
;
and
desired
I
would
get
her
son
into
the
Charter
-
house
.
  
<EOS>
11
.
 
<EOS>
This
morning
the
printer
sent
me
an
account
of
Prior
's
Journey
;
it
makes
a
twopenny
pamphlet
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
you
will
see
it
,
for
I
dare
engage
it
will
run
;
'
tis
a
formal
,
grave
lie
,
from
the
beginning
to
the
end
.
 
<EOS>
I
writ
all
but
about
the
last
page
;
that
I
dictated
,
and
the
printer
writ
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Secretary
sent
to
me
to
dine
where
he
did
;
it
was
at
Prior
's
:
 
when
I
came
in
,
Prior
showed
me
the
pamphlet
,
seemed
to
be
angry
,
and
said
,
"
Here
is
our
English
liberty
!
"
 
<EOS>
I
read
some
of
it
,
and
said
I
liked
it
mightily
,
and
envied
the
rogue
the
thought
;
for
,
had
it
come
into
my
head
,
I
should
have
certainly
done
it
myself
.
 
<EOS>
We
stayed
at
Prior
's
till
past
ten
;
and
then
the
Secretary
received
a
packet
with
the
news
of
Bouchain
being
taken
,
for
which
the
guns
will
go
off
to
-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
Prior
owned
his
having
been
in
France
,
for
it
was
past
denying
:
 
<EOS>
it
seems
he
was
discovered
by
a
rascal
at
Dover
,
who
had
positive
orders
to
let
him
pass
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
we
shall
have
a
peace
.
  
<EOS>
12
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
terrible
rainy
weather
,
and
has
cost
me
three
shillings
in
coaches
and
chairs
to
-
day
,
yet
I
was
dirty
into
the
bargain
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
three
hours
this
morning
with
the
Secretary
about
some
business
of
moment
,
and
then
went
into
the
City
to
dine
.
 
<EOS>
The
printer
tells
me
he
sold
yesterday
a
thousand
of
Prior
's
Journey
,
and
had
printed
five
hundred
more
.
 
<EOS>
It
will
do
rarely
,
I
believe
,
and
is
a
pure
bite
.
 
<EOS>
And
what
is
MD
doing
all
this
while
?
<EOS>
got
again
to
their
cards
,
their
Walls
,
their
deans
,
their
Stoytes
,
and
their
claret
?
<EOS>
Pray
present
my
service
to
Mr.
Stoyte
and
Catherine
.
 
<EOS>
Tell
Goody
Stoyte
<EOS>
she
owes
me
a
world
of
dinners
,
and
I
will
shortly
come
over
and
demand
them
.
 
<EOS>
Did
I
tell
you
of
the
Archbishop
of
Dublin
's
last
letter
?
 
<EOS>
He
had
been
saying
,
in
several
of
his
former
,
that
he
would
shortly
write
to
me
something
about
myself
;
and
it
looked
as
if
he
intended
something
for
me
:
 
at
last
out
<EOS>
it
comes
,
and
consists
of
two
parts
.
 
<EOS>
First
,
he
advises
me
to
strike
in
for
some
preferment
now
<EOS>
I
have
friends
;
and
secondly
,
he
advises
me
,
since
I
have
parts
,
and
learning
,
and
a
happy
pen
,
to
think
of
some
new
subject
in
divinity
not
handled
by
others
,
which
I
should
manage
better
than
anybody
.
 
<EOS>
A
rare
spark
this
,
with
a
pox
!
<EOS>
but
I
shall
answer
him
as
rarely
.
 
<EOS>
Methinks
he
should
have
invited
me
over
,
and
given
me
some
hopes
or
promises
.
 
<EOS>
But
hang
him
!
<EOS>
and
so
good
-
night
,
etc
.
  
<EOS>
13
.
 
<EOS>
It
rained
most
furiously
all
this
morning
till
about
twelve
,
and
sometimes
thundered
;
I
trembled
for
my
shillings
,
but
it
cleared
up
,
and
I
made
a
shift
to
get
a
walk
in
the
Park
,
and
then
went
with
the
Secretary
to
dine
with
Lord
Treasurer
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
Thursdays
there
is
always
a
select
company
:
we
had
the
Duke
of
Shrewsbury
,
Lord
Rivers
,
the
two
Secretaries
,
Mr.
Granville
,
and
Mr.
Prior
.
 
<EOS>
Half
of
them
went
to
Council
at
six
;
but
Rivers
,
Granville
,
Prior
,
and
I
,
stayed
till
eight
.
 
<EOS>
Prior
was
often
affecting
to
be
angry
at
the
account
of
his
journey
to
Paris
;
and
indeed
the
two
last
pages
,
which
the
printer
got
somebody
to
add
,
are
so
romantic
,
they
spoil
all
the
rest
.
 
<EOS>
Dilly
Ashe
pretended
to
me
that
he
was
only
going
to
Oxford
and
Cambridge
for
a
fortnight
,
and
then
would
come
back
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
see
him
as
I
appointed
t'other
day
;
but
some
of
his
friends
tell
me
he
took
leave
of
them
as
going
to
Ireland
;
and
so
they
say
at
his
lodging
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
the
rogue
was
ashamed
to
tell
me
so
,
because
I
advised
him
to
stay
the
winter
,
and
he
said
he
would
.
 
<EOS>
I
find
he
had
got
into
a
good
set
of
scrub
acquaintance
,
and
I
thought
passed
his
time
very
merrily
;
but
I
suppose
he
languished
after
Balderig
,
and
the
claret
of
Dublin
;
and
,
after
all
,
I
think
he
is
in
the
right
;
for
he
can
eat
,
drink
,
and
converse
better
there
than
here
.
 
<EOS>
Bernage
was
with
me
this
morning
:
 
<EOS>
he
calls
now
and
then
;
he
is
in
terrible
fear
of
a
peace
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
he
never
had
his
health
so
well
as
in
Portugal
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a
favourite
of
his
Colonel
.
  
<EOS>
14
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
mortified
enough
to
-
day
,
not
knowing
where
in
the
world
to
dine
<EOS>
,
the
town
is
so
empty
.
 
<EOS>
I
met
H.
Coote
,
and
thought
he
would
invite
me
,
but
he
did
not
:
 
<EOS>
Sir
John
Stanley
did
not
come
into
my
head
;
so
I
took
up
with
Mrs.
Van
,
and
dined
with
her
and
her
damned
landlady
,
who
,
I
believe
,
by
her
eyebrows
,
is
a
bawd
.
 
<EOS>
This
evening
I
met
Addison
and
Pastoral
Philips
in
the
Park
,
and
supped
with
them
at
Addison
's
lodgings
:
 
<EOS>
we
were
very
good
company
,
and
I
yet
know
no
man
half
so
agreeable
to
me
as
he
is
.
 
<EOS>
I
sat
with
them
till
twelve
,
so
you
may
think
it
is
late
,
young
women
;
however
,
I
would
have
some
little
conversation
with
MD
before
your
Presto
goes
to
bed
,
because
it
makes
me
sleep
,
and
dream
,
and
so
forth
.
 
<EOS>
Faith
,
this
letter
goes
on
slowly
enough
,
sirrahs
;
but
I
can
not
write
much
at
a
time
till
you
are
quite
settled
after
your
journey
,
you
know
,
and
have
gone
all
your
visits
,
and
lost
your
money
at
ombre
.
 
<EOS>
You
never
play
at
chess
now
,
Stella
.
 
<EOS>
That
puts
me
in
mind
of
Dick
Tighe
;
I
fancy
<EOS>
I
told
you
he
used
to
beat
his
wife
here
;
and
she
deserved
it
;
and
he
resolves
to
part
with

;
and
they
went
to
Ireland
in
different

.
 
<EOS>
O
Lord
,
I
said
all
this
before
,
I
am
sure
.
 
<EOS>
Go
to
bed
,
sirrahs
.
  
<EOS>
Windsor
,
15
.
 
<EOS>
I
made
the
Secretary
stop
at
Brentford
,
because
we
set
out
at
two
this

,
and
fasting
would
not

.
 
<EOS>
I
only
designed

eat
a
bit
of
bread
-
and
-

;
but
he
would
light
,
and
we
ate
roast

like

.
 
<EOS>
And
he
made

treat
him
and
two

;
faith
,
it
cost

a

.
 
<EOS>
I
do
not
like
such
jesting
,
yet
<EOS>
I
was
mightily

with

.
<EOS>
To

Society
met

:
 
there

;
and

have
chosen

,
the
Earl
of

,
whose

.
'
<EOS>
Tis
past

,

.
  
<EOS>
16
.
 
<EOS>
I
design
to

here
this
week
by
myself
,
about
some
business
that
lies
on
my
hands
,
and
will
take
up
a

deal

.
 
<EOS>
Dr.
Adams
,
one
of
the
canons
,
invited

to
-

to

.
 
<EOS>
The
tables
are
so
full
here
on
Sunday
that
it
is
hard
to

with
a
few
,
and
Dr.
Adams
knows
I
love
to
do

;
which
is
very
obliging
.
 
<EOS>
The
Queen
saw
company
in
her
bed
-
chamber
;
she
looks
very
well
,
but
she
sat
down
.
 
<EOS>
I
supped
with
Lord
Treasurer
as
usual
,
and
stayed
till
past
one
as
usual
,
and
with
our
usual
company
,

Lord

,

this

.
 
<EOS>
I
hate

,
but
I
seldom

.
  
<EOS>
17
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
and
Mr.
Secretary
stay
here
till
tomorrow
;
some
business

,
and
I
am
sorry
for
it
,
for
they
hinder

a

.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Lewis
and
I
were

Court

at
one
.
 
<EOS>
But
Lord
Harley
and
Lord
Dupplin
kept

by

,
and
said
we
should
dine
at
Lord
Treasurer
's
,
who
intended
to
go
at
four
to
London
.
 
<EOS>
I
stayed
like
a
fool
,
and
went
with
the
two
young
lords
to
Lord
Treasurer
,
who
very
fairly
turned
us
all
three
out

doors
.
 
<EOS>
They
both
were
invited
to
the
Duke
of
Somerset
,
but
he
was
gone
to
a
horse
-

,
and
would
not
come
till
five
;
so
we
were
forced
to
go
to
a
tavern
,
and
sent
for
wine
from
Lord
Treasurer
's
,
who
at
last
,
we

told
,
did
not

the

,
and

;
and
I
desired

the

I

.
<EOS>
We
sat

,

I
must

MD
.
  
<EOS>
18
.
 
<EOS>
They
are

this

,
and
I
am
alone

;
but

;

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

,

,

,

And

<EOS>
I
have

<EOS>
I

,

;

;

,

<EOS>

,

;

<EOS>
I

,

;

,

;

;

;

this

.
  
<EOS>
19
.
 
<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>
Mrs.

is

lying
-
in
:
 
<EOS>
I

got

;

lame

.
 
<EOS>
Dr.

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs.

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
Arbuthnot

,

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
We

,

;

<EOS>

,

;

Queen

:
 
<EOS>
we

20
.

;

<EOS>

;

<EOS>
The

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
But

:
 
I
will

<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

against

:
 
I

to

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
22
.
 
<EOS>
This

,

's

,

must
sup

;
and

,

Lewis
a

,
which

.
<EOS>
We
walked
in

about

;
but
I
was

,
that

,
and

two

towards
London
,
hoping
to
meet
Lord
Treasurer
,
and
return
with

;
but
it
grew

,
and
I
was
forced
to
walk
back
,
so
I
walked
nine
miles
in
all
;
and
Lord
Treasurer
did
not
come
till
after

;
which
is
very
wrong
,
for
there
was
no

,
and
I
often

how
ill

does
to

himself

;
but
he

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
and

,
when

is

.
 
<EOS>
He
is

and

as

-

.
'
<EOS>
Tis
late

.
  
<EOS>
23
.
 
<EOS>
The

did
not

,
but

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
seen

,
but

are

as

as

,

.
 
<EOS>
The
Queen
was
at

to

,
but

.
 
<EOS>
I

Lewis

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

this

,

;
and

had

.
 
<EOS>
That

Arbuthnot
puts

upon

.
 
<EOS>
The
Court
was
very
full
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
expected

would
have
invited

;
but
he

;
and
we
had
no

in

-

.
 
<EOS>
It
is
now
seven
at
night
,
and
I
am
at

;
and
I
hope
Lord
Treasurer
will
not
send

me
to

:
 
if

not
,
I
will
reproach
him
;
and
he
will
pretend

me
for
not

.
 
<EOS>
So
farewell
<EOS>
till
I
go
to
bed
,
for
I
am
going
to
be
busy
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
now
past
ten
,
and
I
went
down
to
ask
the
servants
about
Mr.
Secretary
:
 
<EOS>
they
tell
me
the
Queen
is
yet
at
Council
,
and
that
she
went
to
supper
,
and
came
out
to
the
Council
afterwards
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
certain
they
are
managing
a
peace
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
go
to
bed
,
and
there
is
an
end
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
now
eleven
,
and
a
messenger
is
come
from
Lord
Treasurer
to
sup
with
them
;
but
I
have
excused
myself
,
and
am
glad
I
am
in
bed
;
for
else
I
should
sit
up
till
two
,
and
drink
till
I
was

.
 
<EOS>
Now
I
'll
go
sleep
.
  
<EOS>
London
,
24
.
 
<EOS>
I
came
to
town
by
six
with
Lord
Treasurer
,
and
have
stayed
till
ten
.
 
<EOS>
That
of
the
Queen
's
going
out
to
sup
,
and
coming
in
again
,
is
a
lie
,
as
the
Secretary
told
me
this
morning
;
but
I
find
the
Ministry
are
very
busy
with
Mr.
Prior
,
and
I
believe
he
will
go
again
to
France
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
told
so
much
,
that
we
shall
certainly
have
a
peace
very
soon
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
charming
weather
all
last
week
at
Windsor
;
but
we
have
had
a
little
rain
to
-
day
,
and
yesterday
was
windy
.
 
<EOS>
Prior
's
Journey
sells
still
;
they
have
sold
two
thousand
,
although
the
town
is
empty
.
 
<EOS>
I
found
a
letter
from
Mrs.
Fenton
here
,
desiring
me
,
in
Lady
Giffard
's
name
,
to
come
and
pass
a
week
at
Sheen
,
while
she
is

.
  
<EOS>
I

the

to

,

30th

;
and
when

I
found

one

:
 
<EOS>
it
was
from
#
#
#
#
,
 
three

and

in

,

,

the
side

South
,

's

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

the

,

that
ever

,
or
that
ever

into

.
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
A

on
him
<EOS>
,

.
 
<EOS>
I
think

will

that
I
never

Lord

in

:
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure

any

when

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
Our

.
 
<EOS>
Prior

:
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>

:
 
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
This

.
  
<EOS>
26
.
 
<EOS>
Bernage
has
been

these
two
days
;
yesterday

sent

to
let

know
that
Dr.
Arbuthnot
is
putting
in

to

brother

over

's

.
 
<EOS>
Arbuthnot
's
brother
is
but
an

,
but
the
Doctor
has
great

with

Queen
:
 
yet

to

;
and

Colonel

.
 
<EOS>
To

(

)
that

;

is

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

to

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

's
,

;

:
 
he

,
but
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
desire

may

Hawkshaw
to

when

,

;

,

,

of

,

.
 
<EOS>
Go

's
,

.
  
<EOS>
27
.
 
<EOS>
Bernage
was
with

again
to
-

,
and
is
in

fear
,
and

;
but

,

's
,

,

,

,

,

;
that

to

,
and
Bernage
is

.
 
<EOS>
I
called

,

<EOS>
the

's

,

,

;
so

,
and

to
-
morrow

,

.
 
<EOS>
Bernage
is
now
easy
;
he
has
ten
shillings
a
day
,
beside

.
 
<EOS>
However
,
he
gives
a
private

to

Colonel
,
but
it
is
very
cheap
:
 
<EOS>
his
Colonel
loves
him
well
,
but
is
surprised
to
see
him
have
so
many
friends
.
 
<EOS>
So
he
is
now
quite
off
my
hands
.
 
<EOS>
I
left
the
company
early
to
-

,
at
Lord

's
;
but
the

,
to

would

to
W
#
#
#
#
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Lewis
's
man
came
in
before

that
word
beginning

a
W
,
which
ought
to
be
Windsor
,
and

Arbuthnot
,

had
,

,

,

;

's

.
 
<EOS>
Whether

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
says
he
this

morning
begged
Her

to
give

Bernage
the
company
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
mighty
well

;
but

tedious
,

man
,

.
  
<EOS>
Windsor
,
28
.
 
<EOS>
I
came
here
a
day
sooner
than
ordinary
,
at
Mr.
Secretary
's
desire
,
and
supped
with
him
and
Prior
,
and
two

from
France
,
and

.
 
<EOS>
I
know
not
the
two
Ministers
'
names
;
but
they
are
come
about
the
peace
.
 
<EOS>
The
names
the
Secretary
called
them
,
I
suppose
,
were
feigned
;
they
were
good
rational
men
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
already
settled
all
things
with
France
,
and
very
much
to
the
honour
and
advantage
of
England
;
and
the
Queen
is
in
mighty
good
humour
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
news
is
a
mighty
secret
;
the
people
in
general
know
that
a
peace
is
forwarding
.
 
<EOS>
The
Earl
of
Strafford
is
to
go
soon
to
Holland
,
and
let
them
know
what
we
have
been
doing
:
 
and
then
there
will
be
the
devil
and
all
to
pay
;
but
we
'll
make
them
swallow
it
with
a
pox
.
<EOS>
The
French
Ministers
stayed
with
us
till
one
,
and
the
Secretary
<EOS>
and
I
sat
up
talking
till
two
;
so
you
will
own
'
tis
late
,
sirrahs
,
and
time
for
your
little
saucy
Presto
to
go
to
bed
and
sleep
adazy
;
and
God
bless
poor
little
MD
:
 
<EOS>
I
hope
they
are
now
fast
asleep
,
and
dreaming
of
Presto
.
  
<EOS>
29
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
came
to
-
night
,
as
usual
,
at
half
an
hour
after
eight
,
as
dark
as
pitch
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
weary
of
chiding
him
;
so
I
commended
him
for
observing
his
friend
's
advice
,
and
coming
so
early
,
etc
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
two
hours
with
Lady
Oglethorpe
to
-
night
,
and
then
supped
with
Lord
Treasurer
,
after
dining
at
the
Green
Cloth
:
 
<EOS>
I
stayed
till
two
;
this
is
the
effect
of
Lord
Treasurer
's
being
here
;
I
must
sup
with
him
;
and
he
keeps
cursed
hours
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Keeper
and
the
Secretary
were
absent
;
they
can
not
sit
up
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
This
long
sitting
up
makes
the
periods
in
my
letters
so
short
.
 
<EOS>
I
design
to
stay
here
all
the
next
week
,
to
be
at
leisure
by
myself
,
to
finish
something
of
weight
I
have
upon
my
hands
,
and
which
must
soon
be
done
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
then
think
of
returning
to
Ireland
,
if
these
people
will
let
me
;
and
I
know
nothing
else
they
have
for
me
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
I
gave
Dr.
Arbuthnot
my
thanks
for
his
kindness
to
Bernage
,
whose
commission
is
now
signed
.
 
<EOS>
Methinks
I
long
to
know
something
of
Stella
's
health
,
how
it
continues
after
Wexford
waters
.
  
<EOS>
30
.
 
<EOS>
The
Queen
was
not
at
chapel
to
-
day
,
and
all
for
the
better
,
for
we
had
a
dunce
to
preach
:
 
<EOS>
she
has
a
little
of
the
gout
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
my
brother
Masham
,
and
a
moderate
company
,
and
would
not
go
to
Lord
Treasurer
's
till
after
supper
at
eleven
o'clock
,
and
pretended
I
had
mistaken
the
hour
;
so
I
ate
nothing
:
 
and
a
little
after
twelve
the
company
broke
up
,
the
Keeper
and
Secretary
refusing
to
stay
;
<EOS>
so
I
saved
this
night
's
debauch
.
 
<EOS>
Prior
went
away
yesterday
with
his
Frenchmen
,
and
a
thousand
reports
are
raised
in
this
town
.
<EOS>
Some
said
they
knew
one
to
be
the
Abbe
de
Polignac
:
 
others
swore
it
was
the
Abbe
du
Bois
.
 
<EOS>
The
Whigs
are
in
a
rage
about
the
peace
;
but
we
'll
wherret
them
,
I
warrant
,
boys
.
 
<EOS>
Go
,
go
,
go
to
the
Dean
's
and
do
n't
mind
politics
,
young
women
<EOS>
,
they
are
not
good
after
the
waters
;
they
are
stark
naught
:
 
they
strike
up
into
the
head
.
 
<EOS>
Go
,
get
two
black
aces
,
and
fish
for
a
manilio
.
  
<EOS>
Oct.
1
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
John
Walter
,
an
honest
drunken
fellow
,
is
now
in
waiting
,
and
invited
me
to
the
Green
Cloth
to
-
day
,
that
he
might
not
be
behindhand
with
Colonel
Godfrey
,
who
is
a
Whig
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
engaged
to
the
Mayor
's
feast
with
Mr.
Masham
;
but
waiting
to
take
leave
of
Lord
Treasurer
<EOS>
,
I
came
too
late
,
and
so
returned
sneaking
to
the
Green
Cloth
,
and
did
not
see
my
Lord
Treasurer
neither
;
but
was
resolved
not
to
lose
two
dinners
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
took
leave
to
-
day
of
my
friend
and
solicitor
Lord
Rivers
,
who
is
commanded
by
the
Queen
to
set
out
for
Hanover
on
Thursday
.
 
<EOS>
The
Secretary
does
not
go
to
town
till
to
-
morrow
;
he
and
I
,
and
two
friends
more
,
drank
a
sober
bottle
of
wine
here
at
home
,
and
parted
at
twelve
;
he
goes
by
seven
to
-
morrow
morning
,
so
I
shall
not
see
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
power
over
his
cellar
in
his
absence
,
and
make
little
use
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Dartmouth
and
my
friend
Lewis
stay
here
this
week
;
but
I
can
never
work
out
a
dinner
from
Dartmouth
.
 
<EOS>
Masham
has
promised
to
provide
for
me
:
 
<EOS>
I
squired
his
lady
out
of
her
chaise
to
-
day
,
and
must
visit
her
in
a
day
or
two
.
<EOS>
So
you
have
had
a
long
fit
of
the
finest
weather
in
the
world
;
but
I
am
every
day
in
pain
that
it
will
go
off
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
done
no
business
to
-
day
;
I
am
very
idle
.
  
<EOS>
2
.
 
<EOS>
My
friend
Lewis
and
I
,
to
avoid
over
much
eating
and
great
tables
,
dined
with
honest
Jemmy
Eckershall
,
Clerk
of
the
Kitchen
,
now
in
waiting
,
and
I
bespoke
my
dinner
:
 
but
the
cur
had
your
acquaintance
Lovet
,
the
gentleman
porter
,
to
be
our
company
.
 
<EOS>
Lovet
,
towards
the
end
of
dinner
,
after
twenty
wrigglings
,
said
he
had
the
honour
to
see
me
formerly
at
Moor
Park
,
and
thought
he
remembered
my
face
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
I
thought
I
remembered
him
,
and
was
glad
to
see
him
,
etc
.
,
and
I
escaped
for
that
much
,
for
he
was
very
pert
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
rained
all
this
day
,
and
I
doubt
our
good
weather
is
gone
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
very
idle
this
afternoon
,
playing
at
twelvepenny
picquet
with
Lewis
:
 
<EOS>
I
won
seven
shillings
,
which
is
the
only
money
I
won
this
year
:
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
played
above
four
times
,
and
I
think
always
at
Windsor
.
 
<EOS>
Cards
are
very
dear
:
 
there
is
a
duty
on
them
of
sixpence
a
pack
,
which
spoils
small
gamesters
.
  
<EOS>
3
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Masham
sent
this
morning
to
desire
I
would
ride
out
with
him
,
the
weather
growing
again
very
fine
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
very
busy
,
and
sent
my
excuses
;
but
desired
he
would
provide
me
a
dinner
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
him
,
his
lady
,
and
her
sister
,
Mrs.
Hill
,
who
invites
us
to
-
morrow
to
dine
with
her
,
and
we
are
to
ride
out
in
the
morning
.
 
<EOS>
I
sat
with
Lady
Oglethorpe
till
eight
this
evening
,
then
was
going
home
to
write
;
looked
about
for
the
woman
that
keeps
the
key
of
the
house
:
 
<EOS>
she
told
me
Patrick
had
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
cooled
my
heels
in
the
cloisters
till
nine
,
then
went
in
to
the
music
-
meeting
,
where
I
had
been
often
desired
to
go
;
but
was
weary
in
half
an
hour
of
their
fine
stuff
,
and
stole
out
so
privately
that
everybody
saw
me
;
and
cooled
my
heels
in
the
cloisters
again
till
after
ten
:
 
then
came
in
Patrick
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
up
,
shut
the
chamber
door
,
and
gave
him
two
or
three
swinging
cuffs
on
the
ear
,
and
I
have
strained
the
thumb
of
my
left
hand
with
pulling
him
,
which
I
did
not
feel
until
he
was
gone
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
plaguily
afraid
and
humbled
.
  
<EOS>
4
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
finest
day
in
the
world
,
and
we
got
out
before
eleven
,
a
noble
caravan
of
us
.
 
<EOS>
The
Duchess
of
Shrewsbury
in
her
own
chaise
with
one
horse
,
and
Miss
Touchet
with
her
,
Mrs.
Masham
and
Mrs.
Scarborow
,
one
of
the
dressers
,
in
one
of
the
Queen
's
chaises
;
Miss
Forester
and
Miss
Scarborow
,
two
maids
of
honour
,
and
Mrs.
Hill
on
horseback
.
 
<EOS>
The
Duke
of
Shrewsbury
,
Mr.
Masham
,
George
Fielding
,
Arbuthnot
,
and
I
,
on
horseback
too
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Hill
's
horse
was
hired
for
Miss
Scarborow
,
but
she
took
it
in
civility
;
her
own
horse
was
galled
and
could
not
be
rid
,
but
kicked
and
winced
:
 
the
hired
horse
was
not
worth
eighteenpence
.
 
<EOS>
I
borrowed
coat
,
boots
,
and
horse
,
and
in
short
we
had
all
the
difficulties
,
and
more
than
we
used
to
have
in
making
a
party
from
Trim
to
Longfield
's
.
 
<EOS>
My
coat
was
light
camlet
,
faced
with
red
velvet
,
and
silver
buttons
.
 
<EOS>
We
rode
in
the
great
park
and
the
forest
about
a
dozen
miles
,
and
the
Duchess
<EOS>
and
I
had
much
conversation
:
 
<EOS>
we
got
home
by
two
,
and
Mr.
Masham
,
his
lady
,
Arbuthnot
and
I
,
dined
with
Mrs.
Hill
.
 
<EOS>
Arbuthnot
made
us
all
melancholy
,
by
some
symptoms
of
bloody
u####e
:
 
he
expects
a
cruel
fit
of
the
stone
in
twelve
hours
;
he
says
he
is
never
mistaken
,
and
he
appears
like
a
man
that
was
to
be
racked
to
-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
but
hope
it
will
not
be
so
bad
;
he
is
a
perfectly
honest
man
,
and
one
I
have
much
obligation
to
.
 
<EOS>
It
rained
a
little
this
afternoon
,
and
grew
fair
again
.
 
<EOS>
Lady
Oglethorpe
sent
to
speak
to
me
,
and
it
was
to
let
me
know
that
Lady
Rochester
desires
she
and
I
may
be
better
acquainted
.
 
<EOS>
'
Tis
a
little
too
late
;
for
I
am
not
now
in
love
with
Lady
Rochester
:
 
<EOS>
they
shame
me
out
of
her
,
because
she
is
old
.
 
<EOS>
Arbuthnot
says
he
hopes
my
strained
thumb
is
not
the
gout
;
for
he
has
often
found
people
so
mistaken
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
not
remember
the
particular
thing
that
gave
it
me
,
only
I
had
it
just
after
beating
Patrick
,
and
now
it
is
better
;
so
I
believe
he
is
mistaken
.
  
<EOS>
5
.
 
<EOS>
The
Duchess
of
Shrewsbury
sent
to
invite
me
to
dinner
;
but
I
was
abroad
last
night
when
her
servant
came
,
and
this
morning
I
sent
my
excuses
,
because
I
was
engaged
,
which
I
was
sorry
for
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Forester
taxed
me
yesterday
about
the
History
of
the
Maids
of
Honour
;
but
I
told
her
fairly
it
was
no
jest
of
mine
;
for
I
found
they
did
not
relish
it
altogether
well
;
and
I
have
enough
already
of
a
quarrel
with
that
brute
Sir
John
Walter
,
who
has
been
railing
at
me
in
all
companies
ever
since
I
dined
with
him
;
that
I
abused
the
Queen
's
meat
and
drink
,
and
said
nothing
at
the
table
was
good
,
and
all
a
d####d
lie
;
for
after
dinner
,
commending
the
wine
,
I
said
I
thought
it
was
something
small
.
 
<EOS>
You
would
wonder
how
all
my
friends
laugh
at
this
quarrel
.
 
<EOS>
It
will
be
such
a
jest
for
the
Keeper
,
Treasurer
,
and
Secretary
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
honest
Colonel
Godfrey
,
took
a
good
walk
of
an
hour
on
the
terrace
,
and
then
came
up
to
study
;
but
it
grows
bloody
cold
,
and
I
have
no
waistcoat
here
.
  
<EOS>
6
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
dined
with
the
chaplains
till
to
-
day
;
but
my
friend
Gastrell
and
the
Dean
of
Rochester
had
often
invited
me
,
and
I
happened
to
be
disengaged
:
 
<EOS>
it
is
the
worst
provided
table
at
Court
.
 
<EOS>
We
ate
on
pewter
:
<EOS>
every
chaplain
,
when
he
is
made
a
dean
,
gives
a
piece
of
plate
,
and
so
they
have
got
a
little
,
some
of
it
very
old
.
 
<EOS>
One
who
was
made
Dean
of
Peterborough
(
a
small
deanery
)
said
he
would
give
no
plate
;
he
was
only
Dean
of
Pewterborough
.
 
<EOS>
The
news
of
Mr.
Hill
's
miscarriage
in
his
expedition
came
to
-
day
,
and
I
went
to
visit
Mrs.
Masham
and
Mrs.
Hill
,
his
two
sisters
,
to
condole
with
them
.
 
<EOS>
I
advised
them
by
all
means
to
go
to
the
music
-
meeting
to
-
night
,
to
show
they
were
not
cast
down
,
etc
.
,
and
they
thought
my
advice
was
right
,
and
went
.
 
<EOS>
I
doubt
Mr.
Hill
and
his
admiral
made
wrong
steps
;
however
,
we
lay
it
all
to
a
storm
,
etc
.
 
<EOS>
I
sat
with
the
Secretary
at
supper
;
then
we
both
went
to
Lord
Treasurer
's
supper
,
and
sat
till
twelve
.
 
<EOS>
The
Secretary
is
much
mortified
about
Hill
,
because
this
expedition
was
of
his
contriving
,
and
he
counted
much
upon
it
;
but
Lord
Treasurer
was
just
as
merry
as
usual
,
and
old
laughing
at
Sir
John
Walter
and
me
falling
out
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
nothing
grieved
me
but
that
they
would
take
example
,
and
perhaps
presume
upon
it
,
and
get
out
of
my
government
;
but
that
I
thought
I
was
not
obliged
to
govern
bears
,
though
I
governed
men
.
 
<EOS>
They
promise
to
be
as
obedient
as
ever
,
and
so
we
laughed
;
and
<EOS>
so
I
go
to
bed
;
for
it
is
colder
still
,
and
you
have
a
fire
now
,
and
are
at
cards
at
home
.
  
<EOS>
7
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Harley
and
I
dined
privately
to
-
day
with
Mrs.
Masham
and
Mrs.
Hill
,
and
my
brother
Masham
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
Lord
Halifax
at
Court
,
and
we
joined
and
talked
;
and
the
Duchess
of
Shrewsbury
came
up
and
reproached
me
for
not
dining
with
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
that
was
not
so
soon
done
,
for
I
expected
more
advances
from
ladies
,
<EOS>
especially
duchesses
:
 
<EOS>
she
promised
to
comply
with
any
demands
I
pleased
;
and
I
agreed
to
dine
with
her
to
-
morrow
,
if
I
did
not
go
to
London
too
soon
,
as
I
believe
I
shall
before
dinner
.
 
<EOS>
Lady
Oglethorpe
brought
me
and
the
Duchess
of
Hamilton
together
to
-
day
in
the
drawing
-
room
,
and
I
have
given
her
some
encouragement
,
but
not
much
.
 
<EOS>
Everybody
has
been
teasing
Walter
.
 
<EOS>
He
told
Lord
Treasurer
that
he
took
his
company
from
him
that
were
to
dine
with
him
:
 
<EOS>
my
lord
said
,
"
I
will
send
you
Dr.
Swift
:
"
 
Lord
Keeper
bid
him
take
care
what
he
did
;
"
for
,
"
said
he
,
"
Dr.
Swift
is
not
only
all
our
favourite
,
but
our
governor
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
old
company
supped
with
Lord
Treasurer
,
and
got
away
by
twelve
.
  
<EOS>
London
,
8
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
I
shall
go
no
more
to
Windsor
,
for
we
expect
the
Queen
will
come
in
ten
days
to
Hampton
Court
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
frost
last
night
,
and
cruel
cold
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
dine
with
the
Duchess
,
for
I
left
Windsor
half
an
hour
after
one
with
Lord
Treasurer
,
and
we
called
at
Kensington
,
where
Mrs.
Masham
was
got
to
see
her
children
for
two
days
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
,
or
rather
supped
,
with
Lord
Treasurer
,
and
stayed
till
after
ten
.
 
<EOS>
Tisdall
and
his
family
are
gone
from
hence
,
upon
some
wrangle
with
the
family
.
 
<EOS>
Yesterday
I
had
two
letters
brought
me
to
Mr.
Masham
's
;
one
from
Ford
,
and
t'other
from
our
little
MD
,
N.21
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
not
tell
you
till
to
-
day
,
because
I
would
not
.
 
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
answer
it
till
the
next
,
because
I
have
slipped
two
days
by
being
at
Windsor
,
which
I
must
recover
here
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
sirrahs
,
I
must
go
to
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
The
roads
were
as
dry
as
at
midsummer
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
This
letter
shall
go
to
-
morrow
.
  
<EOS>
9
.
 
<EOS>
Morning
.
 
<EOS>
It
rains
hard
this
morning
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
our
fair
weather
is
now
at
an
end
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
I
'll
put
on
my
waistcoat
to
-
day
:
 
<EOS>
shall
I
?
 
<EOS>
Well
,
I
will
then
,
to
please
MD
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
of
dining
at
home
to
-
day
upon
a
chop
and
a
pot
.
<EOS>
The
town
continues
yet
very
thin
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Strafford
is
gone
to
Holland
,
to
tell
them
what
we
have
done
here
toward
a
peace
.
 
<EOS>
We
shall
soon
hear
what
the
Dutch
say
,
and
how
they
take
it
.
 
<EOS>
My
humble
service
to
Mrs.
Walls
,
Mrs.
Stoyte
,
and
Catherine
.
 
<EOS>
Morrow
,
dearest
sirrahs
,
and
farewell
;
and
God
Almighty
bless
MD
,
poor
little
dear
MD
,
for
so
I
mean
,
and
Presto
too
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
write
to
you
again
to
-
night
,
<EOS>
that
is
,
I
'll
begin
my
next
letter
.
 
<EOS>
Farewell
,
etc
.
  
<EOS>
This
little
bit
belongs
to
MD
;
we
must
always
write
on
the
margin
:
 
you
are
saucy
rogues
.
   
<EOS>
LETTER
32
.
 
<EOS>
LONDON
,
Oct.
9
,
1711
.
  
<EOS>
I
was
forced
to
lie
down
at
twelve
to
-
day
,
and
mend
my
night
's
sleep
:
 
<EOS>
I
slept
till
after
two
,
and
then
sent
for
a
bit
of
mutton
and
pot
of
ale
from
the
next
cook
's
shop
,
and
had
no
stomach
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
out
at
four
,
and
called
to
see
Biddy
Floyd
,
which
I
had
not
done
these
three
months
:
 
<EOS>
she
is
something
marked
,
but
has
recovered
her
complexion
quite
,
and
looks
very
well
.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
sat
the
evening
with
Mrs.
Vanhomrigh
,
and
drank
coffee
,
and
ate
an
egg
.
 
<EOS>
I
likewise
took
a
new
lodging
to
-
day
,
not
liking
a
ground
-
floor
,
nor
the
ill
smell
,
and
other
circumstances
.
 
<EOS>
I
lodge
,
or
shall
lodge
,
by
Leicester
Fields
,
and
pay
ten
shillings
a
week
;
that
wo
n't
hold
out
long
,
faith
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
lie
here
<EOS>
but
one
night
more
.
 
<EOS>
It
rained
terribly
till
one
o'clock
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
lie
,
for
I
shall
lie
here
two
nights
,
till
Thursday
,
and
then
remove
.
 
<EOS>
Did
I
tell
you
that
my
friend
Mrs.
Barton
has
a
brother
drowned
,
that
went
on
the
expedition
with
Jack
Hill
?
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
lieutenant
-
colonel
,
and
a
coxcomb
;
and
she
keeps
her
chamber
in
form
,
and
the
servants
say
she
receives
no
messages
.
 
<EOS>
Answer
MD
's
letter
,
Presto
,
d'ye
hear
?
 
<EOS>
No
,
says
Presto
,
I
wo
n't
yet
,
I
'm
busy
;
you
're
a
saucy
rogue
.
 
<EOS>
Who
talks
?
  
<EOS>
10
.
 
<EOS>
It
cost
me
two
shillings
in
coach
-
hire
to
dine
in
the
City
with
a
printer
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
sent
,
and
caused
to
be
sent
,
three
pamphlets
out
in
a
fortnight
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
ply
the
rogues
warm
;
and
whenever
anything
of
theirs
makes
a
noise
,
it
shall
have
an
answer
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
instructed
an
under
spur
-
leather
to
write
so
,
that
it
is
taken
for
mine
.
 
<EOS>
A
rogue
that
writes
a
newspaper
,
called
The
Protestant
Postboy
,
has
reflected
on
me
in
one
of
his
papers
;
but
the
Secretary
has
taken
him
up
,
and
he
shall
have
a
squeeze
extraordinary
.
 
<EOS>
He
says
that
an
ambitious
tantivy
,
missing
of
his
towering
hopes
of
preferment
in
Ireland
,
is
come
over
to
vent
his
spleen
on
the
late
Ministry
,
etc
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
tantivy
him
with
a
vengeance
.
 
<EOS>
I
sat
the
evening
at
home
,
and
am
very
busy
,
and
can
hardly
find
time
to
write
,
unless
it
were
to
MD
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
in
furious
haste
.
  
<EOS>
11
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
with
Lord
Treasurer
.
 
<EOS>
Thursdays
are
now
his
days
when
his
choice
company
comes
,
but
we
are
too
much
multiplied
.
 
<EOS>
George
Granville
sent
his
excuses
upon
being
ill
;
I
hear
he
apprehends
the
apoplexy
,
which
would
grieve
me
much
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
calls
Prior
nothing
but
Monsieur
Baudrier
,
which
was
the
feigned
name
of
the
Frenchman
that
writ
his
Journey
to
Paris
.
<EOS>
They
pretend
to
suspect
me
,
so
I
talk
freely
of
it
,
and
put
them
out
of
their
play
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
calls
me
now
Dr.
Martin
,
because
martin
is
a
sort
of
a
swallow
,
and
so
is
a
swift
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
and
I
came
last
Monday
from
Windsor
,
we
were
reading
all
the
signs
on
the
road
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a
pure
trifler
;
tell
the
Bishop
of
Clogher
so
.
 
<EOS>
I
made
him
make
two
lines
in
verse
for
the
Bell
and
Dragon
,
and
they
were
rare
bad
ones
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
Dilly
is
with
you
by
this
time
:
 
what
could
his
reason
be
of
leaving
London
,
and
not
owning
it
?
 
<EOS>
'
Twas
plaguy
silly
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
his
natural
inconstancy
made
him
weary
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
he
is
the
king
of
inconstancy
.
 
<EOS>
I
stayed
with
Lord
Treasurer
till
ten
;
we
had
five
lords
and
three
commoners
.
 
<EOS>
Go
to
ombre
,
sirrahs
.
  
<EOS>
12
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Vanhomrigh
has
changed
her
lodging
as
well
as
I.
 
<EOS>
She
found
she
had
got
with
a
bawd
,
and
removed
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
her
to
-
day
;
for
though
she
boards
,
her
landlady
does
not
dine
with
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
grown
a
mighty
lover
of
herrings
;
but
they
are
much
smaller
here
than
with
you
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
afternoon
I
visited
an
old
major
-
general
,
and
ate
six
oysters
;
then
sat
an
hour
with
Mrs.
Colledge
,
the
joiner
's
daughter
that
was
hanged
;
it
was
the
joiner
was
hanged
,
and
not
his
daughter
;
with
Thompson
's
wife
,
a
magistrate
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
the
famous
Mrs.
Floyd
of
Chester
,
who
,
I
think
,
is
the
handsomest
woman
(
except
MD
)
that
ever
I
saw
.
 
<EOS>
She
told
me
that
twenty
people
had
sent
her
the
verses
upon
Biddy
,
as
meant
to
her
:
 
and
,
indeed
,
in
point
of
handsomeness
,
she
deserves
them
much
better
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
not
go
to
Windsor
to
-
morrow
,
and
so
I
told
the
Secretary
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
hate
the
thoughts
of
Saturday
and
Sunday
suppers
with
Lord
Treasurer
.
 
<EOS>
Jack
Hill
is
come
home
from
his
unfortunate
expedition
,
and
is
,
I
think
,
now
at
Windsor
:
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
yet
seen
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
privately
blamed
by
his
own
friends
for
want
of
conduct
.
 
<EOS>
He
called
a
council
of
war
,
and
therein
it
was
determined
to
come
back
.
 
<EOS>
But
they
say
a
general
should
not
do
that
,
because
the
officers
will
always
give
their
opinion
for
returning
,
since
the
blame
will
not
lie
upon
them
,
but
the
general
.
 
<EOS>
I
pity
him
heartily
.
<EOS>
Bernage
received
his
commission
to
-
day
.
  
<EOS>
13
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
with
Colonel
Crowe
,
late
Governor
of
Barbadoes
;
he
is
a
great
acquaintance
of
your
friend
Sterne
,
to
whom
I
trusted
the
box
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
has
refused
Sterne
's
business
,
and
I
doubt
he
is
a
rake
;
Jemmy
Leigh
stays
for
him
,
and
nobody
knows
where
to
find
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
so
busy
now
<EOS>
I
have
hardly
time
to
spare
to
write
to
our
little
MD
,
but
in
a
fortnight
I
hope
it
will
be
over
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
going
now
to
be
busy
,
etc
.
  
<EOS>
14
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
going
to
dine
with
Dr.
Cockburn
,
but
Sir
Andrew
Fountaine
met
me
,
and
carried
me
to
Mrs.
Van
's
,
where
I
drank
the
last
bottle
of
Raymond
's
wine
,
admirable
good
,
better
than
any
I
get
among
the
Ministry
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
pick
up
time
to
answer
this
letter
of
MD
's
;
I
'll
do
it
in
a
day
or
two
for
certain
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
glad
I
am
not
at
Windsor
,
for
it
is
very
cold
,
and
I
wo
n't
have
a
fire
till
November
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
contriving
how
to
stop
up
my
grate
with
bricks
.
 
<EOS>
Patrick
was
drunk
last
night
;
but
did
not
come
to
me
,
else
<EOS>
I
should
have
given
him
t'other
cuff
.
 
<EOS>
I
sat
this
evening
with
Mrs.
Barton
;
it
is
the
first
day
of
her
seeing
company
;
but
I
made
her
merry
enough
,
and
we
were
three
hours
disputing
upon
Whig
and
Tory
.
 
<EOS>
She
grieved
for
her
brother
only
for
form
,
and
he
was
a
sad
dog
.
 
<EOS>
Is
Stella
well
enough
to
go
to
church
,
pray
?
<EOS>
no
numbings
left
?
<EOS>
no
darkness
in
your
eyes
?
<EOS>
do
you
walk
and
exercise
?
 
<EOS>
Your
exercise
is
ombre
.
  
<EOS>
People
are
coming
up
to
town
:
 
<EOS>
the
Queen
will
be
at
Hampton
Court
in
a
week
.
<EOS>
Lady
Betty
Germaine
,
I
hear
,
is
come
;
and
Lord
Pembroke
is
coming
:
 
<EOS>
his
wife
is
as
big
with
child
as
she
can
tumble
.
  
<EOS>
15
.
 
<EOS>
I
sat
at
home
till
four
this
afternoon
to
-
day
writing
,
and
ate
a
roll
and
butter
;
then
visited
Will
Congreve
an
hour
or
two
,
and
supped
with
Lord
Treasurer
,
who
came
from
Windsor
to
-
day
,
and
brought
Prior
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
The
Queen
has
thanked
Prior
for
his
good
service
in
France
,
and
promised
to
make
him
a
Commissioner
of
the
Customs
.
 
<EOS>
Several
of
that
Commission
are
to
be
out
;
among
the
rest
,
my
friend
Sir
Matthew
Dudley
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
do
nothing
for
him
<EOS>
,
he
is
so
hated
by
the
Ministry
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
kept
me
till
twelve
,
so
I
need
not
tell
you
it
is
now
late
.
  
<EOS>
16
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
with
Mr.
Secretary
at
Dr.
Coatesworth
's
,
where
he
now
lodges
till
his
house
be
got
ready
in
Golden
Square
.
 
<EOS>
One
Boyer
,
a
French
dog
,
has
abused
me
in
a
pamphlet
,
and
I
have
got
him
up
in
a
messenger
's
hands
:
 
<EOS>
the
Secretary
promises
me
to
swinge
him
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
told
me
last
night
that
he
had
the
honour
to
be
abused
with
me
in
a
pamphlet
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
make
that
rogue
an
example
,
for
warning
to
others
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
to
see
Jack
Hill
this
morning
,
<EOS>
who
made
that
unfortunate
expedition
;
and
there
is
still
more
misfortune
;
for
that
ship
,
which
was
admiral
of
his
fleet
,
is
blown
up
in
the
Thames
,
by
an
accident
and
carelessness
of
some
rogue
,
who
was
going
,
as
they
think
,
to
steal
some
gunpowder
:
 
five
hundred
men
are
lost
.
 
<EOS>
We
do
n't
yet
know
the
particulars
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
got
home
by
seven
,
and
am
going
to
be
busy
,
and
you
are
going
to
play
and
supper
<EOS>
;
you
live
ten
times
happier
than
I
;
but
I
should
live
ten
times
happier
than
you
if
I
were
with
MD
.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
what
would
you
have
me
do
more
?
 
<EOS>
It
cost
me
a
shilling
coming
home
;
it
rains
terribly
,
and
did
so
in
the
morning
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
has
had
an
ill
day
,
in
much
pain
.
 
<EOS>
He
writes
and
does
business
in
his
chamber
<EOS>
now
he
is
ill
:
 
<EOS>
the
man
is
bewitched
:
 
he
desires
to
see
me
,
and
I
'll
maul
him
,
but
he
will
not
value
it
a
rush
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
half
weary
of
them
all
.
 
<EOS>
I
often
burst
out
into
these
thoughts
,
and
will
certainly
steal
away
as
soon
as
I
decently
can
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
many
friends
,
and
many
enemies
;
and
the
last
are
more
constant
in
their
nature
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
shuddering
at
all
to
think
of
retiring

old

,
if
you
can
be
easy
;
but
I

last

;
I
will
not

,
nor

more

a

few
.
  
<EOS>
23
.
 
<EOS>
Morning
.
 
<EOS>
This

to
-

,

.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
takes
physic

-

:
 
<EOS>
I
believe

shall

Dupplin
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.

the

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

a

's

,

false
spelt

:
 
it
is
in
such
sort

as
Harris
's

;
rallies

for

merry

,

not
upon

;
and
is
like

subject

's
last

,

.
 
<EOS>
Can

?
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
ill

;
pray

out
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
a
Latin
verse
at
the
end
of
<EOS>
it
all
rightly

;
yet
the
English
,
as
I

,
affectedly
wrong
in
many

.
 
<EOS>
My
plaguing
time
is
coming
.
 
<EOS>
A
young
fellow
brought

a

Judge
Coote
,

to

a
man
-

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

Tisdall
,
and

;

.
<EOS>
Saucy
Stella

for

'

;
but
now

.
 
<EOS>
Patrick
has

,
and
I

no

.
<EOS>
Farewell
,
etc
.
etc
.
  
<EOS>
Here

's

:
    
Plaguely
,
  
Plaguily
.
         
<EOS>
Dineing
,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Merrit
,

<EOS>
Aboundance

.
        
<EOS>
Secreet

Secret
.
<EOS>
Phamphlets
,
Pamphlets
.
        
Bussiness
,
Business
.
  
<EOS>
Tell

,

,
how

,

<EOS>
There

;
I

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

right
<EOS>
,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
LONDON
,
Oct.
23
,
1711
.
  
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Lord
Dupplin
as
I
told

I
would
,
and
put
my
thirty
-
second
into
the
post
-
office
my
own
self
;
and
I
believe
there
has
not
been
one
moment
since
we
parted
wherein
a
letter
was
not
upon
the
road
going
or
coming
to
or
from
PMD
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
Queen
knew
it
,
she
would
give
us
a
pension
;
for
it
is
we
bring
good
luck
to
their
post
-
boys
and
their
packets
;
else
they
would
break
their
necks
and
sink
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
an
old
saying
and
a
true
one
:
       
<EOS>
Be
it
snow
,
or
storm
,
or
hail
,
     
PMD
's
letters
never
fail
;
     
<EOS>
Cross
winds
may
sometimes
make
them
tarry
,
     
But
PMD
's
letters
ca
n't
miscarry
.
  
<EOS>
Terrible
rain
to
-
day
,
but
<EOS>
it
cleared
up
at
night
enough
to
save
my
twelvepence
coming
home
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
is
much
better
this
evening
.
 
<EOS>
I
hate
to
have
him
ill
,
he
is
so
confoundedly
careless
.
 
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
answer
your
letter
yet
,
so
be
satisfied
.
  
<EOS>
24
.
 
<EOS>
I
called
at
Lord
Treasurer
's
to
-
day
at
noon
:
 
<EOS>
he
was
eating
some
broth
in
his
bed
-

,
undressed
,
with
a
thousand
papers
about

.
 
<EOS>
He
has
a

upon
him
,
and
his
eye
terribly

;
yet
he
dressed
himself
and
went
out
to
the
Treasury
.
 
<EOS>
He
told
me
he
had
a
letter
from
a
lady
with
a
complaint
against
me
;
it
was
from
Mrs.
Cutts
,
a

Lord
Cutts
,
who
writ

that
I
had
abused
her

:
 
<EOS>
you
remember
the
"
Salamander
,
"
it
is
printed
in
the
Miscellany
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
my
lord
that
I
would
never
regard
complaints
,
and
that
I
expected
,
whenever
he
received
any
against
me
,
he
would
immediately
put
them
into
the
fire
,
and
forget
them
,
else
I
should
have
no
quiet
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
a
little
turn
in
my
head
this
morning
;
which
,
though
it
did
not
last
above
a
moment
,
yet
being
of
the
true
sort
,
has
made
me
as

all
this

.
 
<EOS>
'
Tis
<EOS>
the
first
I
have
had
this
half
-

.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
take
my
pills
if
I
hear

it
again
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
at
Lady
Mountjoy
's
with
Harry
Coote
,
and
went
to
see
Lord
Pembroke
upon
his
coming
to
town
.
 
<EOS>
The
Whig
party
are
furious
against
a
peace
,
and
every
day
some
ballad
comes
out
reflecting
on
the
Ministry
on
that
account
.
 
<EOS>
The
Secretary
St.
John
has
seized
on
a
dozen
booksellers
and
publishers
into

'

.
 
<EOS>
Some
of

foreign
Ministers
have
published

agreed

here
between
France
and
England
;
and
people
rail
at
them
as
insufficient
to
treat

peace
upon
;
but
the
secret
is
,
that
the
French
have
agreed
to
articles
much

,
which
our
Ministers
have
not
communicated
,
and
the
people
,

think

,

.
 
<EOS>
This

I
foretold
to
the

,
but

could

to

.
<EOS>
So
there
's
politics
for
you
.
  
<EOS>
25
.
 
<EOS>
The
Queen
is
at
Hampton
Court
:
 
<EOS>
she
went
on
Tuesday
in
that
terrible
rain
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Lewis
at

,
to

.
<EOS>
I
sent
this

Lord
Treasurer
,
and
he
is

;
I
am

.
 
<EOS>
He
has
sent

Dr.
Radcliffe
;
pray

.
 
<EOS>
The

;

:

<EOS>

<EOS>

;

.
 
<EOS>
I
sat
this

with
Mrs.
Barton
,
who
is

near

.
 
<EOS>
It
was

,

,

MD
was

.
<EOS>
This
paper
does

,

's

.
 
<EOS>
I
long
till

-

my
Lord

,

;

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
26
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Mrs.
Van
;
for
the
weather
is
so
bad
,
and
I
am
so
busy
,
that
I
ca
n't

:
 
and
besides
I
dare

but
little
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
is
very
ill
,

I

in

.
 
<EOS>
We
have
no

Whigs
,

;
but
I

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
writ

;

.
 
<EOS>
I
wo
n't

letter

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
27
.
 
<EOS>
I
forgot

go
about
some
business
this
morning
,
which
cost
me
double
the
time
;
and
<EOS>
I
was
forced
to
be
at
the
Secretary
's
office
till
four
,
and
lose
my
dinner
;
so
I
went
to
Mrs.
Van
's
,
and
made
them
get

herrings
,
which
I
am
very
fond
of
,
and
they
are
a
light
victuals
:
 
besides
<EOS>
,
I
was
to
have
supped
at
Lady
Ashburnham
's
;
but
the
drab
did
not
call

in
her

,
as
she
promised
,
but
sent
for
us
,
and
so
I
sent
my

.
 
<EOS>
It
has
been
a
terrible
rainy
day
,
but
so
flattering
in
the
morning
,
that
I
would
needs
go
out
in
my
new
hat
.
 
<EOS>
I
met
Leigh
and
Sterne
as

.
 
<EOS>
Leigh
says

will
go

,

to

;

MD
,

.
<EOS>
I
hate
that
Sterne
for
his

about

;
but

.
  
<EOS>
29
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
all
this
terrible
rainy
day
with
my
friend
Lewis
upon
business
of
importance
;
and
I
dined
with
him
,
and
came
home
about
seven
,
and
thought

would

a
little
,
after
the

I
had

.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
a
volume
of
Congreve
's
plays
in

,
that
Patrick
had
taken
to

;
and
I
looked

,
and
in

loitering
read
in

till
twelve
,
like
an
owl
and
a
fool
:
 
if
ever
<EOS>
I
do
so
again
;
never
saw
the
like
.
 
<EOS>
Count
Gallas
,
the
Emperor
's
Envoy
,
you
will
hear
,
is
in
disgrace
with
us
:
 
<EOS>
the
Queen
has
ordered
her
Ministers
to
have
no
more
commerce
with
him
;
the
reason
is
,
the
fool
writ
a
rude

to
Lord
Dartmouth
,
Secretary
of
State
,
complaining
of
our
proceedings
about
a
peace
;
and
he
is
always
in
close
confidence
with
Lord
Wharton
and

,

others

the
late

.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
you
begin
to
think
there
will
be
no
peace
;
the
Whigs
here
are
sure
it
can
not
be
,
and
stocks
are
fallen
again
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
confident
there
will
,
unless
France
plays
us
tricks
;
and
you
may
venture
a
wager
with
any
of
your
Whig
acquaintance
that
we
shall
not
have
another
campaign
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
get
more
by
it
than
by
ombre
,
sirrah
.
 
<EOS>
I
let
slip
telling
you
yesterday
's
journal
,
which
I
thought
to
have
done
this
morning
,
but
blundered
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
yesterday
at
Harry
Coote
's
,
with
Lord
Hatton
,
Mr.
Finch
,
a
son
of
Lord
Nottingham
,
and
Sir
Andrew
Fountaine
.
 
<EOS>
I
left
them
soon
,
but
hear
they
stayed
till
two
in
the
morning
,
and
were
all
drunk
:
 
and
so
good
-
night
for
last
night
,
and
good
-
night
for
to
-
night
.
 
<EOS>
You
blundering
goosecap
,
an't
<EOS>
you
ashamed
to
blunder
to
young
ladies
?
 
<EOS>
I
shall
have
a
fire
in
three
or
four
days
now
,
<EOS>
oh
ho
.
  
<EOS>
30
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
to
-
day
in
the
City
concerting
some
things
with
a
printer
,
and
am
to
be
to
-
morrow
all
day
busy
with
Mr.
Secretary
about
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
tell
you
now
;
but
the
Ministers
reckon
it
will
do
abundance
of
good
,
and
open
the
eyes
of
the
nation
,
who
are
half
bewitched
against
a
peace
.
 
<EOS>
Few
of
this
generation
can
remember
anything
but
war
and
taxes
,
and
they
think
it
is
as
it
should
be
;
whereas
'
<EOS>
tis
certain
we
are
the
most
undone
people
in
Europe
,
as
I
am
afraid
I
shall
make
<EOS>
appear
beyond
all
contradiction
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
forgot
;
I
wo
n't
tell
you
what
I
will
do
,
nor
what
I
will

31
.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

4
.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

Court
:
 
<EOS>
she
is
now
seldom
without
it
any
long
time
together
;
I
fear
it
will
wear
her
out
in
a
very
few
years
.
 
<EOS>
I
plainly
find
I
have
less
twitchings
about
my
toes
since
these
Ministers
are
sick
and
out
of
town
,
and
that
I
do
n't

with

.
 
<EOS>
I
would
compound
for
a
light
easy
gout
to
be
perfectly
well
in
my
head
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
walk
when
the
frost
comes
,
young
ladies
go
a
frost
-
biting
.
 
<EOS>
It
comes
into
my

,
that
,

you
first

to
Ireland
,
I
have
been
always

to

.
 
<EOS>
The

have

,

many

have

on

;
it
has
got
as

several

;
if

,

.
 
<EOS>
Lady

;

,

.
  
<EOS>
5
.
 
<EOS>
MD

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>

;

<EOS>
I

in

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
We

;

?
 
<EOS>
'

,

<EOS>

6
.
 
<EOS>

,

.

<EOS>
Why

<EOS>

<EOS>
Morning

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
He

'
tis

,
and

;

!
<EOS>
an
old

,
       
Few

,
     
<EOS>
Many

.
  
<EOS>
If

,

<EOS>
To
my
enemies
be
this
curse
,
     
A
dark
day
and
a
light
purse
.
  
<EOS>
And
so
I
'll
rise
,
and
go
to
my

,
for
Patrick
tells

I

a
fire
;
yet
it
is
not

-

,
nor

;
this

.
 
<EOS>
What

of
Dilly
?
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
you
have
him
with
you
.
 
<EOS>
Stella
is
just
now
showing
a
white
leg
,
and
putting
it
into
the
slipper
.
 
<EOS>
Present

to

,

I

the
Dean
,

desire

:
 
or
,
Dingley
,
ca
n't

?
 
<EOS>
This

's

,
no
,

I

.
 
<EOS>
Morrow
,

,

;

<EOS>
I

ca

<EOS>
Morrow

,

.
 
<EOS>
At
night
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with

in

,

;

am

,

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
Three

-

.
 
<EOS>
I
have

's
brother
to

,
to

Masham
.
  
<EOS>
13
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined

.
 
<EOS>
Last
Saturday
night
I
came

,

just

,
and
my
bed

was
all

,
and
I
was
forced

own

,
and
no
fire
:
 
<EOS>
I
was
sick
on

,
and
now
have

.
 
<EOS>
I
scolded
like
a
dog
at
Patrick
,
although

was
out
with

:
 
<EOS>
I
detest

;
ca

,
and

,

?
 
<EOS>
I

for

and

:
 
<EOS>
and
now
everybody
has

.
 
<EOS>
Here
's
a
clutter
:
 
<EOS>
I
'll
go
to
bed
and
sleep
if
I
can
.
  
<EOS>
14
.
 
<EOS>
Lady
Mountjoy

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

that

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs.

,

:
 
'
tis
<EOS>
well

;

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

,

:
 
<EOS>
he
is

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

to

Cook
,

<EOS>

thus
       
"
<EOS>

,
      
<EOS>
A

<EOS>

"

.

<EOS>
My

:

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
15
.
 
<EOS>
The

,

;
but

:
 
and
coming

to

night

,

<EOS>
A

!
<EOS>
he

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

hope

MD

.
 
<EOS>
I
'm

,
and
want
my

to
Laracor
;
they
did
me
more
good
than
all
the

.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-

in

,
but

as

.
 
<EOS>
Lady
Mountjoy
tells

Dilly
is
got
to

,
and
that

Archbishop
of
Dublin
was
the

so

.
 
<EOS>
The

was

two

ago
for
a

,
which
,
with
the
Queen
's

,
makes

.
 
<EOS>
They

the

.
 
<EOS>
London

;
but
I

no

,

.
 
<EOS>
This

shall
go
on
Saturday
;
and
then
I
am
even

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
lent

,
and
can

,

.
  
<EOS>
16
.
 
<EOS>
My
man
made

this
morning
,
and
let

visitor
,
when

see

;
so

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

;

.
 
<EOS>

.

<EOS>
LONDON
,

17
,
1711
.
  
<EOS>
I
put
my
last
this
evening
in
the
post
-
office
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Dr.
Cockburn
.
<EOS>
This
being
Queen
Elizabeth
's
birthday
,
we
have
the
D
#
#
#
#
and
all
to
do
among
us
.
 
<EOS>
I
just
heard
of
the
stir
as
my
letter
was
sealed
this
morning
,
and
was
so
cross
I
would
not
open
it
to
tell
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
visiting
Lady
Oglethorpe
and
Lady
Worsley
;
the
latter
is
lately
come
to
town
for
the
winter
,
and
with
child
,
and
what
care
you
?
 
<EOS>
This
is
Queen
Elizabeth
's
birthday
,
usually
kept
in
this
town
by
apprentices
,
etc
.
<EOS>
;
but
the
Whigs
designed
a
mighty
procession
by
midnight
,
and
had
laid
out
a
thousand
pounds
to
dress
up
the
Pope
,
Devil
,
cardinals
,
Sacheverell
,
etc
.
,
and
carry
them
with

about
,
and
burn
them
.
 
<EOS>
They
did
it
by
contribution
.
 
<EOS>
Garth
gave
five
guineas
;
Dr.
Garth
I
mean
,
if
ever
you
heard
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
they
were
seized
last
night
,
by
order
from
the
Secretary
:
 
<EOS>
you
will
have
an
account
of
it
,
for
they
bawl
it
about
the
streets
already
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
some
very
foolish
and
mischievous
designs
;
and
it
was
thought
they
would
have
put
the
rabble
upon
assaulting
my
Lord
Treasurer
's
house
and
the
Secretary
's
,
and
other
violences
.
<EOS>
The
militia
was
raised
to
prevent
it
,
and
now
,
I
suppose
,
all
will
be
quiet
.
<EOS>
The
figures
are
now
at
the
Secretary
's
office
at
Whitehall
.
 
<EOS>
I
design
to
see
them
if
I
can
.
  
<EOS>
18
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this
morning
with
Mr.
Secretary
,
who
just
came
from
Hampton
Court
.
<EOS>
He
was
telling
me
more
particulars
about
this
business
of
burning
the
Pope
.
<EOS>
It
cost
a
great
deal
of
money
,
and
had
it
gone
on
,
would
have
cost
three
times
as
much
;
but
the
town
is
full
of
it
,
and
half
a
dozen
Grub
Street
papers
already
.
 
<EOS>
The
Secretary
and
I
dined
at
Brigadier
Britton
's
,
but
I
left
them
at
six
,
upon
an

with
some

of
men

,
to

at
Sir
Andrew
Fountaine
's
.
 
<EOS>
We
were
not
very
merry
;
and
I
do
n't
love
rack
punch
<EOS>
,
I
love
it
better
with
brandy
;
are
you
of
my
opinion
?
 
<EOS>
Why
then
,
twelvepenny
weather
;
sirrahs
,
why
do
n't
you
play
at
shuttlecock
?
 
<EOS>
I
have
thought
of
it
a
hundred
times
;
faith
,
Presto
will
come
over
after
Christmas
,
and
will
play
with
Stella
before
the
cold
weather
is
gone
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
read
the
Spectators
?
 
<EOS>
I
never
do
;
they
never
come
in
my
way
;
I
go
to
no
coffee
-
houses
.
<EOS>
They
say
abundance
of
them
are
very
pretty
;
they
are
going
to
be
printed
in
small
volumes
;
I
'll
bring
them
over
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
be
out
of
my
hurry
in
a
week
,
and
if
Leigh
be
not
gone
over
,
I
will
send
you
by

what
I
am
now

.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know

Leigh
is
;
I
have
not
seen

this
good
<EOS>
while
,
though

promised

:
 
I
shall
send

.
 
<EOS>
The
Queen
comes
to
town
on
Thursday
for
good
and
all
.
  
<EOS>
19
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this
morning
at
Lord
Dartmouth
's
office
,
and
sent

for
him
from
the
Committee
of
Council
,
about

.
 
<EOS>
I
was

more
concerning
this

the
figures
in

-

of
the
Pope
,
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
not

,

.
 
<EOS>

Treasurer
made
one
or
two
small
additions
:
 
they
must
work
day

night
to
have
it
out
on
Saturday
;
they
sold
a
thousand
in
two
days
.
 
<EOS>
Our
Society
met
to
-
day
;
nine

us
were
present
:
 
<EOS>
we
dined
at
our
brother

's
.
 
<EOS>
We

,

Orrery
,

,

Masham

.
 
<EOS>
W

.

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
30
.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

:
the

,

;

<EOS>
Pray

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

.

.
 
<EOS>

:

;
