<EOS>
LETTER
36
.
 
<EOS>
LONDON
,
Dec.
1
,
1711
.
  
<EOS>
My
last
was
put
in
this
evening
.
 
<EOS>
I
intended
to
dine
with
Mr.
Masham
to
-
day
,
and
called
at
White
's
chocolate
house
to
see
if
he
was
there
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Wharton
saw
me
at
the
door
,
and
I
saw
him
,
but
took
no
notice
,
and
was
going
away
,
but
he
came
through
the
crowd
,
called
after
me
,
and
asked
me
how
I
did
,
etc
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
pretty
;
and
I
believe
he
wished
every
word
he
spoke
was
a
halter
to
hang
me
.
 
<EOS>
Masham
did
not
dine
at
home
,
so
I
ate
with
a
friend
in
the
neighbourhood
.
<EOS>
The
printer
has
not
sent
me
the
second
edition
;
I
know
not
the
reason
,
for
it
certainly
came
out
to
-
day
;
perhaps
they
are
glutted
with
it
already
.
 
<EOS>
I
found
a
letter
from
Lord
Harley
on
my
table
,
to
tell
me
that
his
father
desires
I
would
make
two
small
alterations
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
going
to
be
busy
,
etc
.
  
<EOS>
2
.
 
Morning
.
 
<EOS>
See
the
blunder
;
I
was
making
it
the
37th
day
of
the
month
,
from
the
number
above
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
but
I
am
staying
here
for
old
Frowde
,
who
appointed
to
call
this
morning
:
 
<EOS>
I
am
ready
dressed
to
go
to
church
:
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
he
dare
not
stir
out
but
on
Sundays
.
 
<EOS>
The
printer
called
early
this
morning
,
told
me
the
second
edition
went
off
yesterday
in
five
hours
,
and
he
must
have
a
third
ready
to
-
morrow
,
for
they
might
have
sold
half
another
:
 
his
men
are
all
at
work
with
it
,
though
it
be
Sunday
.
 
<EOS>
This
old
fool
will
not
come
,
and
I
shall
miss
church
.
 
<EOS>
Morrow
,
sirrahs
.
 
<EOS>
At
night
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
at
Court
to
-
day
:
 
<EOS>
the
Queen
is
well
,
and
walked
through
part
of
the
rooms
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
the
Secretary
,
and
despatched
some
business
.
 
<EOS>
He
tells
me
the
Dutch
Envoy
designs
to
complain
of
that
pamphlet
.
 
<EOS>
The
noise
it
makes
is
extraordinary
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
fit
it
should
answer
the
pains
I
have
been
at
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
it
will
be
printed
in
Ireland
.
 
<EOS>
Some
lay
it
to
Prior
,
others
to
Mr.
Secretary
St.
John
,
but
I
am
always
the
first
they
lay
everything
to
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
go
sleep
,
etc
.
  
<EOS>
3
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
ordered
Patrick
not
to
let
any
odd
fellow
come
up
to
me
;
and
a
fellow
would
needs
speak
with
me
from
Sir
George
Pretyman
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
never
heard
of
him
,
and
would
not
see
the
messenger
:
 
but
at
last
it
proved
that
this
Sir
George
has
sold
his
estate
,
and
is
a
beggar
.
 
<EOS>
Smithers
,
the
Farnham
carrier
,
brought
me
this
morning
a
letter
from
your
mother
,
with
three
papers
enclosed
of
Lady
Giffard
's
writing
;
one
owning
some
exchequer
business
of
100
pounds
to
be
Stella
's
;
another
for
100
pounds
that
she
has
of
yours
,
which
I
made
over
to
you
for
Mariston
;
and
a
third
for
300
pounds
;
the
last
is
on
stamped
paper
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
they
had
better
lie
in
England
in
some
good
hand
till
Lady
Giffard
dies
;
and
I
will
think
of
some
such
hand
before
I
come
over
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
asking
Smithers
about
all
the
people
of
Farnham
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
White
has
left
off
dressing
,
is
troubled
with
lameness
and
swelled
legs
,
and
seldom
stirs
out
;
but
her
old
hang
-
dog
husband
as
hearty
as
ever
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this
morning
with
Lord
Treasurer
,
about
something
he
would
have
altered
in
the
pamphlet
;
but
it
ca
n't
be
till
the
fourth
edition
,
which
I
believe
will
be
soon
;
for
I
dined
with
the
printer
,
and
he
tells
me
they
have
sold
off
half
the
third
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Perceval
and
her
daughter
have
been
in
town
these
three
weeks
,
which
I
never
heard
till
to
-
day
;
and
Mrs.
Wesley
is
come
to
town
too
,
to
consult
Dr.
Radcliffe
.
 
<EOS>
The
Whigs
are
resolved
to
bring
that
pamphlet
into
the
House
of
Lords
to
have
it
condemned
,
so
I
hear
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
printer
will
stand
to
it
,
and
not
own
the
author
;
he
must
say
he
had
it
from
the
penny
-
post
.
 
<EOS>
Some
people
talk
as
if
the
House
of
Lords
would
do
some
peevish
thing
,
for
the
Whigs
are
now
a
great
majority
in
it
;
our
Ministers
are
too
negligent
of
such
things
:
 
<EOS>
I
have
never
slipped
giving
them
warning
;
some
of
them
are
sensible
of
it
;
but
Lord
Treasurer
stands
too
much
upon
his
own
legs
.
 
<EOS>
I
fancy
his
good
fortune
will
bear
him
out
in
everything
;
but
in
reason
I
should
think
this
Ministry
to
stand
very
unsteady
;
if
they
can
carry
a
peace
,
they
may
hold
;
I
believe
not
else
.
  
<EOS>
4
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Secretary
sent
to
me
to
-
day
to
dine
with
him
alone
;
but
we
had
two
more
with
us
,
which
hindered
me
doing
some
business
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this
morning
with
young
Harcourt
,
secretary
to
our
Society
,
to
take
a
room
for
our
weekly
meetings
;
and
the
fellow
asked
us
five
guineas
a
week
only
to
have
leave
to
dine
once
a
week
;
was
not
that
pretty
?
<EOS>
so
we
broke
off
with
him
,
and
are
to
dine
next
Thursday
at
Harcourt
's
(
he
is
Lord
Keeper
's
son
)
.
 
<EOS>
They
have
sold
off
above
half
the
third
edition
,
and
answers
are
coming
out
:
 
<EOS>
the
Dutch
Envoy
refused
dining
with
Dr.
Davenant
,
because
he
was
suspected
to
write
it
:
 
<EOS>
I
have
made
some
alterations
in
every
edition
,
and
it
has
cost
me
more
trouble
,
for
the
time
,
since
the
printing
,
than
before
.
 
<EOS>
'
Tis
sent
over
to
Ireland
,
and
I
suppose
you
will
have
it
reprinted
.
  
<EOS>
5
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
now
printing
the
fourth
edition
,
which
is
reckoned
very
extraordinary
,
considering
'
tis
a
dear
twelvepenny
book
,
and
not
bought
up
in
numbers
by
the
party
to
give
away
,
as
the
Whigs
do
,
but
purely
upon
its
own
strength
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
got
an
under
spur
-
leather
to
write
an
Examiner
again
,
and
the
Secretary
and
I
will
now
and
then
send
hints
;
but
we
would
have
it
a
little
upon
the
Grub
Street
,
to
be
a
match
for
their
writers
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Lord
Treasurer
to
-
day
at
five
:
 
<EOS>
he
dined
by
himself
after
his
family
,
and
drinks
no
claret
yet
,
for
fear
of
his
rheumatism
,
of
which
he
is
almost
well
.
<EOS>
He
was
very
pleasant
,
as
he
is
always
:
 
yet
I
fancied
he
was
a
little
touched
with
the
present
posture
of
affairs
.
 
<EOS>
The
Elector
of
Hanover
's
Minister
here
has
given
in
a
violent
memorial
against
the
peace
,
and
caused
it
to
be
printed
.
 
<EOS>
The
Whig
lords
are
doing
their
utmost
for
a
majority
against
Friday
,
and
design
,
if
they
can
,
to
address
the
Queen
against
the
peace
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Nottingham
,
a
famous
Tory
and
speech
-
maker
,
is
gone
over
to
the
Whig
side
:
they
toast
him
daily
,
and
Lord
Wharton
says
,
It
is
Dismal
<EOS>
(
so
they
call
him
from
his
looks
)
will
save
England
at
last
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
was
hinting
as
if
he
wished
a
ballad
was
made
on
him
,
and
I
will
get
up
one
against
to-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
He
gave
me
a
scurrilous
printed
paper
of
bad
verses
on
himself
,
under
the
name
of
the
English
Catiline
,
and
made
me
read
them
to
the
company
.
<EOS>
It
was
his
birthday
,
which
he
would
not
tell
us
,
but
Lord
Harley
whispered
it
to
me
.
  
<EOS>
6
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this
morning
making
the
ballad
<EOS>
,
two
degrees
above
Grub
Street
:
 
at
noon
I
paid
a
visit
to
Mrs.
Masham
,
and
then
went
to
dine
with
our
Society
.
<EOS>
Poor
Lord
Keeper
dined
below
stairs
,
I
suppose
,
on
a
bit
of
mutton
.
 
<EOS>
We
chose
two
members
:
 
<EOS>
we
were
eleven
met
,
the
greatest
meeting
we
ever
had
:
 
<EOS>
I
am
next
week
to
introduce
Lord
Orrery
.
 
<EOS>
The
printer
came
before
we
parted
,
and
brought
the
ballad
,
which
made
them
laugh
very
heartily
a
dozen
times
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
going
to
print
the
pamphlet
in
small
,
a
fifth
edition
,
to
be
taken
off
by
friends
,
and
sent
into
the
country
.
 
<EOS>
A
sixpenny
answer
is
come
out
,
good
for
nothing
,
but
guessing
me
,
among
others
,
for
the
author
.
 
<EOS>
To
-
morrow
is
the
fatal
day
for
the
Parliament
meeting
,
and
we
are
full
of
hopes
and
fears
.
 
<EOS>
We
reckon
we
have
a
majority
of
ten
on
our
side
in
the
House
of
Lords
;
yet
I
observed
Mrs.
Masham
<EOS>
a
little
uneasy
:
 
<EOS>
she
assures
me
<EOS>
the
Queen
is
stout
.
 
<EOS>
The
Duke
of
Marlborough
has
not
seen
the
Queen
for
some
days
past
;
Mrs.
Masham
is
glad
of
it
,
because
she
says
he
tells
a
hundred
lies
to
his
friends
of
what
she
says
to
him
:
 
he
is
one
day
humble
,
and
the
next
day
on
the
high
ropes
.
 
<EOS>
The
Duke
of
Ormond
,
they
say
,
will
be
in
town
to
-
night
by
twelve
.
  
<EOS>
7
.
 
<EOS>
This
being
the
day
the
Parliament
was
to
meet
,
and
the
great
question
to
be
determined
,
I
went
with
Dr.
Freind
to
dine
in
the
City
,
on
purpose
to
be
out
of
the
way
,
and
we
sent
our
printer
to
see
what
was
our
fate
;
but
he
gave
us
a
most
melancholy
account
of
things
.
 
<EOS>
The
Earl
of
Nottingham
began
,
and
spoke
against
a
peace
,
and
desired
that
in
their
address
they
might
put
in
a
clause
to
advise
the
Queen
not
to
make
a
peace
without
Spain
;
which
was
debated
,
and
carried
by
the
Whigs
by
about
six
voices
:
 
and
this
has
happened
entirely
by
my
Lord
Treasurer
's
neglect
,
who
did
not
take
timely
care
to
make
up
all
his
strength
,
although
every
one
of
us
gave
him
caution
enough
.
<EOS>
Nottingham
has
certainly
been
bribed
.
 
<EOS>
The
question
is
yet
only
carried
in
the
Committee
of
the
whole
House
,
and
we
hope
when
it
is
reported
to
the
House
to
-
morrow
,
we
shall
have
a
majority
,
by
some
Scotch
lords
coming
to
town
.
<EOS>
However
,
it
is
a
mighty
blow
and
loss
of
reputation
to
Lord
Treasurer
,
and
may
end
in
his
ruin
.
 
<EOS>
I
hear
the
thing
only
as
the
printer
brought
it
,
who
was
at
the
debate
;
but
how
the
Ministry
take
it
,
or
what
their
hopes
and
fears
are
,
<EOS>
I
can
not
tell
until
I
see
them
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
be
early
with
the
Secretary
to
-
morrow
,
and
then
I
will
tell
you
more
,
and
shall
write
a
full
account
to
the
Bishop
of
Clogher
to
-
morrow
,
and
to
the
Archbishop
of
Dublin
,
if
I
have
time
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
horribly
down
at
present
.
 
<EOS>
I
long
to
know
how
Lord
Treasurer
bears
this
,
and
what
remedy
he
has
.
 
<EOS>
The
Duke
of
Ormond
came
this
day
to
town
,
and
was
there
.
  
<EOS>
8
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
early
this
morning
with
the
Secretary
,
and
talked
over
this
matter
.
<EOS>
He
hoped
that
when
it
was
reported
this
day
in
the
House
of
Lords
,
they
would
disagree
with
their
Committee
,
and
so
the
matter
would
go
off
,
only
with
a
little
loss
of
reputation
to
the
Lord
Treasurer
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Mr.
Cockburn
,
and
after
,
a
Scotch
member
came
in
,
and
told
us
that
the
clause
was
carried
against
the
Court
in
the
House
of
Lords
almost
two
to
one
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
immediately
to
Mrs.
Masham
,
and
meeting
Dr.
Arbuthnot
(
the
Queen
's
favourite
physician
)
,
we
went
together
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
just
come
from
waiting
at
the
Queen
's
dinner
,
and
going
to
her
own
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
heard
nothing
of
the
thing
being
gone
against
us
.
<EOS>
It
seems
Lord
Treasurer
had
been
so
negligent
that
he
was
with
the
Queen
while
the
question
was
put
in
the
House
:
 
I
immediately
told
Mrs.
Masham
that
either
she
and
Lord
Treasurer
had
joined
with
the
Queen
to
betray
us
,
or
that
they
two
were
betrayed
by
the
Queen
:
 
<EOS>
she
protested
solemnly
it
was
not
the
former
,
and
I
believed
her
;
but
she
gave
me
some
lights
to
suspect
the
Queen
is
changed
.
 
<EOS>
For
yesterday
,
when
the
Queen
was
going
from
the
House
,
where
she
sat
to
hear
the
debate
,
the
Duke
of
Shrewsbury
,
Lord
Chamberlain
,
asked
her
whether
he
or
the
Great
Chamberlain
Lindsey
ought
to
lead
her
out
;
she
answered
short
,
"
Neither
of
you
,
"
and
gave
her
hand
to
the
Duke
of
Somerset
,
who
was
louder
than
any
in
the
House
for
the
clause
against
peace
.
 
<EOS>
She
gave
me
one
or
two
more
instances
of
this
sort
,
which
convince
me
that
the
Queen
is
false
,
or
at
least
very
much
wavering
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Masham
begged
us
to
stay
,
because
Lord
Treasurer
would
call
,
and
we
were
resolved
to
fall
on
him
about
his
negligence
in
securing
a
majority
.
 
<EOS>
He
came
,
and
appeared
in
good
humour
as
usual
,
but
I
thought
his
countenance
was
much
cast
down
.
 
<EOS>
I
rallied
him
,
and
desired
him
to
give
me
his
staff
,
which
he
did
:
 
<EOS>
I
told
him
,
if
he
would
secure
it
me
a
week
,
I
would
set
all
right
:
 
<EOS>
he
asked
how
;
I
said
I
would
immediately
turn
Lord
Marlborough
,
his
two
daughters
,
the
Duke
and
Duchess
of
Somerset
,
and
Lord
Cholmondeley
,
out
of
all
their
employments
;
and
I
believe
he
had
not
a
friend
but
was
of
my
opinion
.
 
<EOS>
Arbuthnot
asked
how
he
came
not
to
secure
a
majority
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
answer
nothing
but
<EOS>
that
he
could
not
help
it
,
if
people
would
lie
and
forswear
.
 
<EOS>
A
poor
answer
for
a
great
Minister
.
 
<EOS>
There
fell
from
him
a
Scripture
expression
,
that
"
the
hearts
of
kings
are
unsearchable
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
I
told
him
it
was
what
I
feared
,
and
was
from
him
the
worst
news
he
could
tell
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
begged
him
to
know
what
he
had
to
trust
to
:
 
<EOS>
he
stuck
a
little
;
but
at
last
bid
me
not
fear
,
for
all
would
be
well
yet
.
 
<EOS>
We
would
fain
have
had
him
eat
a
bit
where
he
was
,
but
he
would
go
home
,
it
was
past
six
:
 
<EOS>
he
made
me
go
home
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
There
we
found
his
brother
and
Mr.
Secretary
.
 
<EOS>
He
made
his
son
take
a
list
of
all
in
the
House
of
Commons
who
had
places
,
and
yet
voted
against
the
Court
,
in
such
a
manner
as
if
they
should
lose
their
places
:
 
<EOS>
I
doubt
he
is
not
able
to
compass
it
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Keeper
came
in
an
hour
,
and
they
were
going
upon
business
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
left
him
,
and
returned
to
Mrs.
Masham
;
but
she
had
company
with
her
,
and
I
would
not
stay
.
  
<EOS>
This
is
a
long
journal
,
and
of
a
day
that
may
produce
great
alterations
,
and
hazard
the
ruin
of
England
.
 
<EOS>
The
Whigs
are
all
in
triumph
;
they
foretold
how
all
this
would
be
,
but
we
thought
it
boasting
.
 
<EOS>
Nay
,
they
said
the
Parliament
should
be
dissolved
before
Christmas
,
and
perhaps
it
may
:
 
<EOS>
this
is
all
your
d-
  
d
 
<EOS>
Duchess
of
Somerset
's
doings
.
 
<EOS>
I
warned
them
of
it
nine
months
ago
,
and
a
hundred
times
since
:
 
the
Secretary
always
dreaded
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
Lord
Treasurer
I
should
have
the
advantage
of
him
;
for
he
would
lose
his
head
,
and
I
should
only
be
hanged
,
and
so
carry
my
body
entire
to
the
grave
.
  
<EOS>
9
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this
morning
with
Mr.
Secretary
:
 
<EOS>
we
are
both
of
opinion
that
the
Queen
is
false
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
him
what
I
heard
,
and
he
confirmed
it
by
other
circumstances
.
 
<EOS>
I
then
went
to
my
friend
Lewis
,
who
had
sent
to
see
me
.
 
<EOS>
He
talks
of
nothing
but
retiring
to
his
estate
in
Wales
.
 
<EOS>
He
gave
me
reasons
to
believe
the
whole
matter
is
settled
between
the
Queen
and
the
Whigs
;
he
hears
that
Lord
Somers
is
to
be
Treasurer
,
and
believes
that
,
sooner
than
turn
out
the
Duchess
of
Somerset
,
she
will
dissolve
the
Parliament
,
and
get
a
Whiggish
one
,
which
may
be
done
by
managing
elections
.
 
<EOS>
Things
are
now
in
the
crisis
,
and
a
day
or
two
will
determine
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
desired
him
to
engage
Lord
Treasurer
that
as
soon
as
he
finds
the
change
is
resolved
on
,
he
will
send
me
abroad
as
Queen
's
Secretary
somewhere
or
other
,
where
I
may
remain
till
the
new
Ministers
recall
me
;
and
then
I
will
be
sick
for
five
or
six
months
,
till
the
storm
has
spent
itself
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
he
will
grant
me
this
;
for
I
should
hardly
trust
myself
to
the
mercy
of
my
enemies
while
their
anger
is
fresh
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
with
the
Secretary
,
who
affects
mirth
,
and
seems
to
hope
all
will
yet
be
well
.
 
<EOS>
I
took
him
aside
after
dinner
,
told
him
how
I
had
served
them
,
and
had
asked
no
reward
,
but
thought
I
might
ask
security
;
and
then
desired
the
same
thing
of
him
,
to
send
me
abroad
before
a
change
.
 
<EOS>
He
embraced
me
,
and
swore
he
would
take
the
same
care
of
me
as
himself
,
etc
.
,
but
bid
me
have
courage
,
for
that
in
two
days
my
Lord
Treasurer
's
wisdom
would
appear
greater
than
ever
;
that
he
suffered
all
that
had
happened
on
purpose
,
and
had
taken
measures
to
turn
it
to
advantage
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
,
"
God
send
it
"
;
<EOS>
but
I
do
not
believe
a
syllable
;
and
,
as
far
as
I
can
judge
,
the
game
is
lost
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
know
more
soon
,
and
my
letters
will
at
least
be
a
good
history
to
show
you
the
steps
of
this
change
.
  
<EOS>
10
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this
morning
with
Lewis
,
who
thinks
they
will
let
the
Parliament
sit
till
they
have
given
the
money
,
and
then
dissolve
them
in
spring
,
and
break
the
Ministry
.
 
<EOS>
He
spoke
to
Lord
Treasurer
about
what
I
desired
him
.
 
<EOS>
My
lord
desired
him
with
great
earnestness
to
assure
me
that
all
would
be
well
,
and
that
I
should
fear
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
in
the
City
with
a
friend
.
 
<EOS>
This
day
the
Commons
went
to
the
Queen
with
their
address
,
and
all
the
Lords
who
were
for
the
peace
went
with
them
,
to
show
their
zeal
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
now
some
further
conviction
that
the
Queen
is
false
,
and
it
begins
to
be
known
.
  
<EOS>
11
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
between
two
and
three
to
see
Mrs.
Masham
;
while
I
was
there
she
went
to
her
bed
-
chamber
to
try
a
petticoat
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
came
in
to
see
her
,
and
seeing
me
in
the
outer
room
,
fell
a
rallying
me
:
 
<EOS>
says
he
,
"
You
had
better
keep
company
with
me
,
than
with
such
a
fellow
as
Lewis
,
who
has
not
the
soul
of
a
chicken
,
nor
the
heart
of
a
mite
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Then
he
went
in
to
Mrs.
Masham
,
and
as
he
came
back
desired
her
leave
to
let
me
go
home
with
him
to
dinner
.
<EOS>
He
asked
whether
I
was
not
afraid
to
be
seen
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
I
never
valued
my
Lord
Treasurer
in
my
life
,
and
therefore
should
have
always
the
same
esteem
for
Mr.
Harley
and
Lord
Oxford
.
 
<EOS>
He
seemed
to
talk
confidently
,
as
if
he
reckoned
that
all
this
would
turn
to
advantage
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
forbear
hinting
that
he
was
not
sure
of
the
Queen
,
and
that
those
scoundrel
,
starving
lords
would
never
have
dared
to
vote
against
the
Court
,
if
Somerset
had
not
assured
them
that
it
would
please
the
Queen
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
that
was
true
,
and
Somerset
did
so
.
 
<EOS>
I
stayed
till
six
;
then
De
Buys
,
the
Dutch
Envoy
,
came
to
him
,
and
I
left
him
.
 
<EOS>
Prior
was
with
us
a
while
after
dinner
.
 
<EOS>
I
see
him
and
all
of
them
cast
down
,
though
they
make
the
best
of
it
.
  
<EOS>
12
.
 
<EOS>
Ford
is
come
to
town
;
I
saw
him
last
night
:
 
<EOS>
he
is
in
no
fear
,
but
sanguine
,
although
I
have
told
him
the
state
of
things
.
 
<EOS>
This
change
so
resembles
the
last
,
that
I
wonder
they
do
not
observe
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
Secretary
sent
for
me
yesterday
to
dine
with
him
,
but
I
was
abroad
;
I
hope
he
had
something
to
say
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
morning
,
and
I
write
in
bed
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
going
to
the
Duke
of
Ormond
,
whom
I
have
not
yet
seen
.
 
<EOS>
Morrow
,
sirrahs
.
 
<EOS>
At
night
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
to
see
the
Duke
of
Ormond
this
morning
:
 
<EOS>
he
asked
me
two
or
three
questions
after
his
civil
way
,
and
they
related
to
Ireland
:
 
<EOS>
at
last
I
told
him
that
,
from
the
time
I
had
seen
him
,
I
never
once
thought
of
Irish
affairs
.
 
<EOS>
He
whispered
me
that
he
hoped
I
had
done
some
good
things
here
:
 
<EOS>
I
said
,
if
everybody
else
had
done
half
as
much
,
we
should
not
be
as
we
are
<EOS>
:
 
<EOS>
then
we
went
aside
,
and
talked
over
affairs
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
him
how
all
things
stood
,
and
advised
him
what
was
to
be
done
.
 
<EOS>
I
then
went
and
sat
an
hour
with
the
Duchess
;
then
as
long
with
Lady
Oglethorpe
,
who
is
so
cunning
a
devil
that
I
believe
she
could
yet
find
a
remedy
,
if
they
would
take
her
advice
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
a
friend
at
Court
.
  
<EOS>
13
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this
morning
with
the
Secretary
:
 
<EOS>
he
will
needs
pretend
to
talk
as
if
things
would
be
well
:
 
<EOS>
"
Will
you
believe
it
,
"
said
he
,
"
if
you
see
these
people
turned
out
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
I
said
,
yes
,
if
I
saw
the
Duke
and
Duchess
of
Somerset
out
:
 
<EOS>
he
swore
if
they
were
not
,
he
would
give
up
his
place
.
 
<EOS>
Our
Society
dined
to
-
day
at
Sir
William
Wyndham
's
;
we
were
thirteen
present
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Orrery
and
two
other
members
were
introduced
:
 
<EOS>
I
left
them
at
seven
.
 
<EOS>
I
forgot
to
tell
you
that
the
printer
told
me
yesterday
that
Morphew
,
the
publisher
,
was
sent
for
by
that
Lord
Chief
-
Justice
,
who
was
a
manager
against
Sacheverell
;
he
showed
him
two
or
three
papers
and
pamphlets
;
among
the
rest
mine
of
the
Conduct
of
the
Allies
,
threatened
him
,
asked
who
was
the
author
,
and
has
bound
him
over
to
appear
next
term
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
not
have
the
impudence
to
do
this
,
if
he
did
not
foresee
what
was
coming
at
Court
.
  
<EOS>
14
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Shelburne
was
with
me
this
morning
,
to
be
informed
of
the
state
of
affairs
,
and
desired
I
would
answer
all
his
objections
against
a
peace
,
which
was
soon
done
,
for
he
would
not
give
me
room
to
put
in
a
word
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a
man
of
good
sense
enough
;
but
argues
so
violently
,
that
he
will
some
day
or
other
put
himself
into
a
consumption
.
 
<EOS>
He
desires
that
he
may
not
be
denied
when
he
comes
to
see
me
,
which
I
promised
,
but
will
not
perform
.
 
<EOS>
Leigh
and
Sterne
set
out
for
Ireland
on
Monday
se'nnight
:
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
they
will
be
with
you
long
before
this
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
to
-
night
drinking
very
good
wine
in
scurvy
company
,
at
least
some
of
them
;
I
was
drawn
in
,
but
will
be
more
cautious
for
the
future
;
'
tis
late
,
etc
.
  
<EOS>
15
.
 
<EOS>
Morning
.
 
<EOS>
They
say
the
Occasional
Bill
is
brought
to
-
day
into
the
House
of
Lords
;
but
I
know
not
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
now
put
an
end
to
my
letter
,
and
give
it
into
the
post
-
house
myself
.
 
<EOS>
This
will
be
a
memorable
letter
,
and
I
shall
sigh
to
see
it
some
years
hence
.
 
<EOS>
Here
are
the
first
steps
toward
the
ruin
of
an
excellent
Ministry
;
for
I
look
upon
them
as
certainly
ruined
;
and
God
knows
what
may
be
the
consequences
.
 
<EOS>
I
now
bid
my
dearest
MD
farewell
;
for
company
is
coming
,
and
I
must
be
at
Lord
Dartmouth
's
office
by
noon
.
 
<EOS>
Farewell
,
dearest
MD
<EOS>
;
I
wish
you
a
merry
Christmas
;
I
believe
you
will
have
this
about
that
time
.
 
<EOS>
Love
Presto
,
who
loves
MD
above
all
things
a
thousand
times
.
<EOS>
Farewell
again
,
dearest
MD
,
etc
.
   
<EOS>
LETTER
37
.
 
<EOS>
LONDON
,
Dec.
15
,
1711
.
  
<EOS>
I
put
in
my
letter
this
evening
myself
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
to
-
day
inquiring
at
the
Secretary
's
office
of
Mr.
Lewis
how
things
went
:
 
<EOS>
I
there
met
Prior
,
<EOS>
who
told
me
he
gave
all
for
gone
,
etc
.
,
and
was
of
opinion
<EOS>
the
whole
Ministry
would
give
up
their
places
next
week
:
 
<EOS>
Lewis
thinks
they
will
not
till
spring
,
when
the
session
is
over
;
both
of
them
entirely
despair
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
to
see
Mrs.
Masham
,
who
invited
me
to
dinner
;
but
I
was
engaged
to
Lewis
.
 
<EOS>
At
four
I
went
to
Masham
's
.
 
<EOS>
He
came
and
whispered
me
that
he
had
it
from
a
very
good
hand
that
all
would
be
well
,
and
I
found
them
both
very
cheerful
.
 
<EOS>
The
company
was
going
to
the
opera
,
but
desired
I
would
come
and
sup
with
them
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
so
at
ten
,
and
Lord
Treasurer
was
there
,
and
sat
with
us
till
past
twelve
,
and
was
more
cheerful
than
I
have
seen
him
these
ten
days
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Masham
told
me
he
was
mightily
cast
down
some
days
ago
,
and
he
could
not
indeed
hide
it
from
me
.
<EOS>
Arbuthnot
is
in
good
hopes
that
the
Queen
has
not
betrayed
us
,
but
only
has
been
frightened
,
and
flattered
,
etc
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
can
not
yet
be
of
his
opinion
,
whether
my
reasons
are
better
,
or
that
my
fears
are
greater
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
resolve
,
if
they
give
up
,
or
are
turned
out
soon
,
to
retire
for
some
months
,
and
I
have
pitched
upon
the
place
already
:
 
<EOS>
but
I
will
take
methods
for
hearing
from
MD
,
and
writing
to
them
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
would
be
out
of
the
way
upon
the
first
of
the
ferment
;
for
they
lay
all
things
on
me
,
even
some
I
have
never
read
.
  
<EOS>
16
.
 
<EOS>
I
took
courage
to
-
day
,
and
went
to
Court
with
a
very
cheerful
countenance
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
mightily
crowded
;
both
parties
coming
to
observe
each
other
's
faces
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
avoided
Lord
Halifax
's
bow
till
he
forced
it
on
me
;
but
we
did
not
talk
together
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
make
less
than
fourscore
bows
,
of
which
about
twenty
might
be
to
Whigs
.
 
<EOS>
The
Duke
of
Somerset
is
gone
to
Petworth
,
and
,
I
hear
,
the
Duchess
too
,
of
which
I
shall
be
very
glad
.
 
<EOS>
Prince
Eugene
,
who
was
expected
here
some
days
ago
,
we
are
now
told
,
will
not
come
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
The
Whigs
designed
to
have
met
him
with
forty
thousand
horse
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
told
me
some
days
ago
of
his
discourse
with
the
Emperor
's
Resident
,
that
puppy
Hoffman
,
about
Prince
Eugene
's
coming
;
by
which
I
found
my
lord
would
hinder
it
,
if
he
could
;
and
we
shall
be
all
glad
if
he
does
not
come
,
and
think
it
a
good
point
gained
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Andrew
Fountaine
,
Ford
,
and
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
with
Mrs.
Van
,
by
invitation
.
  
<EOS>
17
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
mistaken
the
day
of
the
month
,
and
been
forced
to
mend
it
thrice
.
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
with
Mr.
Masham
and
his
lady
,
by
invitation
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
was
to
be
there
,
but
came
not
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
to
entertain
Buys
,
<EOS>
the
Dutch
Envoy
,
who
speaks
English
well
enough
:
 
<EOS>
he
was
plaguily
politic
,
telling
a
thousand
lies
,
of
which
none
passed
upon
any
of
us
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
still
in
the
condition
of
suspense
,
and
I
think
have
little
hopes
.
 
<EOS>
The
Duchess
of
Somerset
is
not
gone
to
Petworth
;
only
the
Duke
,
and
that
is
a
poor
sacrifice
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
the
Queen
certainly
designs
to
change
the
Ministry
,
but
perhaps
may
put
it
off
till
the
session
is
over
:
 
and
<EOS>
I
think
they
had
better
give
up
now
,
if
she
will
not
deal
openly
;
and
then
they
need
not
answer
for
the
consequences
of
a
peace
,
when
it
is
in
other
hands
,
and
may
yet
be
broken
.
 
<EOS>
They
say
my
Lord
Privy
Seal
sets
out
for
Holland
this
week
:
 
<EOS>
so
the
peace
goes
on
.
  
<EOS>
18
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
rained
hard
from
morning
till
night
,
and
cost
me
three
shillings
in
coach
-
hire
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
had
abundance
of
wet
weather
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
in
the
City
,
and
was
with
the
printer
,
who
has
now
a
fifth
edition
of
the
Conduct
,
etc
.
<EOS>
:
it
is
in
small
,
and
sold
for
sixpence
;
they
have
printed
as
many
as
three
editions
,
because
they
are
to
be
sent
in
numbers
into
the
country
by
great
men
,
etc
.
,
who
subscribe
for
hundreds
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
been
sent
a
fortnight
ago
to
Ireland
:
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
you
will
print
it
there
.
 
<EOS>
The
Tory
Lords
and
Commons
in
Parliament
argue
all
from
it
;
and
all
agree
that
never
anything
of
that
kind
was
of
so
great
consequence
,
or
made
so
many
converts
.
 
<EOS>
By
the
time
I
have
sent
this
letter
,
I
expect
to
hear
from
little
MD
:
 
it
will
be
a
month
,
two
days
hence
,
since
I
had
your
last
,
and
I
will
allow
ten
days
for
accidents
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
get
rid
of
the
leavings
of
a
cold
I
got
a
month
ago
,
or
else
it
is
a
new
one
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
writing
letters
all
this
evening
till
I
am
weary
,
and
I
am
sending
out
another
little
thing
,
which
I
hope
to
finish
this
week
,
and
design
to
send
to
the
printer
in
an
unknown
hand
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
printed
a
Grub
Street
speech
of
Lord
Nottingham
;
and
he
was
such
an
owl
to
complain
of
it
in
the
House
of
Lords
,
who
have
taken
up
the
printer
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
heard
at
Court
that
Walpole
(
a
great
Whig
member
)
said
that
I
and
my
whimsical
Club
writ
it
at
one
of
our
meetings
,
and
that
I
should
pay
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
will
find
he
lies
:
 
<EOS>
and
I
shall
let
him
know
by
a
third
hand
<EOS>
my
thoughts
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
to
be
Secretary
of
State
,
if
the
Ministry
changes
;
but
he
has
lately
had
a
bribe
proved
against
him
in
Parliament
,
while
he
was
Secretary
at
War
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
one
of
the
Whigs
'
chief
speakers
.
  
<EOS>
19
.
 
<EOS>
Sad
dismal
weather
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
to
the
Secretary
's
office
,
and
Lewis
made
me
dine
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
intended
to
have
dined
with
Lord
Treasurer
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
seen
the
Secretary
this
week
.
 
<EOS>
Things
do
not
mend
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Dartmouth
despairs
,
and
is
for
giving
up
<EOS>
;
Lewis
is
of
the
same
mind
;
but
Lord
Treasurer
only
says
,
"
Poh
,
poh
,
all
will
be
well
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
I
am
come
home
early
to
finish
something
I
am
doing
;
but
I
find
I
want
heart
and
humour
,
and
would
read
any
idle
book
that
came
in
my
way
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
just
sent
away
a
penny
paper
to
make
a
little
mischief
.
 
<EOS>
Patrick
is
gone
to
the
burial
of
an
Irish
footman
,
who
was
Dr.
King
's
servant
;
he
died
of
a
consumption
,
a
fit
death
for
a
poor
starving
wit
's
footman
.
 
<EOS>
The
Irish
servants
always
club
to
bury
a
countryman
.
  
<EOS>
20
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
with
the
Secretary
this
morning
,
and
,
for
aught
I
can
see
,
we
shall
have
a
languishing
death
:
 
<EOS>
I
can
know
nothing
,
nor
themselves
neither
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
,
you
know
,
with
our
Society
,
and
that
odious
Secretary
would
make
me
President
next
week
;
so
I
must
entertain
them
this
day
se'nnight
at
the
Thatched
House
Tavern
,
where
we
dined
to
-
day
:
 
<EOS>
it
will
cost
me
five
or
six
pounds
;
yet
the
Secretary
says
he
will
give
me
wine
.
 
<EOS>
I
found
a
letter
when
I
came
home
from
the
Bishop
of
Clogher
.
  
<EOS>
21
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
the
first
time
I
ever
got
a
new
cold
before
the
old
one
was
going
:
 
<EOS>
it
came
yesterday
,
and
appeared
in
all
due
forms
,
eyes
and
nose
running
,
etc
.
,
and
is
now
very
bad
;
and
I
can
not
tell
how
I
got
it
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Andrew
Fountaine
and
I
were
invited
to
dine
with
Mrs.
Van
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this
morning
with
the
Duke
of
Ormond
;
and
neither
he
nor
I
can
think
of
anything
to
comfort
us
in
present
affairs
.
 
<EOS>
We
must
certainly
fall
,
if
the
Duchess
of
Somerset
be
not
turned
out
;
and
nobody
believes
the
Queen
will
ever
part
with
her
.
 
<EOS>
The
Duke
and
I
were
settling
when
Mr.
Secretary
and
I
should
dine
with
him
,
and
he
fixes
upon
Tuesday
;
and
when
I
came
away
I
remembered
it
was
Christmas
Day
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
to
see
Lady
#
#
#
#
,
 
who
is
just
up
after
lying
-
in
;
and
the
ugliest
sight
I
have
seen
,
pale
,
dead
,
old
and
yellow
,
for
want
of
her
paint
.
 
<EOS>
She
has
turned
my
stomach
.
 
<EOS>
But
she
will
soon
be
painted
,
and
a
beauty
again
.
  
<EOS>
22
.
 
<EOS>
I
find
myself
disordered
with
a
pain
all
round
the
small
of
my
back
,
which
I
imputed
to
champagne
<EOS>
I
had
drunk
;
but
find
it
to
have
been
only
my
new
cold
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
fine
frosty
day
,
and
I
resolved
to
walk
into
the
City
.
 
<EOS>
I
called
at
Lord
Treasurer
's
at
eleven
,
and
stayed
some
time
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
showed
me
a
letter
from
a
great
Presbyterian

to
him
,
complaining
how
their
friends
had
betrayed
them
by
passing
this
Conformity
Bill
;
and
he
showed

the

he
had
written
,
which
his
friends
would
not
let
him
send
;
but
was
a
very
good
one
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
very
cheerful
;
but
gives
one
no
hopes
,
nor
has
any
to
give
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
into
the
City
,
and
there
I
dined
.
  
<EOS>
23
.
 
<EOS>
Morning
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
was
dressing
to
go
to
church
,
a
friend
that
was
to
see
me
advised
me
not
to
stir
out
;
so
I
shall
keep
at
home
to
-
day
,
and
only
eat
some
broth
,
if
I
can
get
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
terrible
cold
frost
,
and
snow
fell
yesterday
,
which
still
remains
:
 
look
there
<EOS>
,
you
may
see
it
from
the
penthouses
.
 
<EOS>
The
Lords
made
yesterday
two
or
three
votes
about
peace
,
and
Hanover
,
of
a
very
angry
kind
to
vex
the
Ministry
,
and
they
will
meet
sooner
by
a
fortnight
than
the
Commons
;
and
they
say
,
are
preparing
some
knocking
addresses
.
 
<EOS>
Morrow
,
sirrahs
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
sit
at
home
,
and
when
I
go
to
bed
I
will
tell
you
how
I
am
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
sat
at
home
all
day
,
and
eaten
only
a
mess
of
broth
and
a
roll
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
written
a
Prophecy
,
which
I
design
to
print
;
I
did
it
to
-
day
,
and
some
other

.
  
<EOS>
24
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
into
the
City
to
-
day
in
a
coach
,
and
dined
there
.
 
<EOS>
My
cold
is
going
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
now
bitter
hard
frost
,
and
has
been
so
these
three
or
four
days
.
<EOS>
My
Prophecy
is
printed
,
and
will
be
published
after
Christmas
Day
;
I
like
it
mightily
:
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
how
it
will
pass
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
never
understand
it
at
your
distance
,
without
help
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
everybody
will
guess
it
to
be
mine
,
because
it
is
somewhat
in
the
same
manner
with
that
of
"
Merlin
"
in
the
Miscellanies
.
 
<EOS>
My
Lord
Privy
Seal
set
out
this
day
for
Holland
:
 
he
'll
have
a
cold
journey
.
 
<EOS>
I
gave
Patrick
half
a
crown
for
his
Christmas
box
,
on
condition
he
would
be
good
,
and
he
came
home
drunk
at
midnight
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
taken
a
memorandum
of
it
,
because
I
never
design
to
give
him
a
groat
more
.
 
<EOS>
'
Tis
cruel
cold
.
  
<EOS>
25
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
MD
a
merry
Christmas
,
and
many
a
one
;
but
mine
is
melancholy
:
 
I
durst
not
go
to
church
to
-
day
,
finding
myself
a
little
out
of
order
,
and
it
snowing
prodigiously
,
and
freezing
.
 
<EOS>
At
noon
I
went
to
Mrs.
Van
,
who
had
this
week
engaged
me
to
dine
there
to
-
day
:
 
<EOS>
and
there
I
received
the
news
that
poor
Mrs.
Long
died
at
Lynn
in
Norfolk
on
Saturday
last
,
at
four
in
the
morning
<EOS>
:
she
was
sick
but
four
hours
.
 
<EOS>
We
suppose
it
was
the
asthma
,
which
she
was
subject
to
as
well
as
the
dropsy
,
as
she
sent
me
word
in
her
last
letter
,
written
about
five
weeks
ago
;
but
then
said
she
was
recovered
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
was
more
afflicted
at
any
death
.
 
<EOS>
The
poor
creature
had
retired
to
Lynn
two
years
ago
,
to
live
cheap
,
and
pay
her
debts
.
 
<EOS>
In
her
last
letter
she
told
me
she
hoped
to
be
easy
by
Christmas
;
and
she
kept
her
word
,
although
she
meant
it
otherwise
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
all
sorts
of
amiable
qualities
,
and
no
ill
ones
,
but
the
indiscretion
of
too
much
neglecting
her
own
affairs
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
two
thousand
pounds
left
her
by
an
old
grandmother
,
with
which
she
intended
to
pay
her
debts
,
and
live
on
an
annuity
she
had
of
one
hundred
pounds
a
year
,
and
Newburg
House
,
which
would
be
about
sixty
pounds
more
.
 
<EOS>
That
odious
grandmother
living
so
long
,
forced
her
to
retire
;
for
the
two
thousand
pounds
was
settled
on
her
after
the
old
woman
's
death
,
yet
her
brute
of
a
brother
,
Sir
James
Long
,
would
not
advance
it
for
her
;
else
she
might
have
paid
her
debts
,
and
continued
here
,
and
lived
still
:
 
<EOS>
I
believe
melancholy
helped
her
on
to
her
grave
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
ordered
a
paragraph
to
be
put
in
the
Postboy
,
giving
an
account
of
her
death
,
and
making
honourable
mention
of
her
;
which
is
all
I
can
do
to
serve
her
memory
:
 
but
one
reason
was
spite
;
for
her
brother
would
fain
have
her
death
a
secret
,
to
save
the
charge
of
bringing
her
up
here
to
bury
her
,
or
going
into

.
 
<EOS>
Pardon
all
this
,
for
the
sake
of
a
poor
creature
I
had
so
much
friendship
for
.
  
<EOS>
26
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
to
Mr.
Secretary
this
morning
,
and
he
would
have
me
dine
with
him
.
<EOS>
I
called
at
noon
at
Mrs.
Masham
's
,
who
desired
me
not
to
let

Prophecy
be

,
for

angering
the
Queen
about
the
Duchess
of
Somerset
;
so
I
writ
to
the

to
stop

.
 
<EOS>
They
have
been
printed
and
given
about
,
but

.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
Lord
Treasurer
there
,

had
been
two
hours
with
the
Queen
;
and
Mrs.
Masham
is
in

.
 
<EOS>
I
went

again
,
and

Mr.
Masham
's
,
and
Lord
Treasurer
sat
with
us
till
one

.
<EOS>
So
'
tis
late
,
etc
.
  
<EOS>
27
.
 
<EOS>
I
entertained
our
Society
at
the
Thatched
House
Tavern
to
-
day
at

;
but
<EOS>
brother
Bathurst
sent
for
wine
,
the

none
.
 
<EOS>
The
printer
had
not
received
my

,
and

he
brought

dozens

of
the
Prophecy
;
but
I
ordered

to
part
with
no

.
 
<EOS>
'
Tis
an
admirable
good
one
,
and
people
are
mad
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
frost
still
continues
violently
cold
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Masham
invited
me
to
come
to
-
night
and
play
at
cards
;
but
our
Society
did
not
part
till
nine
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
supped
with
Mrs.
Hill
,
her
sister
,
and
there
was
Mrs.
Masham
and
Lord
Treasurer
,
and
we

till
twelve
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
endeavouring
to
get
a
majority
against
next
Wednesday
,
when
the
House
of
Lords
is
to
meet
,
and
the
Whigs
intend
to
make
some
violent
addresses
against
a
peace
,
if
not
prevented
.
<EOS>
God
knows
what
will
become
of
us
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
still
prodigiously
cold
;
but
so
I
told
you
already
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
eggs
on
the
spit
,
I
wish
they
may
not
be
addled
.
<EOS>
When
I
came
home
tonight
I
found
,
forsooth
,
a
letter
from
MD
,
N.24
,
24
,
24
,
24
;
there
,
do
you
know
the
numbers
now
?
<EOS>
and
at

same

one
from
Joe
,
full
of
thanks
:
 
let
him
know
I
have
received
it
,
and
am
glad
of
his
success
,
but
wo
n't
put
him
to

charge
of

letter
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
a
letter
some

ago
from
Mr.
Warburton
,
and
I

of

will

,
and

by

to

.
 
<EOS>
'
Tis
as
follows
:
 
<EOS>
The
Doctor
has
received
Mr.
Warburton
's
letter
,
and
desires
he
will
let
the
Doctor
know
where
that
accident
he
mentions
is
like
soon
to

,
and
he
will

what
he

.
 
<EOS>
And
pray
,
<EOS>
madam
,
let
them
know
that
I
do
this
to
save

the

,
and

the

.
 
<EOS>
And
I
think
that
this
is
enough
for
one
that
comes

twelve
from
a
Lord
Treasurer
and
Mrs.
Masham
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
I
could
tell
you
ten
thousand
things
of
our
mad
politics
,
upon
what
small
circumstances
great
affairs
have
turned
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
will
go
rest
my
busy
head
.
  
<EOS>
28
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this
morning
with
brother
Bathurst
to
see
the
Duke
of
Ormond
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
given
his
Grace
some
hopes
to
be
one
of
our
Society
.
 
<EOS>
The
Secretary
and
I
and
Bathurst
are
to
dine
with
him
on
Sunday
next
.
 
<EOS>
The
Duke
is
not
in
much
hopes
,
but
has
been
very
busy
in
endeavouring
to
bring
over
some
lords
against
next
Wednesday
.
 
<EOS>
The
Duchess
caught
me
as
I
was
going
out
;
she
is
sadly
in
fear
about
things
,
and
blames
me
for
not
mending
them
by
my
credit
with
Lord
Treasurer
;
and
I
blame
her
.
 
<EOS>
She
met
me
in
the
street
at
noon
,
and
engaged
me
to
dine
with
her
,
which
I
did
;
and
we
talked
an
hour
after
dinner
in
her
closet
.
 
<EOS>
If
we
miscarry
on
Wednesday
,
I
believe
it
will
be
by
some
strange
sort
of
neglect
.
 
<EOS>
They
talk
of
making
eight
new
lords
by
calling
up
some
peers
'
eldest
sons
;
but
they
delay
strangely
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
Judge
Coote
to
-
day
at
the
Duke
of
Ormond
's
:
 
<EOS>
he
desires
to
come
and
see
me
,
to
justify
his
principles
.
  
<EOS>
29
.
 
<EOS>
Morning
.
 
<EOS>
This
goes
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
not
answer
yours
,
your
24th
,
till
next
,
which
shall
begin
to
-
night
,
as
usual
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Shelburne
has
sent
to
invite
me
to
dinner
,
but
I
am
engaged
with
Lewis
at
Ned
Southwell
's
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Northampton
and
Lord
Aylesbury
's
sons
are
both
made
peers
;
but
we
shall
want
more
.
 
<EOS>
I
write
this
post
to
your
Dean
.
 
<EOS>
I
owe
the
Archbishop
a
letter
this
long
time
.
 
<EOS>
All
people
that
come
from
Ireland
complain
of
him
,
and
scold
me
for
protecting
him
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
,
Madam
Dingley
,
let
me
know
what
Presto
has
received
for
this
year
,
or
whether
anything
is
due
to

for

:
 
I
can
not

former

now
.
 
<EOS>
As

Dingley
's
own
account
of
her
exchequer

,
I
will
give

on
t'other
side
.
 
<EOS>
Farewell
,
my
own
dearest
MD
,
and
love
Presto
;
and
God

dearest
MD
,
etc
.
<EOS>
etc
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish

.

,

<EOS>

.

.
  
<EOS>
Churchwarden
's

,

.
  
<EOS>
Saturday

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
broke

my
letter
,
and
tore
it
into
the
bargain
,
to
let

know
that
we
are
all

:
 
<EOS>
the
Queen
has
made
no
less
than
twelve
lords
,
to
have
a
majority
;
nine
new
ones
,
the
other
three
peers
'
sons
;
and
has
turned

Duke
of
Somerset
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
awaked
at
last
,
and
so
is
Lord
Treasurer
:
 
<EOS>
I
want
nothing
now
but
to
see
the
Duchess
out
.
 
<EOS>
But
we
shall
do
without
her
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
all
extremely
happy
.
 
<EOS>
Give
me
joy
,
sirrahs
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
written
in
a
coffee
-
house
.
 
<EOS>
Three
of
the
new
lords
are
of
our
Society
.
   
<EOS>
LETTER
38
.
 
<EOS>
LONDON
,
Dec.
29
,
1711
.
  
<EOS>
I
put
my
letter
in
this
evening
,
after
coming
from
dinner
at
Ned
Southwell
's
,
where
I
drank
very
good
Irish
wine
,
and
we
are
in
great
joy
at
this
happy
turn
of
affairs
.
 
<EOS>
The
Queen
has
been
at
last
persuaded
to
her
own
interest
and
security
,
and
I
freely
think
she
must
have
made
both
herself
and
kingdom
very
unhappy
,
if
she
had
done
otherwise
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
still
a
mighty
secret
that
Masham
is
to
be
one
of
the
new
lords
;
they
say
he
does
not
yet
know
it
himself
;
but
the
Queen
is
to
surprise
him
with
it
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Secretary
will
be
a
lord
at
the
end
of
the
session
;
but
they
want
him
still
in
Parliament
.
 
<EOS>
After
all
,
it
is
a
strange
unhappy
necessity
of
making
so
many
peers
together
;
but
the
Queen
has
drawn
it
upon
herself
,
by
her
confounded
trimming
and
moderation
.
 
<EOS>
Three
,
as
I
told
you
,
are
of
our
Society
.
  
<EOS>
30
.
 
<EOS>
I
writ
the
Dean
and
you
a
lie
yesterday
;
for
the
Duke
of
Somerset
is
not
yet
turned
out
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
to
-
day
at
Court
,
and
resolved
to
be
very
civil
to
the
Whigs
;
but
saw
few
there
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
was
in
the
bed
-
chamber
talking
to
Lord
Rochester
,
he
went
up
to
Lady
Burlington
,
who
asked
him
who
I
was
;
and
Lady
Sunderland
<EOS>
and
she
whispered
about
me
:
 
<EOS>
I
desired
Lord
Rochester
to
tell
Lady
Sunderland
<EOS>
I
doubted
she
was
not
as
much
in
love
with
me
as
I
was
with
her
;
but
he
would
not
deliver
my
message
.
 
<EOS>
The
Duchess
of
Shrewsbury
came
running
up
to
me
,
and
clapped
her
fan
up
to
hide
us
from
the
company
,
and
we
gave
one
another
joy
of
this
change
;
but
sighed
when
we
reflected
on
the
Somerset
family
not
being
out
.
 
<EOS>
The
Secretary
and
I
,
and
brother
Bathurst
,
and
Lord
Windsor
,
dined
with
the
Duke
of
Ormond
.
 
<EOS>
Bathurst
and
Windsor
are
to
be
two
of
the
new
lords
.
 
<EOS>
I
desired
my
Lord
Radnor
's
brother
,
at
Court
to
-
day
,
to
let
my
lord
know
I
would
call
on
him
at
six
,
which
I
did
,
and
was
arguing
with
him
three
hours
to
bring
him
over
to
us
,
and
I
spoke
so
closely
that
I
believe
he
will
be
tractable
;
but
he
is
a
scoundrel
,
and
though
I
said
I
only
talked
for
my
love
to
him
,
I
told
a
lie
;
for
I
did
not
care
if
he
were
hanged
:
 
but
everyone
gained
over
is
of
consequence
.
 
<EOS>
The
Duke
of
Marlborough
was
at
Court
today
,
and
nobody
hardly
took
notice
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
Masham
's
being
a
lord
begins
to
take
wind
:
 
<EOS>
nothing
at
Court
can
be
kept
a
secret
.
 
<EOS>
Wednesday
will
be
a
great
day
:
 
you
shall
know
more
.
  
<EOS>
31
.
 
<EOS>
Our
frost
is
broken
since
yesterday
,
and
it
is
very
slabbery
;
yet
I
walked
to
the
City
and
dined
,
and
ordered
some
things
with
the
printer
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
settled
Dr.
King
in
the
Gazette
;
it
will
be
worth
two
hundred
pounds
a
year
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
Our
new
lords
'
patents
are
passed
:
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
like
the
expedient
,
if
we
could
have
found
any
other
.
 
<EOS>
I
see
I
have
said
this
before
.
 
<EOS>
I
hear
the
Duke
of
Marlborough
is
turned
out
of
all
his
employments
:
 
<EOS>
I
shall
know
to
-
morrow
when
I
am
to
carry
Dr.
King
to
dine
with
the
Secretary
.
 
<EOS>
These
are
strong
remedies
;
pray
God
the
patient
is
able
to
bear
them
.
 
<EOS>
The
last
Ministry
people
are
utterly
desperate
.
  
<EOS>
Jan.
1
.
 
<EOS>
Now
I
wish
my
dearest
little
MD
many
happy
new
years
;
yes
,
both
Dingley
and
Stella
,
ay
and
Presto
too
,
many
happy
new
years
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
the
Secretary
,
and
it
is
true
that
the
Duke
of
Marlborough
is
turned
out
of
all
.
<EOS>
The
Duke
of
Ormond
has
got
his
regiment
of
foot
-
guards
,
I
know
not
who
has
the
rest
.
<EOS>
If
the
Ministry
be
not
sure
of
a
peace
,
I
shall
wonder
at
this
step
,
and
do
not
approve
it
at
best
.
<EOS>
The
Queen
and
Lord
Treasurer
mortally
hate
the
Duke
of
Marlborough
,
and
to
that
he
owes
his
fall
,
more
than
to
his
other
faults
:
unless
he
has
been
tampering
too
far
with
his
party
,
of
which
I
have
not
heard
any
particulars
;
however
it
be
,
the
world
abroad
will
blame
us
.
 
<EOS>
I
confess
my
belief
that
he
has
not
one
good
quality
in
the
world
beside
that
of
a
general
,
and
even
that
I
have
heard
denied
by
several
great
soldiers
.
 
<EOS>
But
we
have
had
constant
success
in
arms
while
he
commanded
.
 
<EOS>
Opinion
is
a
mighty
matter
in
war
,
and
I
doubt
the
French
think
it
impossible
to
conquer
an
army
that
he
leads
,
and
our
soldiers
think
the
same
;
and
how
far
even
this
step
may
encourage
the
French
to
play
tricks
with
us
,
no
man
knows
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
not
love
to
see
personal
resentment
mix
with
public
affairs
.
  
<EOS>
2
.
 
<EOS>
This
being
the
day
the
Lords
meet
,
and
the
new
peers
to
be
introduced
,
I
went
to
Westminster
to
see
the
sight
;
but
the
crowd
was
too
great
in
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
only
went
into
the
robing
-
room
,
to
give
my
four
brothers
joy
,
and
Sir
Thomas
Mansel
,
and
Lord
Windsor
;
the
other
six
I
am
not
acquainted
with
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
apprehended
the
Whigs
would
have
raised
some
difficulties
,
but
nothing
happened
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
to
see
Lady
Masham
at
noon
,
and
wish
her
joy
of
her
new
honour
,
and
a
happy
new
year
.
 
<EOS>
I
found
her
very
well
pleased
;
for
peerage
will
be
some
sort
of
protection
to
her
upon
any
turn
of
affairs
.
 
<EOS>
She
engaged
me
to
come
at
night
,
and
sup
with
her
and
Lord
Treasurer
:
 
<EOS>
I
went
at
nine
,
and
she
was
not
at
home
,
so
I
would
not
stay
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
I
wo
n't
answer
your
letter
yet
,
young
women
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
a
friend
in
the
neighbourhood
.
 
<EOS>
I
see
nothing
here
like
Christmas
,
except
brawn
or
mince
-
pies
in
places
where
I
dine
,
and
giving
away
my
half
-
crowns
like
farthings
to
great
men
's
porters
and
butlers
.
<EOS>
Yesterday
I
paid
seven
good
guineas
to
the
fellow
at
the
tavern
where
I
treated
the
Society
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
great
mind
to
send
you
the
bill
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
I
told
you
some
articles
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
heard
whether
anything
was
done
in
the
House
of
Lords
after
introducing
the
new
ones
.
 
<EOS>
Ford
has
been
sitting
with
me
till
peeast
tweeleve
a
clock
.
  
<EOS>
3
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
our
Society
day
:
 
<EOS>
Lord
Dupplin
was
President
;
we
choose
every
week
;
the
last
President
treats
and
chooses
his
successor
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
our
dinner
cost
fifteen
pounds
beside
wine
.
 
<EOS>
The
Secretary
grew
brisk
,
and
would
not
let
me
go
,
nor
Lord
Lansdowne
,
who
would
fain
have
gone
home
to
his
lady
,
being
newly
married
to
Lady
Mary
Thynne
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
near
one
when
we
parted
,
so
you
must
think
I
can
not
write
much
to
-
night
.
 
<EOS>
The
adjourning
of
the
House
of
Lords
yesterday
,
as
the
Queen
desired
,
was
just
carried
by
the
twelve
new
lords
,
and
one
more
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Radnor
was
not
there
:
 
<EOS>
I
hope
I
have
cured
him
.
<EOS>
Did
I
tell
you
that
I
have
brought
Dr.
King
in
to
be
Gazetteer
?
 
<EOS>
It
will
be
worth
above
two
hundred
pounds
a
year
to
him
:
 
<EOS>
I
believe
I
told
you
so
before
,
but
I
am
forgetful
.
 
<EOS>
Go
,
get
you
gone
to
ombre
,
and
claret
,
and
toasted
oranges
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
go
sleep
.
  
<EOS>
4
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
get
rid
of
the
leavings
of
my
cold
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
in
the
City
to
-
day
,
and
dined
with
my
printer
,
and
gave
him
a
ballad
made
by
several
hands
,
I
know
not
whom
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
Lord
Treasurer
had
a
finger
in
it
;
I
added
three
stanzas
;
I
suppose
Dr.
Arbuthnot
had
the
greatest
share
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
been
overseeing
some
other
little
prints
,
and
a
pamphlet
made
by
one
of
my
under
-
strappers
.
<EOS>
Somerset
is
not
out
yet
.
 
<EOS>
I
doubt
not
<EOS>
but
you
will
have
the
Prophecy
in
Ireland
,
although
it
is
not
published
here
,
only
printed
copies
given
to
friends
.
 
<EOS>
Tell
me
,
do
you
understand
it
?
 
<EOS>
No
,
faith
,
not
without
help
.
 
<EOS>
Tell
me
what
you
stick
at
,
and
I
'll
explain
.
 
<EOS>
We
turned
out
a
member
of
our
Society
yesterday
for
gross
neglect
and
non
-
attendance
.
 
<EOS>
I
writ
to
him
by
order
to
give
him
notice
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
Tom
Harley
,
secretary
to
the
Treasurer
,
and
cousin
-
german
to
Lord
Treasurer
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
going
to
Hanover
from
the
Queen
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
to
give
the
Duke
of
Ormond
notice
of
his
election
as
soon
as
I
can
see
him
.
  
<EOS>
5
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
this
morning
with
a
parishioner
of
mine
,
one
Nuttal
,
who
came
over
here
for
a
legacy
of
one
hundred
pounds
,
and
a
roguish
lawyer
had
refused
to
pay
him
,
and
would
not
believe
he
was
the
man
.
 
<EOS>
I
writ
to
the
lawyer
a
sharp
letter
,
that
I
had
taken
Nuttal
into
my
protection
,
and
was
resolved
to
stand
by
him
,
and
the
next
news
was
,
that
the
lawyer
desired
I
would
meet
him
,
and
attest
<EOS>
he
was
the
man
,
which
I
did
,
and
his
money
was
paid
upon
the
spot
.
 
<EOS>
I
then
visited
Lord
Treasurer
,
who
is
now
right
again
,
and
all
well
,
only
that
the
Somerset
family
is
not
out
yet
.
 
<EOS>
I
hate
that
;
I
do
n't
like
it
,
as
the
man
said
,
by
,
etc
.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
went
and
visited
poor
Will
Congreve
,
who
had
a
French
fellow
tampering
with
one
of
his
eyes
;
he
is
almost
blind
of
both
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
some
merchants
in
the
City
,
but
could
not
see
Stratford
,
with
whom
I
had
business
.
 
<EOS>
Presto
,
leave
off
your
impertinence
,
and
answer
our
letter
,
saith
MD
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
,
one
of
these
days
,
when
I
have
nothing
else
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
O
,
faith
,
this
letter
is
a
week
written
,
and
not
one
side
done
yet
.
<EOS>
These
ugly
spots
are
not
tobacco
,
but
this
is
the
last
gilt
sheet
I
have
of
large
paper
,
therefore
hold
your
tongue
.
 
<EOS>
Nuttal
was
surprised
when
they
gave
him
bits
of
paper
instead
of
money
,
but
I
made
Ben
Tooke
put
him
in
his
geers
:
 
he
could
not
reckon
ten
pounds
,
but
was
puzzled
with
the
Irish
way
.
 
<EOS>
Ben
Tooke
and
my
printer
have
desired
me
to
make
them
stationers
to
the
Ordnance
,
of
which
Lord
Rivers
is
Master
,
instead
of
the
Duke
of
Marlborough
.
 
<EOS>
It
will
be
a
hundred
pounds
a
year
apiece
to
them
,
if
I
can
get
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
try
to
-
morrow
.
  
<EOS>
6
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
this
morning
to
Earl
Rivers
,
gave
him
joy
of
his
new
employment
,
and
desired
him
to
prefer
my
printer
and
bookseller
to
be
stationers
to
his
office
.
 
<EOS>
He
immediately
granted
it
me
;
but
,
like
an
old
courtier
,
told
me
it
was
wholly
on
my
account
,
but
that
he
heard
I
had
intended
to

Mr.
Secretary
to
speak

,
and
desired
I
would
engage
him
to
do

,
but
that
,
however
,
he
did

only
for
my

.
 
<EOS>
This
is
a
Court
trick
,
to
oblige
as
many
as
you
can
at
once
.
 
<EOS>
I
read
prayers
to
poor
Mrs.
Wesley
,
who
is
very
much
out
of
order
,
instead
of
going
to
church
;
and
then
I
went
to
Court
,
which
I
found
very
full
,
in
expectation
of
seeing
Prince
Eugene
,
who
landed
last
night
,
and
lies
at
Leicester
House
;
he
was
not
to
see
the
Queen
till
six
this

.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
and
believe
he
comes
too
late
to
do
the
Whigs
<EOS>
any
good
.
 
<EOS>
I
refused

with
the
Secretary
,
and
was
like
to
lose
my
dinner
,
which
was
at

's
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
at
six
 
to
see

Prince
at

,
but
he
was
gone
in
to
the
Queen
;
and
when

,
Mr.
Secretary
,
who

,
walked
so
near

that
he
quite
screened

from

with
his

.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
tell
you
a
good

:
 
as

Eugene

,

Hoffman

,

:
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Was

<EOS>
But

<EOS>
I

,

the

,

,

:
 
and
<EOS>
now

;
that

,

I

.

7
.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
done

a

<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
Lord

<EOS>
there

wo

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

?
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
Poh
,
I

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
have

,

Presto

?
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

;

.
 
<EOS>
I

.

?
 
<EOS>
Stella

;

.
 
<EOS>
Is

as

?
 
<EOS>
I
'm

;
so

.
 
<EOS>
What
?
<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>
Why
,

;
only

:
 
and

.
 
<EOS>
It

nuts

;
a

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

;

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Your

.
 
<EOS>
Stella

;

.
 
<EOS>

;

?
<EOS>
never

?
 
<EOS>

,

,
'

<EOS>
Well

,

<EOS>
The

<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
Mr.

<EOS>
Bernage

,

for

.
 
<EOS>
I
care
not
twopence
.
 
<EOS>
Prince

did
not

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Lewis
and
I
dined
with
a
private
friend
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this
morning
to
see
the
Duke
of
Ormond
,
who

meet

at
the
Cockpit
at
one
,
but

.
 
<EOS>
I
sat
too
some
time
with
the
Duchess
.
 
<EOS>
We
do
n't
like
things
very
well
yet
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
come
home
early
,
and
going
to
be
busy
.
<EOS>
I
'll
go
write
.
  
<EOS>
9
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
go
sleep
last
night
till
past
two
,
and
was
waked
before
three
by
a
noise
of
people
endeavouring
to
break
open
my
window
.
 
<EOS>
For
a
while
I
would
not
stir
,
thinking
it
might
be
my
imagination
;
but
hearing
the
noise
continued
,
I
rose
and
went
to
the
window
,
and
then
it
ceased
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
to
bed
again
,
and
heard
it
repeated
more
violently
;
then
I
rose
and
called
up
the
house
,
and
got
a
candle
:
 
<EOS>
the
rogues
had
lifted
up
the
sash
a
yard
;
there
are
great
sheds
before
my
windows
,
although
my
lodgings
be
a
storey
high
;
and
if
they
get
upon
the
sheds
they
are
almost
even
with
my
window
.
 
<EOS>
We
observed
their
track
,
and
panes
of
glass
fresh
broken
.
 
<EOS>
The
watchmen
told
us
to
-
day
they
saw
them
,
but
could
not
catch
them
.
 
<EOS>
They
attacked
others
in
the
neighbourhood
about
the
same
time
,
and
actually
robbed
a
house
in
Suffolk
Street
,
which
is
the
next
street
but
one
to
us
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
said
they
are
seamen
discharged
from
service
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
up
to
call
my
man
,
and
found
his
bed
empty
;
it
seems
he
often
lies
abroad
.
 
<EOS>
I
challenged
him
this
morning
as
one
of
the
robbers
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a
sad
dog
;
and
the
minute
I
come
to
Ireland
I
will
discard
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
this
day
got
double
iron
bars
to
every
window
in
my
dining
-
room
and
bed
-
chamber
;
and
I
hide
my
purse
in
my
thread
stocking
between
the
bed
's
head
and
the
wainscot
.
 
<EOS>
Lewis
and
I
dined
with
an
old
Scotch
friend
,
who
brought
the
Duke
of
Douglas
and
three
or
four
more
Scots
upon
us
.
  
<EOS>
10
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
our
Society
day
,
you
know
;
but
the
Duke
of
Ormond
could
not
be
with
us
,
because
he
dined
with
Prince
Eugene
.
 
<EOS>
It
cost
me
a
guinea
contribution
to
a
poet
,
who
had
made
a
copy
of
verses
upon
monkeys
,
applying
the
story
to
the
Duke
of
Marlborough
;
the
rest
gave
two
guineas
,
except
the
two
physicians
,
who
followed
my
example
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
like
this
custom
:
 
<EOS>
the
next
time
I
will
give
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
I
sat
this
evening
at
Lord
Masham
's
with
Lord
Treasurer
:
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
like
his
countenance
;
nor
I
do
n't
like
the
posture
of
things
well
.
       
<EOS>
We
can
not
be
stout
,
     
<EOS>
Till
Somerset
's
out
:
  
as
the
old
saying
is
.
  
<EOS>
11
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Lewis
and
I
dined
with
the
Chancellor
of
the
Exchequer
,
who
eats
the
most
elegantly
of
any
man
I
know
in
town
.
 
<EOS>
I
walked
lustily
in
the
Park
by
moonshine
till
eight
,
to
shake
off
my
dinner
and
wine
;
and
then
went
to
sup
at
Mr.
Domville
's
with
Ford
,
and
stayed
till
twelve
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
told
me
to
-
day
as
a
great
secret
that
the
Duke
of
Somerset
will
be
out
soon
,
that
the
thing
is
fixed
;
but
what
shall
we
do
with
the
Duchess
?
 
<EOS>
They
say
the
Duke
will
make
her
leave
the
Queen
out
of
spite
,
if
he
be
out
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
stuck
upon
that
fear
<EOS>
a
good
while
already
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
but
Lewis
gave
me
a
letter
from
MD
,
N.25
.
 
<EOS>
O
Lord
,
I
did
not
expect
one
this
fortnight
,
faith
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
mighty
good
<EOS>
,
that
's
certain
:
 
<EOS>
but
I
wo
n't
answer
it
,
because
this
goes
to
-
morrow
,
only
what
you
say
of
the
printer
being
taken
up
;
I
value
it
not
;
all
's
safe
there
;
nor
do
I
fear
anything
,
unless
the
Ministry
be
changed
:
 
<EOS>
I
hope
that
danger
is
over
.
<EOS>
However
,
I
shall
be
in
Ireland
before
such
a
change
;
which
could
not
be
,
I
think
,
till
the
end
of
the
session
,
if
the
Whigs
'
designs
had
gone
on
.
 
<EOS>
Have
not
you
an
apron
by
Leigh
,
Madam
Stella
?
<EOS>
have
you
all
I
mentioned
in
a
former
letter
?
  
<EOS>
12
.
 
<EOS>
Morning
.
 
<EOS>
This
goes
to
-
day
as
usual
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
of
going
into
the
City
;
but
of
that
at
night
.
 
<EOS>
'
Tis
fine
moderate
weather
these
two
or
three
days
last
.
<EOS>
Farewell
,
etc
.
<EOS>
etc
.
   
<EOS>
LETTER
39
.
 
<EOS>
LONDON
,
Jan.
12,1711
-
12
.
  
<EOS>
When
I
sealed
up
my
letter
this
morning
,
I
looked
upon
myself
to
be
not
worth
a
groat
in
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
Last
night
,
after
Mr.
Ford
and
I
left
Domville
,
Ford
desired
me
to
go
with
him
for
a
minute
upon
earnest
business
,
and
then
told
me
that
both
he
and
I
were
ruined
;
for
he
had
trusted
Stratford
with
five
hundred
pounds
for
tickets
for
the
lottery
,
and
he
had
been
with
Stratford
,
who
confessed
he
had
lost
fifteen
thousand
pounds
by
Sir
Stephen
Evans
,
who
broke
last
week
;
that
he
concluded
Stratford
must
break
too
;
that
he
could
not
get
his
tickets
,
but
Stratford
made
him
several
excuses
,
which
seemed
very
blind
ones
,
etc
.
 
<EOS>
And
Stratford
had
near
four
hundred
pounds
of
mine
,
to
buy
me
five
hundred
pounds
in
the
South
Sea
Company
.
 
<EOS>
I
came
home
reflecting
a
little
;
nothing
concerned
me
but
MD
.
 
<EOS>
I
called
all
my
philosophy
and
religion
up
;
and
,
I
thank
God
,
it
did
not
keep
me
awake
beyond
my
usual
time
above
a
quarter
of
an
hour
.
 
<EOS>
This
morning
I
sent
for
Tooke
,
whom
I
had
employed
to
buy
the
stock
of
Stratford
,
and
settle
things
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
told
me
I
was
secure
;
for
Stratford
had
transferred
it
to
me
in
form
in
the
South
Sea
House
,
and
he
had
accepted
it
for
me
,
and
all
was
done
on
stamped
parchment
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
he
would
be
further
informed
;
and
at
night
sent
me
a
note
to
confirm
me
.
<EOS>
However
,
I
am
not
yet
secure
;
and
,
besides
,
am
in
pain
for
Ford
,
whom
I
first
brought
acquainted
with
Stratford
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
in
the
City
.
  
<EOS>
13
.
 
<EOS>
Domville
and
I
dined
with
Ford
to
-
day
by
appointment
:
 
the
Lord
Mansel
told
me
at
Court
to
-
day
that
I
was
engaged
to
him
;
but
Stratford
had
promised
Ford
to
meet
him
and
me
to
-
night
at
Ford
's
lodgings
.
 
<EOS>
He
did
so
;
said
he
had
hopes
to
save
himself
in
his
affair
with
Evans
.
 
<EOS>
Ford
asked
him
for
his
tickets
:
 
<EOS>
he
said
he
would
send
them
tomorrow
;
but
looking
in
his
pocket
-
book
,
said
he
believed
he
had
some
of
them
about
him
,
and
gave
him
as
many
as
came
to
two
hundred
pounds
,
which
rejoiced
us
much
;
besides
,
he
talked
so
frankly
,
that
we
might
think
there
is
no
danger
.
 
<EOS>
I
asked
him
,
Was
there
any
more
to
be
settled
between
us
in
my
affair
?
 
<EOS>
He
said
,
No
;
and
answered
my
questions
just
as
Tooke
had
got
them
from
others
;
so
I
hope
I
am
safe
.
 
<EOS>
This
has
been
a
scurvy
affair
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
Stella
would
have
half
laughed
at
me
,
to
see
a
suspicious
fellow
like
me
overreached
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
Prince
Eugene
to
-
day
at
Court
:
I
do
n't
think
him
an
ugly
-
faced
fellow
,
but
well
enough
,
and
a
good
shape
.
  
<EOS>
14
.
 
<EOS>
The
Parliament
was
to
sit
to
-
day
,
and
met
;
but
were
adjourned
by
the
Queen
's
directions
till
Thursday
.
 
<EOS>
She
designs
to
make
some
important
speech
then
.
 
<EOS>
She
pretended
illness
;
but
I
believe
they
were
not
ready
,
and
they
expect
some
opposition
:
 
and
the
Scotch
lords
are
angry
,
and
must
be
pacified
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this
morning
to
invite
the
Duke
of
Ormond
to
our
Society
on
Thursday
,
where
he
is
then
to
be
introduced
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
appointed
me
at
twelve
to
-
morrow
about
some
business
:
 
<EOS>
I
would
fain
have
his
help
to
impeach
a
certain
lord
;
but
I
doubt
we
shall
make
nothing
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
intended
to
have
dined
with
Lord
Treasurer
,
but
I
was
told
he
would
be
busy
:
 
<EOS>
so
I
dined
with
Mrs.
Van
;
and
at
night
I
sat
with
Lord
Masham
till
one
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
was
there
,
and
chid
me
for
not
dining
with
him
:
 
<EOS>
he
was
in
very
good
humour
.
 
<EOS>
I
brought
home
two
flasks
of
burgundy
in
my
chair
:
 
<EOS>
I
wish
MD
had
them
.
 
<EOS>
You
see
it
is
very
late
;
so
I
'll
go
to
bed
,
and
bid
MD
good
night
.
  
<EOS>
15
.
 
<EOS>
This
morning
I
presented
my
printer
and
bookseller
to
Lord
Rivers
,
to
be
stationers
to
the
Ordnance
;
stationers
,
that
's
the
word
;
I
did
not
write
it
plain
at
first
.
<EOS>
I
believe
it
will
be
worth
three
hundred
pounds
a
year
between
them
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
the
third
employment
I
have
got
for
them
.
 
<EOS>
Rivers
told
them
the
Doctor
commanded
him
,
and
he
durst
not
refuse
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
have
dined
with
Lord
Treasurer
to
-
day
again
,
but
Lord
Mansel
would
not
let
me
,
and
forced
me
home
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
very
deep
with
the
Duke
of
Ormond
to
-
day
at
the
Cockpit
,
where
we
met
to
be
private
;
but
I
doubt
I
can
not
do
the
mischief
I
intended
.
<EOS>
My
friend
Penn
came
there
,
Will
Penn
the
Quaker
,
at
the
head
of
his
brethren
,
to
thank
the
Duke
for
his
kindness
to
their
people
in
Ireland
.
 
<EOS>
To
see
a
dozen
scoundrels
with
their
hats
on
,
and
the
Duke
complimenting
with
his
off
,
was
a
good
sight
enough
.
 
<EOS>
I
sat
this
evening
with
Sir
William
Robinson
,
who
has
mighty
often
invited
me
to
a
bottle
of
wine
:
 
<EOS>
and
it
is
past
twelve
.
  
<EOS>
16
.
 
<EOS>
This
being
fast
-
day
,
Dr.
Freind
and
I
went
into
the
City
to
dine
late
,
like
good
fasters
.
 
<EOS>
My
printer
and
bookseller
want
me
to
hook
in
another
employment
for
them
in
the
Tower
,
because
it
was
enjoyed
before
by
a
stationer
,
although
it
be
to
serve
the
Ordnance
with
oil
,
tallow
,
etc
.
,
and
is
worth
four
hundred
pounds
per

more
:
 
I
will
try
what
I
can
do
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
resolved
to
ask
several
other
employments
of
the
same
nature
to
other
offices
;
and
I
will
then
grease
fat
sows
,
and
see
whether
it
be
possible
to
satisfy
them
.
 
<EOS>
Why
am
not
I
a
stationer
?
 
<EOS>
The
Parliament
sits
to
-
morrow
,
and
Walpole
,
late
Secretary
at
War
,
is
to
be
swinged
for
bribery
,
and
the
Queen
is
to
communicate
something
of
great
importance
to
the
two
Houses
,
at
least
they
say

.
 
<EOS>
But
I
must
think
of
answering
your
letter
in
a
day
or
two
.
  
<EOS>
17
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
this
morning
to
the
Duke
of
Ormond
about
some
business
,
and
he
told
me
he
could
not
dine
with
us
today
,
being
to

Prince
Eugene
.
<EOS>
Those
of

of
the
House

could

,
the
House
sitting
late
on

.
 
<EOS>
I
left

at
nine
,
and
they
were
not

.
 
<EOS>
We
kept
some

for
them
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
Walpole
will
be
sent
to
the
Tower
,
and
expelled
the
House
;
but
this
afternoon
the
members
I
spoke
with
in
the
Court
of
Requests
talked
dubiously
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
will
be
a
leading
card
to
maul
the
Duke
of
Marlborough
for
the
same
crime
,
or
at
least

censure

.
 
<EOS>
The
Queen
's
message
was
only
to
give

of
the
peace
she
is
treating
,
and
to
desire

will
make
some
law
to

against

Government
;
so
farewell
to
Grub
Street
.
  
<EOS>
18
.
 
<EOS>
I
heard
to
-
day
that
the
commoners
of
our
Society
did
not
leave
the
Parliament
till
eleven
at

,
then
went
to
those
I
left
,
and
stayed
till
three
in

morning
.
 
<EOS>
Walpole
is
expelled
,
and
sent
to
the
Tower
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this
morning
again
with
Lord
Rivers
,
and
have
made

give
the
other
employment
to
my
printer
and
bookseller
;
'
tis
worth
a
great
deal
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
my
friend
Lewis
privately
,
to
talk
over
affairs
.
 
<EOS>
We
want
to
have
this
Duke
of
Somerset
out
,
and
he
apprehends
it
will
not
be
,
but
I
hope
better
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
going
now
at
last
to
change
the
Commissioners
of
the
Customs
;
my
friend
Sir
Matthew
Dudley
will
be
out
,
and
three
more
,
and
Prior
will
be
in
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
made
Ford
copy
out
a
small
pamphlet
,
and
sent
it
to
the
press
,
that
I
might
not
be
known
for
author
;
'
tis
A
Letter
to
the
October
Club
,
if
ever
you
heard

such

.
 
<EOS>
Methinks
this
letter
goes
on
but
slowly
for
almost
a
week
:
 
<EOS>
I
want
some
little
conversation
with
MD
,
and
to
know
what
they
are
doing
just
now
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sick
of
politics
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
dined
with
Lord
Treasurer
these
three
weeks
:
he
chides
me
,
but
I
do
n't
care
:
 
I
do
n't
.
  
<EOS>
19
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
with
Lord
Treasurer
:
 
<EOS>
this
is
his
day
of
choice
company
,
where
they
sometimes
admit
me
,
but
pretend
to
grumble
.
 
<EOS>
And
to
-
day
they
met
on
some
extraordinary
business
;
the
Keeper
,
Steward
,
both
Secretaries
,
Lord
Rivers
,
and
Lord
Anglesea
:
 
<EOS>
I
left
them
at
seven
,
and
came
away
,
and
have
been

to
the
Bishop
of
Clogher
.
 
<EOS>
I
forgot
to
know
where
to
direct

him
since
Sir
George
St.
George
's
death
,
but
I
have
directed
to
the
same
house
<EOS>
:
you
must
tell
me
better
,
for
the
letter
is
sent
by
the
bellman
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
write
to
me
again
till
this
is
gone
,
I
charge
you
,
for
I
wo
n't
answer
two
letters
together
.
 
<EOS>
The
Duke
of
Somerset
is
out
,
and
was
with
his
yellow
liveries
at
Parliament
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
he
had
the
same
with
the
Queen
,
when
he
was
Master
of
the
Horse
:
 
<EOS>
we
hope
the
Duchess
will
follow
,
or
that
he
will
take
her
away
in

.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
,
I
hope
,
has
now
saved
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
Has
the
Dean
received
my
letter
?
<EOS>
ask
him
at
cards
to
-
night
.
  
<EOS>
20
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
world
of
people
to
-
day
at
Court
to
see
Prince
Eugene
,
but
all
bit
,
for
he
did
not
come
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
the
Duchess
of
Somerset
talking
with
the
Duke
of
Buckingham
;
she
looked
a
little
down
,
but
was
extremely

.
 
<EOS>
The
Queen
has
the
gout
,
but
is
not
in
much
pain
.
 
<EOS>
Must
I
fill
this
line
too
?
<EOS>
well
then
,
so
let
it
be
.
 
<EOS>
The
Duke
of
Beaufort
has
a
mighty
mind
to
come
into
our
Society
;
shall
we
let
him
?
 
<EOS>
I
spoke
to
the
Duke
of
Ormond
about
it
,
and
he
doubts
a
little
whether
to
let
him
in
or
no
.
 
<EOS>
They
say
the
Duke
of
Somerset
is
advised
by
his
friends
to
let
his
wife
stay
with
the
Queen
;
I
am
sorry
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
the
Secretary
to
-
day
,
with
mixed
company
;
I
do
n't
love
it
.
 
<EOS>
Our
Society
does
not
meet
till
Friday
,
because
Thursday
will
be
a
busy
day
in
the
House
of
Commons
,
<EOS>
for

the
Duke
of
Marlborough
's

is
to

examined
into
about
the
pension
paid
him
by
those
that
furnished
bread
to
the

.
  
<EOS>
21
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
five
times
with
the
Duke
of
Ormond
about
a
perfect
trifle
,
and
he
forgets
it
:
 
<EOS>
I
used
him
like
a
dog
this
morning
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
asked
to
-
day
by
several
in
the
Court
of

whether
it
was
true
that
the
author
of
the
Examiner
was

an

by
the
Duke
of
Marlborough
?
 
<EOS>
I
dined
in
the
City
,
where
my

a

,
called
Advice
to
the
October
Club
,
which
he
said
was
sent
him
by

:
 
<EOS>
I
commended
it
mightily
;
he
never
suspected
me
;
'
tis
a
twopenny
pamphlet
.
 
<EOS>
I
came
home
and
got
timely
to
bed
;
but
about
eleven
one
of
the
Secretary
's
servants
came
to
me
to
let
me
know
that
Lord
Treasurer
would
immediately

me
at
Lord
Masham
's
upon
earnest
business
,
and
that
,
if
I
was
abed
,
I
should
rise
and

.
 
<EOS>
I
did
so
:
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
was
above
with
the
Queen
;
and
when
he
came
down
he
laughed
,
and
said
it
was
not
he
that
sent
for
me
:
 
<EOS>
the
business
was
of
no
great
importance
,
only
to
give
me
a
paper
,
which
might
have

done
to
-

.
 
<EOS>
I
stayed
with
them
till
past
one
,
and
then
got
to
bed
again
.
 
<EOS>
Pize
take
their
frolics
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
to
have
answered
your
letter
.
  
<EOS>
22
.
 
<EOS>
Dr.
Gastrell
was
to

me
this
morning
:
 
<EOS>
he
is
an
eminent
divine
,
one
of
the
canons
of
Christ
Church
,
and
one
I
love
very

:
 
<EOS>
he
said

was

was
not
with
James
Broad
.
 
<EOS>
I

what

.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
"

,
"

not

Grub

,

Dr.
Swift
was

,

,

?
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>

;
but

twenty

.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Lansdowne
observed
to

that
the
Whigs
spread
three

yesterday
;
that
about

;
and

,
that
Maccartney
,

,

;

,

Jack

's

,

.
 
<EOS>
Lansdowne
thinks

have
some

by
these

;
I
can
not

.
 
<EOS>
Did
I
tell

that
Sacheverell
has
desired
mightily
to
come
and
see

?
<EOS>
but
I
have
put

off
:
 
<EOS>
he

in

a

,

.
 
<EOS>
T'other

Dr.
Yalden
saluted

by

:
 
<EOS>
Sacheverell
,
who
was
just
by
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Last

to

for
that

Sacheverell
's
:
 
he
said

,
but

for

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
that

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

the

,
left

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
23
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined

the

,
but

I

,

upon

,
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
The
Minister
's

that
the
Duke
of
Marlborough
shall
be
censured
as
gently
as

,
provided

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
A

,

just

,

he
is
much

,
and
fallen

;
but

,
if

but
ten

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Solomon
Medina
paid
him
six

a

to

of

,

.
<EOS>
I

to

:

,

:
 
<EOS>
they

commended

to

,

,

health

.
 
<EOS>
But

;

,
"
This

Davenant
's

,
"
which

ca

.
 
<EOS>
But

.
 
<EOS>
Lord

put

in

to

.
 
<EOS>
I
'll

.
  
<EOS>
24
.
 
<EOS>
The
Secretary

,

:
 
<EOS>
I

;
but
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

Domville
and

;
I

.
<EOS>
At

this

went

Secretary
,
but

:
 
<EOS>
I

,

;
and

,

,

;

<EOS>

,

;

<EOS>
It

late
,

.
  
<EOS>
25
.
 
<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

the

<EOS>

<EOS>
let

see
 
The
box
at

;
<EOS>
oh
,

,

;
I

who
went

last

,
but
I
am

.
 
<EOS>
No
,
I
was
not

;
you
see
what

the

has

at
to

.
<EOS>
And
that
Duchess
is
not

,
and

more

.
<EOS>
Somerset
shows
all
about
a

from

Queen
,
desiring

to

wife
continue

her
.
 
<EOS>
Is
not
that
rare
!
 
<EOS>
I
find
Dingley
smelled
a
rat
;
because
the
Whigs
are
UPISH
;
<EOS>
but
if
ever
I
hear
that
word
again
,
I
'll
UPPISH
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
glad
you
got
your
rasp
safe
and
sound
;
does
Stella
like
her
apron
?
 
<EOS>
Your
critics
about
guarantees
of
succession
are
puppies
;
that
's
an
answer
to
the

.
 
<EOS>
The
answerers
here
made
the
same
objection
,
but
it
is
wholly
wrong
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
of
your
opinion
that
Lord
Marlborough
is
used
too
hardly
:
 
<EOS>
I
have
often
scratched
out

from
papers
and

<EOS>
sent

,
before

were

,

.
 
<EOS>
But
he
is

a
vile
man
,
and
has
no

merit
beside

.
 
<EOS>
The
Examiners
are
good
for
little
:
 
I
would
fain
have
hindered

severity
of
the
two

last
,
but

not
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
either
bring
your

over
,
or
leave

Tooke
,
for
whose

I
will
engage
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
think
it
is
best
not
to
venture

with
me
at
sea
.
 
<EOS>
Stella
is
a
prophet
,
by
foretelling
so
very
positively
that
all
would
be
well
.
 
<EOS>
Duke
of
Ormond
speak
against
peace
?
 
<EOS>
No
,
simpleton
,
he
is
one
of
the
staunchest
we
have
for
the
Ministry
.
 
<EOS>
Neither
trouble
yourself
about
the
printer
:
 
<EOS>
he
appeared
the
first
day
of
the
term
,
and
is
to
appear
when
summoned
again
;
but
nothing
else
will
come
of

.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Chief
-
Justice
is
cooled
since
this
new
settlement
.
 
<EOS>
No
<EOS>
;
I
will
not
split
my
journals
in
half
;
I
will
write
but
once
a
fortnight
:
 
<EOS>
but
you
may
do
as
you
will
;
which
is
,
read
only
half
at
once
,
and
t'other
half
next

.
 
<EOS>
So
now

letter
is
answered
.
 
<EOS>
(
P
#
#
#
#
on

.
)
 
<EOS>
What

?
 
<EOS>
I
will

out
in

,
if

fine

;
unless

,

;
but

:
 
for
I
suppose

peace

made
,

service
for

.
 
<EOS>
I
must
make
my
canal
fine
this
summer
,
as
fine
as
I
can
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
I
shall
see
great
neglects
among

quicksets
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
the
cherry
-
trees
on
the
river
walk
are
fine
things
now
.
 
<EOS>
But
no
more
of
this
.
  
<EOS>
26
.
 
<EOS>
I
forgot

this

,
and
am

<EOS>
so
late
I
must

to

;

,

.

,

40
.
 
<EOS>
LONDON
,
Jan.
26
,
1711
-
12
.
  
<EOS>
I
have
no
gilt
paper
left
of
this
size
,
so
you
must
be
content
with
plain
.
<EOS>
Our
Society
dined
together
today
,
for
it
was
put
off
,
as
I
told
you
,
upon
Lord
Marlborough
's
business
on
Thursday
.
 
<EOS>
The
Duke
of
Ormond
dined
with
us
to
-
day
,
the
first
time
:
 
<EOS>
we
were
thirteen
at
table
;
and
Lord
Lansdowne
came
in
after
dinner
,
so
that
we
wanted
but
three
.
 
<EOS>
The
Secretary
proposed
the
Duke
of
Beaufort
,
who
desires
to
be
one
of
our
Society
;
but
I
stopped
it
,
because
the
Duke
of
Ormond
doubts
a
little
about
it
;
and
he
was
gone
before
it
was
proposed
.
 
<EOS>
I
left
them
at
seven
,
and
sat
this
evening
with
poor
Mrs.
Wesley
,
who
has
been
mightily
ill
to
-
day
with
a
fainting
fit
;
she
has
often
convulsions
,
too
:
 
<EOS>
she
takes
a
mixture
with
asafoetida
,
which
I
have
now
in
my
nose
,
and
everything
smells
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
smelt
it
before
;
'
tis
abominable
.
<EOS>
We
have
eight
packets
,
they
say
,
due
from
Ireland
.
  
<EOS>
27
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
see
Prince
Eugene
at
Court
to
-
day
,
the
crowd
was
so
great
.
<EOS>
The
Whigs
contrive
to
have
a
crowd
always
about
him
,
and
employ
the
rabble
to
give
the
word
,
when
he
sets
out
from
any
place
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
Duchess
of
Hamilton
came
from
the
Queen
after
church
,
she
whispered
me
that
she
was
going
to
pay
me
a
visit
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
to
Lady
Oglethorpe
's
,
the
place
appointed
;
for
ladies
always
visit
me
in
third
places
;
and
she
kept
me
till
near
four
:
 
<EOS>
she
talks
too
much
,
is
a
plaguy
detractor
,
and
I
believe
I
shall
not
much
like
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
engaged
to
dine
with
Lord
Masham
:
 
<EOS>
they
stayed
as
long
as
they
could
,
yet
had
almost
dined
,
and
were
going
in
anger
to
pull
down
the
brass
peg
for
my
hat
,
but
Lady
Masham
saved
it
.
 
<EOS>
At
eight
I
went
again
to
Lord
Masham
's
;
Lord
Treasurer
is
generally
there
at
night
:
 
<EOS>
we
sat
up
till
almost
two
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
has
engaged
me
to
contrive
some
way
to
keep
the
Archbishop
of
York
from
being
seduced
by
Lord
Nottingham
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
do
what
I
can
in
it
to
-
morrow
.
'
<EOS>
Tis
very
late
,
so
I
must
go
sleep
.
  
<EOS>
28
.
 
<EOS>
Poor
Mrs.
Manley
,
the
author
,
is
very
ill
of
a
dropsy
and
sore
leg
:
 
<EOS>
the
printer
tells
me
he
is
afraid
she
can
not
live
long
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
heartily
sorry
for
her
:
 
<EOS>
she
has
very
generous
principles
for
one
of
her
sort
,
and
a
great
deal
of
good
sense
and
invention
:
 
<EOS>
she
is
about
forty
,
very
homely
,
and
very
fat
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Van
made
me
dine
with
her
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this
morning
with
the
Duke
of
Ormond
and
the
Prolocutor
about
what
Lord
Treasurer
spoke
to
me
yesterday
;
I
know
not
what
will
be
the
issue
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
but
a
slender
majority
in
the
House
of
Lords
,
and
we
want
more
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
sadly
mortified
at
the
news
of
the
French
taking
the
town
in
Brazil
from
the
Portuguese
.
 
<EOS>
The
sixth
edition
of
three
thousand
of
the
Conduct
of
the
Allies
is
sold
,
and
the
printer
talks
of
a
seventh
:
 
eleven
thousand
of
them
have
been
sold
,
which
is
a
most
prodigious
run
.
 
<EOS>
The
little
twopenny
Letter
of
Advice
to
the
October
Club
does
not
sell
:
I
know
not
the
reason
,
<EOS>
for
it
is
finely
written
,
I
assure
you
;
and
,
like
a
true
author
,
I
grow
fond
of
it
,
because
it
does
not
sell
:
 
you
know
that
it
is
usual
to
writers
to
condemn
the
judgment
of
the
world
:
 
if
I
had
hinted
it
to
be
mine
,
everybody
would
have
bought
it
,
but
it
is
a
great
secret
.
  
<EOS>
29
.
 
<EOS>
I
borrowed
one
or
two
idle
books
of
Contes
des
Fees
,
and
have
been
reading
them
these
two
days
,
although
I
have
much
business
upon
my
hands
.
 
<EOS>
I
loitered
till
one
at
home
;
then
went
to
Mr.
Lewis
at
his
office
;
and
the
Vice
-
Chamberlain
told

that
Lady
Rialton
had
yesterday

of

the
bed

,
and
that
Lady
Jane
Hyde
,
Lord
Rochester
's
daughter
,
a
mighty

,
is
to

.
 
<EOS>
He
said
,
too
,
that
Lady
Sunderland
would

in
a

or

.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Lewis
,
and
then
went
to
see
Mrs.
Wesley
,
who
is
better
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
But
you
must
know
that
Mr.
Lewis
gave

two

,
one
from
the
Bishop
of
Cloyne
,
with

enclosed
from
Lord
Inchiquin
to
Lord

,
which

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
told
that
lord
was
much
in
with
Lord
Wharton
,
and
I
remember
he
was
to

Lords

;
yet
the

Church
,

.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
do
what
I
think
proper
.
 
<EOS>
T'other
letter
was
from
little
saucy
MD
,
N.26
.
 
<EOS>
O
Lord
,
never
saw
the
like
,
under
a
cover
,
too
,
and
by
way
of
journal
;
we
shall
never

.
 
<EOS>
Sirrahs
,
how
durst
you
write
so
soon
,
sirrahs
?
 
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
answer
it
yet
.
  
<EOS>
30
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this
morning
with
the
Secretary
,
who
was
sick
,
and
out
of
humour
<EOS>
:
he
would
needs
drink
champagne
some
days
ago
,
on
purpose
to

me
,
because
I
advised
him
against

,
and
now

.
 
<EOS>
Stella
used
to
do
such
tricks
formerly
;
he
put
me
in

.
 
<EOS>
Lady
Sunderland
has

place
too
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
Lady
Catherine
Hyde
that
succeeds
Lady
Rialton
,
and
not
Lady
Jane
.
 
<EOS>
Lady
Catherine
is
the
late
Earl
of
Rochester
's
daughter
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
the
Secretary
,
then
visited
his
lady
;
and
sat
this
evening
with
Lady
Masham
:
 
the

came
to

;
but
Lord
Treasurer
did

;

the

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
Our
Society
does
not

till
to
-
morrow
se'nnight
,
because
we
think
the
Parliament
will
be
very

to
-

upon
the
state

the
war
,
and
the
Secretary
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
fancy

of
persons
and
things
here
<EOS>
must
be
very

to
you
,
because
you
know
nothing
of

,
and
I
talk

.
 
<EOS>
You
know
Kevin
's

,

Werburgh
Street
,
<EOS>
and
(

?
)
<EOS>

,

,

;

?
 
<EOS>
Why

,

?
 
<EOS>
I

it
is
well
.
  
<EOS>
31
.
 
<EOS>
Trimnel
,
Bishop
of
Norwich
,
who
was
with
this
Lord

at
Moor

in

,

the
House

Lords
;
and
to
-

the

was

to

,
and
print

;
but
passed
against

;
for

was
a

Whig
sermon
.
 
<EOS>
The
Bill
to
repeal
the
Act
for
naturalising
Protestant
foreigners
passed
the
House
of
Lords
to
-
day
by
a

twenty
,
though

Scotch
lords
went
out
,
and
would
vote
neither

,
in

about
the
Duke
of
Hamilton
's
patent
,
if
you
know
anything
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
A
poem
is
come
out
to
-
day
inscribed
to
me
,
by
way
of
a
flirt
;
for
it
is
a
Whiggish
poem
,
and
good
for
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
They
plagued
me
with
it
in
the
Court
of
Requests
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Lord
Treasurer
at
five
alone
,
only

Dutchman
.
 
<EOS>
Prior
is
now
a
Commissioner
of

Customs
.
 
<EOS>
I
told

so
before
,
I
suppose
.
 
<EOS>
When

to
-

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Lord

sent

about

:
 
<EOS>
so
good
<EOS>
a

was
I
,

.
  
<EOS>
Feb.
1
.
 
<EOS>
Has
not

of

Patrick
received

?
<EOS>
you
say
nothing
of
it
,
although

writ
above

.
 
<EOS>
My

has
got

,
and
I
was
forced
to
go
to
him
to
-
day
,

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
most

day
:
 
<EOS>
why
do

observe
whether
the
same
days
be
fine

?
 
<EOS>
To

,

six
,

,

,

,

,

,

:
 
there
<EOS>
we

till

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
here
take

to
tell

Dingley
that
the

in
the
Conduct
of
the
Allies
is
so
far

that

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

;
but

:
 
'

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

;

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
2
.
 
<EOS>
This
ends
Christmas
,
and
what
care
I
?
 
<EOS>
I
have
neither
seen
,
nor
felt
,
nor
heard
any
Christmas
this
year
.
 
<EOS>
I
passed
a
lazy
dull
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this
morning
with
Lord
Treasurer
,
to
get
some
papers
from
him
,
which
he
will
remember
as
much
as
a
cat
,
although
it
be
his
own
business
.
 
<EOS>
It
threatened
rain
,
but
did
not
much
;
and
Prior
and
I
walked
an
hour
in
the
Park
,
which
quite
put
me
out
of
my
measures
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
a
friend
hard
by
;
and
in
the
evening
sat
with
Lord
Masham
till
twelve
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
did
not
come
;
this
is
an
idle
dining
-
day
usually
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
We
want
to
hear
from
Holland
how
our
peace
goes
on
;
for
we
are
afraid
of
those
scoundrels
the
Dutch
,
lest
they
should
play
us
tricks
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Mar
,
a
Scotch
earl
,
was
with
us
at
Lord
Masham
's
:
 
<EOS>
I
was
arguing
with
him
about
the
stubbornness
and
folly
of
his
countrymen
;
they
are
so
angry
about
the
affair
of
the
Duke
of
Hamilton
,
whom
the
Queen
has
made
a
duke
of
England
,
and
the
House
of
Lords
will
not
admit
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
swears
he
would
vote
for
us
,
but
dare
not
,
because
all
Scotland
would
detest
him
if
he
did
:
 
he
should
never
be
chosen
again
,
nor
be
able
to
live
there
.
  
<EOS>
3
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
at
Court
to
-
day
to
look
for
a
dinner
,
but
did
not
like
any
that
were
offered
me
;
and
I
dined
with
Lord
Mountjoy
.
 
<EOS>
The
Queen
has
the
gout
in
her
knee
,
and
was
not
at
chapel
.
 
<EOS>
I
hear
we
have
a
Dutch
mail
,
but
<EOS>
I
know
not
what
news
,
although
I
was
with
the
Secretary
this

.
 
<EOS>
He
showed
me
a
letter
from
the
Hanover
Envoy
,
Mr.
Bothmar
,
complaining
that
the
Barrier
Treaty
is
laid

House

;
and

may

made
in
the

of
the

;
but

has

.
 
<EOS>
I
fancy
<EOS>
you
understand
all
this
,
and
are
able
states
-
girls
,
since
you
have
read
the
Conduct
of
the
Allies
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
all
preparing
against
the
Birthday
;
I
think
it
is
Wednesday
next
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
Queen
's
gout
increases
,
it
will
spoil
sport
.
 
<EOS>
Prince
Eugene
has
two
fine
suits
made
against
it
;
and
the
Queen
is
to
give
him
a
sword
worth
four
thousand
pounds
,
the
diamonds
set
transparent
.
  
<EOS>
4
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this
morning
soliciting
at
the
House
of
Commons
'
door
for
Mr.
Vesey
,
a
son
of
the
Archbishop
of
Tuam
,
who
has

for

Bill
to

in
some

about
