:
 
<EOS>
I
secured
him
above
fifty
members
.
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Lady
Masham
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
no
packet
from
Holland
,
as
I
was
told
yesterday
:
 
and
this
wind
will
hinder
many
people
from
appearing
at
the
Birthday
,
who
expected
clothes
from
Holland
.
 
<EOS>
I
appointed
to
meet
a
gentleman
at
the
Secretary
's
to
-
night
,
and
they
both
failed
.
 
<EOS>
The
House
of
Commons
have
this
day
made
many
severe
votes
about
our
being
abused
by
our
Allies
.
 
<EOS>
Those
who
spoke
drew
all
their
arguments
from
my
book
,
and
their
votes
confirm
all
I
writ
;
the
Court
had
a
majority
of
a
hundred
and
fifty
:
 
<EOS>
all
agree
that
it
was
my
book
that
spirited
them
to
these
resolutions
;
I
long
to
see
them
in
print
.
<EOS>
My
head
has
not
been
as
well
as
I
could
wish
it
for
some
days
past
,
but
I
have
not
had
any
giddy
fit
,
and
I
hope
it
will
go
over
.
  
<EOS>
5
.
 
<EOS>
The
Secretary
turned
me
out
of
his
room
this
morning
,
and
showed
me
fifty
guineas
rolled
up
,
which
he
was
going
to
give
some
French
spy
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
four
Irishmen
at
a
tavern
to
-
day
:
 
<EOS>
I
thought
I
had
resolved
against
it
before
,
but
I
broke
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
played
at
cards
this
evening
at
Lady
Masham
's
,
but
I
only
played
for
her
while
she
was
waiting
;
and
I
won
her
a
pool
,
and
supped
there
.
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
was
with
us
,
but
went
away
before
twelve
.
 
<EOS>
The
ladies
and
lords
have
all
their
clothes
ready
against
to
-
morrow
:
 
<EOS>
I
saw
several
mighty
fine
,
and
I
hope
there
will
be
a
great
appearance
,
in
spite
of
that
spiteful
French
fashion
of
the
Whiggish
ladies
not
to
come
,
which
they
have
all
resolved
to
a
woman
;
and
I
hope
it
will
more
spirit
the
Queen
against
them
for
ever
.
  
<EOS>
6
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
to
dine
at
Lord
Masham
's
at
three
,
and
met
all
the
company
just
coming
out
of
Court
;
a
mighty
crowd
:
 
<EOS>
they
stayed
long
for
their
coaches
:
 
<EOS>
I
had
an
opportunity
of
seeing
several
lords
and
ladies
of
my
acquaintance
in
their
fineries
.
 
<EOS>
Lady
Ashburnham
looked
the
best
in
my
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
They
say
the
Court
was
never
fuller
nor
finer
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
,
his
lady
,
and
two
daughters
and
Mrs.
Hill
,
dined
with
Lord
and
Lady
Masham
;
the
five
ladies
were
monstrous
fine
.
 
<EOS>
The
Queen
gave
Prince
Eugene
the
diamond
sword
to
-
day
;
but
nobody
was
by
when
she
gave
it
except
my
Lord
Chamberlain
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
an
entertainment
of
opera
songs
at
night
,
and
the
Queen
was
at
all
the
entertainment
,
and
is
very
well
after
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
Lady
Wharton
,
as
ugly
as
the
devil
,
coming
out
in
the
crowd
all
in
an
undress
;
she
has
been
with
the
Marlborough
daughters
and
Lady
Bridgewater
in
St.
James
's
,
looking
out
of
the
window
<EOS>
all
undressed
to
see
the
sight
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
not
hear
that
one
Whig
lady
was
there
,
except
those
of
the
bed
-
chamber
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
has
made
so
great
a
noise
as
one
Kelson
's
chariot
,
that
cost
nine
hundred
and
thirty
pounds
,
the
finest
was
ever
seen
.
 
<EOS>
The
rabble
huzzaed
him
as
much
as
they
did
Prince
Eugene
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
Birthday
chat
.
  
<EOS>
7
.
 
<EOS>
Our
Society
met
to
-
day
:
 
<EOS>
the
Duke
of
Ormond
was
not
with
us
;
we
have
lessened
our
dinners
,
which
were
grown
so
extravagant
that
Lord
Treasurer
and
everybody
else
cried
shame
.
 
<EOS>
I
left
them
at
seven
,
visited
for
an
hour
,
and
then
came
home
,
like
a
good
boy
.
 
<EOS>
The
Queen
is
much
better
after
yesterday
's
exercise
:
 
<EOS>
her
friends
wish
she
would
use
a
little
more
.
 
<EOS>
I
opposed
Lord
Jersey
's
election
into
our
Society
,
and
he
is
refused
:
 
<EOS>
I
likewise
opposed
the
Duke
of
Beaufort
;
but
I
believe
he
will
be
chosen
in
spite
of
me
:
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
much
care
<EOS>
;
I
shall
not
be
with
them
above
two
months
;
for
I
resolve
to
set
out
for
Ireland
the
beginning
of
April
next
(
before
I
treat

again
)
,
and
see
my
willows
.
  
<EOS>
8
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-

in
the
City
.
 
<EOS>
This
morning
a
scoundrel
dog
,
one
of
the
Queen
's
music
,
a
German
,
whom
I

never

,

Patrick
's

,

to

in

,

;
and

to

,

:
 
<EOS>
I
used
him
civiller
than

;
but
it
vexed

to
the

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
told
I
had
a
mighty
interest
with
Lord
Treasurer
,
and
one

of

,
etc
.
<EOS>
Well
;
I
got

MD
's

,
N.26
;
for
this

to
-

.
 
<EOS>
Well
;
I
never
saw
such

in

;
so
saucy
,
<EOS>
so
journalish
,
so

,
<EOS>
so

,
so
everything
.
 
<EOS>
I
satisfied
all
your
fears
in
my
last
:
 
<EOS>
all
is
gone
well
,
as
you
say
;
yet
you
are
an
impudent
slut
to
be
so
positive
;
you
will
swagger
so
upon
your
sagacity
that
we
shall
never
have
done
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
do
n't
mislay
your
reply
;
I
would
certainly
print
it
,
if
I
had
it
here
:
 
<EOS>
how
long
is
it
?
<EOS>
I
suppose
half
a
sheet
:
 
was
the
answer
written
in
Ireland
?
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
,
you
shall
have
a
letter
when
you
come
from
Ballygall
.
 
<EOS>
I
need
not
tell
you
again
who
's
out
and
who
's
in
:
 
we
can
never

out
the
Duchess

Somerset
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
they
say
Presto
writ
the

,

.
 
<EOS>
Do

?
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't

;
but
the

printed
t'other

in
the
Votes
are
almost
quotations
from

,
and

never

passed

.
 
<EOS>
I

not

the
Spectator
,
let

fair
-
sex

's
end
.
 
<EOS>
My
disorder
is
over
,
but
blood
was
not
from
the
p
-
les
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
Madam
Dingley
,
the
frost
;
why
,

,
but
I

;
it

:
 
<EOS>
I

;
but

,

;

<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>

;

:
 
<EOS>

;

.
 
<EOS>
Well
;
I

do
Mr.
Manley
all

;
but
he
will

.
 
<EOS>
What
business

to
engage
at
all
about

City
?
 
<EOS>
Ca
n't
he
wish
his
cause
well
,
and

,
when

finds
that
stirring
will
do

no

,

a

?
 
<EOS>
I

not

:
 
<EOS>
it

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
So

.
 
<EOS>

Catherine
<EOS>
;

.

9
.
 
<EOS>
Morning
.
 
<EOS>
My

;

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
They

way
of

,
that
peace
is
very
near

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>

,

;

.

,

.

.
 
<EOS>
LONDON
,

,
1711
-
12
.
  
<EOS>
When
my
letter
is
gone
,
and
I
have
none
of
yours
to
answer
,
my
conscience
is
so
clear
,
and
my
shoulder
so
light
,
and
I
go
on
with
such
courage
to
prate
upon
nothing
to
deerichar
MD
,
oo
would
wonder
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Sir
Matthew
Dudley
,
who
is
newly
turned
out
of
Commission
of
the
Customs
.
 
<EOS>
He
affects
a
good
heart
,
and
talks
in
the
extremity
of
Whiggery
,
which
was
always
his
principle
,
though
he
was
gentle
a
little
,
while
he
kept
in
employment
.
 
<EOS>
We
can
yet
get
no
packets
from
Holland
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
been
with
any
of
the
Ministry
these
two
or
three
days
.
 
<EOS>
I
keep
out
of
their
way
on
purpose
,
for
a
certain
reason
,
for
some
time
,
though
I
must
dine
with
the
Secretary
to
-
morrow
,
the
choosing
of
the
company
being
left
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
engaged
Lord
Anglesea
and
Lord
Carteret
,
and
have
promised
to
get
three
more
;
but
I
have
a
mind
that
none
else
should
be
admitted
:
 
however
,
if
I
like
anybody
at
Court
to
-
morrow
,
I
may
perhaps
invite
them
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
got
another
cold
,
but
not
very
bad
.
 
<EOS>
Nite
.
.
.
<EOS>
MD
.
  
<EOS>
10
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
Prince
Eugene
at
Court
to
-
day
very
plain
;
he
's
plaguy
yellow
,
and
tolerably
ugly
besides
.
 
<EOS>
The
Court
was
very
full
,
and
people
had
their
Birthday
clothes
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
the
Secretary
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
to
invite
five
,
but
I
only
invited
two
,
Lord
Anglesea
and
Lord
Carteret
.
 
<EOS>
Pshaw
,
I
told
you
this
but
yesterday
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
no
packets
from
Holland
yet
.
 
<EOS>
Here
are
a
parcel
of
drunken
Whiggish
lords
,
like
your
Lord
Santry
,
who
come
into
chocolate
-
houses
and
rail
aloud
at
the
Tories
,
and
have
challenges
sent
them
,
and
the
next
morning
come
and
beg
pardon
.
 
<EOS>
General
Ross
was
like
to
swinge
the
Marquis
of
Winchester
for
this
trick
t'other
day
;
and
we
have
nothing
else
now
to
talk
of
till
the
Parliament
has
had
another
bout
with
the
state
of
the
war
,
as
they
intended
in
a
few
days
.
 
<EOS>
They
have
ordered
the
Barrier
Treaty
to
be
laid
before
them
;
and
it
was
talked
some
time
ago
,
as
if
there
was
a
design
to
impeach
Lord
Townshend
,
who
made
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
more
politics
now
.
 
<EOS>
Nite
dee
MD
.
  
<EOS>
11
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Lord
Anglesea
to
-
day
,
who
had
seven
Irishmen
to
be
my

,
of
which
two
only
were
coxcombs
;
one
I
did
not
know
,
and
t'other
was
young
Blith
,
who
is
a
puppy
of
figure
here
,
with
a
fine
chariot
.
 
<EOS>
He
asked
me
one
day
at
Court
,
when
I
had

just

with
some
lords
who
stood
near

,
"
Doctor
,
when
shall
we
see

in

Meath
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
I
whispered
him
to
take

what

said
,
for
the
people
would
think
he
was
some

.
 
<EOS>
He
never

speak

me
since
,
till
we
met
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
to
Lady
Masham
's
to

,
and
sat

and

there
till

;
and

,

,

,
but

till

,
'
tis

very
late
;
but
I
must
always
be
.
.
.
<EOS>
,
late

early
.
 
<EOS>
Nite
deelest
sollahs
.
  
<EOS>
12
.
 
<EOS>
One

was
from
the
Bishop
of
Clogher
last

,
and
t'other

,
about

South
's

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

;

,

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

nothing
of
your

's

.
 
<EOS>
I

Clements
,

Lord
Anglesea
last

,

's

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

Anglesea
that
I
was
[
glad
]
<EOS>
I
had

good
luck
to

,
etc
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
in
the
City
with
my
printer
,
to
consult

him
about
some
papers
Lord
Treasurer
gave
me
last
night
,
as
he
always
does
,
too
late
;
however
,
I
will
do
something
with
them
.
 
<EOS>
My
third
cold
is
a
little
better
;
I
never
had
anything
like
it
before
,
three
colds
successively
;
I
hope
I
shall
have
the
fourth
.
 
<EOS>
Those
messengers
come
from
Holland
to
-
day
,
and
they
brought
over
the
six
packets
that
were
due
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
not
the
particulars
yet
,
for
when
I
was
with
the
Secretary
at
noon
they
were
just
opening
;
but
one
thing
I
find
,
that
the
Dutch
are
playing
us
tricks
,
and
tampering
with
the
French
;
they
are
dogs
;
I
shall
know
more
tomollow
.
<EOS>
.
.
 
<EOS>
MD
.
  
<EOS>
13
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
privately
with
my
friend
Lewis
,
at
his
lodgings
,
to
consult
about
some
observations
on
the
Barrier
Treaty
.
 
<EOS>
Our
news
from
Holland
is
not
good
.
 
<EOS>
The
French
raise
difficulties
,
and
make
such
offers
to
the
Allies
as
can
not
be
accepted
.
 
<EOS>
And
the
Dutch
are
uneasy
that
we
are
likely
to
get
anything
for
ourselves
;
and
the
Whigs
are
glad
at
all
this
.
 
<EOS>
I
came
home
early
,
and
have
been
very
busy
three
or
four
hours
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
a
letter
from
Dr.
Pratt
to
-
day
by
a
private
hand
,
recommending
the
bearer
to
me
,
for
something
that
I
shall
not
trouble
myself
about
.
 
<EOS>
Wesley
writ
to
recommend
the
same
fellow
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
His
expression
is
that
,
hearing
I
am

<EOS>
After

to

MD

I
dined
with
the
Secretary
to
-

,
who
is
much
out

order
with
a
cold
,
and
feverish
;
yet
he
went
to
the

tonight
at

,
against

.
 
<EOS>
The
Secretary
is
much
the
greatest

in
England
,
and
turns
the
whole
Parliament
,
who
can
do
nothing
without
him
;

,
I

,
be
one

at
the
head
of
affairs
.
 
<EOS>
I
have

sometimes
that
,

,
I

cultivate

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
But

oo

?

;

<EOS>
I

,

's

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

out

all
his
employments
last
year
,
and
had
about
10,000
pounds
left
to
live
on
.
 
<EOS>
Stratford
,
upon
friendship
,
desired
he
might
have
the
management
of
it
for
Meredith
,
to
put
it
into
the

for
the

,
and
now

has
lost

.
 
<EOS>
You
have

talk
of
Stratford
;
we

class

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
his

,

,

this

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
while

,
of

he

,

;

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Ford
narrowly
"

,

.

.
 
Morning
.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

brother
Sir

's

,

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
The

of
Ormond

.
 
<EOS>
Brother
Wyndham
gave
6,000

but

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

's

;
<EOS>
you

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Mr.

's

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

.
.

.
 
<EOS>
Take

,

;

,

;

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
LONDON
,
March
8
,
1711
-
12
.
  
<EOS>
I
carried
my
forty
-
second
letter
in
my
pocket
till
evening
,
and
then
put
it
in
the
general
post
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
in
the
morning
to
see
Lord
Treasurer
,
who
had
taken
physic
,
and
was
drinking
his
broth
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
been
with
the
Secretary
before
,
to
recommend
a
friend
,
one
Dr.
Freind
,
to
be
Physician
-
General
;
and
the
Secretary
promised
to
mention
it
to
the
Queen
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
serve
everybody
but
myself
.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
went
to
Court
,
and
carried
Lord
Keeper
and
the
Secretary
to
dine
with
Lord
Masham
,
when
we
drank
the
Queen
and
Lord
Treasurer
with
every
health
,
because
this
was
the
day
of
his
stabbing
.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
went
and
played
pools
at
picquet
with
Lady
Masham
and
Mrs.
Hill
;
won
ten
shillings
,
gave
a
crown
to
the
box
,
and
came
home
.
 
<EOS>
I
met
at
my
lodgings
a
letter
from
Joe
,
with
a
bit
annexed
from
Ppt
.
 
<EOS>
What
Joe
asks
is
entirely
out
of
my
way
,
and
I
take
it
for
a
foolish
whim
in
him
.
 
<EOS>
Besides
,
I
know
not
who
is
to
give
a
patent
:
if
the
Duke
of
Ormond
,
I
would
speak
to
him
;
and
if
it
come
in
my
head
I
will
mention
it
to
Ned
Southwell
.
 
<EOS>
They
have
no
patents
that
I
know
of
for
such
things
here
,

next

not

,

.
 
<EOS>

?

LETTER
45
.
 
<EOS>
LONDON
,
April
24
,
1712
.
  
<EOS>
I
had
your
twenty
-
eighth
two
or
three
days
ago
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
hardly
answer
it
now
.
<EOS>
Since
my
last
I
have
been
extremely
ill
.
 
<EOS>
'
Tis
this
day
just
a
month
since
I
felt
a
small
pain
on
the
tip
of
my
left
shoulder
,
which
grew
worse
,
and
spread
for
six
days
;
then
broke
all
out
by
my
collar
and
left
side
of
my
neck
in
monstrous
red
spots
inflamed
,
and
these
grew
to
small
pimples
.
 
<EOS>
For
four
days
I
had
no
rest
,
nor
nights
,
for
a
pain
in
my
neck
;
then
I
grew
a
little
better
;
afterward
,
where
my
pains
were
,
a
cruel
itching
seized
me
,
beyond
whatever
I
could
imagine
,
and
kept
me
awake
several
nights
.
 
<EOS>
I
rubbed
it
vehemently
,
but
did
not
scratch
it
:
 
<EOS>
then
it
grew
into
three
or
four
great
sores
like
blisters
,
and
run
;
at
last
I
advised
the
doctor
to
use
it
like
a
blister
,
so
I
did
with
melilot
plasters
,
which
still
run
:
 
and
am
now
in
pain
enough
,
but
am
daily
mending
.
 
<EOS>
I
kept
my
chamber
a
fortnight
,
then
went
out
a
day
or
two
,
but
then
confined
myself
again
.
 
<EOS>
Two
days
ago
I
went
to
a
neighbour
to
dine
,
but
yesterday
again
kept
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
To
-
day
I
will
venture
abroad
a
little
,
and
hope
to
be
well
in
a
week
or
ten
days
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
suffered
so
much
in
my
life
.
<EOS>
I
have
taken
my
breeches
in
above
two
inches
,
so
I
am
leaner
,
which
answers
one
question
in
your
letter
.
 
<EOS>
The
weather
is
mighty
fine
.
 
<EOS>
I
write
in
the
morning
,
because
I
am
better
then
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
go
and
try
to
walk
a
little
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
give
DD
's
certificate
to
Tooke
to
-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
Farewell
,
MD
MD
MD
,
ME
ME
,
FW
FW
ME
ME
.
   
<EOS>
LETTER
46
.
 
<EOS>
LONDON
,
May
10
,
1712
.
  
<EOS>
I
have
not
yet
ease
or
humour
enough
to
go
on
in
my
journal
method
,
though
I
have
left
my
chamber
these
ten
days
.
 
<EOS>
My
pain
continues
still
in
my
shoulder
and
collar
:
I
keep
flannel
on
it
,
and
rub
it
with
brandy
,
and
take
a
nasty
diet
drink
.
 
<EOS>
I
still
itch
terribly
,
and
have
some
few
pimples
;
I
am
weak
,
and
sweat
;
and
then
the
flannel
makes
me
mad
with
itching
;
but
I
think
my
pain
lessens
.
 
<EOS>
A
journal
,
while
I
was
sick
,
would
have
been
a
noble
thing
,
made
up
of
pain
and
physic
,
visits
,
and
messages
;
<EOS>
the
two
last
were
almost
as
troublesome
as
the
two
first
.
 
<EOS>
One
good
circumstance
is
that
I
am
grown
much
leaner
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
I
told
you
that
I
have
taken
in
my
breeches
two
inches
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
your
N.29
last
night
.
 
<EOS>
In
answer
to
your
good
opinion
of
my
disease
,
the
doctors
said
they
never
saw
anything
so
odd
of
the
kind
;
they
were
not
properly
shingles
,
but
herpes
miliaris
,
and
twenty
other
hard
names
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
never
be
sick
like
other
people
,
but
always
something
out
of
the
common
way
;
and
as
for
your
notion
of
its
coming
without
pain
,
it
neither
came
,
nor
stayed
,
nor
went
without
pain
,
and
the
most
pain
I
ever
bore
in
my
life
.
<EOS>
Medemeris
is
retired
in
the
country
,
with
the
beast
her
husband
,
long
ago
.
<EOS>
I
thank
the
Bishop
of
Clogher
for
his
proxy
;
I
will
write
to
him
soon
.
 
<EOS>
Here
is
Dilly
's
wife
in
town
;
but
I
have
not
seen
her
yet
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
sinkerton
:
 
'
tis
not
a
sign
of
health
,
but
a
sign
that
,
if
it
had
not
come
out
,
some
terrible
fit
of
sickness
would
have
followed
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
at
our
Society
last
Thursday
,
to
receive
a
new
member
,
the
Chancellor
of
the
Exchequer
;
but
I
drink
nothing
above
wine
and
water
.
 
<EOS>
We
shall
have
a
peace
,
I
hope
,
soon
,
or
at
least
entirely
broke
;
but
I
believe
the
first
.
 
<EOS>
My
Letter
to
Lord
Treasurer
,
about
the
English
tongue
,
is
now
printing
;
and
I
suffer
my
name
to
be
put
at
the
end
of
it
,
which
I
never
did
before
in
my
life
.
 
<EOS>
The
Appendix
to
the
Third
Part
of
John
Bull
was
published
yesterday
;
it
is
equal
to
the
rest
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
you
read
John
Bull
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
Scotch
gentleman
,
a
friend
of
mine
,
that
writ
it
;
but
they
put
it
upon
me
.
 
<EOS>
The
Parliament
will
hardly
be
up
till
June
.
 
<EOS>
We
were
like
to
be
undone
some
days
ago
with
a
tack
;
but
we
carried
it
bravely
,
and
the
Whigs

to

.
 
<EOS>
Poor
Lady
Masham
,
I

,
will

,
<EOS>
about

,

king
's
evil
.
 
<EOS>
I
never

Fenton

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
Bernage
has

of

.
<EOS>
His

,
and
he
only
upon

-

;

.
 
<EOS>
I

the

and

are

,
but

.
 
<EOS>
I

in

;

of
Hamilton
,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
to

scrub

back
against

;
and

Ormond

the

.
 
<EOS>
Many

friends
are
gone
to
Kensington
,
where
the
Queen
has
been
removed
for
some

.
 
<EOS>
This
is
a
long
letter
for
a
kick
body
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
begin

next
in
the
journal
way
,

sorry

.
 
<EOS>
My
left

is
very
weak
,
and

;
but
my
right

has
not

.
       
<EOS>
This
is
a
pitiful
letter
     
<EOS>
For

;

,

.

Ah
!

my

!

.

?
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

LETTER
47
.
 
<EOS>
LONDON
,
May
31
,
1712
.
  
<EOS>
I
can
not
yet
arrive
to
my
journal
letters
,
my
pains
continuing
still
,
though
with
less
violence
;
but
I
do
n't
love
to
write
journals
while
I
am
in
pain
;
and
above
all
,
not
journals
to
MD
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
however
,
I
am
so
much
mended
,
<EOS>
that
I
intend
my
next
<EOS>
shall
be
in
the
old
way
;
and
yet
I
shall
,
perhaps
,
break
my
resolution
when
I
feel
pain
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
I
have
lost
credit
with
you
,
in
relation
to
my
coming
over
;
but
I
protest
it
is
impossible
for
one
who
has
anything
to
do
with
this
Ministry
to
be
certain
when
he
fixes
any
time
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
a
business
which
,
till
it
take
some
turn
or
other
,
I
can
not
leave
this
place
in
prudence
or
honour
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
never
wished
so
much
as
now
that
I
had
stayed
in
Ireland
;
but
the
die
is
cast
,
and
is
now
a
spinning
,
and
till
it
settles
,
I
can
not
tell
whether
it
be
an
ace
or
a
sise
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
confident
by
what
you
know
yourselves
,
that
you
will
justify
me
in
all
this
.
 
<EOS>
The
moment
I
am
used
ill
,
I
will
leave
them
;
but
know
not
how
to
do
it
while
things
are
in
suspense
.
<EOS>
The
session
will
soon
be
over
(
I
believe
in
a
fortnight
)
,
and
the
peace
,
we
hope
,
will
be
made
in
a
short
time
;
and
there
will
be
no
further
occasion
for
me
;
nor
have
I
anything
to
trust
to
<EOS>
but
Court
gratitude
,
so
that
I
expect
to
see
my
willows
a
month
after
the
Parliament
is
up
:
 
<EOS>
but
I
will
take
MD
in
my
way
,
and
not
go
to
Laracor
like
an
unmannerly
spraenekich
ferrow
.
 
<EOS>
Have
you
seen
my
Letter
to
Lord
Treasurer
?
 
<EOS>
There
are
two
answers
come
out
to
it
already
;
though
it
is
no
politics
,
but
a
harmless
proposal
about
the
improvement
of
the
English
Tongue
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
if
I
writ
an
essay
upon
a
straw
some
fool
would
answer
it
.
 
<EOS>
About
ten
days
hence
I
expect
a
letter
from
MD
;
N.30
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
now
writing
it
,
near
the
end
,
as

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
received
DD
's
money
;
but
I
will
give
you
a
note
for
it
on
Parvisol
,
and
bed
oo
paadon
I
have
not
done
it
before
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
just
now
thinking
to
go
lodge
at
Kensington
for
the
air
.
 
<EOS>
Lady
Masham
has
teased
me
to
do
it
,
but
business
has
hindered
me
;
but
now
Lord
Treasurer
has
removed
thither
.
 
<EOS>
Fifteen
of
our
Society
dined
together
under
a
canopy
in
an
arbour
at
Parson
's
Green
last
Thursday
:
 
I
never
saw
anything
so
fine
and
romantic
.
 
<EOS>
We
got
a
great
victory
last
Wednesday
in
the
House
of
Lords
by
a
majority
,
I
think
,
of
twenty
-
eight
;
and
the
Whigs
had
desired
their
friends
to
bespeak
places
to
see
Lord
Treasurer
carried
to
the
Tower
.
 
<EOS>
I
met
your
Higgins
here
yesterday
:
he
roars
at
the
insolence
of
the
Whigs
in
Ireland
,
talks
much
of
his
own
sufferings
and
expenses
in
asserting
the
cause
of
the
Church
;
and
I
find
he
would
fain
plead
merit
enough
to
desire
that
his
fortune
should
be
mended
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
he
designs
to
make
as
much
noise
as
he
can
in
order
to
preferment
.
<EOS>
Pray
let
the
Provost
,
when
he
sees
you
,
give
you
ten
English
shillings
,
and
I
will
give
as
much
here
to
the
man
who
delivered
me
Rymer
's
books
:
 
<EOS>
he
knows
the
meaning
.
 
<EOS>
Tell
him
I
will
not
trust
him
,
but
that
you
can
order
it
to
be
paid
me
here
;
and
I
will
trust
you
till
I
see
you
.
 
<EOS>
Have
I
told
you
that
the
rogue
Patrick
has
left
me
these
two
months
,
to
my
great
satisfaction
?
 
<EOS>
I
have
got
another
,
who
seems
to
be
much
better
,
if
he
continues
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
printing
a
threepenny
pamphlet
,
and
shall
print
another
in
a
fortnight
,
and
then
I
have
done
,
unless
some
new
occasion
starts
.
 
<EOS>
Is
my
curate
Warburton
married
to
Mrs.
Melthrop
in
my
parish
?
<EOS>
so
I
hear
.
 
<EOS>
Or
is
it
a
lie
?
 
<EOS>
Has
Raymond
got
to
his
new
house
?
 
<EOS>
Do
you
see
Joe
now
and
then
?
 
<EOS>
What
luck
have

at

?
 
<EOS>
How
stands

Dean
?
.
.
.
 
<EOS>
My
service
to
Mrs.
Stoyte
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not

Dilly
Ashe
's

.
 
<EOS>
I
called

,
but
she
was
not
at

:
 
<EOS>
I
think
she
is
under
the
doctor
's
hand
.
.
.
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
the
news
of
the
Duke
of
Ormond
producing
letters
in
the
council
of
war
,
with
orders
not
to
fight
,
will
surprise
you
in
Ireland
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
said
in
the
House
of
Lords
that
in
a
few
days
the
treaty
of
peace
should
be
laid
before
them
;
and
our
Court
thought
it
wrong
to
hazard

,
and
sacrifice
many
lives
in
such

.
 
<EOS>
If
the
peace
holds
,
all
will
do
well
,
otherwise
I
know
not
how
we
shall
weather
it
.
 
<EOS>
And
it
was
reckoned
as
a
wrong
step
in
politics
for
Lord
Treasurer
to
open

so
much
.
 
<EOS>
The
Secretary

to

Whigs
in

House

;
but

.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
say
no
more
to
oo
to
-

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
KENSINGTON
,
July
1
,
1712
.
  
<EOS>
I
never
was
in
a
worse
station
for
writing
letters
than
this
,
especially
for
writing
to
MD
,
since
I
left
off
my
journals
.
 
<EOS>
For
I
go
to
town
early
;
and
when
I
come
home
at
night
,
I
generally
go
to
Lord
Masham
,
where
Lord
Treasurer
comes
,
and
we
stay
till
past
twelve
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
am
now
resolved
to
write
journals
again
,
though
my
shoulder
is
not
yet
well
;
for
I
have
still
a
few
itching
pimples
,
and
a
little
pain
now
and
then
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
now
high
cherry
-
time
with
us
;
take
notice
,
is
it
so
soon
with
you
?
 
<EOS>
And
we
have
early
apricots
,
and
gooseberries
are
ripe
.
 
<EOS>
On
Sunday
Archdeacon
Parnell
came
here
to
see
me
.
 
<EOS>
It
seems
he
has
been
ill
for
grief
of
his
wife
's
death
,
and
has
been
two
months
at
the
Bath
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
a
mind
to
go
to
Dunkirk
with
Jack
Hill
,
and
I
persuade
him
to
it
,
and
have
spoke
to
Hill
to
receive
him
;
but
I
doubt
he
wo
n't
have
spirit
to
go
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
made
Ford
Gazetteer
,
and
got
two
hundred
pounds
a
year
settled
on
the
employment
by
the
Secretary
of
State
,
beside
the

.
 
<EOS>
It
is
the
prettiest
employment
in
England
of
its
bigness
;
yet
the
puppy
does
not
seem
satisfied
with
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
people
keep
some
follies
to
themselves
,
till
they
have
occasion
to
produce
them
.
 
<EOS>
He
thinks
it
not
genteel
enough
,
and
makes
twenty
difficulties
.
 
<EOS>
'
Tis
impossible
to
make
any
man
easy
.
 
<EOS>
His
salary
is
paid
him
every
week
,
if
he
pleases
,
without
taxes
or
abatements
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
little
to
do

.
 
<EOS>
He
has
a
pretty
office
,
with
coals
,

,
papers
,
etc
.
<EOS>
;
can
frank
what
letters
he
will
;
and
his
perquisites
,
if
he
takes
care
,
may
be
worth
one
hundred

more
.
 
<EOS>
I
hear
the
Bishop
of
Clogher
is
landing
,
or
landed
,
in
England
;
and
I
hope
to
see

in
a
few
days
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
to
see
Mrs.
Bradley
on
Sunday
night
.
 
<EOS>
Her
youngest
son
is
married
to
somebody
worth
nothing
,
and
her
daughter
was
forced
to
leave
Lady
Giffard
,
because
she
was
striking
up
an
intrigue
with
a
footman
,
who
played
well
upon
the
flute
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
the
mother
's
account
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
Yesterday
the
old
Bishop
of
Worcester
,
who

,

to
the
Queen
,

,

,
out

,

.
;

.
 
<EOS>
Lord

,

,

,

;
and

Treasurer

,
which

.
 
<EOS>
He

near

.
 
<EOS>
Old

,

.
 
<EOS>

's

?
 
<EOS>
But

,

.
 
<EOS>
Here

,

in

compass

upon
.
 
<EOS>
We

,
which

;
but

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

down

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

;

.

,

?

?
 
<EOS>
No

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

;

;

;

,

.

.

<EOS>

MD

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

that

;
but

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
much

order
of
late
with
the
old

.
 
<EOS>
I
took
a
vomit
for
it
two

ago
,
and
will
take
another
about
a
day
or

hence
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
eat
mighty
little
fruit
;
yet
I
impute
my

to
that

,
and
shall

.
 
<EOS>
I
am

a

,
and
have

can
of

,

rest
;

,

,

,
when

.
 
<EOS>
One
is

in

;
and
when

reason

,

how

can
last
as

are
.
 
<EOS>
God
only

,
but
it

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
again

,
as
I

last

,
to
keep

from
breaking
to

upon
a
hundred

.
 
<EOS>
One
can
not
withhold

from
drawing
different
ways
,
while
the
enemy
is
watching
to
destroy
both
.
 
<EOS>
See
how

style
is
altered
,
by
living
and

and

among
these
people
,
instead

my

.
 
<EOS>
I
lose

here
among

;
so
that
I
never
play
when
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
have

five

the

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

;

;

<EOS>

,

.

,

Carteret
,
two
friends
of
mine
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
in
the
Queen
's
Bench
,
for
about
six
thousand
a
year
(
or
nine
,
I
think
)
.
 
<EOS>
I
sat
under
Lord
Chief
-
Justice
Parker
,
and
his
pen
falling
down
<EOS>
I
reached
it
up
.
 
<EOS>
He
made
me
a
low
bow
;
and
I
was
going
to
whisper
him
that
I
HAD
DONE
GOOD
FOR
EVIL
;
FOR
HE
WOULD
HAVE
TAKEN
MINE
FROM
ME
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
it
Lord
Treasurer
and
Bolingbroke
.
<EOS>
Parker
would
not
have
known
me
,
if
several
lords
on
the
bench
,
and
in
the
court
,
bowing
,
had
not
turned
everybody
's
eyes
,
and
set
them
a
whispering
.
 
<EOS>
I
owe
the
dog
a
spite
,
and
will
pay
him
in
two
months
at
furthest
,
if
I
can
.
 
<EOS>
So
much
for
that
.
 
<EOS>
But
you
must
have
chat
,
and
<EOS>
I
must
say
every
sorry
thing
that
comes
into
my
head
.
 
<EOS>
They
say
the
Queen
will
stay
a
month
longer
at
Windsor
.
<EOS>
These
devils
of
Grub
Street
rogues
,
that
write
the
Flying
Post
and
Medley
in
one
paper
,
will
not
be
quiet
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
always
mauling
Lord
Treasurer
,
Lord
Bolingbroke
,
and
me
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
the
dog
under
prosecution
,
but
Bolingbroke
is
not
active
enough
;
but
I
hope
to
swinge
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a
Scotch
rogue
,
one
Ridpath
.
 
<EOS>
They
get
out
upon
bail
,
and
write
on
.
 
<EOS>
We
take
them
again
,
and
get
fresh
bail
;
so
it
goes
round
.
 
<EOS>
They
say
some
learned
Dutchman
has
wrote
a
book
,
proving
by
civil
law
that
we
do
them
wrong
by
this
peace
;
but
I
shall
show
by
plain
reason
that
we
have
suffered
the
wrong
,
and
not
they
.
 
<EOS>
I
toil
like
a
horse
,
and
have
hundreds
of
letters
still
to
read
and
squeeze
a
line
out
of
each
,
or
at
least
the
seeds
of
a

.
 
<EOS>
Strafford
goes
back
to
Holland
in
a
day
or
two
,
and
I
hope
our
peace
is
very
near
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
about
thirty
pages
more
to
write
(
that
is
,
to

extracted
)
,
which
will
be
sixty
in

.
 
<EOS>
It
is
the
most

part
of
all
,
and
I
can
not

,
though
I

,

;
but

of

.
  
<EOS>
30
.
 
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
Lady

.
 
<EOS>
She

.
 
<EOS>
I

not

last
post
for

.
 
<EOS>
Lord

has
had

these

,

.
 
<EOS>
Is
Tisdall
yet

?
 
<EOS>
I
propose

,
to

name

.
 
<EOS>
The
Duke
of
Ormond

not

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

Duke
of

yet
;

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
The

Hamilton

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
Ppt

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
Lady
Orkney
is

of

own

,
and
a
bed
nightgown
.
 
<EOS>
She

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

in

the

,
that

of

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

;

,
that

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
We
have

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
,
the

,

.
 
<EOS>
Our

is

of
late
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
not

in

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

;

,

;

that

,

.
  
<EOS>
Our

.
 
<EOS>

;

LETTER
55
.
 
<EOS>
LONDON
,
Nov.
15
,
1712
.
  
<EOS>
Before
this
comes
to
your
hands
,
you
will
have
heard
of
the
most
terrible
accident
that
hath
almost
ever
happened
.
 
<EOS>
This
morning
,
at
eight
,
my
man
brought
me
word
that
the
Duke
of
Hamilton
had
fought
with
Lord
Mohun
,
and
killed
him
,
and
was
brought
home
wounded
.
 
<EOS>
I
immediately
sent
him
to
the
Duke
's
house
,
in
St.
James
's
Square
;
but
the
porter
could
hardly
answer
for
tears
,
and
a
great
rabble
was
about
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,
they
fought
at
seven
this
morning
.
 
<EOS>
The
dog
Mohun
was
killed
on
the
spot
;
and
while
the
Duke
was
over
him
,
Mohun
,
shortening
his
sword
,
stabbed
him
in
at
the
shoulder
to
the
heart
.
 
<EOS>
The
Duke
was
helped
toward
the
cake
-
house
by
the
Ring
in
Hyde
Park
(
where
they
fought
)
,
and
died
on
the
grass
,
before
he
could
reach
the
house
;
and
was
brought
home
in
his
coach
by
eight
,
while
the
poor
Duchess
was
asleep
.
 
<EOS>
Maccartney
,
and
one
Hamilton
,
were
the
seconds
,
who
fought
likewise
,
and
are
both
fled
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
told
that
a
footman
of
Lord
Mohun
's
stabbed
the
Duke
of
Hamilton
;
and
some
say
Maccartney
did
so
too
.
 
<EOS>
Mohun
gave
the
affront
,
and
yet
sent
the
challenge
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
infinitely
concerned
for
the
poor
Duke
,
who
was
a
frank
,
honest
,
good
-
natured
man
.
 
<EOS>
I
loved
him
very
well
,
and
I
think
he
loved
me
better
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
the
greatest
mind
in
the
world
to
have
me
go
with
him
to
France
,
but
durst
not
tell
it
me
;
and
those
he
did
,
said
I
could
not
be
spared
,
which
was
true
.
 
<EOS>
They
have
removed
the
poor
Duchess
to
a
lodging
in
the
neighbourhood
,
where
I
have
been
with
her
two
hours
,
and
am
just
come
away
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
saw
so
melancholy
a
scene
;
for
indeed
all
reasons
for
real
grief
belong
to
her
;
nor
is
it
possible
for
anybody
to
be
a
greater
loser
in
all
regards
.
 
<EOS>
She
has
moved
my
very
soul
.
 
<EOS>
The
lodging
was
inconvenient
,
and
they
would
have
removed
her
to
another
;
but
I
would
not
suffer
it
,
because
it
had
no
room
backward
,
and
she
must
have
been
tortured
with
the
noise
of
the
Grub
Street
screamers
mention[ing
]
her
husband
's
murder
to
her
ears
.
  
<EOS>
I
believe
you
have
heard
the
story
of
my
escape
,
in
opening
the
bandbox
sent
to
Lord
Treasurer
.
 
<EOS>
The
prints
have
told
a
thousand
lies
of
it
;
but
at
last
we
gave
them
a
true
account
of
it
at
length
,
printed
in
the
evening
;
only
I
would
not
suffer
them
to
name
me
,
having
been
so
often
named
before
,
and
teased
to
death
with
questions
.
 
<EOS>
I
wonder
how
I
came
to
have
so
much
presence
of
mind
,
which
is
usually
not
my
talent
;
but
so
it
pleased
God
,
and
I
saved
myself
and
him
;
for
there
was
a
bullet
apiece
.
 
<EOS>
A
gentleman
told
me
that
if
I
had
been
killed
,
the
Whigs
would
have
called
it
a
judgment
,
because
the
barrels
were
of
inkhorns
,
with
which
I
had
done
them
so
much
mischief
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
pure
Grub
Street
of
it
,
full
of
lies
and
inconsistencies
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
not
like
these
things
at
all
,
and
I
wish
myself
more
and
more
among
my
willows
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
a
devilish
spirit
among
people
,
and
the
Ministry
must
exert
themselves
,
or
sink
.
 
<EOS>
Nite
dee
sollahs
,
I
'll
go
seep
.

16
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
to
have

this
yesterday
;
but
was

much
disturbed
.
 
<EOS>
I
sent

letter
early
this
morning

Lady
Masham
,

to

.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to-[day
]
<EOS>

at

,
where
she
is

to

.
 
<EOS>
She
has

to
get

Queen
to
write

Duchess

on
this

;
and
to
-
morrow
I
will
beg
Lord
Treasurer
to
visit
and
comfort

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
with
her
two
hours
again
,
and
find
her
worse
:
 
her
violences
not
so
frequent
,
but
her
melancholy
more
formal
and
settled
.
 
<EOS>
She
has
abundance
of
wit
and
spirit
;
about
thirty
-
three
years
old
;
handsome
and
airy
,
and
seldom
spared
anybody
that
gave
her
the
least

;
by
which
she
had
many
enemies
and
few

.
 
<EOS>
Lady
Orkney
,
her
sister
-
in
-
law
,
is

to

on
this

,
and
has
been
to

,
and
behaved

with
great

.
<EOS>
They
have
been
always
very
ill
together
,
and
the
poor
Duchess
could
not
have
patience
when
people
told
her
I
went
often

Lady
Orkney
's
.
 
<EOS>
But

am
resolved

make

;
for

Duchess
is
now
no
more
the
object
of

,
and
must

from
the
severest

,
Affliction
.
 
<EOS>
I
design

Ministry

proclamation
<EOS>
(
if

)
against

.
 
<EOS>
What

?
 
<EOS>
I

to

,

;

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
I

,

,

,

.

,

.
 
<EOS>

.

.

.

.
 
<EOS>

's

,

.
 
<EOS>

)

,

.

.
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
The

<EOS>

;

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

that
poor
dear
Lady
Ashburnham
,
the
Duke
of
Ormond
's
daughter
,
died
yesterday
at
her
country
house
.
 
<EOS>
The
poor
creature
was
with
child
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
my
greatest
favourite
,
and
I
am
in
excessive
concern
for
her
loss
.
 
<EOS>
I
hardly
knew
a
more
valuable
person
on
all
accounts
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
have
heard
me
talk
of
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
to
see
the
Duke
and
Duchess
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
naturally
very
healthy
;
I
am
afraid
she
has
been
thrown
away
for
want
of
care
.
<EOS>
Pray
condole
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
'
Tis
extremely
moving
.
 
<EOS>
Her
lord
's
a
puppy
<EOS>
;
and
I
shall
never
think
it
worth
my
while
to
be
troubled
with
him
,
now
he
has
lost
all
that
was
valuable
in
his
possession
;
yet
I
think
he
used
her
pretty
well
.
 
<EOS>
I
hate
life
when
I
think
it
exposed
to
such
accidents
;
and
to
see
so
many
thousand
wretches
burdening
the
earth
,
while
such
as
her
die
,
makes
me
think
God
did
never
intend
life
for
a
blessing
.
 
<EOS>
Farewell
.
   
<EOS>
LETTER
58
.
 
<EOS>
LONDON
,

,

13
.
  
<EOS>
I
ended
my
last
with
the
melancholy
news
of
poor
Lady
Ashburnham
's
death
.
 
<EOS>
The
Bishop
of
Clogher
and
Dr.
Pratt
made
me
dine
with
them
to
-
day
at
Lord
Mountjoy
's
,
pursuant
to
an
engagement
,
which
I
had

.
 
<EOS>
Lady
Mountjoy
told
me
that
Maccartney
was
got
safe
out
of
our
clutches
,
for
she
had
spoke
with
one
who
had
a
letter
from
him
from
Holland
.
 
<EOS>
Others
say
the
same
thing
.
 
<EOS>
'
Tis
hard
such
a
dog
should
escape
.
 
<EOS>
As

Lord
Mountjoy
's
<EOS>

Duke

,

,

Bolingbroke

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
and

Court
,

.
 
<EOS>
I
was

Duke
of
Argyle

bed

,
when
the

.
 
<EOS>
Argyle
presented

,
and
Lord
Bolingbroke
<EOS>
and

.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a
fine

,
something
like

Duke

,

.
 
<EOS>

5
.
 
<EOS>
Our

,

.
 
<EOS>
Lord

is

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

Lady
Oxford
,

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

Brown
,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
:
 
in
short
,
<EOS>
all

his
character
,
which
I
made

to

.
 
<EOS>
What
dogs
there
are
in
the
world
!
 
<EOS>
I
was
to
see
the
poor
Duke
and
Duchess
of
Ormond
this
morning
.
 
<EOS>
The
Duke
was
in

,

Southwell

.
 
<EOS>
When
Southwell

,

something
of
Lord
Ashburnham
,
that
he

Whigs
would

.
 
<EOS>
He
bore

as

,
but
<EOS>
something

in

,

,

(

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Lord

;

<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
is

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

,

;

.
<EOS>
Very
warm

,

;

,

,

<EOS>
And

MD

now

,

?
 
<EOS>

and

Walls
?
 
<EOS>
I

Maccartney

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
verse

,

,

;
but
I
have

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
have

,

'

;

do

.

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

;

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
At
seven
<EOS>
this

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Lord

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
Soon

,

Duke

Ormond
and

,
and
ran

;
but
chid

for

,

this
last

,
not

;
and
he

so

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
left
England
with
a

,
by
his
coach

,
<EOS>
that
made

spit

,
and
was

ill
,
we
expected
every

to

;
but
he
outrode

or

,

,

is

.
 
<EOS>
He
is
at
least
sixty
,
and
has
more

than

.
 
<EOS>
He
has

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.

.

<EOS>
The

dined

,

,

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
You

;

.
 
<EOS>
Our

.
<EOS>
Those
puppies
the
Dutch
will
not
yet

,

Queen

;

how

,
in

House

Lords
:

,

Others

,

;

<EOS>

,

.

,

,

,

.

.

,

<EOS>
We

to

,
that
,

,
I

;

,

:
 
so

Court

.
 
<EOS>
Next

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
It
is
grown

this

.
 
<EOS>
I

such

to
-

?
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
Lord

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>

:

.

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
Our

,

.

:

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
The

,

;

,

,
vex

,

;

;

<EOS>
It

;

:
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>

3
.
 
<EOS>
The
Parliament
met
,
and
was
prorogued
,
as
I
said
,
and
I
found
some
cloudy
faces
,
and
heard
some

.
 
<EOS>
We
have
got
over
all
our
difficulties
with
France
,
I
think
.
 
<EOS>
They
have
now

all
the
articles
of
commerce
between
us
and
them
,
wherein
they
were
very

to
play
the
rogue
if

to
[
it
]
;
and
this

we
wait

of

,
who
are
finding
an

to

;
but
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
with
Lord
Treasurer
,

he

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

<EOS>

perform
<EOS>
(

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

:
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
This
is
the
Queen
's
Birthday
,
and
I
never

with

,

,

.
<EOS>
Pray

.
 
<EOS>
She

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

Nite

.

<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
Pray

DD

:

.
 
<EOS>
This
,

;

:
 
<EOS>
so

let

,

<EOS>
Lord

,

:
 
he

.
 
<EOS>
Our
weather
is
constant
rain
above

,
which
hinders

,
so
that

spring
is
not
like

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
seen
Fanny
Manley

;

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
in

with
all
my

,
but
I
will
mend
with
my
health
and

.

Clogher
make

figure
!

.

Colds
!
<EOS>

;

,

.

<EOS>
It

<EOS>

;

<EOS>

management
!
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
The

Clogher
's

has

some

,

.
 
<EOS>
She
is

full
;
but

,

.
 
<EOS>
Lady

;

Sir

's
;

.
 
<EOS>
He

;

.

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
All

's
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Ashe
is

,

not

;
my
man
calls

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
was
this

Jersey
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
She

reduced

to

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
My

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
He

,

:

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I

.

Nite

.
  
<EOS>
12
.
<EOS>
I
have

;

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
with
our
Society
,
the

I
have

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
at
Jack
Hill
's
,
the
Governor
of
Dunkirk
.
 
<EOS>
I
gave
an
account
of
sixty
guineas
I
had
collected
,
and
am
to
give
them
away
to
two
authors
to
-
morrow
;
and
Lord
Treasurer
has
promised

a
hundred
pounds
to
reward
some
others
.
 
<EOS>
I
found
a
letter
on
my

last
night
to
tell
me
that
poor
little
Harrison
,
the
Queen
's
Secretary
,
that
came
lately

Utrecht

Barrier
Treaty
,
was
ill
,
and
desired
to
see
me
at
night
;
but
it
was
late
,
and
I
could
not
go
till
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
often
mentioned
him
in
my
letters
,
you
may
remember
.
.
.
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
in
the
morning
,
and
found
him
mighty
ill
,
and

guineas
for

Bolingbroke
,
and

Treasury

to
-
morrow
;
and
I
have
got

to
Knightsbridge
for
air
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
a
fever
and
inflammation
on
his
lungs
;
but
I
hope
will
do
well
.
 
<EOS>
Nite
.
  
<EOS>
13
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
to
see
a
poor
poet
,
one
Mr.
Diaper
,
in
a
nasty
garret
,
very
sick
.
 
<EOS>
I
gave

twenty
guineas
from
Lord
Bolingbroke
,
and
disposed

other

to
two
other
authors
,
and

to

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
sent
to
see
how
he
did
,
and
he
is
extremely
ill
;
and
I
very
much
afflicted
for
him
,
for
he
is
my
own
creature
,
and
in
a
very
honourable
post
,
and
very
worthy

it
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
in
the
City
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
in
much
concern
for
this
poor
lad
.
 
<EOS>
His
mother
and
sister
attend

,
and
he
wants
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
Nite
poo
dee
MD
.
  
<EOS>
14
.
 
<EOS>
I
took
Parnell
this
morning
,
and
we

to
see

.
 
<EOS>
I
had
the

pounds

.
 
<EOS>
I
told
Parnell
<EOS>
I
was
afraid
to
knock
at
the

;
my

.
 
<EOS>
I
knocked
,
and
his
man
in

told

his
master
was
dead
an
hour
before
.
 
<EOS>
Think
what

this
is
to

!
 
<EOS>
I
went
to
his
mother
,
and
have
been
ordering
things
for
his
funeral
with
as
little
cost
as

,
to
-
morrow
at
ten
at
night
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Treasurer
was
much
concerned
when
I
told
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
dine
with
Lord
Treasurer
,
nor
anywhere
else
;
but
got
a
bit
of
meat
toward
evening
.
 
<EOS>
No
loss
ever
grieved
me
so
much
:
 
poor
creature
!
<EOS>
Pray
<EOS>
God

MD
.
 
<EOS>

.

,

.

<EOS>
LONDON
,

.
  
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
with
Mr.
Rowe
and
a
projector
,
who
has
been
teasing
me
with
twenty
schemes
to
get
grants
;
and
I
do
n't
like
one
of
them
;
and
,
besides
,
I
was
out
of
humour
for
the
loss
of
poor
Harrison
.
 
<EOS>
At
ten
this
night
I
was
at
his
funeral
,
which
I
ordered
to
be
as
private
as
possible
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
<EOS>
but
one
coach
with
four
of
us
;
<EOS>
and
when
it
was
carrying
us
home
after
the
funeral
,
the
braces
broke
;
and
we
were
forced
to
sit
in
it
,
and
have
it
held
up
,
till
my
man
went
for
chairs
,
at
eleven
at
night
in
terrible
rain
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
come
home
very
melancholy
,
and
will
go
to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
Nite
.
.
.
 
<EOS>
MD
.
  
<EOS>
16
.
 
<EOS>
I
dined
to
-
day
with
Lord
Dupplin
and
some
company
to
divert
me
;
but
left
them
early
,
and
have
been
reading
a
foolish
book
for
amusement
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
never
have
courage
again
to
care
for
making
anybody
's
fortune
.
 
<EOS>
The
Parliament
meets
to
-
morrow
,
and
will
be
prorogued
another
fortnight
,
at
which
several
of
both
parties
were
angry
;
but
it
can
not
be
helped
,
though
everything
about
the
peace
is
past
all
danger
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
saw
such
a
continuance
of
rainy
weather
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
not
had
two
fair
days
together
these
ten
weeks
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
dined
with
Lord
Treasurer
these
four
days
,
nor
can
I
till
Saturday
;
for
I
have
several
engagements
till
then
,
and
he
will
chide

to
some

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
perplexed
with
this
hundred
pounds
of
poor
Harrison
's
,
what
to
do
with
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not

his
relations
till
they
administer
,
for
he
is
much
in

;
but
I
will
have
the
staff

,
and

nothing
.
 
<EOS>
Nite
poo
dee
MD
.
  
<EOS>
17
.
 
<EOS>
Lady
Jersey
and
I
dined
by

to

with
Lord
Bolingbroke
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
sending

brother
to

Mr.
Harrison
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
the
prettiest
post
in
Europe
for
a
young
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
I
lose
my
money
at
ombre
sadly
;
I
make
a
thousand
blunders
.
 
<EOS>
I
play
but
threepenny
ombre
;
but
it
is
what
you
call
running
ombre
.
 
<EOS>
Lady
Clarges
,
and
a
drab
I
hate
,
won
a
dozen
shillings
of
me
last
night
.
 
<EOS>
The
Parliament
was
prorogued
to
-
day
;
and
people
grumble
;
and
the
good
of
it
is
the
peace
can
not
be
finished
by
the
time
they
meet
,
there
are
so
many

things
to

.
 
<EOS>
Is
Ppt
an
ombre
lady
yet
?
 
<EOS>
You
know
all
the
tricks
of
it
now
,
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
reckon
you
have
all
your
cards
from
France
,
for
ours
pay
sixpence
a
pack
taxes
,
which
goes
deep
to

box
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
given
away
all
my
Spa
water
,
and
take
some

drops
,
and
my

has

this

.
 
<EOS>
I
send
every
day
to
see
how
Miss
Ashe
does
:
she
is
very
full
,
they
say
,
but
in

.
 
<EOS>
I

will

.
 
<EOS>
The
son
lies
out

.
 
<EOS>
I
wish

had
them
too
,
while

.

MD
.

.
 
<EOS>
The
Earl

;

.
 
<EOS>
We

,

Ash

.
 
<EOS>

nothing

,

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
Our

poison
;
yet
the

has
twelve

.
 
<EOS>
His

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

;

;

Davis

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
Have
you

?
 
<EOS>
He
married
the
Duchess
of
Grafton
in
his
youth
<EOS>
(
she

)
.
 
<EOS>
He

in

.
 
<EOS>
He
went
last

to
Flanders
,
with

of

;
from

to

,

;
but

,
and
he
has

come

.
 
<EOS>
He
is
much
out

with
things
:
 
<EOS>
he
thinks
the
peace
is
kept
off
too

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
It

is

of

,
instead

Lord

.
 
<EOS>
We
have
been

these
two

;
and
I

,

or

,
to

an

's

on

.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
the

of
Clogher
at
Court
;
Miss
is

.
 
<EOS>
I
know
not
how
much
she
will
be
marked
.
<EOS>
The
Queen
is
slowly
mending
of

gout
,
and
intends
to
be

in
a
chair
to
Parliament
when

,

;

,

.

.

.
 
<EOS>
It
was

,

,

,

-
five

;
so

.
 
<EOS>
Dilly

;

.

Miss

;

.
 
<EOS>

;

,

,
hard

;

,

,

,

.

24
.
 
<EOS>
I
walked
this

,

Atterbury
,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

's

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
Lord

,

,
young
Bromley

,

,

;

,

the

.
 
<EOS>
Lady
Jersey
was
abroad
,
and
I
chid

,
and

;
but
since
I
came

she

that
I

,

is

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
worse

than

I
left
you
,
and
every
day
forget
appointments
;
but
here
my
memory
was
by
chance
too
good
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
'll
go
to
-
morrow
;
for
Lady
Catherine
Hyde
and
Lady
Bolingbroke
are
to

there
by

,
and
I
listed

,
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
who

.

<EOS>

,

.

,

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

;

,

,

,

.

<EOS>
